There is, probably, no man who\r\nbecomes naturally so hard in regard to money as he who is bound to\r\nlive among rich men, who is not rich himself, and who is yet honest.\r\nThe weight of the work of life in these circumstances is so crushing,\r\nrequires such continued thought, and makes itself so continually\r\nfelt, that the mind of the sufferer is never free from the\r\ncontamination of sixpences. Of such a one it is not fair to judge\r\nas of other men with similar incomes. Lord Fawn had declared to his\r\nfuture bride that he had half five thousand a year to spend,--or the\r\nhalf, rather, of such actual income as might be got in from an estate\r\npresumed to give five thousand a year,--and it may be said that an\r\nunmarried gentleman ought not to be poor with such an income. But\r\nLord Fawn unfortunately was a lord, unfortunately was a landlord,\r\nunfortunately was an Irish landlord. Let him be as careful as he\r\nmight with his sixpences, his pounds would fly from him, or, as\r\nmight, perhaps, be better said, could not be made to fly to him. He\r\nwas very careful with his sixpences, and was always thinking, not\r\nexactly how he might make two ends meet, but how to reconcile the\r\nstrictest personal economy with the proper bearing of an English\r\nnobleman.\r\n\r\nSuch a man almost naturally looks to marriage as an assistance in\r\nthe dreary fight. It soon becomes clear to him that he cannot marry\r\nwithout money, and he learns to think that heiresses have been\r\ninvented exactly to suit his case. He is conscious of having been\r\nsubjected to hardship by Fortune, and regards female wealth as his\r\nlegitimate mode of escape from it. He has got himself, his position,\r\nand, perhaps, his title to dispose of, and they are surely worth\r\nso much per annum. As for giving anything away, that is out of the\r\nquestion. He has not been so placed as to be able to give. But, being\r\nan honest man, he will, if possible, make a fair bargain. Lord Fawn\r\nwas certainly an honest man, and he had been endeavouring for the\r\nlast six or seven years to make a fair bargain. But then it is so\r\nhard to decide what is fair. Who is to tell a Lord Fawn how much per\r\nannum he ought to regard himself as worth? He had, on one or two\r\noccasions, asked a high price, but no previous bargain had been made.\r\nNo doubt he had come down a little in his demand in suggesting a\r\nmatrimonial arrangement to a widow with a child, and with only four\r\nthousand a year. Whether or no that income was hers in perpetuity, or\r\nonly for life, he had not positively known when he made his offer.\r\nThe will made by Sir Florian Eustace did not refer to the property\r\nat all. In the natural course of things, the widow would only have\r\na life-interest in the income. Why should Sir Florian make away, in\r\nperpetuity, with his family property? Nevertheless, there had been\r\na rumour abroad that Sir Florian had been very generous; that the\r\nScotch estate was to go to a second son in the event of there being\r\na second son;--but that otherwise it was to be at the widow\'s own\r\ndisposal. No doubt, had Lord Fawn been persistent, he might have\r\nfound out the exact truth. He had, however, calculated that he could\r\nafford to accept even the life-income. If more should come of it, so\r\nmuch the better for him. He might, at any rate, so arrange the family\r\nmatters, that his heir, should he have one, should not at his death\r\nbe called upon to pay something more than half the proceeds of the\r\nfamily property to his mother,--as was now done by himself.\r\n\r\nLord Fawn breakfasted at Fawn Court on the Monday, and his mother sat\r\nat the table with him, pouring out his tea. "Oh, Frederic," she said,\r\n"it is so important!"\r\n\r\n"Just so;--very important indeed. I should like you to call and see\r\nher either to-day or to-morrow."\r\n\r\n"That\'s of course."\r\n\r\n"And you had better get her down here."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know that she\'ll come. Ought I to ask the little boy?"\r\n\r\n"Certainly," said Lord Fawn, as he put a spoonful of egg into his\r\nmouth; "certainly."\r\n\r\n"And Miss Macnulty?"\r\n\r\n"No; I don\'t see that at all. I\'m not going to marry Miss Macnulty.\r\nThe child, of course, must be one of us."\r\n\r\n"And what is the income, Frederic?"\r\n\r\n"Four thousand a year. Something more, nominally, but four thousand\r\nto spend."\r\n\r\n"You are sure about that?"\r\n\r\n"Quite sure."\r\n\r\n"And for ever?"\r\n\r\n"I believe so. Of that I am not sure."\r\n\r\n"It makes a great difference, Frederic."\r\n\r\n"A very great difference indeed. I think it is her own. But, at any\r\nrate, she is much younger than I am, and there need be no settlement\r\nout of my property. That is the great thing. Don\'t you think\r\nshe\'s--nice?"\r\n\r\n"She is very lovely."\r\n\r\n"And clever?"\r\n\r\n"Certainly very clever. I hope she is not self-willed, Frederic."\r\n\r\n"If she is, we must try and balance it," said Lord Fawn, with a\r\nlittle smile. But, in truth, he had thought nothing about any such\r\nquality as that to which his mother now referred. The lady had an\r\nincome. That was the first and most indispensable consideration. She\r\nwas fairly well-born, was a lady, and was beautiful. In doing Lord\r\nFawn justice, we must allow that, in all his attempted matrimonial\r\nspeculations, some amount of feminine loveliness had been combined\r\nwith feminine wealth. He had for two years been a suitor of Violet\r\nEffingham, who was the acknowledged beauty of the day,--of Violet\r\nEffingham who, at the present time, was the wife of Lord Chiltern;\r\nand he had offered himself thrice to Madame Max Goesler, who was\r\nreputed to be as rich as she was beautiful. In either case, the\r\nfortune would have been greater than that which he would now win, and\r\nthe money would certainly have been for ever. But in these attempts\r\nhe had failed; and Lord Fawn was not a man to think himself ill-used\r\nbecause he did not get the first good thing for which he asked.\r\n\r\n"I suppose I may tell the girls?" said Lady Fawn.\r\n\r\n"Yes;--when I am gone. I must be off now, only I could not bear not\r\nto come and see you."\r\n\r\n"It was so like you, Frederic."\r\n\r\n"And you\'ll go to-day?"\r\n\r\n"Yes; if you wish it,--certainly."\r\n\r\n"Go up in the carriage, you know, and take one of the girls with you.\r\nI would not take more than one. Augusta will be the best. You\'ll see\r\nClara, I suppose." Clara was the married sister, Mrs. Hittaway.\r\n\r\n"If you wish it."\r\n\r\n"She had better call too,--say on Thursday. It\'s quite as well that\r\nit should be known. I sha\'n\'t choose to have more delay than can be\r\navoided. Well;--I believe that\'s all."\r\n\r\n"I hope she\'ll be a good wife to you, Frederic."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t see why she shouldn\'t. Good-bye, mother. Tell the girls I\r\nwill see them next Saturday." He didn\'t see why this woman he was\r\nabout to marry should not be a good wife to him! And yet he knew\r\nnothing about her, and had not taken the slightest trouble to make\r\ninquiry. That she was pretty he could see; that she was clever he\r\ncould understand; that she lived in Mount Street was a fact; her\r\nparentage was known to him;--that she was the undoubted mistress\r\nof a large income was beyond dispute. But, for aught he knew, she\r\nmight be afflicted by every vice to which a woman can be subject. In\r\ntruth, she was afflicted by so many, that the addition of all the\r\nothers could hardly have made her worse than she was. She had never\r\nsacrificed her beauty to a lover,--she had never sacrificed anything\r\nto anybody,--nor did she drink. It would be difficult, perhaps, to\r\nsay anything else in her favour; and yet Lord Fawn was quite content\r\nto marry her, not having seen any reason why she should not make a\r\ngood wife! Nor had Sir Florian seen any reason;--but she had broken\r\nSir Florian\'s heart.\r\n\r\nWhen the girls heard the news, they were half frightened and half\r\ndelighted. Lady Fawn and her daughters lived very much out of the\r\nworld. They also were poor rich people,--if such a term may be\r\nused,--and did not go much into society. There was a butler kept at\r\nFawn Court, and a boy in buttons, and two gardeners, and a man to\r\nlook after the cows, and a carriage and horses, and a fat coachman.\r\nThere was a cook and a scullery maid, and two lady\'s maids,--who had\r\nto make the dresses,--and two housemaids and a dairymaid. There was a\r\nlarge old brick house to be kept in order, and handsome grounds with\r\nold trees. There was, as we know, a governess, and there were seven\r\nunmarried daughters. With such encumbrances, and an income altogether\r\nnot exceeding three thousand pounds per annum, Lady Fawn could not be\r\nrich. And yet who would say that an old lady and her daughters could\r\nbe poor with three thousand pounds a year to spend? It may be taken\r\nalmost as a rule by the unennobled ones of this country, that the\r\nsudden possession of a title would at once raise the price of every\r\narticle consumed twenty per cent. Mutton that before cost ninepence\r\nwould cost tenpence a pound, and the mouths to be fed would demand\r\nmore meat. The chest of tea would run out quicker. The labourer\'s\r\nwork, which for the farmer is ten hours a day, for the squire nine,\r\nis for the peer only eight. Miss Jones, when she becomes Lady de\r\nJongh, does not pay less than threepence apiece for each "my lady"\r\nwith which her ear is tickled. Even the baronet when he becomes a\r\nlord has to curtail his purchases, because of increased price, unless\r\nhe be very wide awake to the affairs of the world. Old Lady Fawn, who\r\nwould not on any account have owed a shilling which she could not\r\npay, and who, in the midst of her economies, was not close-fisted,\r\nknew very well what she could do and what she could not. The old\r\nfamily carriage and the two lady\'s maids were there,--as necessaries\r\nof life; but London society was not within her reach. It was,\r\ntherefore, the case that they had not heard very much about Lizzie\r\nEustace. But they had heard something. "I hope she won\'t be too fond\r\nof going out," said Amelia, the second girl.\r\n\r\n"Or extravagant," said Georgina, the third.\r\n\r\n"There was some story of her being terribly in debt when she married\r\nSir Florian Eustace," said Diana, the fourth.\r\n\r\n"Frederic will be sure to see to that," said Augusta, the eldest.\r\n\r\n"She is very beautiful," said Lydia, the fifth.\r\n\r\n"And clever," said Cecilia, the sixth.\r\n\r\n"Beauty and cleverness won\'t make a good wife," said Amelia, who was\r\nthe wise one of the family.\r\n\r\n"Frederic will be sure to see that she doesn\'t go wrong," said\r\nAugusta, who was not wise.\r\n\r\nThen Lucy Morris entered the room with Nina, the cadette of the\r\nfamily. "Oh, Nina, what do you think?" said Lydia.\r\n\r\n"My dear!" said Lady Fawn, putting up her hand and stopping further\r\nindiscreet speech.\r\n\r\n"Oh, mamma, what is it?" asked the cadette.\r\n\r\n"Surely Lucy may be told," said Lydia.\r\n\r\n"Well, yes; Lucy may be told certainly. There can be no reason why\r\nLucy should not know all that concerns our family;--and the more so\r\nas she has been for many years intimate with the lady. My dear, my\r\nson is going to be married to Lady Eustace."\r\n\r\n"Lord Fawn going to marry Lizzie!" said Lucy Morris, in a tone which\r\ncertainly did not express unmingled satisfaction.\r\n\r\n"Unless you forbid the banns," said Diana.\r\n\r\n"Is there any reason why he should not?" said Lady Fawn.\r\n\r\n"Oh, no;--only it seems so odd. I didn\'t know that they knew each\r\nother;--not well, that is. And then--"\r\n\r\n"Then what, my dear?"\r\n\r\n"It seems odd;--that\'s all. It\'s all very nice, I dare say, and I\'m\r\nsure I hope they will be happy." Lady Fawn, however, was displeased,\r\nand did not speak to Lucy again before she started with Augusta on\r\nthe journey to London.\r\n\r\nThe carriage first stopped at the door of the married daughter in\r\nWarwick Square. Now, Mrs. Hittaway, whose husband was chairman of\r\nthe Board of Civil Appeals and who was very well known at all Boards\r\nand among official men generally, heard much more about things that\r\nwere going on than did her mother. And, having been emancipated from\r\nmaternal control for the last ten or twelve years, she could express\r\nherself before her mother with more confidence than would have become\r\nthe other girls. "Mamma," she said, "you don\'t mean it!"\r\n\r\n"I do mean it, Clara. Why should I not mean it?"\r\n\r\n"She is the greatest vixen in all London."\r\n\r\n"Oh, Clara!" said Augusta.\r\n\r\n"And such a liar," said Mrs. Hittaway.\r\n\r\nThere came a look of pain across Lady Fawn\'s face, for Lady Fawn\r\nbelieved in her eldest daughter. But yet she intended to fight her\r\nground on a matter so important to her as was this. "There is no word\r\nin the English language," she said, "which conveys to me so little\r\nof defined meaning as that word vixen. If you can, tell me what you\r\nmean, Clara."\r\n\r\n"Stop it, mamma."\r\n\r\n"But why should I stop it,--even if I could?"\r\n\r\n"You don\'t know her, mamma."\r\n\r\n"She has visited at Fawn Court, more than once. She is a friend of\r\nLucy\'s."\r\n\r\n"If she is a friend of Lucy Morris, mamma, Lucy Morris shall never\r\ncome here."\r\n\r\n"But what has she done? I have never heard that she has behaved\r\nimproperly. What does it all mean? She goes out everywhere. I don\'t\r\nthink she has had any lovers. Frederic would be the last man in the\r\nworld to throw himself away upon an ill-conditioned young woman."\r\n\r\n"Frederic can see just as far as some other men, and not a bit\r\nfarther. Of course she has an income,--for her life."\r\n\r\n"I believe it is her own altogether, Clara."\r\n\r\n"She says so, I don\'t doubt. I believe she is the greatest liar about\r\nLondon. You find out about her jewels before she married poor Sir\r\nFlorian, and how much he had to pay for her; or rather, I\'ll find\r\nout. If you want to know, mamma, you just ask her own aunt, Lady\r\nLinlithgow."\r\n\r\n"We all know, my dear, that Lady Linlithgow quarrelled with her."\r\n\r\n"It\'s my belief that she is over head and ears in debt again. But\r\nI\'ll learn. And when I have found out, I shall not scruple to tell\r\nFrederic. Orlando will find out all about it." Orlando was the\r\nChristian name of Mrs. Hittaway\'s husband. "Mr. Camperdown, I have\r\nno doubt, knows all the ins and outs of her story. The long and the\r\nshort of it is this, mamma, that I\'ve heard quite enough about Lady\r\nEustace to feel certain that Frederic would live to repent it."\r\n\r\n"But what can we do?" said Lady Fawn.\r\n\r\n"Break it off," said Mrs. Hittaway.\r\n\r\nHer daughter\'s violence of speech had a most depressing effect upon\r\npoor Lady Fawn. As has been said, she did believe in Mrs. Hittaway.\r\nShe knew that Mrs. Hittaway was conversant with the things of the\r\nworld, and heard tidings daily which never found their way down\r\nto Fawn Court. And yet her son went about quite as much as did\r\nher daughter. If Lady Eustace was such a reprobate as was now\r\nrepresented, why had not Lord Fawn heard the truth? And then she had\r\nalready given in her own adhesion, and had promised to call. "Do you\r\nmean that you won\'t go to her?" said Lady Fawn.\r\n\r\n"As Lady Eustace,--certainly not. If Frederic does marry her, of\r\ncourse I must know her. That\'s a different thing. One has to make\r\nthe best one can of a bad bargain. I don\'t doubt they\'d be separated\r\nbefore two years were over."\r\n\r\n"Oh, dear, how dreadful!" exclaimed Augusta.\r\n\r\nLady Fawn, after much consideration, was of opinion that she must\r\ncarry out her intention of calling upon her son\'s intended bride\r\nin spite of all the evil things that had been said. Lord Fawn had\r\nundertaken to send a message to Mount Street, informing the lady of\r\nthe honour intended for her. And in truth Lady Fawn was somewhat\r\ncurious now to see the household of the woman who might perhaps do\r\nher the irreparable injury of ruining the happiness of her only son.\r\nPerhaps she might learn something by looking at the woman in her own\r\ndrawing-room. At any rate she would go. But Mrs. Hittaway\'s words had\r\nthe effect of inducing her to leave Augusta where she was. If there\r\nwere contamination, why should Augusta be contaminated? Poor Augusta!\r\nShe had looked forward to the delight of embracing her future\r\nsister-in-law;--and would not have enjoyed it the less, perhaps,\r\nbecause she had been told that the lady was false, profligate, and a\r\nvixen. As, however, her position was that of a girl, she was bound to\r\nbe obedient,--though over thirty years old,--and she obeyed.\r\n\r\nLizzie was of course at home, and Miss Macnulty was of course\r\nvisiting the Horticultural Gardens or otherwise engaged. On such an\r\noccasion Lizzie would certainly be alone. She had taken great pains\r\nwith her dress, studying not so much her own appearance as the\r\ncharacter of her visitor. She was very anxious, at any rate for the\r\npresent, to win golden opinions from Lady Fawn. She was dressed\r\nrichly, but very simply. Everything about her room betokened wealth;\r\nbut she had put away the French novels, and had placed a Bible on\r\na little table, not quite hidden, behind her own seat. The long\r\nlustrous lock was tucked up, but the diamonds were still upon\r\nher fingers. She fully intended to make a conquest of her future\r\nmother-in-law and sister-in-law;--for the note which had come up to\r\nher from the India Office had told her that Augusta would accompany\r\nLady Fawn. "Augusta is my favourite sister," said the enamoured\r\nlover, "and I hope that you two will always be friends." Lizzie, when\r\nshe had read this, had declared to herself that of all the female\r\noafs she had ever seen, Augusta Fawn was the greatest oaf. When she\r\nfound that Lady Fawn was alone, she did not betray herself, or ask\r\nfor the beloved friend of the future. "Dear, dear Lady Fawn!" she\r\nsaid, throwing herself into the arms and nestling herself against the\r\nbosom of the old lady, "this makes my happiness perfect." Then she\r\nretreated a little, still holding the hand she had grasped between\r\nher own, and looking up into the face of her future mother-in-law.\r\n"When he asked me to be his wife, the first thing I thought of was\r\nwhether you would come to me at once." Her voice as she thus spoke\r\nwas perfect. Her manner was almost perfect. Perhaps there was a\r\nlittle too much of gesture, too much gliding motion, too violent an\r\nappeal with the eyes, too close a pressure of the hand. No suspicion,\r\nhowever, of all this would have touched Lady Fawn had she come to\r\nMount Street without calling in Warwick Square on the way. But those\r\nhorrible words of her daughter were ringing in her ears, and she did\r\nnot know how to conduct herself.\r\n\r\n"Of course I came as soon as he told me," she said.\r\n\r\n"And you will be a mother to me?" demanded Lizzie.\r\n\r\nPoor Lady Fawn! There was enough of maternity about her to have\r\nenabled her to undertake the duty for a dozen sons\' wives,--if the\r\nwives were women with whom she could feel sympathy. And she could\r\nfeel sympathy very easily; and was a woman not at all prone to\r\ninquire too curiously as to the merits of a son\'s wife. But what was\r\nshe to do after the caution she had received from Mrs. Hittaway? How\r\nwas she to promise maternal tenderness to a vixen and a liar? By\r\nnature she was not a deceitful woman. "My dear," she said, "I hope\r\nyou will make him a good wife."\r\n\r\nIt was not very encouraging, but Lizzie made the best of it. It was\r\nher desire to cheat Lady Fawn into a good opinion, and she was not\r\ndisappointed when no good opinion was expressed at once. It is seldom\r\nthat a bad person expects to be accounted good. It is the general\r\ndesire of such a one to conquer the existing evil impression; but it\r\nis generally presumed that the evil impression is there. "Oh, Lady\r\nFawn!" she said, "I will so strive to make him happy. What is it that\r\nhe likes? What would he wish me to do and to be? You know his noble\r\nnature, and I must look to you for guidance."\r\n\r\nLady Fawn was embarrassed. She had now seated herself on the sofa,\r\nand Lizzie was close to her, almost enveloped within her mantle. "My\r\ndear," said Lady Fawn, "if you will endeavour to do your duty by him,\r\nI am sure he will do his by you."\r\n\r\n"I know it. I am sure of it. And I will; I will. You will let me love\r\nyou, and call you mother?" A peculiar perfume came up from Lizzie\'s\r\nhair which Lady Fawn did not like. Her own girls, perhaps, were not\r\ngiven to the use of much perfumery. She shifted her seat a little,\r\nand Lizzie was compelled to sit upright, and without support.\r\nHitherto Lady Fawn had said very little, and Lizzie\'s part was one\r\ndifficult to play. She had heard of that sermon read every Sunday\r\nevening at Fawn Court, and she believed that Lady Fawn was peculiarly\r\nreligious. "There," she said, stretching out her hand backwards and\r\nclasping the book which lay upon the small table,--"there; that\r\nshall be my guide. That will teach me how to do my duty by my noble\r\nhusband."\r\n\r\nLady Fawn in some surprise took the book from Lizzie\'s hand, and\r\nfound that it was the Bible. "You certainly can\'t do better, my dear,\r\nthan read your Bible," said Lady Fawn,--but there was more of censure\r\nthan of eulogy in the tone of her voice. She put the Bible down very\r\nquietly, and asked Lady Eustace when it would suit her to come down\r\nto Fawn Court. Lady Fawn had promised her son to give the invitation,\r\nand could not now, she thought, avoid giving it.\r\n\r\n"Oh, I should like it so much!" said Lizzie. "Whenever it will suit\r\nyou, I will be there at a minute\'s notice." It was then arranged\r\nthat she should be at Fawn Court on that day week, and stay for a\r\nfortnight. "Of all things that which I most desire now," said Lizzie,\r\n"is to know you and the dear girls,--and to be loved by you all."\r\n\r\nLady Eustace, as soon as she was alone in the room, stood in the\r\nmiddle of it, scowling,--for she could scowl. "I\'ll not go near\r\nthem," she said to herself,--"nasty, stupid, dull, puritanical\r\ndrones. If he don\'t like it, he may lump it. After all it\'s no such\r\ngreat catch." Then she sat down to reflect whether it was or was not\r\na catch. As soon as ever Lord Fawn had left her after the engagement\r\nwas made, she had begun to tell herself that he was a poor creature,\r\nand that she had done wrong. "Only five thousand a year!" she said\r\nto herself;--for she had not perfectly understood that little\r\nexplanation which he had given respecting his income. "It\'s nothing\r\nfor a lord." And now again she murmured to herself, "It\'s my money\r\nhe\'s after. He\'ll find out that I know how to keep what I\'ve got in\r\nmy own hands." Now that Lady Fawn had been cold to her, she thought\r\nstill less of the proposed marriage. But there was this inducement\r\nfor her to go on with it. If they, the Fawn women, thought that they\r\ncould break it off, she would let them know that they had no such\r\npower.\r\n\r\n"Well, mamma, you\'ve seen her?" said Mrs. Hittaway.\r\n\r\n"Yes, my dear; I\'ve seen her. I had seen her two or three times\r\nbefore, you know."\r\n\r\n"And you are still in love with her?"\r\n\r\n"I never said that I was in love with her, Clara."\r\n\r\n"And what has been fixed?"\r\n\r\n"She is to come down to Fawn Court next week, and stay a fortnight\r\nwith us. Then we shall find out what she is."\r\n\r\n"That will be best, mamma," said Augusta.\r\n\r\n"Mind, mamma; you understand me. I shall tell Frederic plainly just\r\nwhat I think. Of course he will be offended, and if the marriage goes\r\non, the offence will remain,--till he finds out the truth."\r\n\r\n"I hope he\'ll find out no such truth," said Lady Fawn. She was,\r\nhowever, quite unable to say a word in behalf of her future\r\ndaughter-in-law. She said nothing as to that little scene with the\r\nBible, but she never forgot it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER X\r\n\r\nLizzie and Her Lover\r\n\r\n\r\nDuring the remainder of that Monday and all the Tuesday, Lizzie\'s\r\nmind was, upon the whole, averse to matrimony. She had told Miss\r\nMacnulty of her prospects, with some amount of exultation; and the\r\npoor dependant, though she knew that she must be turned out into the\r\nstreet, had congratulated her patroness. "The Vulturess will take\r\nyou in again, when she knows you\'ve nowhere else to go," Lizzie had\r\nsaid,--displaying, indeed, some accurate discernment of her aunt\'s\r\ncharacter. But after Lady Fawn\'s visit she spoke of the marriage in a\r\ndifferent tone. "Of course, my dear, I shall have to look very close\r\nafter the settlement."\r\n\r\n"I suppose the lawyers will do that," said Miss Macnulty.\r\n\r\n"Yes;--lawyers! That\'s all very well. I know what lawyers are. I\'m\r\nnot going to trust any lawyer to give away my property. Of course we\r\nshall live at Portray, because his place is in Ireland;--and nothing\r\nshall take me to Ireland. I told him that from the very first. But I\r\ndon\'t mean to give up my own income. I don\'t suppose he\'ll venture to\r\nsuggest such a thing." And then again she grumbled. "It\'s all very\r\nwell being in the Cabinet--!"\r\n\r\n"Is Lord Fawn in the Cabinet?" asked Miss Macnulty, who in such\r\nmatters was not altogether ignorant.\r\n\r\n"Of course he is," said Lizzie, with an angry gesture. It may\r\nseem unjust to accuse her of being stupidly unacquainted with\r\ncircumstances, and a liar at the same time; but she was both. She\r\nsaid that Lord Fawn was in the Cabinet because she had heard some\r\none speak of him as not being a Cabinet Minister, and in so speaking\r\nappear to slight his political position. Lizzie did not know how much\r\nher companion knew, and Miss Macnulty did not comprehend the depth of\r\nthe ignorance of her patroness. Thus the lies which Lizzie told were\r\namazing to Miss Macnulty. To say that Lord Fawn was in the Cabinet,\r\nwhen all the world knew that he was an Under-Secretary! What good\r\ncould a woman get from an assertion so plainly, so manifestly false?\r\nBut Lizzie knew nothing of Under-Secretaries. Lord Fawn was a lord,\r\nand even commoners were in the Cabinet. "Of course he is," said\r\nLizzie; "but I sha\'n\'t have my drawing-room made a Cabinet. They\r\nsha\'n\'t come here." And then again on the Tuesday evening she\r\ndisplayed her independence. "As for those women down at Richmond, I\r\ndon\'t mean to be overrun by them, I can tell you. I said I would go\r\nthere, and of course I shall keep my word."\r\n\r\n"I think you had better go," said Miss Macnulty.\r\n\r\n"Of course, I shall go. I don\'t want anybody to tell me where I\'m to\r\ngo, my dear, and where I\'m not. But it\'ll be about the first and the\r\nlast visit. And as for bringing those dowdy girls out in London, it\'s\r\nthe last thing I shall think of doing. Indeed, I doubt whether they\r\ncan afford to dress themselves." As she went up to bed on the Tuesday\r\nevening, Miss Macnulty doubted whether the match would go on. She\r\nnever believed her friend\'s statements; but if spoken words might\r\nbe supposed to mean anything, Lady Eustace\'s words on that Tuesday\r\nbetokened a strong dislike to everything appertaining to the Fawn\r\nfamily. She had even ridiculed Lord Fawn himself, declaring that he\r\nunderstood nothing about anything beyond his office.\r\n\r\nAnd, in truth, Lizzie almost had made up her mind to break it off.\r\nAll that she would gain did not seem to weigh down with sufficient\r\npreponderance all that she would lose. Such were her feelings on the\r\nTuesday night. But on the Wednesday morning she received a note which\r\nthrew her back violently upon the Fawn interest. The note was as\r\nfollows: "Messrs. Camperdown and Son present their compliments to\r\nLady Eustace. They have received instructions to proceed by law for\r\nthe recovery of the Eustace diamonds, now in Lady Eustace\'s hands,\r\nand will feel obliged to Lady Eustace if she will communicate to\r\nthem the name and address of her attorney. 62, New Square, May 30,\r\n186--." The effect of this note was to drive Lizzie back upon the\r\nFawn interest. She was frightened about the diamonds, and was,\r\nnevertheless, almost determined not to surrender them. At any rate,\r\nin such a strait she would want assistance, either in keeping them or\r\nin giving them up. The lawyer\'s letter afflicted her with a sense of\r\nweakness, and there was strength in the Fawn connexion. As Lord Fawn\r\nwas so poor, perhaps he would adhere to the jewels. She knew that she\r\ncould not fight Mr. Camperdown with no other assistance than what\r\nMessrs. Mowbray and Mopus might give her, and therefore her heart\r\nsoftened towards her betrothed. "I suppose Frederic will be here\r\nto-day," she said to Miss Macnulty, as they sat at breakfast together\r\nabout noon. Miss Macnulty nodded. "You can have a cab, you know, if\r\nyou like to go anywhere." Miss Macnulty said she thought she would\r\ngo to the National Gallery. "And you can walk back, you know," said\r\nLizzie. "I can walk there and back too," said Miss Macnulty,--in\r\nregard to whom it may be said that the last ounce would sometimes\r\nalmost break the horse\'s back.\r\n\r\n"Frederic" came and was received very graciously. Lizzie had placed\r\nMr. Camperdown\'s note on the little table behind her, beneath the\r\nBible, so that she might put her hand upon it at once, if she could\r\nmake an opportunity of showing it to her future husband. "Frederic"\r\nsat himself beside her, and the intercourse for awhile was such as\r\nmight be looked for between two lovers of whom one was a widow, and\r\nthe other an Under-Secretary of State from the India Office. They\r\nwere loving, but discreetly amatory, talking chiefly of things\r\nmaterial, each flattering the other, and each hinting now and again\r\nat certain little circumstances of which a more accurate knowledge\r\nseemed to be desirable. The one was conversant with things in\r\ngeneral, but was slow; the other was quick as a lizard in turning\r\nhither and thither, but knew almost nothing. When she told Lord Fawn\r\nthat the Ayrshire estate was "her own, to do what she liked with,"\r\nshe did not know that he would certainly find out the truth from\r\nother sources before he married her. Indeed, she was not quite sure\r\nherself whether the statement was true or false, though she would not\r\nhave made it so frequently had her idea of the truth been a fixed\r\nidea. It had all been explained to her;--but there had been something\r\nabout a second son, and there was no second son. Perhaps she might\r\nhave a second son yet,--a future little Lord Fawn, and he might\r\ninherit it. In regard to honesty, the man was superior to the woman,\r\nbecause his purpose was declared, and he told no lies;--but the one\r\nwas as mercenary as the other. It was not love that had brought Lord\r\nFawn to Mount Street.\r\n\r\n"What is the name of your place in Ireland?" she asked.\r\n\r\n"There is no house, you know."\r\n\r\n"But there was one, Frederic?"\r\n\r\n"The town-land where the house used to be, is called Killeagent. The\r\nold demesne is called Killaud."\r\n\r\n"What pretty names! and--and--does it go a great many miles?"\r\nLord Fawn explained that it did run a good many miles up into the\r\nmountains. "How beautifully romantic!" said Lizzie. "But the people\r\nlive on the mountain and pay rent?"\r\n\r\nLord Fawn asked no such inept questions respecting the Ayrshire\r\nproperty, but he did inquire who was Lizzie\'s solicitor. "Of course\r\nthere will be things to be settled," he said, "and my lawyer had\r\nbetter see yours. Mr. Camperdown is a--"\r\n\r\n"Mr. Camperdown!" almost shrieked Lizzie. Lord Fawn then explained,\r\nwith some amazement, that Mr. Camperdown was his lawyer. As far as\r\nhis belief went, there was not a more respectable gentleman in the\r\nprofession. Then he inquired whether Lizzie had any objection to Mr.\r\nCamperdown. "Mr. Camperdown was Sir Florian\'s lawyer," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"That will make it all the easier, I should think," said Lord Fawn.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know how that may be," said Lizzie, trying to bring her mind\r\nto work upon the subject steadily. "Mr. Camperdown has been very\r\nuncourteous to me;--I must say that; and, as I think, unfair. He\r\nwishes to rob me now of a thing that is quite my own."\r\n\r\n"What sort of a thing?" asked Lord Fawn slowly.\r\n\r\n"A very valuable thing. I\'ll tell you all about it, Frederic. Of\r\ncourse I\'ll tell you everything now. I never could keep back anything\r\nfrom one that I loved. It\'s not my nature. There; you might as\r\nwell read that note." Then she put her hand back and brought Mr.\r\nCamperdown\'s letter from under the Bible. Lord Fawn read it very\r\nattentively, and as he read it there came upon him a great doubt.\r\nWhat sort of woman was this to whom he had engaged himself because\r\nshe was possessed of an income? That Mr. Camperdown should be in the\r\nwrong in such a matter was an idea which never occurred to Lord Fawn.\r\nThere is no form of belief stronger than that which the ordinary\r\nEnglish gentleman has in the discretion and honesty of his own family\r\nlawyer. What his lawyer tells him to do, he does. What his lawyer\r\ntells him to sign, he signs. He buys and sells in obedience to the\r\nsame direction, and feels perfectly comfortable in the possession of\r\na guide who is responsible and all but divine. "What diamonds are\r\nthey?" asked Lord Fawn in a very low voice.\r\n\r\n"They are my own,--altogether my own. Sir Florian gave them to me.\r\nWhen he put them into my hands, he said that they were to be my own\r\nfor ever and ever. \'There,\' said he,--\'those are yours to do what you\r\nchoose with them.\' After that they oughtn\'t to ask me to give them\r\nback,--ought they? If you had been married before, and your wife had\r\ngiven you a keepsake,--to keep for ever and ever, would you give it\r\nup to a lawyer? You would not like it;--would you, Frederic?" She had\r\nput her hand on his, and was looking up into his face as she asked\r\nthe question. Again, perhaps, the acting was a little overdone; but\r\nthere were the tears in her eyes, and the tone of her voice was\r\nperfect.\r\n\r\n"Mr. Camperdown calls them Eustace diamonds,--family diamonds," said\r\nLord Fawn. "What do they consist of? What are they worth?"\r\n\r\n"I\'ll show them to you," said Lizzie, jumping up and hurrying out of\r\nthe room. Lord Fawn, when he was alone, rubbed his hands over his\r\neyes and thought about it all. It would be a very harsh measure,\r\non the part of the Eustace family and of Mr. Camperdown, to demand\r\nfrom her the surrender of any trinket which her late husband might\r\nhave given her in the manner she had described. But it was, to his\r\nthinking, most improbable that the Eustace people or the lawyer\r\nshould be harsh to a widow bearing the Eustace name. The Eustaces\r\nwere by disposition lavish, and old Mr. Camperdown was not one who\r\nwould be strict in claiming little things for rich clients. And yet\r\nhere was his letter, threatening the widow of the late baronet with\r\nlegal proceedings for the recovery of jewels which had been given by\r\nSir Florian himself to his wife as a keepsake! Perhaps Sir Florian\r\nhad made some mistake, and had caused to be set in a ring or brooch\r\nfor his bride some jewel which he had thought to be his own, but\r\nwhich had, in truth, been an heirloom. If so, the jewel should, of\r\ncourse, be surrendered,--or replaced by one of equal value. He was\r\nmaking out some such solution, when Lizzie returned with the morocco\r\ncase in her hand. "It was the manner in which he gave it to me," said\r\nLizzie, as she opened the clasp, "which makes its value to me."\r\n\r\nLord Fawn knew nothing about jewels, but even he knew that if the\r\ncircle of stones which he saw, with a Maltese cross appended to it,\r\nwas constituted of real diamonds, the thing must be of great value.\r\nAnd it occurred to him at once that such a necklace is not given by a\r\nhusband even to a bride in the manner described by Lizzie. A ring, or\r\nbrooch, or perhaps a bracelet, a lover or a loving lord may bring in\r\nhis pocket. But such an ornament as this on which Lord Fawn was now\r\nlooking, is given in another sort of way. He felt sure that it was\r\nso, even though he was entirely ignorant of the value of the stones.\r\n"Do you know what it is worth?" he asked.\r\n\r\nLizzie hesitated a moment, and then remembered that "Frederic," in\r\nhis present position in regard to herself, might be glad to assist\r\nher in maintaining the possession of a substantial property. "I think\r\nthey say its value is about--ten thousand pounds," she replied.\r\n\r\n"Ten--thousand--pounds!" Lord Fawn riveted his eyes upon them.\r\n\r\n"That\'s what I am told--by a jeweller."\r\n\r\n"By what jeweller?"\r\n\r\n"A man had to come and see them,--about some repairs,--or something\r\nof that kind. Poor Sir Florian wished it. And he said so."\r\n\r\n"What was the man\'s name?"\r\n\r\n"I forget his name," said Lizzie, who was not quite sure whether her\r\nacquaintance with Mr. Benjamin would be considered respectable.\r\n\r\n"Ten thousand pounds! You don\'t keep them in the house;--do you?"\r\n\r\n"I have an iron case up-stairs for them;--ever so heavy."\r\n\r\n"And did Sir Florian give you the iron case?"\r\n\r\nLizzie hesitated for a moment. "Yes," said she. "That is,--no. But he\r\nordered it to be made; and then it came,--after he was--dead."\r\n\r\n"He knew their value, then?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, dear, yes. Though he never named any sum. He told me, however,\r\nthat they were very--very valuable."\r\n\r\nLord Fawn did not immediately recognise the falseness of every word\r\nthat the woman said to him, because he was slow and could not think\r\nand hear at the same time. But he was at once involved in a painful\r\nmaze of doubt and almost of dismay. An action for the recovery of\r\njewels brought against the lady whom he was engaged to marry, on\r\nbehalf of the family of her late husband, would not suit him at all.\r\nTo have his hands quite clean, to be above all evil report, to be\r\nrespectable, as it were, all round, was Lord Fawn\'s special ambition.\r\nHe was a poor man, and a greedy man, but he would have abandoned his\r\nofficial salary at a moment\'s notice, rather than there should have\r\nfallen on him a breath of public opinion hinting that it ought to be\r\nabandoned. He was especially timid, and lived in a perpetual fear\r\nlest the newspapers should say something hard of him. In that matter\r\nof the Sawab he had been very wretched, because Frank Greystock had\r\naccused him of being an administrator of tyranny. He would have liked\r\nhis wife to have ten thousand pounds\' worth of diamonds very well;\r\nbut he would rather go without a wife for ever,--and without a wife\'s\r\nfortune,--than marry a woman subject to an action for claiming\r\ndiamonds not her own. "I think," said he, at last, "that if you were\r\nto put them into Mr. Camperdown\'s hands--"\r\n\r\n"Into Mr. Camperdown\'s hands!"\r\n\r\n"And then let the matter be settled by arbitration--"\r\n\r\n"Arbitration? That means going to law?"\r\n\r\n"No, dearest,--that means not going to law. The diamonds would be\r\nentrusted to Mr. Camperdown. And then some one would be appointed to\r\ndecide whose property they were."\r\n\r\n"They\'re my property," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"But he says they belong to the family."\r\n\r\n"He\'ll say anything," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"My dearest girl, there can\'t be a more respectable man than Mr.\r\nCamperdown. You must do something of the kind, you know."\r\n\r\n"I sha\'n\'t do anything of the kind," said Lizzie. "Sir Florian\r\nEustace gave them to me, and I shall keep them." She did not look\r\nat her lover as she spoke; but he looked at her, and did not like\r\nthe change which he saw on her countenance. And he did not like\r\nthe circumstances in which he found himself placed. "Why should Mr.\r\nCamperdown interfere?" continued Lizzie. "If they don\'t belong to me,\r\nthey belong to my son;--and who has so good a right to keep them for\r\nhim as I have? But they belong to me."\r\n\r\n"They should not be kept in a private house like this at all, if they\r\nare worth all that money."\r\n\r\n"If I were to let them go, Mr. Camperdown would get them. There\'s\r\nnothing he wouldn\'t do to get them. Oh, Frederic, I hope you\'ll stand\r\nto me, and not see me injured. Of course I only want them for my\r\ndarling child."\r\n\r\nFrederic\'s face had become very long, and he was much disturbed in\r\nhis mind. He could only suggest that he himself would go and see Mr.\r\nCamperdown, and ascertain what ought to be done. To the last, he\r\nadhered to his assurance that Mr. Camperdown could do no evil;--till\r\nLizzie, in her wrath, asked him whether he believed Mr. Camperdown\'s\r\nword before hers. "I think he would understand a matter of business\r\nbetter than you," said the prudent lover.\r\n\r\n"He wants to rob me," said Lizzie, "and I shall look to you to\r\nprevent it."\r\n\r\nWhen Lord Fawn took his leave,--which he did not do till he\r\nhad counselled her again and again to leave the matter in Mr.\r\nCamperdown\'s hands,--the two were not in good accord together. It was\r\nhis fixed purpose, as he declared to her, to see Mr. Camperdown; and\r\nit was her fixed purpose,--so, at least, she declared to him,--to\r\nkeep the diamonds, in spite of Mr. Camperdown. "But, my dear, if it\'s\r\ndecided against you--" said Lord Fawn gravely.\r\n\r\n"It can\'t be decided against me, if you stand by me as you ought to\r\ndo."\r\n\r\n"I can do nothing," said Lord Fawn, in a tremor. Then Lizzie looked\r\nat him,--and her look, which was very eloquent, called him a poltroon\r\nas plain as a look could speak. Then they parted, and the signs of\r\naffection between them were not satisfactory.\r\n\r\nThe door was hardly closed behind him before Lizzie began to declare\r\nto herself that he shouldn\'t escape her. It was not yet twenty-four\r\nhours since she had been telling herself that she did not like the\r\nengagement and would break it off; and now she was stamping her\r\nlittle feet, and clenching her little hands, and swearing to herself\r\nby all her gods, that this wretched, timid lordling should not get\r\nout of her net. She did, in truth, despise him because he would not\r\nclutch the jewels. She looked upon him as mean and paltry because he\r\nwas willing to submit to Mr. Camperdown. But still she was prompted\r\nto demand all that could be demanded from her engagement,--because\r\nshe thought that she perceived a something in him which might\r\nproduce in him a desire to be relieved from it. No! he should not be\r\nrelieved. He should marry her. And she would keep the key of that\r\niron box with the diamonds, and he should find what sort of a noise\r\nshe would make if he attempted to take it from her. She closed the\r\nmorocco case, ascended with it to her bed-room, locked it up in the\r\niron safe, deposited the little patent key in its usual place round\r\nher neck, and then seated herself at her desk, and wrote letters to\r\nher various friends, making known to them her engagement. Hitherto\r\nshe had told no one but Miss Macnulty,--and, in her doubts, had gone\r\nso far as to desire Miss Macnulty not to mention it. Now she was\r\nresolved to blazon forth her engagement before all the world.\r\n\r\nThe first "friend" to whom she wrote was Lady Linlithgow. The reader\r\nshall see two or three of her letters, and that to the countess shall\r\nbe the first.\r\n\r\n\r\n   MY DEAR AUNT,\r\n\r\n   When you came to see me the other day, I cannot say that\r\n   you were very kind to me, and I don\'t suppose you care\r\n   very much what becomes of me. But I think it right to\r\n   let you know that I am going to be married. I am engaged\r\n   to Lord Fawn, who, as you know, is a peer, and a member\r\n   of Her Majesty\'s Government, and a nobleman of great\r\n   influence. I do not suppose that even you can say anything\r\n   against such an alliance.\r\n\r\n   I am, your affectionate niece,\r\n\r\n   ELI. EUSTACE.\r\n\r\n\r\nThen she wrote to Mrs. Eustace, the wife of the Bishop of\r\nBobsborough. Mrs. Eustace had been very kind to her in the first\r\ndays of her widowhood, and had fully recognised her as the widow\r\nof the head of her husband\'s family. Lizzie had liked none of\r\nthe Bobsborough people. They were, according to her ideas, slow,\r\nrespectable, and dull. But they had not found much open fault with\r\nher, and she was aware that it was for her interest to remain on good\r\nterms with them. Her letter, therefore, to Mrs. Eustace was somewhat\r\nless acrid than that written to her aunt Linlithgow.\r\n\r\n\r\n   MY DEAR MRS. EUSTACE,\r\n\r\n   I hope you will be glad to hear from me, and will not be\r\n   sorry to hear my news. I am going to be married again. Of\r\n   course I am not about to take a step which is in every way\r\n   so very important without thinking about it a great deal.\r\n   But I am sure it will be better for my darling little\r\n   Florian in every way; and as for myself, I have felt for\r\n   the last two years how unfitted I have been to manage\r\n   everything myself. I have therefore accepted an offer\r\n   made to me by Lord Fawn, who is, as you know, a peer\r\n   of Parliament, and a most distinguished member of Her\r\n   Majesty\'s Government; and he is, too, a nobleman of very\r\n   great influence in every respect, and has a property in\r\n   Ireland, extending over ever so many miles, and running up\r\n   into the mountains. His mansion there is called Killmage,\r\n   but I am not sure that I remember the name quite rightly.\r\n   I hope I may see you there some day, and the dear bishop.\r\n   I look forward with delight to doing something to make\r\n   those dear Irish happier. The idea of rambling up into our\r\n   own mountains charms me, for nothing suits my disposition\r\n   so well as that kind of solitude.\r\n\r\n   Of course Lord Fawn is not so rich a man as Sir Florian,\r\n   but I have never looked to riches for my happiness. Not\r\n   but what Lord Fawn has a good income from his Irish\r\n   estates; and then, of course, he is paid for doing Her\r\n   Majesty\'s Government;--so there is no fear that he will\r\n   have to live upon my jointure, which, of course, would not\r\n   be right. Pray tell the dear bishop and dear Margaretta\r\n   all this, with my love. You will be happy, I know, to hear\r\n   that my little Flo is quite well. He is already so fond of\r\n   his new papa! [Lizzie\'s turn for lying was exemplified in\r\n   this last statement, for, as it happened, Lord Fawn had\r\n   never yet seen the child.]\r\n\r\n   Believe me to be always your most affectionate niece,\r\n\r\n   ELI. EUSTACE.\r\n\r\n\r\nThere were two other letters,--one to her uncle, the dean, and the\r\nother to her cousin Frank. There was great doubt in her mind as to\r\nthe expediency of writing to Frank Greystock; but at last she decided\r\nthat she would do it. The letter to the dean need not be given in\r\nfull, as it was very similar to that written to the bishop\'s wife.\r\nThe same mention was made of her intended husband\'s peerage, and the\r\nsame allusion to Her Majesty\'s Government,--a phrase which she had\r\nheard from Lord Fawn himself. She spoke of the Irish property, but\r\nin terms less glowing than she had used in writing to the lady, and\r\nended by asking for her uncle\'s congratulation--and blessing. Her\r\nletter to Frank was as follows, and, doubtless, as she wrote it,\r\nthere was present to her mind a remembrance of the fact that he\r\nhimself might have offered to her, and have had her if he would.\r\n\r\n\r\n   MY DEAR COUSIN,\r\n\r\n   As I would rather that you should hear my news from myself\r\n   than from any one else, I write to tell you that I am\r\n   going to be married to Lord Fawn. Of course I know that\r\n   there are certain matters as to which you and Lord Fawn do\r\n   not agree,--in politics, I mean; but still I do not doubt\r\n   but you will think that he is quite able to take care of\r\n   your poor little cousin. It was only settled a day or\r\n   two since, but it has been coming on ever so long. You\r\n   understand all about that;--don\'t you? Of course you\r\n   must come to my wedding, and be very good to me,--a\r\n   kind of brother, you know; for we have always been\r\n   friends;--haven\'t we? And if the dean doesn\'t come up to\r\n   town, you must give me away. And you must come and see me\r\n   ever so often; for I have a sort of feeling that I have\r\n   no one else belonging to me that I can call really my\r\n   own, except you. And you must be great friends with Lord\r\n   Fawn, and must give up saying that he doesn\'t do his work\r\n   properly. Of course he does everything better than anybody\r\n   else could possibly do it,--except Cousin Frank.\r\n\r\n   I am going down next week to Richmond. Lady Fawn has\r\n   insisted on my staying there for a fortnight. Oh, dear,\r\n   what shall I do all the time? You must positively come\r\n   down and see me,--and see somebody else too! Only, you\r\n   naughty coz! you mustn\'t break a poor girl\'s heart.\r\n\r\n   Your affectionate cousin,\r\n\r\n   ELI. EUSTACE.\r\n\r\n\r\nSomebody, in speaking on Lady Eustace\'s behalf, and making the best\r\nof her virtues, had declared that she did not have lovers. Hitherto\r\nthat had been true of her;--but her mind had not the less dwelt on\r\nthe delight of a lover. She still thought of a possible Corsair who\r\nwould be willing to give up all but his vices for her love, and\r\nfor whose sake she would be willing to share even them. It was but\r\na dream, but nevertheless it pervaded her fancy constantly. Lord\r\nFawn,--peer of Parliament, and member of Her Majesty\'s Government,\r\nas he was,--could not have been such a lover to her. Might it not\r\nbe possible that there should exist something of romance between\r\nher and her cousin Frank? She was the last woman in the world to\r\nrun away with a man, or to endanger her position by a serious\r\nindiscretion; but there might, perhaps, be a something between her\r\nand her cousin,--a liaison quite correct in its facts, a secret\r\nunderstanding, if nothing more,--a mutual sympathy, which should be\r\nchiefly shown in the abuse of all their friends,--and in this she\r\ncould indulge her passion for romance and poetry.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XI\r\n\r\nLord Fawn at His Office\r\n\r\n\r\nThe news was soon all about London,--as Lizzie had intended. She had\r\nmade a sudden resolve that Lord Fawn should not escape her, and she\r\nhad gone to work after the fashion we have seen. Frank Greystock had\r\ntold John Eustace, and John Eustace had told Mr. Camperdown before\r\nLord Fawn himself, in the slow prosecution of his purpose, had\r\nconsulted the lawyer about the necklace. "God bless my soul;--Lord\r\nFawn!" the old lawyer had said when the news was communicated to him.\r\n"Well,--yes;--he wants money. I don\'t envy him; that\'s all. We shall\r\nget the diamonds now, John. Lord Fawn isn\'t the man to let his wife\r\nkeep what doesn\'t belong to her." Then, after a day or two, Lord Fawn\r\nhad himself gone to Mr. Camperdown\'s chambers. "I believe I am to\r\ncongratulate you, my lord," said the lawyer. "I\'m told you are going\r\nto marry--; well, I mustn\'t really say another of my clients, but the\r\nwidow of one of them. Lady Eustace is a very beautiful woman, and she\r\nhas a very pretty income too. She has the whole of the Scotch\r\nproperty for her life."\r\n\r\n"It\'s only for her life, I suppose?" said Lord Fawn.\r\n\r\n"Oh, no, no;--of course not. There\'s been some mistake on her\r\npart;--at least, so I\'ve been told. Women never understand. It\'s\r\nall as clear as daylight. Had there been a second son, the second\r\nson would have had it. As it is, it goes with the rest of the\r\nproperty--just as it ought to do, you know. Four thousand a year\r\nisn\'t so bad, you know, considering that she isn\'t more than a girl\r\nyet, and that she hadn\'t sixpence of her own. When the admiral died,\r\nthere wasn\'t sixpence, Lord Fawn."\r\n\r\n"So I have heard."\r\n\r\n"Not sixpence. It\'s all Eustace money. She had six or eight thousand\r\npounds, or something like that, besides. She\'s as lovely a young\r\nwidow as I ever saw,--and very clever."\r\n\r\n"Yes;--she is clever."\r\n\r\n"By-the-bye, Lord Fawn, as you have done me the honour of\r\ncalling,--there\'s a stupid mistake about some family diamonds."\r\n\r\n"It is in respect to them that I\'ve come," said Lord Fawn. Then Mr.\r\nCamperdown, in his easy, off-hand way, imputing no blame to the lady\r\nin the hearing of her future husband, and declaring his opinion that\r\nshe was doubtless unaware of its value, explained the matter of the\r\nnecklace. Lord Fawn listened, but said very little. He especially did\r\nnot say that Lady Eustace had had the stones valued. "They\'re real, I\r\nsuppose?" he asked. Mr. Camperdown assured him that no diamonds more\r\nreal had ever come from Golconda, or passed through Mr. Garnett\'s\r\nhands. "They are as well known as any family diamonds in England,"\r\nsaid Mr. Camperdown. "She has got into bad hands,"--continued Mr.\r\nCamperdown. "Mowbray and Mopus;--horrible people; sharks, that make\r\none blush for one\'s profession; and I was really afraid there would\r\nhave been trouble. But, of course, it\'ll be all right now;--and if\r\nshe\'ll only come to me, tell her I\'ll do everything I can to make\r\nthings straight and comfortable for her. If she likes to have another\r\nlawyer, of course, that\'s all right. Only make her understand who\r\nMowbray and Mopus are. It\'s quite out of the question, Lord Fawn,\r\nthat your wife should have anything to do with Mowbray and Mopus."\r\nEvery word that Mr. Camperdown said was gospel to Lord Fawn.\r\n\r\nAnd yet, as the reader will understand, Mr. Camperdown had by no\r\nmeans expressed his real opinion in this interview. He had spoken of\r\nthe widow in friendly terms,--declaring that she was simply mistaken\r\nin her ideas as to the duration of her interest in the Scotch\r\nproperty, and mistaken again about the diamonds;--whereas in truth he\r\nregarded her as a dishonest, lying, evil-minded harpy. Had Lord Fawn\r\nconsulted him simply as a client, and not have come to him an engaged\r\nlover, he would have expressed his opinion quite frankly; but it is\r\nnot the business of a lawyer to tell his client evil things of the\r\nlady whom that client is engaged to marry. In regard to the property\r\nhe spoke the truth, and he spoke what he believed to be the truth\r\nwhen he said that the whole thing would no doubt now be easily\r\narranged. When Lord Fawn took his leave, Mr. Camperdown again\r\ndeclared to himself that as regarded money the match was very well\r\nfor his lordship; but that, as regarded the woman, Lizzie was dear\r\nat the price. "Perhaps he doesn\'t mind it," said Mr. Camperdown to\r\nhimself, "but I wouldn\'t marry such a woman myself, though she owned\r\nall Scotland."\r\n\r\nThere had been much in the interview to make Lord Fawn unhappy.\r\nIn the first place, that golden hope as to the perpetuity of the\r\nproperty was at an end. He had never believed that it was so; but a\r\nman may hope without believing. And he was quite sure that Lizzie was\r\nbound to give up the diamonds,--and would ultimately be made to give\r\nthem up. Of any property in them, as possibly accruing to himself,\r\nhe had not thought much;--but he could not abstain from thinking of\r\nthe woman\'s grasp upon them. Mr. Camperdown\'s plain statement, which\r\nwas gospel to him, was directly at variance with Lizzie\'s story. Sir\r\nFlorian certainly would not have given such diamonds in such a way.\r\nSir Florian would not have ordered a separate iron safe for them,\r\nwith a view that they might be secure in his wife\'s bed-room. And\r\nthen she had had them valued, and manifestly was always thinking of\r\nher treasure. It was very well for a poor, careful peer to be always\r\nthinking of his money, but Lord Fawn was well aware that a young\r\nwoman such as Lady Eustace should have her thoughts elsewhere. As he\r\nsat signing letters at the India Board, relieving himself when he was\r\nleft alone between each batch by standing up with his back to the\r\nfire-place, his mind was full of all this. He could not unravel truth\r\nquickly, but he could grasp it when it came to him. She was certainly\r\ngreedy, false, and dishonest. And,--worse than all this,--she had\r\ndared to tell him to his face that he was a poor creature because he\r\nwould not support her in her greed, and falsehoods, and dishonesty!\r\nNevertheless, he was engaged to marry her! Then he thought of one\r\nViolet Effingham whom he had loved, and then came over him some\r\nsuspicion of a fear that he himself was hard and selfish. And yet\r\nwhat was such a one as he to do? It was of course necessary for the\r\nmaintenance of the very constitution of his country that there should\r\nbe future Lord Fawns. There could be no future Lord Fawns unless he\r\nmarried;--and how could he marry without money? "A peasant can marry\r\nwhom he pleases," said Lord Fawn, pressing his hand to his brow, and\r\ndropping one flap of his coat, as he thought of his own high and\r\nperilous destiny, standing with his back to the fire-place, while a\r\nhuge pile of letters lay there before him waiting to be signed.\r\n\r\nIt was a Saturday evening, and as there was no House there was\r\nnothing to hurry him away from the office. He was the occupier for\r\nthe time of a large, well-furnished official room, looking out into\r\nSt. James\'s Park, and as he glanced round it he told himself that his\r\nown happiness must be there, and not in the domesticity of a quiet\r\nhome. The House of Lords, out of which nobody could turn him, and\r\nofficial life,--as long as he could hold to it,--must be all in all\r\nto him. He had engaged himself to this woman, and he must--marry\r\nher. He did not think that he could now see any way of avoiding that\r\nevent. Her income would supply the needs of her home, and then there\r\nmight probably be a continuation of Lord Fawns. The world might have\r\ndone better for him,--had he been able to find favour in Violet\r\nEffingham\'s sight. He was a man capable of love,--and very capable\r\nof constancy to a woman true to him. Then he wiped away a tear as he\r\nsat down to sign the huge batch of letters. As he read some special\r\nletter in which instructions were conveyed as to the insufficiency\r\nof the Sawab\'s claims, he thought of Frank Greystock\'s attack upon\r\nhim, and of Frank Greystock\'s cousin. There had been a time in\r\nwhich he had feared that the two cousins would become man and wife.\r\nAt this moment he uttered a malediction against the member for\r\nBobsborough, which might perhaps have been spared had the member\r\nbeen now willing to take the lady off his hands. Then the door was\r\nopened, and the messenger told him that Mrs. Hittaway was in the\r\nwaiting-room. Mrs. Hittaway was, of course, at once made welcome to\r\nthe Under-Secretary\'s own apartment.\r\n\r\nMrs. Hittaway was a strong-minded woman,--the strongest-minded\r\nprobably of the Fawn family,--but she had now come upon a task\r\nwhich taxed all her strength to the utmost. She had told her mother\r\nthat she would tell "Frederic" what she thought about his proposed\r\nbride, and she had now come to carry out her threat. She had asked\r\nher brother to come and dine with her, but he had declined. His\r\nengagements hardly admitted of his dining with his relatives. She had\r\ncalled upon him at the rooms he occupied in Victoria Street,--but\r\nof course she had not found him. She could not very well go to his\r\nclub;--so now she had hunted him down at his office. From the very\r\ncommencement of the interview Mrs. Hittaway was strong-minded. She\r\nbegan the subject of the marriage, and did so without a word of\r\ncongratulation. "Dear Frederic," she said, "you know that we have all\r\ngot to look up to you."\r\n\r\n"Well, Clara,--what does that mean?"\r\n\r\n"It means this,--that you must bear with me, if I am more anxious as\r\nto your future career than another sister might be."\r\n\r\n"Now I know you are going to say something unpleasant."\r\n\r\n"Yes, I am, Frederic. I have heard so many bad things about Lady\r\nEustace!"\r\n\r\nThe Under-Secretary sat silent for awhile in his great arm-chair.\r\n"What sort of evil things do you mean, Clara?" he asked at last.\r\n"Evil things are said of a great many people,--as you know. I am sure\r\nyou would not wish to repeat slanders."\r\n\r\nMrs. Hittaway was not to be silenced after this fashion. "Not\r\nslanders, certainly, Frederic. But when I hear that you intend to\r\nraise this lady to the rank and position of your wife, then of course\r\nthe truth or falsehood of these reports becomes a matter of great\r\nmoment to us all. Don\'t you think you had better see Mr. Camperdown?"\r\n\r\n"I have seen him."\r\n\r\n"And what does he say?"\r\n\r\n"What should he say? Lady Eustace has, I believe, made some mistake\r\nabout the condition of her property, and people who have heard it\r\nhave been good-natured enough to say that the error has been wilful.\r\nThat is what I call slander, Clara."\r\n\r\n"And have you heard about her jewels?" Mrs. Hittaway was alluding\r\nhere to the report which had reached her as to Lizzie\'s debt to\r\nHarter and Benjamin when she married Sir Florian; but Lord Fawn of\r\ncourse thought of the diamond necklace.\r\n\r\n"Yes;" said he, "I have heard all about them. Who told you?"\r\n\r\n"I have known it ever so long. Sir Florian never got over it." Lord\r\nFawn was again in the dark, but he did not choose to commit himself\r\nby asking further questions. "And then her treatment of Lady\r\nLinlithgow, who was her only friend before she married, was something\r\nquite unnatural. Ask the dean\'s people what they think of her. I\r\nbelieve even they would tell you."\r\n\r\n"Frank Greystock desired to marry her himself."\r\n\r\n"Yes,--for her money, perhaps;--because he has not got a farthing in\r\nthe world. Dear Frederic, I only wish to put you on your guard. Of\r\ncourse this is very unpleasant, and I shouldn\'t do it if I didn\'t\r\nthink it my duty. I believe she is artful and very false. She\r\ncertainly deceived Sir Florian Eustace about her debts;--and he never\r\nheld up his head after he found out what she was. If she has told you\r\nfalsehoods, of course you can break it off. Dear Frederic, I hope you\r\nwon\'t be angry with me."\r\n\r\n"Is that all?" he asked.\r\n\r\n"Yes;--that is all."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll bear it in mind," he said. "Of course it isn\'t very pleasant."\r\n\r\n"No;--I know it is not pleasant," said Mrs. Hittaway, rising, and\r\ntaking her departure with an offer of affectionate sisterly greeting,\r\nwhich was not accepted with cordiality.\r\n\r\nIt was very unpleasant. That very morning Lord Fawn had received\r\nletters from the Dean and the Bishop of Bobsborough congratulating\r\nhim on his intended marriage,--both those worthy dignitaries of the\r\nChurch having thought it expedient to verify Lizzie\'s statements.\r\nLord Fawn was, therefore, well aware that Lady Eustace had published\r\nthe engagement. It was known to everybody, and could not be broken\r\noff without public scandal.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XII\r\n\r\n"I Only Thought of It"\r\n\r\n\r\nThere was great perturbation down at Fawn Court. On the day fixed,\r\nMonday, June 5, Lizzie arrived. Nothing further had been said by Lady\r\nFawn to urge the invitation; but, in accordance with the arrangement\r\nalready made, Lady Eustace, with her child, her nurse, and her own\r\nmaid, was at Fawn Court by four o\'clock. A very long letter had been\r\nreceived from Mrs. Hittaway that morning,--the writing of which\r\nmust have seriously interfered with the tranquillity of her Sunday\r\nafternoon. Lord Fawn did not make his appearance at Richmond on the\r\nSaturday evening,--nor was he seen on the Sunday. That Sunday was,\r\nwe may presume, chiefly devoted to reflection. He certainly did not\r\ncall upon his future wife. His omission to do so no doubt increased\r\nLizzie\'s urgency in the matter of her visit to Richmond. Frank\r\nGreystock had written to congratulate her. "Dear Frank," she had said\r\nin reply, "a woman situated as I am has so many things to think of.\r\nLord Fawn\'s position will be of service to my child. Mind you come\r\nand see me at Fawn Court. I count so much on your friendship and\r\nassistance."\r\n\r\nOf course she was expected at Richmond,--although throughout the\r\nmorning Lady Fawn had entertained almost a hope that she wouldn\'t\r\ncome. "He was only lukewarm in defending her," Mrs. Hittaway had said\r\nin her letter, "and I still think that there may be an escape." Not\r\neven a note had come from Lord Fawn himself,--nor from Lady Eustace.\r\nPossibly something violent might have been done, and Lady Eustace\r\nwould not appear. But Lady Eustace did appear,--and, after a fashion,\r\nwas made welcome at Fawn Court.\r\n\r\nThe Fawn ladies were not good hypocrites. Lady Fawn had said almost\r\nnothing to her daughters of her visit to Mount Street, but Augusta\r\nhad heard the discussion in Mrs. Hittaway\'s drawing-room as to the\r\ncharacter of the future bride. The coming visit had been spoken of\r\nalmost with awe, and there was a general conviction in the dovecote\r\nthat an evil thing had fallen upon them. Consequently, their\r\naffection to the new-comer, though spoken in words, was not made\r\nevident by signs and manners. Lizzie herself took care that the\r\nposition in which she was received should be sufficiently declared.\r\n"It seems so odd that I am to come among you as a sister," she said.\r\nThe girls were forced to assent to the claim, but they assented\r\ncoldly. "He has told me to attach myself especially to you," she\r\nwhispered to Augusta. The unfortunate chosen one, who had but little\r\nstrength of her own, accepted the position, and then, as the only\r\nmeans of escaping the embraces of her newly-found sister, pleaded the\r\nviolence of a headache. "My mother!" said Lizzie to Lady Fawn. "Yes,\r\nmy dear," said Lady Fawn. "One of the girls had perhaps better go up\r\nand show you your room." "I am very much afraid about it," said Lady\r\nFawn to her daughter Amelia. Amelia replied only by shaking her head.\r\n\r\nOn the Tuesday morning there came a note from Lord Fawn to his\r\nlady-love. Of course the letter was not shown, but Lizzie received it\r\nat the breakfast table, and read it with many little smiles and signs\r\nof satisfaction. And then she gave out various little statements as\r\nhaving been made in that letter. He says this, and he says that, and\r\nhe is coming here, and going there, and he will do one thing, and\r\nhe won\'t do the other. We have often seen young ladies crowing over\r\ntheir lovers\' letters, and it was pleasant to see Lizzie crowing over\r\nhers. And yet there was but very little in the letter. Lord Fawn told\r\nher that what with the House and what with the Office, he could not\r\nget down to Richmond before Saturday; but that on Saturday he would\r\ncome. Then he signed himself "yours affectionately, Fawn." Lizzie\r\ndid her crowing very prettily. The outward show of it was there\r\nto perfection,--so that the Fawn girls really believed that their\r\nbrother had written an affectionate lover\'s letter. Inwardly, Lizzie\r\nswore to herself, as she read the cold words with indignation, that\r\nthe man should not escape her.\r\n\r\nThe days went by very tediously. On the Wednesday and the Friday Lady\r\nEustace made an excuse of going up to town, and insisted on taking\r\nthe unfortunate Augusta with her. There was no real reason for these\r\njourneys to London,--unless that glance which on each occasion\r\nwas given to the contents of the iron case was a real reason. The\r\ndiamonds were safe, and Miss Macnulty was enjoying herself. On the\r\nFriday Lizzie proposed to Augusta that they should jointly make a\r\nraid upon the member of Her Majesty\'s Government at his office; but\r\nAugusta positively refused to take such a step. "I know he would\r\nbe angry," pleaded Augusta. "Psha! who cares for his anger?" said\r\nLizzie. But the visit was not made.\r\n\r\nOn the Saturday,--the Saturday which was to bring Lord Fawn down to\r\ndinner,--another most unexpected visitor made his appearance. At\r\nabout three o\'clock Frank Greystock was at Fawn Court. Now it was\r\ncertainly understood that Mr. Greystock had been told not to come to\r\nFawn Court as long as Lucy Morris was there. "Dear Mr. Greystock, I\'m\r\nsure you will take what I say as I mean it," Lady Fawn had whispered\r\nto him. "You know how attached we all are to our dear little Lucy.\r\nPerhaps you know--." There had been more of it; but the meaning of it\r\nall was undoubtedly this,--that Frank was not to pay visits to Lucy\r\nMorris at Fawn Court. Now he had come to see his cousin Lizzie\r\nEustace.\r\n\r\nOn this occasion Lady Fawn, with Amelia and two of the other girls,\r\nwere out in the carriage. The unfortunate Augusta had been left at\r\nhome with her bosom friend;--while Cecilia and Nina were supposed to\r\nbe talking French with Lucy Morris. They were all out in the grounds,\r\nsitting upon the benches, and rambling among the shrubberies, when\r\nof a sudden Frank Greystock was in the midst of them. Lizzie\'s\r\nexpression of joy at seeing her cousin was almost as great as though\r\nhe had been in fact a brother. She ran up to him and grasped his\r\nhand, and hung on his arm, and looked up into his face, and then\r\nburst into tears. But the tears were not violent tears. There were\r\njust three sobs, and two bright eyes full of water, and a lace\r\nhandkerchief,--and then a smile. "Oh, Frank," she said, "it does make\r\none think so of old times!" Augusta had by this time been almost\r\npersuaded to believe in her,--though the belief by no means made the\r\npoor young woman happy. Frank thought that his cousin looked very\r\nwell, and said something as to Lord Fawn being "the happiest fellow\r\ngoing." "I hope I shall make him happy," said Lizzie, clasping her\r\nhands together.\r\n\r\nLucy meanwhile was standing in the circle with the others. It never\r\noccurred to her that it was her duty to run away from the man she\r\nloved. She had shaken hands with him, and felt something of affection\r\nin his pressure. She did believe that his visit was made entirely to\r\nhis cousin, and had no idea at the moment of disobeying Lady Fawn.\r\nDuring the last few days she had been thrown very much with her old\r\nfriend Lizzie, and had been treated by the future peeress with many\r\nsigns of almost sisterly affection. "Dear Lucy," Lizzie had said,\r\n"you can understand me. These people,--oh, they are so good, but\r\nthey can\'t understand me." Lucy had expressed a hope that Lord\r\nFawn understood her. "Oh, Lord Fawn,--well; yes; perhaps;--I don\'t\r\nknow. It so often happens that one\'s husband is the last person to\r\nunderstand one."\r\n\r\n"If I thought so, I wouldn\'t marry him," said Lucy.\r\n\r\n"Frank Greystock will understand you," said Lizzie. It was indeed\r\ntrue that Lucy did understand something of her wealthy friend\'s\r\ncharacter, and was almost ashamed of the friendship. With Lizzie\r\nGreystock she had never sympathised, and Lizzie Eustace had always\r\nbeen distasteful to her. She already felt that the less she should\r\nsee of Lizzie Fawn the better she should like it.\r\n\r\nBefore an hour was over, Frank Greystock was walking round the\r\nshrubberies with Lucy,--and was walking with Lucy alone. It was\r\nundoubtedly the fact that Lady Eustace had contrived that it should\r\nbe so. The unfitness of the thing recommended it to her. Frank could\r\nhardly marry a wife without a shilling. Lucy would certainly not\r\nthink at all of shillings. Frank,--as Lizzie knew,--had been almost\r\nat her feet within the last fortnight, and might, in some possible\r\nemergency, be there again. In the midst of such circumstances nothing\r\ncould be better than that Frank and Lucy should be thrown together.\r\nLizzie regarded all this as romance. Poor Lady Fawn, had she known it\r\nall, would have called it diabolical wickedness and inhuman cruelty.\r\n\r\n"Well, Lucy;--what do you think of it?" Frank Greystock said to her.\r\n\r\n"Think of what, Mr. Greystock?"\r\n\r\n"You know what I mean;--this marriage?"\r\n\r\n"How should I be able to think? I have never seen them together. I\r\nsuppose Lord Fawn isn\'t very rich. She is rich. And then she is very\r\nbeautiful. Don\'t you think her very beautiful?"\r\n\r\n"Sometimes exquisitely lovely."\r\n\r\n"Everybody says so;--and I am sure it is the fact. Do you know;--but\r\nperhaps you\'ll think I am envious."\r\n\r\n"If I thought you envious of Lizzie, I should have to think you very\r\nfoolish at the same time."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know what that means;"--she did know well enough what it\r\nmeant;--"but sometimes to me she is almost frightful to look at."\r\n\r\n"In what way?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, I can\'t tell you. She looks like a beautiful animal that you are\r\nafraid to caress for fear it should bite you;--an animal that would\r\nbe beautiful if its eyes were not so restless, and its teeth so sharp\r\nand so white."\r\n\r\n"How very odd."\r\n\r\n"Why odd, Mr. Greystock?"\r\n\r\n"Because I feel exactly in the same way about her. I am not in\r\nthe least afraid that she\'ll bite me; and as for caressing the\r\nanimal,--that kind of caressing which you mean,--it seems to me to be\r\njust what she\'s made for. But, I do feel sometimes, that she is like\r\na cat."\r\n\r\n"Something not quite so tame as a cat," said Lucy.\r\n\r\n"Nevertheless she is very lovely,--and very clever. Sometimes I think\r\nher the most beautiful woman I ever saw in the world."\r\n\r\n"Do you, indeed?"\r\n\r\n"She will be immensely run after as Lady Fawn. When she pleases she\r\ncan make her own house quite charming. I never knew a woman who could\r\nsay pretty things to so many people at once."\r\n\r\n"You are making her out to be a paragon of perfection, Mr.\r\nGreystock."\r\n\r\n"And when you add to all the rest that she has four thousand a year,\r\nyou must admit that Lord Fawn is a lucky man."\r\n\r\n"I have said nothing against it."\r\n\r\n"Four thousand a year is a very great consideration, Lucy." Lucy for\r\na while said nothing. She was making up her mind that she would say\r\nnothing;--that she would make no reply indicative of any feeling on\r\nher part. But she was not sufficiently strong to keep her resolution.\r\n"I wonder, Mr. Greystock," she said, "that you did not attempt to win\r\nthe great prize yourself. Cousins do marry."\r\n\r\nHe had thought of attempting it, and at this moment he would not lie\r\nto her. "The cousinship had nothing to do with it," he said.\r\n\r\n"Perhaps you did think of it."\r\n\r\n"I did, Lucy. Yes, I did. Thank God, I only thought of it." She\r\ncould not refrain herself from looking up into his face and clasping\r\nher hands together. A woman never so dearly loves a man as when he\r\nconfesses that he has been on the brink of a great crime,--but has\r\nrefrained, and has not committed it. "I did think of it. I am not\r\ntelling you that she would have taken me. I have no reason whatever\r\nfor thinking so."\r\n\r\n"I am sure she would," said Lucy, who did not in the least know what\r\nwords she was uttering.\r\n\r\n"It would have been simply for her money,--her money and her beauty.\r\nIt would not have been because I love her."\r\n\r\n"Never--never ask a girl to marry you, unless you love her, Mr.\r\nGreystock."\r\n\r\n"Then there is only one that I can ever ask," said he. There was\r\nnothing of course that she could say to this. If he did not choose\r\nto go further, she was not bound to understand him. But would he go\r\nfurther? She felt at the moment that an open declaration of his love\r\nto herself would make her happy for ever, even though it should be\r\naccompanied by an assurance that he could not marry her. If they only\r\nknew each other,--that it was so between them,--that, she thought,\r\nwould be enough for her. And as for him--if a woman could bear such a\r\nposition, surely he might bear it. "Do you know who that one is?" he\r\nasked.\r\n\r\n"No," she said,--shaking her head.\r\n\r\n"Lucy, is that true?"\r\n\r\n"What does it matter?"\r\n\r\n"Lucy;--look at me, Lucy," and he put his hand upon her arm.\r\n\r\n"No,--no,--no!" she said.\r\n\r\n"I love you so well, Lucy, that I never can love another. I have\r\nthought of many women, but could never even think of one, as a woman\r\nto love, except you. I have sometimes fancied I could marry for\r\nmoney and position,--to help myself on in the world by means of a\r\nwife,--but when my mind has run away with me, to revel amidst ideas\r\nof feminine sweetness, you have always--always been the heroine of\r\nthe tale, as the mistress of the happy castle in the air."\r\n\r\n"Have I?" she asked.\r\n\r\n"Always,--always. As regards this,"--and he struck himself on the\r\nbreast,--"no man was ever more constant. Though I don\'t think much of\r\nmyself as a man, I know a woman when I see her." But he did not ask\r\nher to be his wife;--nor did he wait at Fawn Court till Lady Fawn had\r\ncome back with the carriage.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIII\r\n\r\nShowing What Frank Greystock Did\r\n\r\n\r\nFrank Greystock escaped from the dovecote before Lady Fawn had\r\nreturned. He had not made his visit to Richmond with any purpose of\r\nseeing Lucy Morris, or of saying to her when he did see her anything\r\nspecial,--of saying anything that should, or anything that should\r\nnot, have been said. He had gone there, in truth, simply because his\r\ncousin had asked him, and because it was almost a duty on his part to\r\nsee his cousin on the momentous occasion of this new engagement. But\r\nhe had declared to himself that old Lady Fawn was a fool, and that\r\nto see Lucy again would be very pleasant. "See her;--of course I\'ll\r\nsee her," he had said. "Why should I be prevented from seeing her?"\r\nNow he had seen her, and as he returned by the train to London, he\r\nacknowledged to himself that it was no longer in his power to promote\r\nhis fortune by marriage. He had at last said that to Lucy which made\r\nit impossible for him to offer his hand to any other woman. He had\r\nnot, in truth, asked her to be his wife; but he had told her that he\r\nloved her, and could never love any other woman. He had asked for no\r\nanswer to this assurance, and then he had left her.\r\n\r\nIn the course of that afternoon he did question himself as to his\r\nconduct to this girl, and subjected himself to some of the rigours\r\nof a cross-examination. He was not a man who could think of a girl\r\nas the one human being whom he loved above all others, and yet look\r\nforward with equanimity to the idea of doing her an injury.
