Such arrangement, therefore,\r\n   can only hold good for lives in existence and for 21 years\r\n   afterwards. Chattels so secured would not be heirlooms.\r\n   See Carr v. Lord Errol, 14 Vesey, and Rowland v. Morgan.\r\n\r\n   Lord Eldon remarks, that such chattels held in families\r\n   are "rather favourites of the court." This was in the\r\n   Ormonde case. Executors, therefore, even when setting\r\n   aside any claim as for heirlooms, ought not to apply such\r\n   property in payment of debts unless obliged.\r\n\r\n   The law allows of claims for paraphernalia for widows,\r\n   and, having adjusted such claims, seems to show that the\r\n   claim may be limited.\r\n\r\n   If a man deliver cloth to his wife, and die, she shall\r\n   have it, though she had not fashioned it into the garment\r\n   intended.\r\n\r\n   Pearls and jewels, even though only worn on state\r\n   occasions, may go to the widow as paraphernalia,--but\r\n   with a limit. In the case of Lady Douglas, she being the\r\n   daughter of an Irish Earl and widow of the King\'s Sergeant\r\n   (temp. Car. I.), it was held that \xa3370 was not too much,\r\n   and she was allowed a diamond and a pearl chain to that\r\n   value.\r\n\r\n   In 1674, Lord Keeper Finch declared that he would never\r\n   allow paraphernalia, except to the widow of a nobleman.\r\n\r\n   But in 1721 Lord Macclesfield gave Mistress Tipping\r\n   paraphernalia to the value of \xa3200,--whether so persuaded\r\n   by law and precedent, or otherwise, may be uncertain.\r\n\r\n   Lord Talbot allowed a gold watch as paraphernalia.\r\n\r\n   Lord Hardwicke went much further, and decided that Mrs.\r\n   Northey was entitled to wear jewels to the value of\r\n   \xa33000,--saying that value made no difference; but seems to\r\n   have limited the nature of her possession in the jewels\r\n   by declaring her to be entitled to wear them only when\r\n   full-dressed.\r\n\r\n   It is, I think, clear that the Eustace estate cannot claim\r\n   the jewels as an heirloom. They are last mentioned, and,\r\n   as far as I know, only mentioned as an heirloom in the\r\n   will of the great-grandfather of the present baronet,--if\r\n   these be the diamonds then named by him. As such, he could\r\n   not have devised them to the present claimant, as he died\r\n   in 1820, and the present claimant is not yet two years\r\n   old.\r\n\r\n   Whether the widow could claim them as paraphernalia is\r\n   more doubtful. I do not know that Lord Hardwicke\'s ruling\r\n   would decide the case; but, if so, she would, I think,\r\n   be debarred from selling, as he limits the use of jewels\r\n   of lesser value than these to the wearing of them when\r\n   full-dressed. The use being limited, possession with power\r\n   of alienation cannot be intended.\r\n\r\n   The lady\'s claim to them as a gift from her husband\r\n   amounts to nothing. If they are not hers by will,--and it\r\n   seems that they are not so,--she can only hold them as\r\n   paraphernalia belonging to her station.\r\n\r\n   I presume it to be capable of proof that the diamonds were\r\n   not in Scotland when Sir Florian made his will or when he\r\n   died. The former fact might be used as tending to show his\r\n   intention when the will was made. I understand that he did\r\n   leave to his widow by will all the chattels in Portray\r\n   Castle.\r\n\r\n   J. D.\r\n\r\n   15 August, 18--.\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen Mr. Camperdown had thrice read this opinion, he sat in his chair\r\nan unhappy old man. It was undoubtedly the case that he had been\r\na lawyer for upwards of forty years, and had always believed that\r\nany gentleman could make any article of value an heirloom in his\r\nfamily. The title-deeds of vast estates had been confided to his\r\nkeeping, and he had had much to do with property of every kind;\r\nand now he was told that, in reference to property of a certain\r\ndescription,--property which, by its nature, could only belong to\r\nsuch as they who were his clients,--he had been long without any\r\nknowledge whatsoever. He had called this necklace an heirloom to John\r\nEustace above a score of times; and now he was told by Mr. Dove not\r\nonly that the necklace was not an heirloom, but that it couldn\'t have\r\nbeen an heirloom. He was a man who trusted much in a barrister,--as\r\nwas natural with an attorney; but he was now almost inclined to doubt\r\nMr. Dove. And he was hardly more at ease in regard to the other\r\nclauses of the opinion. Not only could not the estate claim the\r\nnecklace as an heirloom, but that greedy siren, that heartless snake,\r\nthat harpy of a widow,--for it was thus that Mr. Camperdown in his\r\nsolitude spoke to himself of poor Lizzie, perhaps throwing in a\r\nharder word or two,--that female swindler could claim it\r\nas--paraphernalia!\r\n\r\nThere was a crumb of comfort for him in the thought that he could\r\nforce her to claim that privilege from a decision of the Court of\r\nQueen\'s Bench, and that her greed would be exposed should she do so.\r\nAnd she could be prevented from selling the diamonds. Mr. Dove seemed\r\nto make that quite clear. But then there came that other question, as\r\nto the inheritance of the property under the husband\'s will. That Sir\r\nFlorian had not intended that she should inherit the necklace, Mr.\r\nCamperdown was quite certain. On that point he suffered no doubt.\r\nBut would he be able to prove that the diamonds had never been in\r\nScotland since Sir Florian\'s marriage? He had traced their history\r\nfrom that date with all the diligence he could use, and he thought\r\nthat he knew it. But it might be doubtful whether he could prove it.\r\nLady Eustace had first stated,--had so stated before she had learned\r\nthe importance of any other statement,--that Sir Florian had given\r\nher the diamonds in London, as they passed through London from\r\nScotland to Italy, and that she had carried them thence to Naples,\r\nwhere Sir Florian had died. If this were so, they could not have\r\nbeen at Portray Castle till she took them there as a widow, and they\r\nwould undoubtedly be regarded as a portion of that property which Sir\r\nFlorian habitually kept in London. That this was so Mr. Camperdown\r\nentertained no doubt. But now the widow alleged that Sir Florian\r\nhad given the necklace to her in Scotland, whither they had gone\r\nimmediately after their marriage, and that she herself had brought\r\nthem up to London. They had been married on the 5th of September; and\r\nby the jewellers\' books it was hard to tell whether the trinket had\r\nbeen given up to Sir Florian on the 4th or 24th of September. On the\r\n24th Sir Florian and his young bride had undoubtedly been in London.\r\nMr. Camperdown anathematised the carelessness of everybody connected\r\nwith Messrs. Garnett\'s establishment. "Those sort of people have no\r\nmore idea of accuracy than--than--" than he had had of heirlooms, his\r\nconscience whispered to him, filling up the blank.\r\n\r\nNevertheless he thought he could prove that the necklace was first\r\nput into Lizzie\'s hands in London. The middle-aged and very discreet\r\nman at Messrs. Garnett\'s, who had given up the jewel-case to Sir\r\nFlorian, was sure that he had known Sir Florian to be a married man\r\nwhen he did so. The lady\'s maid who had been in Scotland with Lady\r\nEustace, and who was now living in Turin, having married a courier,\r\nhad given evidence before an Italian man of law, stating that she\r\nhad never seen the necklace till she came to London. There were,\r\nmoreover, the probabilities of the case. Was it likely that Sir\r\nFlorian should take such a thing down in his pocket to Scotland? And\r\nthere was the statement as first made by Lady Eustace herself to her\r\ncousin Frank, repeated by him to John Eustace, and not to be denied\r\nby any one. It was all very well for her now to say that she had\r\nforgotten; but would any one believe that on such a subject she could\r\nforget?\r\n\r\nBut still the whole thing was very uncomfortable. Mr. Dove\'s opinion,\r\nif seen by Lady Eustace and her friends, would rather fortify\r\nthem than frighten them. Were she once to get hold of that word\r\nparaphernalia, it would be as a tower of strength to her. Mr.\r\nCamperdown specially felt this,--that whereas he had hitherto\r\nbelieved that no respectable attorney would take up such a case as\r\nthat of Lady Eustace, he could not now but confess to himself that\r\nany lawyer seeing Mr. Dove\'s opinion would be justified in taking\r\nit up. And yet he was as certain as ever that the woman was robbing\r\nthe estate which it was his duty to guard, and that should he cease\r\nto be active in the matter, the necklace would be broken up and the\r\nproperty sold and scattered before a year was out, and then the woman\r\nwould have got the better of him! "She shall find that we have not\r\ndone with her yet," he said to himself, as he wrote a line to John\r\nEustace.\r\n\r\nBut John Eustace was out of town, as a matter of course;--and on the\r\nnext day Mr. Camperdown himself went down and joined his wife and\r\nfamily at a little cottage which he had at Dawlish. The necklace,\r\nhowever, interfered much with his holiday.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVI\r\n\r\nMr. Gowran Is Very Funny\r\n\r\n\r\nFrank Greystock certainly went over to Portray too often,--so often\r\nthat the pony was proved to be quite necessary. Miss Macnulty held\r\nher tongue and was gloomy,--believing that Lady Eustace was still\r\nengaged to Lord Fawn, and feeling that in that case there should not\r\nbe so many visits to the rocks. Mr. Gowran was very attentive, and\r\ncould tell on any day, to five minutes, how long the two cousins were\r\nsitting together on the sea-shore. Arthur Herriot, who cared nothing\r\nfor Lady Eustace, but who knew that his friend had promised to marry\r\nLucy Morris, was inclined to be serious on the subject; but,--as is\r\nalways the case with men,--was not willing to speak about it.\r\n\r\nOnce, and once only, the two men dined together at the castle,--for\r\nthe doing of which it was necessary that a gig should be hired all\r\nthe way from Prestwick. Herriot had not been anxious to go over,\r\nalleging various excuses,--the absence of dress clothes, the calls of\r\nStone and Toddy, his bashfulness, and the absurdity of paying fifteen\r\nshillings for a gig. But he went at last, constrained by his friend,\r\nand a very dull evening he passed. Lizzie was quite unlike her usual\r\nself,--was silent, grave, and solemnly courteous; Miss Macnulty\r\nhad not a word to say for herself; and even Frank was dull. Arthur\r\nHerriot had not tried to exert himself, and the dinner had been a\r\nfailure.\r\n\r\n"You don\'t think much of my cousin, I daresay," said Frank, as they\r\nwere driving back.\r\n\r\n"She is a very pretty woman."\r\n\r\n"And I should say that she does not think much of you."\r\n\r\n"Probably not."\r\n\r\n"Why on earth wouldn\'t you speak to her? I went on making speeches to\r\nMiss Macnulty on purpose to give you a chance. Lizzie generally talks\r\nabout as well as any young woman I know; but you had not a word to\r\nsay to her, nor she to you."\r\n\r\n"Because you devoted yourself to Miss Mac--whatever her name is."\r\n\r\n"That\'s nonsense," said Frank; "Lizzie and I are more like brother\r\nand sister than anything else. She has no one else belonging to her,\r\nand she has to come to me for advice, and all that sort of thing. I\r\nwanted you to like her."\r\n\r\n"I never like people, and people never like me. There is an old\r\nsaying that you should know a man seven years before you poke his\r\nfire. I want to know persons seven years before I can ask them how\r\nthey do. To take me out to dine in this way was of all things the\r\nmost hopeless."\r\n\r\n"But you do dine out,--in London."\r\n\r\n"That\'s different. There\'s a certain routine of conversation going,\r\nand one falls into it. At such affairs as that this evening one\r\nhas to be intimate, or it is a bore. I don\'t mean to say anything\r\nagainst Lady Eustace. Her beauty is undeniable, and I don\'t doubt her\r\ncleverness."\r\n\r\n"She is sometimes too clever," said Frank.\r\n\r\n"I hope she is not becoming too clever for you. You\'ve got to\r\nremember that you\'re due elsewhere;--eh, old fellow?" This was the\r\nfirst word that Herriot had said on the subject, and to that word\r\nFrank Greystock made no answer. But it had its effect, as also did\r\nthe gloomy looks of Miss Macnulty, and the not unobserved presence of\r\nMr. Andy Gowran on various occasions.\r\n\r\nBetween them they shot more grouse,--so the keeper swore,--than\r\nhad ever been shot on these mountains before. Herriot absolutely\r\nkilled one or two himself, to his own great delight, and Frank, who\r\nwas fairly skilful, would get four or five in a day. There were\r\nexcursions to be made, and the air of the hills was in itself a treat\r\nto both of them. Though Greystock was so often away at the castle,\r\nHerriot did not find the time hang heavily on his hands, and was\r\nsorry when his fortnight was over. "I think I shall stay a couple of\r\ndays longer," Frank said, when Herriot spoke of their return. "The\r\ntruth is I must see Lizzie again. She is bothered by business, and I\r\nhave to see her about a letter that came this morning. You needn\'t\r\npull such a long face. There\'s nothing of the kind you\'re thinking\r\nof."\r\n\r\n"I thought so much of what you once said to me about another girl\r\nthat I hope she at any rate may never be in trouble."\r\n\r\n"I hope she never may,--on my account," said Frank. "And what\r\ntroubles she may have,--as life will be troublesome, I trust that I\r\nmay share and lessen."\r\n\r\nOn that evening Herriot went, and on the next morning Frank Greystock\r\nagain rode over to Portray Castle; but when he was alone after\r\nHerriot\'s departure, he wrote a letter to Lucy Morris. He had\r\nexpressed a hope that he might never be a cause of trouble to Lucy\r\nMorris, and he knew that his silence would trouble her. There could\r\nbe no human being less inclined to be suspicious than Lucy Morris. Of\r\nthat Frank was sure. But there had been an express stipulation with\r\nLady Fawn that she should be allowed to receive letters from him, and\r\nshe would naturally be vexed when he did not write to her. So he\r\nwrote.\r\n\r\n\r\n   Portray Cottage, 3 Sept., 18--.\r\n\r\n   DEAREST LUCY,\r\n\r\n   We have been here for a fortnight, shooting grouse,\r\n   wandering about the mountains, and going to sleep on the\r\n   hill-sides. You will say that there never was a time so\r\n   fit for the writing of letters, but that will be because\r\n   you have not learned yet that the idler people are,\r\n   the more inclined they are to be idle. We hear of Lord\r\n   Chancellors writing letters to their mothers every day\r\n   of their lives; but men who have nothing on earth to do\r\n   cannot bring themselves to face a sheet of paper. I would\r\n   promise that when I am Lord Chancellor I would write to\r\n   you every day, were it not that when that time comes I\r\n   shall hope to be always with you.\r\n\r\n   And, in truth, I have had to pay constant visits to my\r\n   cousin, who lives in a big castle on the sea-side, ten\r\n   miles from here, over the mountains, and who is in a\r\n   peck of troubles;--in spite of her prosperity one of\r\n   the unhappiest women, I should say, that you could meet\r\n   anywhere. You know so much of her affairs that, without\r\n   breach of trust, I may say so much. I wish she had a\r\n   father or a brother to manage her matters for her; but\r\n   she has none, and I cannot desert her. Your Lord Fawn is\r\n   behaving badly to her; and so, as far as I can see, are\r\n   the people who manage the Eustace property. Lizzie, as you\r\n   know, is not the most tractable of women, and altogether\r\n   I have more to do in the matter than I like. Riding ten\r\n   miles backwards and forwards so often over the same route\r\n   on a little pony is not good fun, but I am almost glad the\r\n   distance is not less. Otherwise I might have been always\r\n   there. I know you don\'t quite like Lizzie, but she is to\r\n   be pitied.\r\n\r\n   I go up to London on Friday, but shall only be there for\r\n   one or two days,--that is, for one night. I go almost\r\n   entirely on her business, and must, I fear, be here again,\r\n   or at the castle, before I can settle myself either\r\n   for work or happiness. On Sunday night I go down to\r\n   Bobsborough,--where, indeed, I ought to have been earlier.\r\n   I fear I cannot go to Richmond on the Saturday, and on the\r\n   Sunday Lady Fawn would hardly make me welcome. I shall be\r\n   at Bobsborough for about three weeks, and there, if you\r\n   have commands to give, I will obey them.\r\n\r\n   I may, however, tell you the truth at once,--though it\r\n   is a truth you must keep very much to yourself. In the\r\n   position in which I now stand as to Lord Fawn,--being\r\n   absolutely forced to quarrel with him on Lizzie\'s\r\n   behalf,--Lady Fawn could hardly receive me with comfort\r\n   to herself. She is the best of women; and, as she is your\r\n   dear friend, nothing is further from me than any idea of\r\n   quarrelling with her; but of course she takes her son\'s\r\n   part, and I hardly know how all allusion to the subject\r\n   could be avoided.\r\n\r\n   This, however, dearest, need ruffle no feather between you\r\n   and me, who love each other better than we love either the\r\n   Fawns or the Lizzies. Let me find a line at my chambers to\r\n   say that it is so, and always shall be so.\r\n\r\n   God bless my own darling,\r\n   Ever and always your own,\r\n\r\n   F. G.\r\n\r\n\r\nOn the following day he rode over to the castle. He had received a\r\nletter from John Eustace, who had found himself forced to run up to\r\nLondon to meet Mr. Camperdown. The lawyer had thought to postpone\r\nfurther consideration of the whole matter till he and everybody\r\nelse would be naturally in London,--till November that might be, or,\r\nperhaps, even till after Christmas. But his mind was ill at ease; and\r\nhe knew that so much might be done with the diamonds in four months!\r\nThey might even now be in the hands of some Benjamin or of some\r\nHarter, and it might soon be beyond the power either of lawyers\r\nor of policemen to trace them. He therefore went up from Dawlish\r\nand persuaded John Eustace to come from Yorkshire. It was a great\r\nnuisance, and Eustace freely anathematised the necklace. "If only\r\nsome one would steal it, so that we might hear no more of the thing!"\r\nhe said. But, as Mr. Camperdown had frequently remarked, the value\r\nwas too great for trifling, and Eustace went up to London. Mr.\r\nCamperdown put into his hands the Turtle Dove\'s opinion, explaining\r\nthat it was by no means expedient that it should be shown to the\r\nother party. Eustace thought that the opinion should be common to\r\nthem all. "We pay for it," said Mr. Camperdown, "and they can get\r\ntheir opinion from any other barrister if they please." But what was\r\nto be done? Eustace declared that as to the present whereabouts of\r\nthe necklace, he did not in the least doubt that he could get the\r\ntruth from Frank Greystock. He therefore wrote to Greystock, and with\r\nthat letter in his pocket, Frank rode over to the castle for the last\r\ntime.\r\n\r\nHe, too, was heartily sick of the necklace;--but unfortunately he was\r\nnot equally sick of her who held it in possession. And he was, too,\r\nbetter alive to the importance of the value of the trinket than John\r\nEustace, though not so keenly as was Mr. Camperdown. Lady Eustace was\r\nout somewhere among the cliffs, the servant said. He regretted this\r\nas he followed her, but he was obliged to follow her. Half way down\r\nto the sea-shore, much below the knob on which she had attempted to\r\nsit with her Shelley, but yet not below the need of assistance, he\r\nfound her seated in a little ravine. "I knew you would come," she\r\nsaid. Of course she had known that he would come. She did not rise,\r\nor even give him her hand, but there was a spot close beside her on\r\nwhich it was to be presumed that he would seat himself. She had a\r\nvolume of Byron in her hand,--the Corsair, Lara, and the Giaour,--a\r\nkind of poetry which was in truth more intelligible to her than Queen\r\nMab. "You go to-morrow?"\r\n\r\n"Yes;--I go to-morrow."\r\n\r\n"And Lubin has gone?" Arthur Herriot was Lubin.\r\n\r\n"Lubin has gone. Though why Lubin, I cannot guess. The normal Lubin\r\nto me is a stupid fellow always in love. Herriot is not stupid and is\r\nnever in love."\r\n\r\n"Nevertheless, he is Lubin if I choose to call him so. Why did he\r\ntwiddle his thumbs instead of talking? Have you heard anything of\r\nLord Fawn?"\r\n\r\n"I have had a letter from your brother-in-law."\r\n\r\n"And what is John the Just pleased to say?"\r\n\r\n"John the Just, which is a better name for the man than the\r\nother, has been called up to London, much against his will, by Mr.\r\nCamperdown."\r\n\r\n"Who is Samuel the Unjust." Mr. Camperdown\'s name was Samuel.\r\n\r\n"And now wants to know where this terrible necklace is at this\r\npresent moment." He paused a moment, but Lizzie did not answer him.\r\n"I suppose you have no objection to telling me where it is."\r\n\r\n"None in the least:--or to giving it you to keep for me, only that\r\nI would not so far trouble you. But I have an objection to telling\r\nthem. They are my enemies. Let them find out."\r\n\r\n"You are wrong, Lizzie. You do not want, or at any rate should not\r\nwant, to have any secret in the matter."\r\n\r\n"They are here,--in the castle; in the very place in which Sir\r\nFlorian kept them when he gave them to me. Where should my own jewels\r\nbe but in my own house? What does that Mr. Dove say, who was to be\r\nasked about them? No doubt they can pay a barrister to say anything."\r\n\r\n"Lizzie, you think too hardly of people."\r\n\r\n"And do not people think too hardly of me? Does not all this amount\r\nto an accusation against me that I am a thief? Am I not persecuted\r\namong them? Did not this impudent attorney stop me in the public\r\nstreet and accuse me of theft before my very servants? Have they not\r\nso far succeeded in misrepresenting me, that the very man who is\r\nengaged to be my husband betrays me? And now you are turning against\r\nme? Can you wonder that I am hard?"\r\n\r\n"I am not turning against you."\r\n\r\n"Yes; you are. You take their part, and not mine, in everything.\r\nI tell you what, Frank;--I would go out in that boat that you see\r\nyonder, and drop the bauble into the sea, did I not know that they\'d\r\ndrag it up again with their devilish ingenuity. If the stones would\r\nburn, I would burn them. But the worst of it all is, that you are\r\nbecoming my enemy!" Then she burst into violent and almost hysteric\r\ntears.\r\n\r\n"It will be better that you should give them into the keeping of some\r\none whom you can both trust, till the law has decided to whom they\r\nbelong."\r\n\r\n"I will never give them up. What does Mr. Dove say?"\r\n\r\n"I have not seen what Mr. Dove says. It is clear that the necklace is\r\nnot an heirloom."\r\n\r\n"Then how dare Mr. Camperdown say so often that it was?"\r\n\r\n"He said what he thought," pleaded Frank.\r\n\r\n"And he is a lawyer!"\r\n\r\n"I am a lawyer, and I did not know what is or what is not an\r\nheirloom. But Mr. Dove is clearly of opinion that such a property\r\ncould not have been given away simply by word of mouth." John Eustace\r\nin his letter had made no allusion to that complicated question of\r\nparaphernalia.\r\n\r\n"But it was," said Lizzie. "Who can know but myself, when no one else\r\nwas present?"\r\n\r\n"The jewels are here now?"\r\n\r\n"Not in my pocket. I do not carry them about with me. They are in the\r\ncastle."\r\n\r\n"And will they go back with you to London?"\r\n\r\n"Was ever lady so interrogated? I do not know yet that I shall go\r\nback to London. Why am I asked such questions? As to you, Frank, I\r\nwould tell you everything,--my whole heart, if only you cared to know\r\nit. But why is John Eustace to make inquiry as to personal ornaments\r\nwhich are my own property? If I go to London, I will take them there,\r\nand wear them at every house I enter. I will do so in defiance of Mr.\r\nCamperdown and Lord Fawn. I think, Frank, that no woman was ever so\r\nill-treated as I am."\r\n\r\nHe himself thought that she was ill-treated. She had so pleaded her\r\ncase, and had been so lovely in her tears and her indignation, that\r\nhe began to feel something like true sympathy for her cause. What\r\nright had he, or had Mr. Camperdown, or any one, to say that the\r\njewels did not belong to her? And if her claim to them was just, why\r\nshould she be persuaded to give up the possession of them? He knew\r\nwell that were she to surrender them with the idea that they should\r\nbe restored to her if her claim were found to be just, she would not\r\nget them back very soon. If once the jewels were safe, locked up in\r\nMr. Garnett\'s strong box, Mr. Camperdown would not care how long it\r\nmight be before a jury or a judge should have decided on the case.\r\nThe burthen of proof would then be thrown upon Lady Eustace. In order\r\nthat she might recover her own property she would have to thrust\r\nherself forward as a witness, and appear before the world a claimant,\r\ngreedy for rich ornaments. Why should he advise her to give them up?\r\n"I am only thinking," said he, "what may be the best for your own\r\npeace."\r\n\r\n"Peace!"--she exclaimed. "How am I to have peace? Remember the\r\ncondition in which I find myself! Remember the manner in which that\r\nman is treating me, when all the world has been told of my engagement\r\nto him! When I think of it my heart is so bitter that I am inclined\r\nto throw, not the diamonds, but myself from off the rocks. All that\r\nremains to me is the triumph of getting the better of my enemies. Mr.\r\nCamperdown shall never have the diamonds. Even if they could prove\r\nthat they did not belong to me, they should find them--gone."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t think they can prove it."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll flaunt them in the eyes of all of them till they do; and\r\nthen--they shall be gone. And I\'ll have such revenge on Lord Fawn\r\nbefore I have done with him, that he shall know that it may be worse\r\nto have to fight a woman than a man. Oh, Frank, I do not think that I\r\nam hard by nature, but these things make a woman hard." As she spoke\r\nshe took his hand in hers, and looked up into his eyes through her\r\ntears. "I know that you do not care for me, and you know how much I\r\ncare for you."\r\n\r\n"Not care for you, Lizzie?"\r\n\r\n"No;--that little thing at Richmond is everything to you. She is tame\r\nand quiet,--a cat that will sleep on the rug before the fire, and\r\nyou think that she will never scratch. Do not suppose that I mean to\r\nabuse her. She was my dear friend before you had ever seen her. And\r\nmen, I know, have tastes which we women do not understand. You want\r\nwhat you call--repose."\r\n\r\n"We seldom know what we want, I fancy. We take what the gods send\r\nus." Frank\'s words were perhaps more true than wise. At the present\r\nmoment the gods had clearly sent Lizzie Eustace to him, and unless he\r\ncould call up some increased strength of his own, quite independent\r\nof the gods,--or of what we may perhaps call chance,--he would have\r\nto put up with the article sent.\r\n\r\nLizzie had declared that she would not touch Lord Fawn with a pair of\r\ntongs, and in saying so had resolved that she could not and would not\r\nnow marry his lordship even were his lordship in her power. It had\r\nbeen decided by her as quickly as thoughts flash, but it was decided.\r\nShe would torture the unfortunate lord, but not torture him by\r\nbecoming his wife. And, so much being fixed as the stars in heaven,\r\nmight it be possible that she should even yet induce her cousin to\r\ntake the place that had been intended for Lord Fawn? After all that\r\nhad passed between them she need hardly hesitate to tell him of her\r\nlove. And with the same flashing thoughts she declared to herself\r\nthat she did love him, and that therefore this arrangement would be\r\nso much better than that other one which she had proposed to herself.\r\nThe reader, perhaps, by this time, has not a high opinion of Lady\r\nEustace, and may believe that among other drawbacks on her character\r\nthere is especially this,--that she was heartless. But that was\r\nby no means her own opinion of herself. She would have described\r\nherself,--and would have meant to do so with truth,--as being all\r\nheart. She probably thought that an over-amount of heart was the\r\nmalady under which she specially suffered. Her heart was overflowing\r\nnow towards the man who was sitting by her side. And then it would\r\nbe so pleasant to punish that little chit who had spurned her gift\r\nand had dared to call her mean! This man, too, was needy, and she was\r\nwealthy. Surely, were she to offer herself to him, the generosity of\r\nthe thing would make it noble. She was still dissolved in tears and\r\nwas still hysteric. "Oh, Frank!" she said, and threw herself upon his\r\nbreast.\r\n\r\nFrank Greystock felt his position to be one of intense difficulty,\r\nbut whether his difficulty was increased or diminished by the\r\nappearance of Mr. Andy Gowran\'s head over a rock at the entrance of\r\nthe little cave in which they were sitting, it might be difficult to\r\ndetermine. But there was the head. And it was not a head that just\r\npopped itself up and then retreated, as a head would do that was\r\ndiscovered doing that which made it ashamed of itself. The head, with\r\nits eyes wide open, held its own, and seemed to say,--"Ay,--I\'ve\r\ncaught you, have I?" And the head did speak, though not exactly in\r\nthose words. "Coosins!" said the head; and then the head was wagged.\r\nIn the meantime Lizzie Eustace, whose back was turned to the head,\r\nraised her own, and looked up into Greystock\'s eyes for love. She\r\nperceived at once that something was amiss, and, starting to her\r\nfeet, turned quickly round. "How dare you intrude here?" she said to\r\nthe head. "Coosins!" replied the head, wagging itself.\r\n\r\nIt was clearly necessary that Greystock should take some steps, if\r\nonly with the object of proving to the impudent factotum that he was\r\nnot altogether overcome by the awkwardness of his position. That he\r\nwas a good deal annoyed, and that he felt not altogether quite equal\r\nto the occasion, must be acknowledged. "What is it that the man\r\nwants?" he said, glaring at the head. "Coosins!" said the head,\r\nwagging itself again. "If you don\'t take yourself off, I shall have\r\nto thrash you," said Frank. "Coosins!" said Andy Gowran, stepping\r\nfrom behind the rock and showing his full figure. Andy was a man on\r\nthe wrong side of fifty, and therefore, on the score of age, hardly\r\nfit for thrashing. And he was compact, short, broad, and as hard as\r\nflint;--a man bad to thrash, look at it from what side you would.\r\n"Coosins!" he said yet again. "Ye\'re mair couthie than coosinly, I\'m\r\nthinking."\r\n\r\n"Andy Gowran, I dismiss you from my service for your impertinence,"\r\nsaid Lady Eustace.\r\n\r\n"It\'s ae ane to Andy Gowran for that, my leddie. There\'s timber and a\r\nwarld o\' things aboot the place as wants proteection on behalf o\' the\r\nheir. If your leddieship is minded to be quit o\' my sarvices, I\'ll\r\nfind a maister in Mr. Camperdoon, as\'ll nae alloo me to be thrown out\r\no\' employ. Coosins!"\r\n\r\n"Walk off from this!" said Frank Greystock, coming forward and\r\nputting his hand upon the man\'s breast. Mr. Gowran repeated the\r\nobjectionable word yet once again, and then retired.\r\n\r\nFrank Greystock immediately felt how very bad for him was his\r\nposition. For the lady, if only she could succeed in her object, the\r\nannoyance of the interruption would not matter much after its first\r\nabsurdity had been endured. When she had become the wife of Frank\r\nGreystock there would be nothing remarkable in the fact that she had\r\nbeen found sitting with him in a cavern by the sea-shore. But for\r\nFrank the difficulty of extricating himself from his dilemma was\r\ngreat, not in regard to Mr. Gowran, but in reference to his cousin\r\nLizzie. He might, it was true, tell her that he was engaged to Lucy\r\nMorris;--but then why had he not told her so before? He had not told\r\nher so;--nor did he tell her on this occasion. When he attempted to\r\nlead her away up the cliff, she insisted on being left where she was.\r\n"I can find my way alone," she said, endeavouring to smile through\r\nher tears. "The man has annoyed me by his impudence,--that is all.\r\nGo,--if you are going."\r\n\r\nOf course he was going; but he could not go without a word of\r\ntenderness. "Dear, dear Lizzie," he said, embracing her.\r\n\r\n"Frank, you\'ll be true to me?"\r\n\r\n"I will be true to you."\r\n\r\n"Then go now," she said. And he went his way up the cliff, and got\r\nhis pony, and rode back to the cottage, very uneasy in his mind.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVII\r\n\r\nLucy Morris Misbehaves\r\n\r\n\r\nLucy Morris got her letter and was contented. She wanted some\r\ndemonstration of love from her lover, but very little sufficed for\r\nher comfort. With her it was almost impossible that a man should be\r\nloved and suspected at the same time. She could not have loved the\r\nman, or at any rate confessed her love, without thinking well of\r\nhim; and she could not think good and evil at the same time. She had\r\nlonged for some word from him since she last saw him; and now she had\r\ngot a word. She had known that he was close to his fair cousin,--the\r\ncousin whom she despised, and whom, with womanly instinct, she had\r\nalmost regarded as a rival. But to her the man had spoken out; and\r\nthough he was far away from her, living close to the fair cousin, she\r\nwould not allow a thought of trouble on that score to annoy her. He\r\nwas her own, and let Lizzie Eustace do her worst, he would remain her\r\nown. But she had longed to be told that he was thinking of her, and\r\nat last the letter had come. She answered it that same night with the\r\nsweetest, prettiest little letter, very short, full of love and full\r\nof confidence. Lady Fawn, she said, was the dearest of women;--but\r\nwhat was Lady Fawn to her, or all the Fawns, compared with her lover?\r\nIf he could come to Richmond without disturbance to himself, let\r\nhim come; but if he felt that, in the present unhappy condition of\r\naffairs between him and Lord Fawn, it was better that he should stay\r\naway, she had not a word to say in the way of urging him. To see him\r\nwould be a great delight. But had she not the greater delight of\r\nknowing that he loved her? That was quite enough to make her happy.\r\nThen there was a little prayer that God might bless him, and an\r\nassurance that she was in all things his own, own Lucy. When she was\r\nwriting her letter she was in all respects a happy girl.\r\n\r\nBut on the very next day there came a cloud upon her happiness,--not\r\nin the least, however, affecting her full confidence in her lover. It\r\nwas a Saturday, and Lord Fawn came down to Richmond. Lord Fawn had\r\nseen Mr. Greystock in London on that day, and the interview had been\r\nby no means pleasant to him. The Under-Secretary of State for India\r\nwas as dark as a November day when he reached his mother\'s house, and\r\nthere fell upon every one the unintermittent cold drizzling shower of\r\nhis displeasure from the moment in which he entered the house. There\r\nwas never much reticence among the ladies at Richmond in Lucy\'s\r\npresence, and since the completion of Lizzie\'s unfortunate visit to\r\nFawn Court, they had not hesitated to express open opinions adverse\r\nto the prospects of the proposed bride. Lucy herself could say but\r\nlittle in defence of her old friend, who had lost all claim upon\r\nthat friendship since the offer of the bribe had been made,--so that\r\nit was understood among them all that Lizzie was to be regarded as\r\na black sheep;--but hitherto Lord Fawn himself had concealed his\r\nfeelings before Lucy. Now unfortunately he spoke out, and in speaking\r\nwas especially bitter against Frank. "Mr. Greystock has been most\r\ninsolent," he said as they were all sitting together in the library\r\nafter dinner. Lady Fawn made a sign to him and shook her head. Lucy\r\nfelt the hot blood fly into both her cheeks, but at the moment she\r\ndid not speak. Lydia Fawn put out her hand beneath the table and took\r\nhold of Lucy\'s. "We must all remember that he is her cousin," said\r\nAugusta.\r\n\r\n"His relationship to Lady Eustace cannot justify ungentlemanlike\r\nimpertinence to me," said Lord Fawn. "He has dared to use words to me\r\nwhich would make it necessary that I should call him out, only--"\r\n\r\n"Frederic, you shall do nothing of the kind!" said Lady Fawn, jumping\r\nup from her chair.\r\n\r\n"Oh, Frederic, pray, pray don\'t!" said Augusta, springing on to her\r\nbrother\'s shoulder.\r\n\r\n"I am sure Frederic does not mean that," said Amelia.\r\n\r\n"Only that nobody does call any body out now," added the pacific\r\nlord. "But nothing on earth shall ever induce me to speak again to\r\na man who is so little like a gentleman." Lydia now held Lucy\'s\r\nhand still tighter, as though to prevent her rising. "He has never\r\nforgiven me," continued Lord Fawn, "because he was so ridiculously\r\nwrong about the Sawab."\r\n\r\n"I am sure that had nothing to do with it," said Lucy.\r\n\r\n"Miss Morris, I shall venture to hold my own opinion," said Lord\r\nFawn.\r\n\r\n"And I shall hold mine," said Lucy bravely. "The Sawab of Mygawb had\r\nnothing to do with what Mr. Greystock may have said or done about his\r\ncousin. I am quite sure of it."\r\n\r\n"Lucy, you are forgetting yourself," said Lady Fawn.\r\n\r\n"Lucy, dear, you shouldn\'t contradict my brother," said Augusta.\r\n\r\n"Take my advice, Lucy, and let it pass by," said Amelia.\r\n\r\n"How can I hear such things said and not notice them?" demanded Lucy.\r\n"Why does Lord Fawn say them when I am by?"\r\n\r\nLord Fawn had now condescended to be full of wrath against his\r\nmother\'s governess. "I suppose I may express my own opinion, Miss\r\nMorris, in my mother\'s house."\r\n\r\n"And I shall express mine," said Lucy. "Mr. Greystock is a gentleman.\r\nIf you say that he is not a gentleman, it is not true." Upon hearing\r\nthese terrible words spoken, Lord Fawn rose from his seat and slowly\r\nleft the room. Augusta followed him with both her arms stretched\r\nout. Lady Fawn covered her face with her hands, and even Amelia was\r\ndismayed.\r\n\r\n"Oh, Lucy! why could you not hold your tongue?" said Lydia.\r\n\r\n"I won\'t hold my tongue!" said Lucy, bursting out into tears. "He is\r\na gentleman."\r\n\r\nThen there was great commotion at Fawn Court. After a few moments\r\nLady Fawn followed her son without having said a word to Lucy, and\r\nAmelia went with her. Poor Lucy was left with the younger girls, and\r\nwas no doubt very unhappy. But she was still indignant, and would\r\nyield nothing. When Georgina, the fourth daughter, pointed out to her\r\nthat, in accordance with all rules of good breeding, she should have\r\nabstained from asserting that her brother had spoken an untruth, she\r\nblazed up again. "It was untrue," she said.\r\n\r\n"But, Lucy, people never accuse each other of untruth. No lady should\r\nuse such a word to a gentleman."\r\n\r\n"He should not have said so. He knows that Mr. Greystock is more to\r\nme than all the world."\r\n\r\n"If I had a lover," said Nina, "and anybody were to say a word\r\nagainst him, I know I\'d fly at them. I don\'t know why Frederic is to\r\nhave it all his own way."\r\n\r\n"Nina, you\'re a fool," said Diana.\r\n\r\n"I do think it was very hard for Lucy to bear," said Lydia.\r\n\r\n"And I won\'t bear it!" exclaimed Lucy. "To think that Mr. Greystock\r\nshould be so mean as to bear malice about a thing like that wild\r\nIndian because he takes his own cousin\'s part! Of course I\'d better\r\ngo away. You all think that Mr. Greystock is an enemy now; but he\r\nnever can be an enemy to me."\r\n\r\n"We think that Lady Eustace is an enemy," said Cecilia, "and a very\r\nnasty enemy, too."\r\n\r\n"I did not say a word about Lady Eustace," said Lucy. "But Mr.\r\nGreystock is a gentleman."\r\n\r\nAbout an hour after this Lady Fawn sent for Lucy, and the two were\r\ncloseted together for a long time. Lord Fawn was very angry, and had\r\nhitherto altogether declined to overlook the insult offered. "I am\r\nbound to tell you," declared Lady Fawn, with much emphasis, "that\r\nnothing can justify you in having accused Lord Fawn of telling an\r\nuntruth. Of course, I was sorry that Mr. Greystock\'s name should have\r\nbeen mentioned in your presence; but as it was mentioned, you should\r\nhave borne what was said with patience."\r\n\r\n"I couldn\'t be patient, Lady Fawn."\r\n\r\n"That is what wicked people say when they commit murder, and then\r\nthey are hung for it."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll go away, Lady Fawn--"\r\n\r\n"That is ungrateful, my dear. You know that I don\'t wish you to go\r\naway. But if you behave badly, of course I must tell you of it."\r\n\r\n"I\'d sooner go away. Everybody here thinks ill of Mr. Greystock. But\r\nI don\'t think ill of Mr. Greystock, and I never shall. Why did Lord\r\nFawn say such very hard things about him?"\r\n\r\nIt was suggested to her that she should be down-stairs early the next\r\nmorning, and apologise to Lord Fawn for her rudeness; but she would\r\nnot, on that night, undertake to do any such thing. Let Lady Fawn say\r\nwhat she might, Lucy thought that the injury had been done to her,\r\nand not to his lordship. And so they parted hardly friends. Lady\r\nFawn gave her no kiss as she went, and Lucy, with obstinate pride,\r\naltogether refused to own her fault. She would only say that she had\r\nbetter go, and when Lady Fawn over and over again pointed out to her\r\nthat the last thing that such a one as Lord Fawn could bear was to be\r\naccused of an untruth, she would continue to say that in that case he\r\nshould be careful to say nothing that was untrue. All this was very\r\ndreadful, and created great confusion and unhappiness at Fawn Court.\r\nLydia came into her room that night, and the two girls talked the\r\nmatter over for hours. In the morning Lucy was up early, and found\r\nLord Fawn walking in the grounds. She had been told that he would\r\nprobably be found walking in the grounds, if she were willing to\r\ntender to him any apology.\r\n\r\nHer mind had been very full of the subject,--not only in reference to\r\nher lover, but as it regarded her own conduct. One of the elder Fawn\r\ngirls had assured her that under no circumstances could a lady be\r\njustified in telling a gentleman that he had spoken an untruth, and\r\nshe was not quite sure but that the law so laid down was right. And\r\nthen she could not but remember that the gentleman in question was\r\nLord Fawn, and that she was Lady Fawn\'s governess. But Mr. Greystock\r\nwas her affianced lover, and her first duty was to him. And then,\r\ngranting that she herself had been wrong in accusing Lord Fawn of\r\nuntruth, she could not refrain from asking herself whether he had not\r\nbeen much more wrong in saying in her hearing that Mr. Greystock was\r\nnot a gentleman? And his offence had preceded her offence, and had\r\ncaused it! She hardly knew whether she did or did not owe an apology\r\nto Lord Fawn, but she was quite sure that Lord Fawn owed an apology\r\nto her.\r\n\r\nShe walked straight up to Lord Fawn, and met him beneath the trees.\r\nHe was still black and solemn, and was evidently brooding over his\r\ngrievance; but he bowed to her, and stood still as she approached\r\nhim. "My lord," said she, "I am very sorry for what happened last\r\nnight."\r\n\r\n"And so was I,--very sorry, Miss Morris."\r\n\r\n"I think you know that I am engaged to marry Mr. Greystock?"\r\n\r\n"I cannot allow that that has anything to do with it."\r\n\r\n"When you think that he must be dearer to me than all the world, you\r\nwill acknowledge that I couldn\'t hear hard things said of him without\r\nspeaking." His face became blacker than ever, but he made no reply.\r\nHe wanted an abject begging of unconditional pardon from the little\r\ngirl who loved his enemy. If that were done, he would vouchsafe his\r\nforgiveness; but he was too small by nature to grant it on other\r\nterms. "Of course," continued Lucy, "I am bound to treat you with\r\nspecial respect in Lady Fawn\'s house." She looked almost beseechingly\r\ninto his face as she paused for a moment.\r\n\r\n"But you treated me with especial disrespect," said Lord Fawn.\r\n\r\n"And how did you treat me, Lord Fawn?"\r\n\r\n"Miss Morris, I must be allowed, in discussing matters with my\r\nmother, to express my own opinions in such language as I may think\r\nfit to use. Mr. Greystock\'s conduct to me was--was--was altogether\r\nmost ungentlemanlike."\r\n\r\n"Mr. Greystock is a gentleman."\r\n\r\n"His conduct was most offensive, and most--most ungentlemanlike. Mr.\r\nGreystock disgraced himself."\r\n\r\n"It isn\'t true!" said Lucy. Lord Fawn gave one start, and then walked\r\noff to the house as quick as his legs could carry him.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVIII\r\n\r\nMr. Dove in His Chambers\r\n\r\n\r\nThe scene between Lord Fawn and Greystock had taken place in Mr.\r\nCamperdown\'s chambers, and John Eustace had also been present. The\r\nlawyer had suffered considerable annoyance, before the arrival of the\r\ntwo first-named gentlemen, from reiterated assertions made by Eustace\r\nthat he would take no further trouble whatsoever about the jewels.\r\nMr. Camperdown had in vain pointed out to him that a plain duty lay\r\nupon him as executor and guardian to protect the property on behalf\r\nof his nephew; but Eustace had asserted that, though he himself was\r\ncomparatively a poor man, he would sooner replace the necklace out of\r\nhis own property, than be subject to the nuisance of such a continued\r\nquarrel. "My dear John; ten thousand pounds!" Mr. Camperdown had\r\nsaid. "It is a fortune for a younger son."\r\n\r\n"The boy is only two years old, and will have time enough to\r\nmake fortunes for his own younger sons, if he does not squander\r\neverything. If he does, the ten thousand pounds will make no\r\ndifference."\r\n\r\n"But the justice of the thing, John!"\r\n\r\n"Justice may be purchased too dearly."\r\n\r\n"Such a harpy as she is, too!" pleaded the lawyer. Then Lord Fawn had\r\ncome in, and Greystock had followed immediately afterwards.\r\n\r\n"I may as well say at once," said Greystock, "that Lady Eustace is\r\ndetermined to maintain her right to the property; and that she will\r\nnot give up the diamonds till some adequate court of law shall have\r\ndecided that she is mistaken in her views. Stop one moment, Mr.\r\nCamperdown. I feel myself bound to go further than that, and express\r\nmy own opinion that she is right."\r\n\r\n"I can hardly understand such an opinion as coming from you," said\r\nMr. Camperdown.\r\n\r\n"You have changed your mind, at any rate," said John Eustace.\r\n\r\n"Not so, Eustace. Mr. Camperdown, you\'ll be good enough to understand\r\nthat my opinion expressed here is that of a friend, and not that of a\r\nlawyer. And you must understand, Eustace," continued Greystock, "that\r\nI am speaking now of my cousin\'s right to the property. Though the\r\nvalue be great, I have advised her to give up the custody of it for a\r\nwhile, till the matter shall be clearly decided. That has still been\r\nmy advice to her, and I have in no respect changed my mind. But she\r\nfeels that she is being cruelly used, and with a woman\'s spirit will\r\nnot, in such circumstances, yield anything. Mr. Camperdown actually\r\nstopped her carriage in the street."\r\n\r\n"She would not answer a line that anybody wrote to her," said the\r\nlawyer.\r\n\r\n"And I may say plainly,--for all here know the circumstances,--that\r\nLady Eustace feels the strongest possible indignation at the manner\r\nin which she is being treated by Lord Fawn."\r\n\r\n"I have only asked her to give up the diamonds till the question\r\nshould be settled," said Lord Fawn.\r\n\r\n"And you backed your request, my lord, by a threat! My cousin is\r\nnaturally most indignant; and, my lord, you must allow me to tell you\r\nthat I fully share the feeling."\r\n\r\n"There is no use in making a quarrel about it," said Eustace.\r\n\r\n"The quarrel is already made," replied Greystock. "I am here to tell\r\nLord Fawn in your presence, and in the presence of Mr. Camperdown,\r\nthat he is behaving to a lady with ill-usage, which he would not\r\ndare to exercise did he not know that her position saves him from\r\nlegal punishment, as do the present usages of society from other\r\nconsequences."\r\n\r\n"I have behaved to her with every possible consideration," said Lord\r\nFawn.\r\n\r\n"That is a simple assertion," said the other. "I have made one\r\nassertion, and you have made another. The world will have to judge\r\nbetween us. What right have you to take upon yourself to decide\r\nwhether this thing or that belongs to Lady Eustace or to any one\r\nelse?"\r\n\r\n"When the thing was talked about I was obliged to have an opinion,"\r\nsaid Lord Fawn, who was still thinking of words in which to reply to\r\nthe insult offered him by Greystock without injury to his dignity as\r\nan Under-Secretary of State.\r\n\r\n"Your conduct, sir, has been altogether inexcusable." Then Frank\r\nturned to the attorney. "I have been given to understand that you are\r\ndesirous of knowing where this diamond necklace is at present. It is\r\nat Lady Eustace\'s house in Scotland;--at Portray Castle." Then he\r\nshook hands with John Eustace, bowed to Mr. Camperdown, and succeeded\r\nin leaving the room before Lord Fawn had so far collected his senses\r\nas to be able to frame his anger into definite words.\r\n\r\n"I will never willingly speak to that man again," said Lord Fawn.\r\nBut as it was not probable that Greystock would greatly desire any\r\nfurther conversation with Lord Fawn, this threat did not carry with\r\nit any powerful feeling of severity.\r\n\r\nMr. Camperdown groaned over the matter with thorough vexation of\r\nspirit. It seemed to him as though the harpy, as he called her, would\r\nreally make good her case against him,--at any rate, would make it\r\nseem to be good for so long a time that all the triumph of success\r\nwould be hers. He knew that she was already in debt, and gave her\r\ncredit for a propensity to fast living which almost did her an\r\ninjustice. Of course, the jewels would be sold for half their value,\r\nand the harpy would triumph. Of what use to him or to the estate\r\nwould be a decision of the courts in his favour when the diamonds\r\nshould have been broken up and scattered to the winds of heaven? Ten\r\nthousand pounds! It was, to Mr. Camperdown\'s mind, a thing quite\r\nterrible that, in a country which boasts of its laws and of the\r\nexecution of its laws, such an impostor as was this widow should be\r\nable to lay her dirty, grasping fingers on so great an amount of\r\nproperty, and that there should be no means of punishing her. That\r\nLizzie Eustace had stolen the diamonds, as a pickpocket steals a\r\nwatch, was a fact as to which Mr. Camperdown had in his mind no\r\nshadow of a doubt. And, as the reader knows, he was right. She had\r\nstolen them. Mr. Camperdown knew that she had stolen them, and was\r\na wretched man. From the first moment of the late Sir Florian\'s\r\ninfatuation about this woman, she had worked woe for Mr. Camperdown.\r\nMr. Camperdown had striven hard,--to the great and almost permanent\r\noffence of Sir Florian,--to save Portray from its present condition\r\nof degradation; but he had striven in vain. Portray belonged to the\r\nharpy for her life; and moreover, he himself had been forced to be\r\ninstrumental in paying over to the harpy a large sum of Eustace\r\nmoney almost immediately on her becoming a widow. Then had come the\r\naffair of the diamonds;--an affair of ten thousand pounds!--as Mr.\r\nCamperdown would exclaim to himself, throwing his eyes up to the\r\nceiling. And now it seemed that she was to get the better of him even\r\nin that, although there could not be a shadow of doubt as to her\r\nfalsehood and fraudulent dishonesty! His luck in the matter was so\r\nbad! John Eustace had no backbone, no spirit, no proper feeling as to\r\nhis own family. Lord Fawn was as weak as water, and almost disgraced\r\nthe cause by the accident of his adherence to it. Greystock, who\r\nwould have been a tower of strength, had turned against him, and was\r\nnow prepared to maintain that the harpy was right. Mr. Camperdown\r\nknew that the harpy was wrong,--that she was a harpy, and he would\r\nnot abandon the cause; but the difficulties in his way were great,\r\nand the annoyance to which he was subjected was excessive. His\r\nwife and daughters were still at Dawlish, and he was up in town in\r\nSeptember, simply because the harpy had the present possession of\r\nthese diamonds.\r\n\r\nMr. Camperdown was a man turned sixty, handsome, grey-haired,\r\nhealthy, somewhat florid, and carrying in his face and person\r\nexternal signs of prosperity and that kind of self-assertion which\r\nprosperity always produces. But they who knew him best were aware\r\nthat he did not bear trouble well. In any trouble, such as was\r\nthis about the necklace, there would come over his face a look of\r\nweakness which betrayed the want of real inner strength. How many\r\nfaces one sees which, in ordinary circumstances, are comfortable,\r\nself-asserting, sufficient, and even bold; the lines of which,\r\nunder difficulties, collapse and become mean, spiritless, and\r\ninsignificant. There are faces which, in their usual form, seem\r\nto bluster with prosperity, but which the loss of a dozen points\r\nat whist will reduce to that currish aspect which reminds one of\r\na dog-whip. Mr. Camperdown\'s countenance, when Lord Fawn and Mr.\r\nEustace left him, had fallen away into this meanness of appearance.\r\nHe no longer carried himself as a man owning a dog-whip, but rather\r\nas the hound that feared it.\r\n\r\nA better attorney, for the purposes to which his life was devoted,\r\ndid not exist in London than Mr. Camperdown. To say that he was\r\nhonest, is nothing. To describe him simply as zealous, would be to\r\nfall very short of his merits. The interests of his clients were his\r\nown interests, and the legal rights of the properties of which he had\r\nthe legal charge, were as dear to him as his own blood. But it could\r\nnot be said of him that he was a learned lawyer. Perhaps in that\r\nbranch of a solicitor\'s profession in which he had been called upon\r\nto work, experience goes further than learning. It may be doubted,\r\nindeed, whether it is not so in every branch of every profession. But\r\nit might, perhaps, have been better for Mr. Camperdown had he devoted\r\nmore hours of his youth to reading books on conveyancing. He was now\r\ntoo old for such studies, and could trust only to the reading of\r\nother people. The reading, however, of other people was always at his\r\ncommand, and his clients were rich men who did not mind paying for\r\nan opinion. To have an opinion from Mr. Dove, or some other learned\r\ngentleman, was the every-day practice of his life; and when he\r\nobtained, as he often did, little coigns of legal vantage and subtle\r\ndefinitions as to property which were comfortable to him, he would\r\nrejoice to think that he could always have a Dove at his hand to\r\ntell him exactly how far he was justified in going in defence of his\r\nclients\' interests. But now there had come to him no comfort from his\r\ncorner of legal knowledge. Mr. Dove had taken extraordinary pains in\r\nthe matter, and had simply succeeded in throwing over his employer.\r\n"A necklace can\'t be an heirloom!" said Mr. Camperdown to himself,\r\ntelling off on his fingers half-a-dozen instances in which he had\r\neither known or had heard that the head of a family had so arranged\r\nthe future possession of the family jewels. Then he again read Mr.\r\nDove\'s opinion, and actually took a law-book off his shelves with the\r\nview of testing the correctness of the barrister in reference to some\r\nspecial assertion. A pot or a pan might be an heirloom, but not a\r\nnecklace! Mr. Camperdown could hardly bring himself to believe that\r\nthis was law. And then as to paraphernalia! Up to this moment, though\r\nhe had been called upon to arrange great dealings in reference to\r\nwidows, he had never as yet heard of a claim made by a widow for\r\nparaphernalia. But then the widows with whom he had been called upon\r\nto deal, had been ladies quite content to accept the good things\r\nsettled upon them by the liberal prudence of their friends and\r\nhusbands,--not greedy, blood-sucking harpies such as this Lady\r\nEustace. It was quite terrible to Mr. Camperdown that one of his\r\nclients should have fallen into such a pit. Mors omnibus est\r\ncommunis. But to have left such a widow behind one!\r\n\r\n"John," he said, opening his door. John was his son and partner, and\r\nJohn came to him, having been summoned by a clerk from another room.\r\n"Just shut the door. I\'ve had such a scene here;--Lord Fawn and Mr.\r\nGreystock almost coming to blows about that horrid woman."\r\n\r\n"The Upper House would have got the worst of it, as it usually does,"\r\nsaid the younger attorney.\r\n\r\n"And there is John Eustace cares no more what becomes of the property\r\nthan if he had nothing to do with it;--absolutely talks of replacing\r\nthe diamonds out of his own pocket; a man whose personal interest in\r\nthe estate is by no means equal to her own."\r\n\r\n"He wouldn\'t do it, you know," said Camperdown Junior, who did not\r\nknow the family.\r\n\r\n"It\'s just what he would do," said the father, who did. "There\'s\r\nnothing they wouldn\'t give away when once the idea takes them. Think\r\nof that woman having the whole Portray estate, perhaps for the next\r\nsixty years,--nearly the fee-simple of the property,--just because\r\nshe made eyes to Sir Florian!"\r\n\r\n"That\'s done and gone, father."\r\n\r\n"And here\'s Dove tells us that a necklace can\'t be an heirloom,\r\nunless it belongs to the Crown."\r\n\r\n"Whatever he says, you\'d better take his word for it."\r\n\r\n"I\'m not so sure of that. It can\'t be. I\'ll tell you what I\'ll do.\r\nI\'ll go over and see him. We can file a bill in Chancery, I don\'t\r\ndoubt, and prove that the property belongs to the family and must go\r\nby the will. But she\'ll sell them before we can get the custody of\r\nthem."\r\n\r\n"Perhaps she has done that already."\r\n\r\n"Greystock says they are at Portray, and I believe they are. She was\r\nwearing them in London only in July,--a day or two before I saw her\r\nas she was leaving town. If anybody like a jeweller had been down at\r\nthe castle, I should have heard of it. She hasn\'t sold \'em yet, but\r\nshe will."\r\n\r\n"She could do that just the same if they were an heirloom."\r\n\r\n"No, John. I think not. We could have acted much more quickly, and\r\nhave frightened her."\r\n\r\n"If I were you, father, I\'d drop the matter altogether, and let\r\nJohn Eustace replace them if he pleases. We all know that he would\r\nnever be called on to do anything of the kind. It isn\'t our sort of\r\nbusiness."\r\n\r\n"Not ten thousand pounds!" said Camperdown Senior, to whom the\r\nmagnitude of the larceny almost ennobled the otherwise mean duty\r\nof catching the thief. Then Mr. Camperdown rose, and slowly walked\r\nacross the New Square, Lincoln\'s Inn, under the low archway, by the\r\nentrance to the old court in which Lord Eldon used to sit, to the Old\r\nSquare, in which the Turtle Dove had built his legal nest on a first\r\nfloor, close to the old gateway.\r\n\r\nMr. Dove was a gentleman who spent a very great portion of his life\r\nin this somewhat gloomy abode of learning. It was not now term time,\r\nand most of his brethren were absent from London, recruiting their\r\nstrength among the Alps, or drinking in vigours for fresh campaigns\r\nwith the salt sea breezes of Kent and Sussex, or perhaps shooting\r\ndeer in Scotland, or catching fish in Connemara. But Mr. Dove was a\r\nman of iron, who wanted no such recreation. To be absent from his\r\nlaw-books and the black, littered, ink-stained old table on which he\r\nwas wont to write his opinions, was, to him, to be wretched. The only\r\nexercise necessary to him was that of putting on his wig and going\r\ninto one of the courts that were close to his chambers;--but even\r\nthat was almost distasteful to him. He preferred sitting in his old\r\narm-chair, turning over his old books in search of old cases, and\r\nproducing opinions which he would be prepared to back against all the\r\nworld of Lincoln\'s Inn. He and Mr. Camperdown had known each other\r\nintimately for many years, and though the rank of the two men in\r\ntheir profession differed much, they were able to discuss questions\r\nof law without any appreciation of that difference among themselves.\r\nThe one man knew much, and the other little; the one was not only\r\nlearned, but possessed also of great gifts, while the other was\r\nsimply an ordinary clear-headed man of business; but they had\r\nsympathies in common which made them friends; they were both honest\r\nand unwilling to sell their services to dishonest customers; and\r\nthey equally entertained a deep-rooted contempt for that portion of\r\nmankind who thought that property could be managed and protected\r\nwithout the intervention of lawyers. The outside world to them was a\r\nworld of pretty, laughing, ignorant children; and lawyers were the\r\nparents, guardians, pastors, and masters by whom the children should\r\nbe protected from the evils incident to their childishness.\r\n\r\n"Yes, sir; he\'s here," said the Turtle Dove\'s clerk. "He is talking\r\nof going away, but he won\'t go. He\'s told me I can have a week, but I\r\ndon\'t know that I like to leave him. Mrs. Dove and the children are\r\ndown at Ramsgate, and he\'s here all night. He hadn\'t been out for so\r\nlong that when he wanted to go as far as the Temple yesterday, we\r\ncouldn\'t find his hat." Then the clerk opened the door, and ushered\r\nMr. Camperdown into the room. Mr. Dove was the younger man by five or\r\nsix years, and his hair was still black. Mr. Camperdown\'s was nearer\r\nwhite than grey; but, nevertheless, Mr. Camperdown looked as though\r\nhe were the younger man. Mr. Dove was a long, thin man, with a\r\nstoop in his shoulders, with deep-set, hollow eyes, and lanthorn\r\ncheeks, and sallow complexion, with long, thin hands, who seemed to\r\nacknowledge by every movement of his body and every tone of his voice\r\nthat old age was creeping on him,--whereas the attorney\'s step was\r\nstill elastic, and his speech brisk. Mr. Camperdown wore a blue\r\nfrock-coat, and a coloured cravat, and a light waistcoat. With Mr.\r\nDove every visible article of his raiment was black, except his\r\nshirt, and he had that peculiar blackness which a man achieves when\r\nhe wears a dress-coat over a high black waistcoat in the morning.\r\n\r\n"You didn\'t make much, I fear, of what I sent you about heirlooms,"\r\nsaid Mr. Dove, divining the purport of Mr. Camperdown\'s visit.\r\n\r\n"A great deal more than I wanted, I can assure you, Mr. Dove."\r\n\r\n"There is a common error about heirlooms."\r\n\r\n"Very common, indeed, I should say. God bless my soul! when one knows\r\nhow often the word occurs in family deeds, it does startle one to be\r\ntold that there isn\'t any such thing."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t think I said quite so much as that. Indeed, I was careful to\r\npoint out that the law does acknowledge heirlooms."\r\n\r\n"But not diamonds," said the attorney.\r\n\r\n"I doubt whether I went quite so far as that."\r\n\r\n"Only the Crown diamonds."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t think I ever debarred all other diamonds. A diamond in a\r\nstar of honour might form a part of an heirloom; but I do not think\r\nthat a diamond itself could be an heirloom."\r\n\r\n"If in a star of honour, why not in a necklace?" argued Mr.\r\nCamperdown almost triumphantly.\r\n\r\n"Because a star of honour, unless tampered with by fraud, would\r\nnaturally be maintained in its original form. The setting of a\r\nnecklace will probably be altered from generation to generation. The\r\none, like a picture or a precious piece of furniture,--"\r\n\r\n"Or a pot or a pan," said Mr. Camperdown, with sarcasm.\r\n\r\n"Pots and pans may be precious, too," replied Mr. Dove. "Such things\r\ncan be traced, and can be held as heirlooms without imposing too\r\ngreat difficulties on their guardians. The Law is generally very wise\r\nand prudent, Mr. Camperdown;--much more so often than are they who\r\nattempt to improve it."\r\n\r\n"I quite agree with you there, Mr. Dove."\r\n\r\n"Would the Law do a service, do you think, if it lent its authority\r\nto the special preservation in special hands of trinkets only to be\r\nused for vanity and ornament? Is that a kind of property over which\r\nan owner should have a power of disposition more lasting, more\r\nautocratic, than is given him even in regard to land? The land, at\r\nany rate, can be traced. It is a thing fixed and known. A string of\r\npearls is not only alterable, but constantly altered, and cannot\r\neasily be traced."\r\n\r\n"Property of such enormous value should, at any rate, be protected,"\r\nsaid Mr. Camperdown indignantly.\r\n\r\n"All property is protected, Mr. Camperdown;--although, as we know\r\ntoo well, such protection can never be perfect. But the system of\r\nheirlooms, if there can be said to be such a system, was not devised\r\nfor what you and I mean when we talk of protection of property."\r\n\r\n"I should have said that that was just what it was devised for."\r\n\r\n"I think not. It was devised with the more picturesque idea of\r\nmaintaining chivalric associations. Heirlooms have become so, not\r\nthat the future owners of them may be assured of so much wealth,\r\nwhatever the value of the thing so settled may be,--but that the son\r\nor grandson or descendant may enjoy the satisfaction which is derived\r\nfrom saying, my father or my grandfather or my ancestor sat in that\r\nchair, or looked as he now looks in that picture, or was graced\r\nby wearing on his breast that very ornament which you now see\r\nlying beneath the glass. Crown jewels are heirlooms in the same\r\nway, as representing not the possession of the sovereign, but the\r\ntime-honoured dignity of the Crown. The Law, which, in general,\r\nconcerns itself with our property or lives and our liberties, has in\r\nthis matter bowed gracefully to the spirit of chivalry and has lent\r\nits aid to romance;--but it certainly did not do so to enable the\r\ndiscordant heirs of a rich man to settle a simple dirty question of\r\nmoney, which, with ordinary prudence, the rich man should himself\r\nhave settled before he died."\r\n\r\nThe Turtle Dove had spoken with emphasis and had spoken well, and Mr.\r\nCamperdown had not ventured to interrupt him while he was speaking.\r\nHe was sitting far back on his chair, but with his neck bent and with\r\nhis head forward, rubbing his long thin hands slowly over each other,\r\nand with his deep bright eyes firmly fixed on his companion\'s face.\r\nMr. Camperdown had not unfrequently heard him speak in the same\r\nfashion before, and was accustomed to his manner of unravelling the\r\nmysteries and searching into the causes of Law with a spirit which\r\nalmost lent poetry to the subject. When Mr. Dove would do so, Mr.\r\nCamperdown would not quite understand the words spoken, but he would\r\nlisten to them with an undoubting reverence. And he did understand\r\nthem in part, and was conscious of an infusion of a certain amount of\r\npoetic spirit into his own bosom. He would think of these speeches\r\nafterwards, and would entertain high but somewhat cloudy ideas of the\r\nbeauty and the majesty of Law. Mr. Dove\'s speeches did Mr. Camperdown\r\ngood, and helped to preserve him from that worst of all diseases,--a\r\nlow idea of humanity.\r\n\r\n"You think, then, we had better not claim them as heirlooms?" he\r\nasked.\r\n\r\n"I think you had better not."\r\n\r\n"And you think that she could claim them--as paraphernalia?"\r\n\r\n"That question has hardly been put to me,--though I allowed myself to\r\nwander into it. But for my intimacy with you, I should hardly have\r\nventured to stray so far."\r\n\r\n"I need hardly say how much obliged we are. But we will submit one or\r\ntwo other cases to you."\r\n\r\n"I am inclined to think the court would not allow them to her as\r\nparaphernalia, seeing that their value is excessive as compared with\r\nher income and degree; but if it did, it would do so in a fashion\r\nthat would guard them from alienation."\r\n\r\n"She would sell them--under the rose."\r\n\r\n"Then she would be guilty of stealing them,--which she would hardly\r\nattempt, even if not restrained by honesty, knowing, as she would\r\nknow, that the greatness of the value would almost assuredly lead to\r\ndetection. The same feeling would prevent buyers from purchasing."\r\n\r\n"She says, you know, that they were given to her, absolutely."\r\n\r\n"I should like to know the circumstances."\r\n\r\n"Yes;--of course."\r\n\r\n"But I should be disposed to think that in equity no allegation by\r\nthe receiver of such a gift, unsubstantiated either by evidence or\r\nby deed, would be allowed to stand. The gentleman left behind him a\r\nwill, and regular settlements. I should think that the possession of\r\nthese diamonds,--not, I presume, touched on in the settlements--"\r\n\r\n"Oh dear no;--not a word about them."\r\n\r\n"I should think, then, that, subject to any claim for paraphernalia,\r\nthe possession of the diamonds would be ruled by the will." Mr.\r\nCamperdown was rushing into the further difficulty of the chattels\r\nin Scotland and those in England, when the Turtle Dove stopped him,\r\ndeclaring that he could not venture to discuss matters as to which he\r\nknew none of the facts.\r\n\r\n"Of course not;--of course not," said Mr. Camperdown. "We\'ll have\r\ncases prepared. I\'d apologise for coming at all, only that I get so\r\nmuch from a few words."\r\n\r\n"I\'m always delighted to see you, Mr. Camperdown," said the Turtle\r\nDove, bowing.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIX\r\n\r\n"I Had Better Go Away"\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen Lord Fawn gave a sudden jump and stalked away towards the house\r\non that Sunday morning before breakfast, Lucy Morris was a very\r\nunhappy girl. She had a second time accused Lord Fawn of speaking an\r\nuntruth. She did not quite understand the usages of the world in the\r\nmatter; but she did know that the one offence which a gentleman is\r\nsupposed never to commit is that of speaking an untruth. The offence\r\nmay be one committed oftener than any other by gentlemen,--as also\r\nby all other people; but, nevertheless, it is regarded by the usages\r\nof society as being the one thing which a gentleman never does. Of\r\nall this Lucy understood something. The word "lie" she knew to be\r\nutterly abominable. That Lizzie Eustace was a little liar had been\r\nacknowledged between herself and the Fawn girls very often,--but to\r\nhave told Lady Eustace that any word spoken by her was a lie, would\r\nhave been a worse crime than the lie itself. To have brought such\r\nan accusation, in that term, against Lord Fawn, would have been to\r\ndegrade herself for ever. Was there any difference between a lie\r\nand an untruth? That one must be, and that the other need not be,\r\nintentional, she did feel; but she felt also that the less offensive\r\nword had come to mean a lie,--the world having been driven so to use\r\nit because the world did not dare to talk about lies; and this word,\r\nbearing such a meaning in common parlance, she had twice applied to\r\nLord Fawn. And yet, as she was well aware, Lord Fawn had told no lie.\r\nHe had himself believed every word that he had spoken against Frank\r\nGreystock. That he had been guilty of unmanly cruelty in so speaking\r\nof her lover in her presence, Lucy still thought, but she should not\r\ntherefore have accused him of falsehood. "It was untrue all the\r\nsame," she said to herself, as she stood still on the gravel walk,\r\nwatching the rapid disappearance of Lord Fawn, and endeavouring to\r\nthink what she had better now do with herself. Of course Lord Fawn,\r\nlike a great child, would at once go and tell his mother what that\r\nwicked governess had said to him.\r\n\r\nIn the hall she met her friend Lydia. "Oh, Lucy, what is the matter\r\nwith Frederic?" she asked.\r\n\r\n"Lord Fawn is very angry indeed."\r\n\r\n"With you?"\r\n\r\n"Yes;--with me. He is so angry that I am sure he would not sit down\r\nto breakfast with me. So I won\'t come down. Will you tell your mamma?\r\nIf she likes to send to me, of course I\'ll go to her at once."\r\n\r\n"What have you done, Lucy?"\r\n\r\n"I\'ve told him again that what he said wasn\'t true."\r\n\r\n"But why?"\r\n\r\n"Because--Oh, how can I say why? Why does any person do everything\r\nthat she ought not to do? It\'s the fall of Adam, I suppose."\r\n\r\n"You shouldn\'t make a joke of it, Lucy."\r\n\r\n"You can have no conception how unhappy I am about it. Of course Lady\r\nFawn will tell me to go away. I went out on purpose to beg his pardon\r\nfor what I said last night, and I just said the very same thing\r\nagain."\r\n\r\n"But why did you say it?"\r\n\r\n"And I should say it again and again and again, if he were to go on\r\ntelling me that Mr. Greystock isn\'t a gentleman. I don\'t think he\r\nought to have done it. Of course, I have been very wrong; I know\r\nthat. But I think he has been wrong too. But I must own it, and he\r\nneedn\'t. I\'ll go up now and stay in my own room till your mamma sends\r\nfor me."\r\n\r\n"And I\'ll get Jane to bring you some breakfast."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t care a bit about breakfast," said Lucy.\r\n\r\nLord Fawn did tell his mother, and Lady Fawn was perplexed in the\r\nextreme. She was divided in her judgment and feelings between the\r\nprivilege due to Lucy as a girl possessed of an authorised lover,--a\r\nprivilege which no doubt existed, but which was not extensive,--and\r\nthe very much greater privilege which attached to Lord Fawn as a man,\r\nas a peer, as an Under-Secretary of State,--but which attached to\r\nhim especially as the head and only man belonging to the Fawn family.\r\nSuch a one, when, moved by filial duty, he condescends to come once a\r\nweek to his mother\'s house, is entitled to say whatever he pleases,\r\nand should on no account be contradicted by any one. Lucy no doubt\r\nhad a lover,--an authorised lover; but perhaps that fact could not\r\nbe taken as more than a balancing weight against the inferiority\r\nof her position as a governess. Lady Fawn was of course obliged to\r\ntake her son\'s part, and would scold Lucy. Lucy must be scolded very\r\nseriously. But it would be a thing so desirable if Lucy could be\r\ninduced to accept her scolding and have done with it, and not to make\r\nmatters worse by talking of going away! "You don\'t mean that she came\r\nout into the shrubbery, having made up her mind to be rude to you?"\r\nsaid Lady Fawn to her son.\r\n\r\n"No;--I do not think that. But her temper is so ungovernable, and she\r\nhas, if I may say so, been so spoilt among you here,--I mean by the\r\ngirls, of course,--that she does not know how to restrain herself."\r\n\r\n"She is as good as gold, you know, Frederic." He shrugged his\r\nshoulders, and declared that he had not a word more to say about\r\nit. He could, of course, remain in London till it should suit Mr.\r\nGreystock to take his bride. "You\'ll break my heart if you say that!"\r\nexclaimed the unhappy mother. "Of course, she shall leave the house\r\nif you wish it."\r\n\r\n"I wish nothing," said Lord Fawn. "But I peculiarly object to be told\r\nthat I am a--liar." Then he stalked away along the corridor and went\r\ndown to breakfast, as black as a thunder-cloud.\r\n\r\nLady Fawn and Lucy sat opposite to each other in church, but they\r\ndid not speak till the afternoon. Lady Fawn went to church in the\r\ncarriage and Lucy walked, and as Lucy retired to her room immediately\r\non her return to the house, there had not been an opportunity even\r\nfor a word. After lunch Amelia came up to her, and sat down for a\r\nlong discussion. "Now, Lucy, something must be done, you know," said\r\nAmelia.\r\n\r\n"I suppose so."\r\n\r\n"Of course, mamma must see you. She can\'t allow things to go on\r\nin this way. Mamma is very unhappy, and didn\'t eat a morsel of\r\nbreakfast." By this latter assertion Amelia simply intended to imply\r\nthat her mother had refused to be helped a second time to fried\r\nbacon, as was customary.\r\n\r\n"Of course, I shall go to her the moment she sends for me. Oh,--I am\r\nso unhappy!"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t wonder at that, Lucy. So is my brother unhappy. These things\r\nmake people unhappy. It is what the world calls--temper, you know,\r\nLucy."\r\n\r\n"Why did he tell me that Mr. Greystock isn\'t a gentleman? Mr.\r\nGreystock is a gentleman. I meant to say nothing more than that."\r\n\r\n"But you did say more, Lucy."\r\n\r\n"When he said that Mr. Greystock wasn\'t a gentleman, I told him it\r\nwasn\'t true. Why did he say it? He knows all about it. Everybody\r\nknows. Would you think it wise to come and abuse him to me, when you\r\nknow what he is to me? I can\'t bear it, and I won\'t. I\'ll go away\r\nto-morrow, if your mamma wishes it." But that going away was just\r\nwhat Lady Fawn did not wish.\r\n\r\n"I think you know, Lucy, you should express your deep sorrow at what\r\nhas passed."\r\n\r\n"To your brother?"\r\n\r\n"Yes."\r\n\r\n"Then he would abuse Mr. Greystock again, and it would all be as bad\r\nas ever. I\'ll beg Lord Fawn\'s pardon if he\'ll promise beforehand not\r\nto say a word about Mr. Greystock."\r\n\r\n"You can\'t expect him to make a bargain like that, Lucy."\r\n\r\n"I suppose not. I daresay I\'m very wicked, and I must be left wicked.\r\nI\'m too wicked to stay here. That\'s the long and the short of it."\r\n\r\n"I\'m afraid you\'re proud, Lucy."\r\n\r\n"I suppose I am. If it wasn\'t for all that I owe to everybody\r\nhere, and that I love you all so much, I should be proud of being\r\nproud;--because of Mr. Greystock. Only it kills me to make Lady Fawn\r\nunhappy."\r\n\r\nAmelia left the culprit, feeling that no good had been done, and Lady\r\nFawn did not see the delinquent till late in the afternoon. Lord Fawn\r\nhad, in the meantime, wandered out along the river all alone to brood\r\nover the condition of his affairs. It had been an evil day for him in\r\nwhich he had first seen Lady Eustace. From the first moment of his\r\nengagement to her he had been an unhappy man.
