Look at Lord Fawn and Lady Eustace."\r\n\r\n"Mr. Greystock and I are not like that," said Lucy, proudly.\r\n\r\n"Such things are very dreadful, Lucy, but they do happen."\r\n\r\n"Do you mean anything;--anything real, Lady Fawn?"\r\n\r\n"I have so strong a reliance on your good sense, that I will tell\r\nyou just what I do mean. A rumour has reached me that Mr. Greystock\r\nis--paying more attention than he ought to do to Lady Eustace."\r\n\r\n"His own cousin!"\r\n\r\n"But people marry their cousins, Lucy."\r\n\r\n"To whom he has always been just like a brother! I do think that is\r\nthe cruellest thing. Because he sacrifices his time and his money\r\nand all his holidays to go and look after her affairs, this is to be\r\nsaid of him! She hasn\'t another human being to look after her, and,\r\ntherefore, he is obliged to do it. Of course he has told me all about\r\nit. I do think, Lady Fawn,--I do think that is the greatest shame I\r\never heard!"\r\n\r\n"But if it should be true--?"\r\n\r\n"It isn\'t true."\r\n\r\n"But just for the sake of showing you, Lucy--; if it was to be true."\r\n\r\n"It won\'t be true."\r\n\r\n"Surely I may speak to you as your friend, Lucy. You needn\'t be so\r\nabrupt with me. Will you listen to me, Lucy?"\r\n\r\n"Of course I will listen;--only nothing that anybody on earth could\r\nsay about that would make me believe a word of it."\r\n\r\n"Very well! Now just let me go on. If it were to be so--"\r\n\r\n"Oh-h, Lady Fawn!"\r\n\r\n"Don\'t be foolish, Lucy. I will say what I\'ve got to say. If--if--\r\nLet me see. Where was I? I mean just this. You had better remain\r\nhere till things are a little more settled. Even if it be only a\r\nrumour,--and I\'m sure I don\'t believe it\'s anything more,--you had\r\nbetter hear about it with us,--with friends round you, than with a\r\nperfect stranger like Lady Linlithgow. If anything were to go wrong\r\nthere, you wouldn\'t know where to go for comfort. If anything were\r\nwrong with you here, you could come to me as though I were your\r\nmother.--Couldn\'t you, now?"\r\n\r\n"Indeed, indeed I could! And I will;--I always will. Lady Fawn, I\r\nlove you and the dear darling girls better than all the world--except\r\nMr. Greystock. If anything like that were to happen, I think I should\r\ncreep here and ask to die in your house. But it won\'t. And just now\r\nit will be better that I should go away."\r\n\r\nIt was found at last that Lucy must have her way, and letters were\r\nwritten both to Mrs. Greystock and to Frank, requesting that the\r\nsuggested overtures might at once be made to Lady Linlithgow. Lucy,\r\nin her letter to her lover, was more than ordinarily cheerful and\r\njocose. She had a good deal to say about Lady Linlithgow that was\r\nreally droll, and not a word to say indicative of the slightest fear\r\nin the direction of Lady Eustace. She spoke of poor Lizzie, and\r\ndeclared her conviction that that marriage never could come off now.\r\n"You mustn\'t be angry when I say that I can\'t break my heart for\r\nthem, for I never did think that they were very much in love. As for\r\nLord Fawn, of course he is my--ENEMY!" And she wrote the word in big\r\nletters. "And as for Lizzie,--she\'s your cousin, and all that. And\r\nshe\'s ever so pretty, and all that. And she\'s as rich as Croesus,\r\nand all that. But I don\'t think she\'ll break her own heart. I would\r\nbreak mine; only--only--only-- You will understand the rest. If it\r\nshould come to pass, I wonder whether \'the duchess\' would ever let a\r\npoor creature see a friend of hers in Bruton Street?" Frank had once\r\ncalled Lady Linlithgow the duchess, after a certain popular picture\r\nin a certain popular book, and Lucy never forgot anything that Frank\r\nhad said.\r\n\r\nIt did come to pass. Mrs. Greystock at once corresponded with Lady\r\nLinlithgow, and Lady Linlithgow, who was at Ramsgate for her autumn\r\nvacation, requested that Lucy Morris might be brought to see her at\r\nher house in London on the 2nd of October. Lady Linlithgow\'s autumn\r\nholiday always ended on the last day of September. On the 2nd of\r\nOctober Lady Fawn herself took Lucy up to Bruton Street, and Lady\r\nLinlithgow appeared. "Miss Morris," said Lady Fawn, "thinks it right\r\nthat you should be told that she\'s engaged to be married." "Who\r\nto?" demanded the countess. Lucy was as red as fire, although she\r\nhad especially made up her mind that she would not blush when the\r\ncommunication was made. "I don\'t know that she wishes me to mention\r\nthe gentleman\'s name, just at present; but I can assure you that he\r\nis all that he ought to be." "I hate mysteries," said the countess.\r\n"If Lady Linlithgow--" began Lucy. "Oh, it\'s nothing to me,"\r\ncontinued the old woman. "It won\'t come off for six months, I\r\nsuppose?" Lucy gave a mute assurance that there would be no such\r\ndifficulty as that. "And he can\'t come here, Miss Morris." To this\r\nLucy said nothing. Perhaps she might win over even the countess, and\r\nif not, she must bear her six months of prolonged exclusion from the\r\nlight of day. And so the matter was settled. Lucy was to be taken\r\nback to Richmond, and to come again on the following Monday. "I don\'t\r\nlike this parting at all, Lucy," Lady Fawn said on her way home.\r\n\r\n"It is better so, Lady Fawn."\r\n\r\n"I hate people going away; but, somehow, you don\'t feel it as we do."\r\n\r\n"You wouldn\'t say that if you really knew what I do feel."\r\n\r\n"There was no reason why you should go. Frederic was getting not\r\nto care for it at all. What\'s Nina to do now? I can\'t get another\r\ngoverness after you. I hate all these sudden breaks up. And all for\r\nsuch a trumpery thing. If Frederic hasn\'t forgotten all about it, he\r\nought."\r\n\r\n"It hasn\'t come altogether from him, Lady Fawn."\r\n\r\n"How has it come, then?"\r\n\r\n"I suppose it is because of Mr. Greystock. I suppose when a girl has\r\nengaged herself to marry a man she must think more of him than of\r\nanything else."\r\n\r\n"Why couldn\'t you think of him at Fawn Court?"\r\n\r\n"Because--because things have been unfortunate. He isn\'t your\r\nfriend,--not as yet. Can\'t you understand, Lady Fawn, that, dear as\r\nyou all must be to me, I must live in his friendships, and take his\r\npart when there is a part?"\r\n\r\n"Then I suppose that you mean to hate all of us?" Lucy could only cry\r\nat hearing this;--whereupon Lady Fawn also burst into tears.\r\n\r\nOn the Sunday before Lucy took her departure, Lord Fawn was again\r\nat Richmond. "Of course, you\'ll come down,--just as if nothing had\r\nhappened," said Lydia. "We\'ll see," said Lucy. "Mamma will be very\r\nangry if you don\'t," said Lydia.\r\n\r\nBut Lucy had a little plot in her head, and her appearance at the\r\ndinner-table on that Sunday must depend on the manner in which her\r\nplot was executed. After church, Lord Fawn would always hang about\r\nthe grounds for awhile before going into the house; and on this\r\nmorning Lucy also remained outside. She soon found her opportunity,\r\nand walked straight up to him, following him on the path. "Lord\r\nFawn," she said, "I have come to beg your pardon."\r\n\r\nHe had turned round hearing footsteps behind him, but still was\r\nstartled and unready. "It does not matter at all," he said.\r\n\r\n"It matters to me, because I behaved badly."\r\n\r\n"What I said about Mr. Greystock wasn\'t intended to be said to you,\r\nyou know."\r\n\r\n"Even if it was it would make no matter. I don\'t mean to think of\r\nthat now. I beg your pardon because I said what I ought not to have\r\nsaid."\r\n\r\n"You see, Miss Morris, that as the head of this family--"\r\n\r\n"If I had said it to Juniper, I would have begged his pardon." Now\r\nJuniper was the gardener, and Lord Fawn did not quite like the way in\r\nwhich the thing was put to him. The cloud came across his brow, and\r\nhe began to fear that she would again insult him. "I oughtn\'t to\r\naccuse anybody of an untruth,--not in that way; and I am very sorry\r\nfor what I did, and I beg your pardon." Then she turned as though she\r\nwere going back to the house.\r\n\r\nBut he stopped her. "Miss Morris, if it will suit you to stay with my\r\nmother, I will never say a word against it."\r\n\r\n"It is quite settled that I am to go to-morrow, Lord Fawn. Only for\r\nthat I would not have troubled you again."\r\n\r\nThen she did turn towards the house, but he recalled her. "We will\r\nshake hands, at any rate," he said, "and not part as enemies." So\r\nthey shook hands, and Lucy came down and sat in his company at the\r\ndinner-table.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIV\r\n\r\nLady Linlithgow at Home\r\n\r\n\r\nLucy, in her letter to her lover, had distinctly asked whether she\r\nmight tell Lady Linlithgow the name of her future husband, but had\r\nreceived no reply when she was taken to Bruton Street. The parting at\r\nRichmond was very painful, and Lady Fawn had declared herself quite\r\nunable to make another journey up to London with the ungrateful\r\nrunagate. Though there was no diminution of affection among the\r\nFawns, there was a general feeling that Lucy was behaving badly. That\r\nobstinacy of hers was getting the better of her. Why should she have\r\ngone? Even Lord Fawn had expressed his desire that she should remain.\r\nAnd then, in the breasts of the wise ones, all faith in the Greystock\r\nengagement had nearly vanished. Another letter had come from Mrs.\r\nHittaway, who now declared that it was already understood about\r\nPortray that Lady Eustace intended to marry her cousin. This was\r\ndescribed as a terrible crime on the part of Lizzie, though the\r\nantagonistic crime of a remaining desire to marry Lord Fawn was still\r\nimputed to her. And, of course, the one crime heightened the other.\r\nSo that words from the eloquent pen of Mrs. Hittaway failed to make\r\ndark enough the blackness of poor Lizzie\'s character. As for Mr.\r\nGreystock, he was simply a heartless man of the world, wishing to\r\nfeather his nest. Mrs. Hittaway did not for a moment believe that he\r\nhad ever dreamed of marrying Lucy Morris. Men always have three or\r\nfour little excitements of that kind going on for the amusement of\r\ntheir leisure hours,--so, at least, said Mrs. Hittaway. "The girl had\r\nbetter be told at once." Such was her decision about poor Lucy. "I\r\ncan\'t do more than I have done," said Lady Fawn to Augusta. "She\'ll\r\nnever get over it, mamma; never," said Augusta.\r\n\r\nNothing more was said, and Lucy was sent off in the family carriage.\r\nLydia and Nina were sent with her, and though there was some weeping\r\non the journey, there was also much laughing. The character of the\r\n"duchess" was discussed very much at large, and many promises were\r\nmade as to long letters. Lucy, in truth, was not unhappy. She would\r\nbe nearer to Frank; and then it had been almost promised her that she\r\nshould go to the deanery, after a residence of six months with Lady\r\nLinlithgow. At the deanery of course she would see Frank; and she\r\nalso understood that a long visit to the deanery would be the surest\r\nprelude to that home of her own of which she was always dreaming.\r\n\r\n"Dear me;--sent you up in the carriage, has she? Why shouldn\'t you\r\nhave come by the railway?"\r\n\r\n"Lady Fawn thought the carriage best. She is so very kind."\r\n\r\n"It\'s what I call twaddle, you know. I hope you ain\'t afraid of going\r\nin a cab."\r\n\r\n"Not in the least, Lady Linlithgow."\r\n\r\n"You can\'t have the carriage to go about here. Indeed, I never have a\r\npair of horses till after Christmas. I hope you know that I\'m as poor\r\nas Job."\r\n\r\n"I didn\'t know."\r\n\r\n"I am, then. You\'ll get nothing beyond wholesome food with me. And\r\nI\'m not sure it is wholesome always. The butchers are scoundrels, and\r\nthe bakers are worse. What used you to do at Lady Fawn\'s?"\r\n\r\n"I still did lessons with the two youngest girls."\r\n\r\n"You won\'t have any lessons to do here, unless you do \'em with me.\r\nYou had a salary there?"\r\n\r\n"Oh yes."\r\n\r\n"Fifty pounds a year, I suppose."\r\n\r\n"I had eighty."\r\n\r\n"Had you, indeed; eighty pounds;--and a coach to ride in!"\r\n\r\n"I had a great deal more than that, Lady Linlithgow."\r\n\r\n"How do you mean?"\r\n\r\n"I had downright love and affection. They were just so many dear\r\nfriends. I don\'t suppose any governess was ever so treated before. It\r\nwas just like being at home. The more I laughed, the better every one\r\nliked it."\r\n\r\n"You won\'t find anything to laugh at here; at least, I don\'t. If you\r\nwant to laugh, you can laugh up-stairs, or down in the parlour."\r\n\r\n"I can do without laughing for a while."\r\n\r\n"That\'s lucky, Miss Morris. If they were all so good to you, what\r\nmade you come away? They sent you away, didn\'t they?"\r\n\r\n"Well;--I don\'t know that I can explain it just all. There were a\r\ngreat many things together. No;--they didn\'t send me away. I came\r\naway because it suited."\r\n\r\n"It was something to do with your having a lover, I suppose." To this\r\nLucy thought it best to make no answer, and the conversation for a\r\nwhile was dropped.\r\n\r\nLucy had arrived at about half-past three, and Lady Linlithgow was\r\nthen sitting in the drawing-room. After the first series of questions\r\nand answers, Lucy was allowed to go up to her room, and on her return\r\nto the drawing-room, found the countess still sitting upright in her\r\nchair. She was now busy with accounts, and at first took no notice of\r\nLucy\'s return. What were to be the companion\'s duties? What tasks in\r\nthe house were to be assigned to her? What hours were to be her own;\r\nand what was to be done in those of which the countess would demand\r\nthe use? Up to the present moment nothing had been said of all\r\nthis. She had simply been told that she was to be Lady Linlithgow\'s\r\ncompanion,--without salary, indeed,--but receiving shelter,\r\nguardianship, and bread and meat in return for her services. She took\r\nup a book from the table and sat with it for ten minutes. It was\r\nTupper\'s great poem, and she attempted to read it. Lady Linlithgow\r\nsat, totting up her figures, but said nothing. She had not spoken a\r\nword since Lucy\'s return to the room; and as the great poem did not\r\nat first fascinate the new companion,--whose mind not unnaturally\r\nwas somewhat disturbed,--Lucy ventured upon a question. "Is there\r\nanything I can do for you, Lady Linlithgow?"\r\n\r\n"Do you know about figures?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, yes. I consider myself quite a ready-reckoner."\r\n\r\n"Can you make two and two come to five on one side of the sheet, and\r\nonly come to three on the other?"\r\n\r\n"I\'m afraid I can\'t do that, and prove it afterwards."\r\n\r\n"Then you ain\'t worth anything to me." Having so declared, Lady\r\nLinlithgow went on with her accounts and Lucy relapsed into her great\r\npoem.\r\n\r\n"No, my dear," said the countess, when she had completed her work.\r\n"There isn\'t anything for you to do. I hope you haven\'t come here\r\nwith that mistaken idea. There won\'t be any sort of work of any kind\r\nexpected from you. I poke my own fires, and I carve my own bit of\r\nmutton. And I haven\'t got a nasty little dog to be washed. And I\r\ndon\'t care twopence about worsted work. I have a maid to darn my\r\nstockings, and because she has to work, I pay her wages. I don\'t like\r\nbeing alone, so I get you to come and live with me. I breakfast at\r\nnine, and if you don\'t manage to be down by that time, I shall be\r\ncross."\r\n\r\n"I\'m always up long before that."\r\n\r\n"There\'s lunch at two,--just bread and butter and cheese, and perhaps\r\na bit of cold meat. There\'s dinner at seven;--and very bad it is,\r\nbecause they don\'t have any good meat in London. Down in Fifeshire\r\nthe meat\'s a deal better than it is here, only I never go there now.\r\nAt half-past ten I go to bed. It\'s a pity you\'re so young, because\r\nI don\'t know what you\'ll do about going out. Perhaps, as you ain\'t\r\npretty, it won\'t signify."\r\n\r\n"Not at all, I should think," said Lucy.\r\n\r\n"Perhaps you consider yourself pretty. It\'s all altered now since\r\nI was young. Girls make monsters of themselves, and I\'m told the\r\nmen like it;--going about with unclean, frowsy structures on their\r\nheads, enough to make a dog sick. They used to be clean and sweet and\r\nnice,--what one would like to kiss. How a man can like to kiss a face\r\nwith a dirty horse\'s tail all whizzing about it, is what I can\'t at\r\nall understand. I don\'t think they do like it, but they have to do\r\nit."\r\n\r\n"I haven\'t even a pony\'s tail," said Lucy.\r\n\r\n"They do like to kiss you, I daresay."\r\n\r\n"No, they don\'t," ejaculated Lucy, not knowing what answer to make.\r\n\r\n"I haven\'t hardly looked at you, but you didn\'t seem to me to be a\r\nbeauty."\r\n\r\n"You\'re quite right about that, Lady Linlithgow."\r\n\r\n"I hate beauties. My niece, Lizzie Eustace, is a beauty; and I think\r\nthat, of all the heartless creatures in the world, she is the most\r\nheartless."\r\n\r\n"I know Lady Eustace very well."\r\n\r\n"Of course you do. She was a Greystock, and you know the Greystocks.\r\nAnd she was down staying with old Lady Fawn at Richmond. I should\r\nthink old Lady Fawn had a time with her;--hadn\'t she?"\r\n\r\n"It didn\'t go off very well."\r\n\r\n"Lizzie would be too much for the Fawns, I should think. She was too\r\nmuch for me, I know. She\'s about as bad as anybody ever was. She\'s\r\nfalse, dishonest, heartless, cruel, irreligious, ungrateful, mean,\r\nignorant, greedy, and vile!"\r\n\r\n"Good gracious, Lady Linlithgow!"\r\n\r\n"She\'s all that, and a great deal worse. But she is handsome. I don\'t\r\nknow that I ever saw a prettier woman. I generally go out in a cab\r\nat three o\'clock, but I sha\'n\'t want you to go with me. I don\'t know\r\nwhat you can do. Macnulty used to walk round Grosvenor Square and\r\nthink that people mistook her for a lady of quality. You mustn\'t go\r\nand walk round Grosvenor Square by yourself, you know. Not that I\r\ncare."\r\n\r\n"I\'m not a bit afraid of anybody," said Lucy.\r\n\r\n"Now you know all about it. There isn\'t anything for you to do. There\r\nare Miss Edgeworth\'s novels down-stairs, and \'Pride and Prejudice\' in\r\nmy bed-room. I don\'t subscribe to Mudie\'s, because when I asked for\r\n\'Adam Bede,\' they always sent me the \'Bandit Chief.\' Perhaps you can\r\nborrow books from your friends at Richmond. I daresay Mrs. Greystock\r\nhas told you that I\'m very cross."\r\n\r\n"I haven\'t seen Mrs. Greystock for ever so long."\r\n\r\n"Then Lady Fawn has told you,--or somebody. When the wind is east,\r\nor north-east, or even north, I am cross, for I have the lumbago.\r\nIt\'s all very well talking about being good-humoured. You can\'t be\r\ngood-humoured with the lumbago. And I have the gout sometimes in my\r\nknee. I\'m cross enough then, and so you\'d be. And, among \'em all, I\r\ndon\'t get much above half what I ought to have out of my jointure.\r\nThat makes me very cross. My teeth are bad, and I like to have the\r\nmeat tender. But it\'s always tough, and that makes me cross. And when\r\npeople go against the grain with me, as Lizzie Eustace always did,\r\nthen I\'m very cross."\r\n\r\n"I hope you won\'t be very bad with me," said Lucy.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t bite, if you mean that," said her ladyship.\r\n\r\n"I\'d sooner be bitten than barked at,--sometimes," said Lucy.\r\n\r\n"Humph!" said the old woman, and then she went back to her accounts.\r\n\r\nLucy had a few books of her own, and she determined to ask Frank to\r\nsend her some. Books are cheap things, and she would not mind asking\r\nhim for magazines, and numbers, and perhaps for the loan of a few\r\nvolumes. In the meantime she did read Tupper\'s poem, and "Pride and\r\nPrejudice," and one of Miss Edgeworth\'s novels,--probably for the\r\nthird time. During the first week in Bruton Street she would have\r\nbeen comfortable enough, only that she had not received a line from\r\nFrank. That Frank was not specially good at writing letters she had\r\nalready taught herself to understand. She was inclined to believe\r\nthat but few men of business do write letters willingly, and that, of\r\nall men, lawyers are the least willing to do so. How reasonable it\r\nwas that a man who had to perform a great part of his daily work with\r\na pen in his hand, should loathe a pen when not at work. To her the\r\nwriting of letters was perhaps the most delightful occupation of her\r\nlife, and the writing of letters to her lover was a foretaste of\r\nheaven; but then men, as she knew, are very different from women. And\r\nshe knew this also,--that of all her immediate duties, no duty could\r\nbe clearer than that of abstaining from all jealousy, petulance, and\r\nimpatient expectation of little attentions. He loved her, and had\r\ntold her so, and had promised her that she should be his wife, and\r\nthat ought to be enough for her. She was longing for a letter,\r\nbecause she was very anxious to know whether she might mention his\r\nname to Lady Linlithgow;--but she would abstain from any idea of\r\nblaming him because the letter did not come.\r\n\r\nOn various occasions the countess showed some little curiosity about\r\nthe lover; and at last, after about ten days, when she found herself\r\nbeginning to be intimate with her new companion, she put the question\r\npoint-blank. "I hate mysteries," she said. "Who is the young man you\r\nare to marry?"\r\n\r\n"He is a gentleman I\'ve known a long time."\r\n\r\n"That\'s no answer."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t want to tell his name quite yet, Lady Linlithgow."\r\n\r\n"Why shouldn\'t you tell his name, unless it\'s something improper? Is\r\nhe a gentleman?"\r\n\r\n"Yes;--he is a gentleman."\r\n\r\n"And how old?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, I don\'t know;--perhaps thirty-two."\r\n\r\n"And has he any money?"\r\n\r\n"He has his profession."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t like these kind of secrets, Miss Morris. If you won\'t say\r\nwho he is, what was the good of telling me that you were engaged at\r\nall? How is a person to believe it?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t want you to believe it."\r\n\r\n"Highty, tighty!"\r\n\r\n"I told you my own part of the affair, because I thought you ought\r\nto know it as I was coming into your house. But I don\'t see that you\r\nought to know his part of it. As for not believing, I suppose you\r\nbelieved Lady Fawn?"\r\n\r\n"Not a bit better than I believe you. People don\'t always tell truth\r\nbecause they have titles, nor yet because they\'ve grown old. He don\'t\r\nlive in London;--does he?"\r\n\r\n"He generally lives in London. He is a barrister."\r\n\r\n"Oh,--oh; a barrister is he. They\'re always making a heap of money,\r\nor else none at all. Which is it with him?"\r\n\r\n"He makes something."\r\n\r\n"As much as you could put in your eye and see none the worse." To\r\nsee the old lady, as she made this suggestion, turn sharp round upon\r\nLucy, was as good as a play. "My sister\'s nephew, the dean\'s son, is\r\none of the best of the rising ones, I\'m told." Lucy blushed up to\r\nher hair, but the dowager\'s back was turned, and she did not see the\r\nblushes. "But he\'s in Parliament, and they tell me he spends his\r\nmoney faster than he makes it. I suppose you know him?"\r\n\r\n"Yes;--I knew him at Bobsborough."\r\n\r\n"It\'s my belief that after all this fuss about Lord Fawn, he\'ll marry\r\nhis cousin, Lizzie Eustace. If he\'s a lawyer, and as sharp as they\r\nsay, I suppose he could manage her. I wish he would."\r\n\r\n"And she so bad as you say she is!"\r\n\r\n"She\'ll be sure to get somebody, and why shouldn\'t he have her money\r\nas well as another? There never was a Greystock who didn\'t want\r\nmoney. That\'s what it will come to;--you\'ll see."\r\n\r\n"Never," said Lucy decidedly.\r\n\r\n"And why not?"\r\n\r\n"What I mean is that Mr. Greystock is,--at least, I should think\r\nso from what I hear,--the very last man in the world to marry for\r\nmoney."\r\n\r\n"What do you know of what a man would do?"\r\n\r\n"It would be a very mean thing;--particularly if he does not love\r\nher."\r\n\r\n"Bother!" said the countess. "They were very near it in town last\r\nyear before Lord Fawn came up at all. I knew as much as that. And\r\nit\'s what they\'ll come to before they\'ve done."\r\n\r\n"They\'ll never come to it," said Lucy.\r\n\r\nThen a sudden light flashed across the astute mind of the countess.\r\nShe turned round in her chair, and sat for awhile silent, looking at\r\nLucy. Then she slowly asked another question. "He isn\'t your young\r\nman;--is he?" To this Lucy made no reply. "So that\'s it, is it?" said\r\nthe dowager. "You\'ve done me the honour of making my house your home\r\ntill my own sister\'s nephew shall be ready to marry you?"\r\n\r\n"And why not?" said Lucy, rather roughly.\r\n\r\n"And dame Greystock, from Bobsborough, has sent you here to keep you\r\nout of her son\'s way. I see it all. And that old frump at Richmond\r\nhas passed you over to me because she did not choose to have such\r\ngoings on under her own eye."\r\n\r\n"There have been no goings on," said Lucy.\r\n\r\n"And he\'s to come here, I suppose, when my back\'s turned?"\r\n\r\n"He is not thinking of coming here. I don\'t know what you mean.\r\nNobody has done anything wrong to you. I don\'t know why you say such\r\ncruel things."\r\n\r\n"He can\'t afford to marry you, you know."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know anything about it. Perhaps we must wait ever so\r\nlong;--five years. That\'s nobody\'s business but my own."\r\n\r\n"I found it all out;--didn\'t I?"\r\n\r\n"Yes;--you found it out."\r\n\r\n"I\'m thinking of that sly old dame Greystock at Bobsborough,--sending\r\nyou here!" Neither on that nor on the two following days did Lady\r\nLinlithgow say a word further to Lucy about her engagement.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXV\r\n\r\nToo Bad for Sympathy\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen Frank Greystock left Bobsborough to go to Scotland, he had not\r\nsaid that he would return, nor had he at that time made up his mind\r\nwhether he would do so or no. He had promised to go and shoot in\r\nNorfolk, and had half undertaken to be up in London with Herriot,\r\nworking. Though it was holiday-time, still there was plenty of work\r\nfor him to do,--various heavy cases to get up, and papers to be read,\r\nif only he could settle himself down to the doing of it. But the\r\nscenes down in Scotland had been of a nature to make him unfit for\r\nsteady labour. How was he to sail his bark through the rocks by which\r\nhis present voyage was rendered so dangerous? Of course, to the\r\nreader, the way to do so seems to be clear enough. To work hard at\r\nhis profession; to explain to his cousin that she had altogether\r\nmistaken his feelings; and to be true to Lucy Morris was so\r\nmanifestly his duty, that to no reader will it appear possible that\r\nto any gentleman there could be a doubt. Instead of the existence\r\nof a difficulty, there was a flood of light upon his path,--so the\r\nreader will think;--a flood so clear that not to see his way was\r\nimpossible. A man carried away by abnormal appetites, and wickedness,\r\nand the devil, may of course commit murder, or forge bills, or become\r\na fraudulent director of a bankrupt company. And so may a man be\r\nuntrue to his troth,--and leave true love in pursuit of tinsel, and\r\nbeauty, and false words, and a large income. But why should one tell\r\nthe story of creatures so base? One does not willingly grovel in\r\ngutters, or breathe fetid atmospheres, or live upon garbage. If we\r\nare to deal with heroes and heroines, let us, at any rate, have\r\nheroes and heroines who are above such meanness as falsehood in love.\r\nThis Frank Greystock must be little better than a mean villain, if he\r\nallows himself to be turned from his allegiance to Lucy Morris for an\r\nhour by the seductions and money of such a one as Lizzie Eustace.\r\n\r\nWe know the dear old rhyme:--\r\n\r\n\r\n   "It is good to be merry and wise,\r\n       It is good to be honest and true,\r\n    It is good to be off with the old love\r\n       Before you are on with the new."\r\n\r\n\r\nThere was never better truth spoken than this, and if all men and\r\nwomen could follow the advice here given, there would be very little\r\nsorrow in the world. But men and women do not follow it. They are no\r\nmore able to do so than they are to use a spear, the staff of which\r\nis like a weaver\'s beam, or to fight with the sword Excalibur. The\r\nmore they exercise their arms, the nearer will they get to using the\r\ngiant\'s weapon,--or even the weapon that is divine. But as things\r\nare at present, their limbs are limp and their muscles soft, and\r\nover-feeding impedes their breath. They attempt to be merry without\r\nbeing wise, and have theories about truth and honesty with which they\r\ndesire to shackle others, thinking that freedom from such trammels\r\nmay be good for themselves. And in that matter of love,--though love\r\nis very potent,--treachery will sometimes seem to be prudence, and a\r\nhankering after new delights will often interfere with real devotion.\r\n\r\nIt is very easy to depict a hero,--a man absolutely stainless,\r\nperfect as an Arthur,--a man honest in all his dealings, equal to all\r\ntrials, true in all his speech, indifferent to his own prosperity,\r\nstruggling for the general good, and, above all, faithful in love.\r\nAt any rate, it is as easy to do that as to tell of the man who is\r\none hour good and the next bad, who aspires greatly but fails in\r\npractice, who sees the higher but too often follows the lower course.\r\nThere arose at one time a school of art, which delighted to paint\r\nthe human face as perfect in beauty; and from that time to this we\r\nare discontented unless every woman is drawn for us as a Venus, or,\r\nat least, a Madonna. I do not know that we have gained much by this\r\nuntrue portraiture, either in beauty or in art. There may be made\r\nfor us a pretty thing to look at, no doubt;--but we know that that\r\npretty thing is not really visaged as the mistress whom we serve, and\r\nwhose lineaments we desire to perpetuate on the canvas. The winds of\r\nheaven, or the flesh-pots of Egypt, or the midnight gas,--passions,\r\npains, and, perhaps, rouge and powder, have made her something\r\ndifferent. But there still is the fire of her eye, and the eager\r\neloquence of her mouth, and something, too, perhaps, left of the\r\ndeparting innocence of youth, which the painter might give us without\r\nthe Venus or the Madonna touches. But the painter does not dare to\r\ndo it. Indeed, he has painted so long after the other fashion that\r\nhe would hate the canvas before him, were he to give way to the\r\nrouge-begotten roughness or to the flesh-pots,--or even to the winds.\r\nAnd how, my lord, would you, who are giving hundreds, more than\r\nhundreds, for this portrait of your dear one, like to see it in print\r\nfrom the art critic of the day, that she is a brazen-faced hoyden who\r\nseems to have had a glass of wine too much, or to have been making\r\nhay?\r\n\r\nAnd so also has the reading world taught itself to like best the\r\ncharacters of all but divine men and women. Let the man who paints\r\nwith pen and ink give the gas-light, and the flesh-pots, the passions\r\nand pains, the prurient prudence and the rouge-pots and pounce-boxes\r\nof the world as it is, and he will be told that no one can care a\r\nstraw for his creations. With whom are we to sympathise? says the\r\nreader, who not unnaturally imagines that a hero should be heroic.\r\nOh, thou, my reader, whose sympathies are in truth the great and only\r\naim of my work, when you have called the dearest of your friends\r\nround you to your hospitable table, how many heroes are there sitting\r\nat the board? Your bosom friend,--even if he be a knight without\r\nfear, is he a knight without reproach? The Ivanhoe that you know, did\r\nhe not press Rebecca\'s hand? Your Lord Evandale,--did he not bring\r\nhis coronet into play when he strove to win his Edith Bellenden?\r\nWas your Tresilian still true and still forbearing when truth and\r\nforbearance could avail him nothing? And those sweet girls whom you\r\nknow, do they never doubt between the poor man they think they love,\r\nand the rich man whose riches they know they covet?\r\n\r\nGo into the market, either to buy or sell, and name the thing you\r\ndesire to part with or to get, as it is, and the market is closed\r\nagainst you. Middling oats are the sweepings of the granaries. A\r\nuseful horse is a jade gone at every point. Good sound port is sloe\r\njuice. No assurance short of A 1 betokens even a pretence to merit.\r\nAnd yet in real life we are content with oats that are really\r\nmiddling, are very glad to have a useful horse, and know that if we\r\ndrink port at all we must drink some that is neither good nor sound.\r\nIn those delineations of life and character which we call novels a\r\nsimilarly superlative vein is desired. Our own friends around us are\r\nnot always merry and wise, nor, alas! always honest and true. They\r\nare often cross and foolish, and sometimes treacherous and false.\r\nThey are so, and we are angry. Then we forgive them, not without a\r\nconsciousness of imperfection on our own part. And we know--or, at\r\nleast, believe,--that though they be sometimes treacherous and false,\r\nthere is a balance of good. We cannot have heroes to dine with us.\r\nThere are none. And were these heroes to be had, we should not like\r\nthem. But neither are our friends villains,--whose every aspiration\r\nis for evil, and whose every moment is a struggle for some\r\nachievement worthy of the devil.\r\n\r\nThe persons whom you cannot care for in a novel, because they are so\r\nbad, are the very same that you so dearly love in your life, because\r\nthey are so good. To make them and ourselves somewhat better,--not by\r\none spring heavenwards to perfection, because we cannot so use our\r\nlegs,--but by slow climbing, is, we may presume, the object of all\r\nteachers, leaders, legislators, spiritual pastors, and masters. He\r\nwho writes tales such as this, probably also has, very humbly, some\r\nsuch object distantly before him. A picture of surpassing godlike\r\nnobleness,--a picture of a King Arthur among men, may perhaps do\r\nmuch. But such pictures cannot do all. When such a picture is\r\npainted, as intending to show what a man should be, it is true. If\r\npainted to show what men are, it is false. The true picture of life\r\nas it is, if it could be adequately painted, would show men what they\r\nare, and how they might rise, not, indeed, to perfection, but one\r\nstep first, and then another, on the ladder.\r\n\r\nOur hero, Frank Greystock, falling lamentably short in his heroism,\r\nwas not in a happy state of mind when he reached Bobsborough. It\r\nmay be that he returned to his own borough and to his mother\'s arms\r\nbecause he felt, that were he to determine to be false to Lucy, he\r\nwould there receive sympathy in his treachery. His mother would, at\r\nany rate, think that it was well, and his father would acknowledge\r\nthat the fault committed was in the original engagement with poor\r\nLucy, and not in the treachery. He had written that letter to her in\r\nhis chambers one night in a fit of ecstasy; and could it be right\r\nthat the ruin of a whole life should be the consequence?\r\n\r\nIt can hardly be too strongly asserted that Lizzie Greystock did not\r\nappear to Frank as she has been made to appear to the reader. In all\r\nthis affair of the necklace he was beginning to believe that she\r\nwas really an ill-used woman; and as to other traits in Lizzie\'s\r\ncharacter,--traits which he had seen, and which were not of a nature\r\nto attract,--it must be remembered that beauty reclining in a man\'s\r\narms does go far towards washing white the lovely blackamoor. Lady\r\nLinlithgow, upon whom Lizzie\'s beauty could have no effect of that\r\nkind, had nevertheless declared her to be very beautiful. And this\r\nloveliness was of a nature that was altogether pleasing, if once the\r\nbeholder of it could get over the idea of falseness which certainly\r\nLizzie\'s eye was apt to convey to the beholder. There was no unclean\r\nhorse\'s tail. There was no get-up of flounces, and padding, and\r\npaint, and hair, with a dorsal excrescence appended with the object\r\nsurely of showing in triumph how much absurd ugliness women can force\r\nmen to endure. She was lithe, and active, and bright,--and was at\r\nthis moment of her life at her best. Her growing charms had as yet\r\nhardly reached the limits of full feminine loveliness,--which, when\r\nreached, have been surpassed. Luxuriant beauty had with her not as\r\nyet become comeliness; nor had age or the good things of the world\r\nadded a pound to the fairy lightness of her footstep. All this had\r\nbeen tendered to Frank,--and with it that worldly wealth which was\r\nso absolutely necessary to his career. For though Greystock would\r\nnot have said to any man or woman that nature had intended him to\r\nbe a spender of much money and a consumer of many good things, he\r\ndid undoubtedly so think of himself. He was a Greystock, and to\r\nwhat miseries would he not reduce his Lucy if, burthened by such\r\npropensities, he were to marry her and then become an aristocratic\r\npauper!\r\n\r\nThe offer of herself by a woman to a man is, to us all, a thing\r\nso distasteful that we at once declare that the woman must be\r\nabominable. There shall be no whitewashing of Lizzie Eustace. She\r\nwas abominable. But the man to whom the offer is made hardly sees\r\nthe thing in the same light. He is disposed to believe that, in his\r\npeculiar case, there are circumstances by which the woman is, if not\r\njustified, at least excused. Frank did put faith in his cousin\'s\r\nlove for himself. He did credit her when she told him that she had\r\naccepted Lord Fawn\'s offer in pique, because he had not come to her\r\nwhen he had promised that he would come. It did seem natural to him\r\nthat she should have desired to adhere to her engagement when he\r\nwould not advise her to depart from it. And then her jealousy about\r\nLucy\'s ring, and her abuse of Lucy, were proofs to him of her love.\r\nUnless she loved him, why should she care to marry him? What was his\r\nposition that she should desire to share it;--unless she so desired\r\nbecause he was dearer to her than aught beside? He had not eyes\r\nclear enough to perceive that his cousin was a witch whistling for a\r\nwind, and ready to take the first blast that would carry her and her\r\nbroomstick somewhere into the sky. And then, in that matter of the\r\noffer, which in ordinary circumstances certainly should not have\r\ncome from her to him, did not the fact of her wealth and of his\r\ncomparative poverty cleanse her from such stain as would, in usual\r\ncircumstances, attach to a woman who is so forward? He had not\r\nacceded to her proposition. He had not denied his engagement to Lucy.\r\nHe had left her presence without a word of encouragement, because\r\nof that engagement. But he believed that Lizzie was sincere. He\r\nbelieved, now, that she was genuine; though he had previously been\r\nall but sure that falsehood and artifice were second nature to her.\r\n\r\nAt Bobsborough he met his constituents, and made them the normal\r\nautumn speech. The men of Bobsborough were well pleased and gave him\r\na vote of confidence. As none but those of his own party attended\r\nthe meeting, it was not wonderful that the vote was unanimous. His\r\nfather, mother, and sister all heard his speech, and there was a\r\nstrong family feeling that Frank was born to set the Greystocks once\r\nmore upon their legs. When a man can say what he likes with the\r\ncertainty that every word will be reported, and can speak to those\r\naround him as one manifestly their superior, he always looms large.\r\nWhen the Conservatives should return to their proper place at the\r\nhead of affairs, there could be no doubt that Frank Greystock would\r\nbe made Solicitor-General. There were not wanting even ardent\r\nadmirers who conceived that, with such claims and such talents as\r\nhis, the ordinary steps in political promotion would not be needed,\r\nand that he would become Attorney-General at once. All men began to\r\nsay all good things to the dean, and to Mrs. Greystock it seemed\r\nthat the woolsack, or at least the Queen\'s Bench with a peerage, was\r\nhardly an uncertainty. But then,--there must be no marriage with a\r\npenniless governess. If he would only marry his cousin one might say\r\nthat the woolsack was won.\r\n\r\nThen came Lucy\'s letter; the pretty, dear, joking letter about\r\nthe "duchess," and broken hearts. "I would break my heart,\r\nonly--only--only--" Yes, he knew very well what she meant. I shall\r\nnever be called upon to break my heart, because you are not a false\r\nscoundrel. If you were a false scoundrel,--instead of being, as you\r\nare, a pearl among men,--then I should break my heart. That was what\r\nLucy meant. She could not have been much clearer, and he understood\r\nit perfectly. It is very nice to walk about one\'s own borough and be\r\nvoted unanimously worthy of confidence, and be a great man; but if\r\nyou are a scoundrel, and not used to being a scoundrel, black care\r\nis apt to sit very close behind you as you go caracoling along the\r\nstreets.\r\n\r\nLucy\'s letter required an answer, and how should he answer it? He\r\ncertainly did not wish her to tell Lady Linlithgow of her engagement,\r\nbut Lucy clearly wished to be allowed to tell, and on what ground\r\ncould he enjoin her to be silent? He knew, or he thought he knew,\r\nthat till he answered the letter, she would not tell his secret,--and\r\ntherefore from day to day he put off the answer. A man does not write\r\na love-letter easily when he is in doubt himself whether he does or\r\ndoes not mean to be a scoundrel.\r\n\r\nThen there came a letter to "Dame" Greystock from Lady Linlithgow,\r\nwhich filled them all with amazement.\r\n\r\n\r\n   MY DEAR MADAM,--[began the letter]\r\n\r\n   Seeing that your son is engaged to marry Miss Morris,--at\r\n   least she says so,--you ought not to have sent her here\r\n   without telling me all about it. She says you know of the\r\n   match, and she says that I can write to you if I please.\r\n   Of course, I can do that without her leave. But it seems\r\n   to me that if you know all about it, and approve the\r\n   marriage, your house and not mine would be the proper\r\n   place for her.\r\n\r\n   I\'m told that Mr. Greystock is a great man. Any lady\r\n   being with me as my companion can\'t be a great woman. But\r\n   perhaps you wanted to break it off;--else you would have\r\n   told me. She shall stay here six months, but then she must\r\n   go.\r\n\r\n   Yours truly,\r\n\r\n   SUSANNA LINLITHGOW.\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was considered absolutely necessary that this letter should be\r\nshown to Frank. "You see," said his mother, "she told the old lady at\r\nonce."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t see why she shouldn\'t." Nevertheless Frank was annoyed.\r\nHaving asked for permission, Lucy should at least have waited for a\r\nreply.\r\n\r\n"Well, I don\'t know," said Mrs. Greystock. "It is generally\r\nconsidered that young ladies are more reticent about such things. She\r\nhas blurted it out and boasted about it at once."\r\n\r\n"I thought girls always told of their engagements," said Frank, "and\r\nI can\'t for the life of me see that there was any boasting in it."\r\nThen he was silent for a moment. "The truth is, we are, all of us,\r\ntreating Lucy very badly."\r\n\r\n"I cannot say that I see it," said his mother.\r\n\r\n"We ought to have had her here."\r\n\r\n"For how long, Frank?"\r\n\r\n"For as long as a home was needed by her."\r\n\r\n"Had you demanded it, Frank, she should have come, of course. But\r\nneither I nor your father could have had pleasure in receiving her as\r\nyour future wife. You, yourself, say that it cannot be for two years\r\nat least."\r\n\r\n"I said one year."\r\n\r\n"I think, Frank, you said two. And we all know that such a marriage\r\nwould be ruinous to you. How could we make her welcome? Can you see\r\nyour way to having a house for her to live in within twelve months?"\r\n\r\n"Why not a house? I could have a house to-morrow."\r\n\r\n"Such a house as would suit you in your position? And, Frank, would\r\nit be a kindness to marry her and then let her find that you were in\r\ndebt?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t believe she\'d care if she had nothing but a crust to eat."\r\n\r\n"She ought to care, Frank."\r\n\r\n"I think," said the dean to his son, on the next day, "that in our\r\nclass of life an imprudent marriage is the one thing that should be\r\navoided. My marriage has been very happy, God knows; but I have\r\nalways been a poor man, and feel it now when I am quite unable\r\nto help you. And yet your mother had some fortune. Nobody, I\r\nthink, cares less for wealth than I do. I am content almost with\r\nnothing."--The nothing with which the dean had hitherto been\r\ncontented had always included every comfort of life, a well-kept\r\ntable, good wine, new books, and canonical habiliments with the gloss\r\nstill on; but as the Bobsborough tradesmen had, through the agency of\r\nMrs. Greystock, always supplied him with these things as though they\r\ncame from the clouds, he really did believe that he had never asked\r\nfor anything.--"I am content almost with nothing. But I do feel that\r\nmarriage cannot be adopted as the ordinary form of life by men in our\r\nclass as it can be by the rich or by the poor. You, for instance, are\r\ncalled upon to live with the rich, but are not rich. That can only\r\nbe done by wary walking, and is hardly consistent with a wife and\r\nchildren."\r\n\r\n"But men in my position do marry, sir."\r\n\r\n"After a certain age,--or else they marry ladies with money. You see,\r\nFrank, there are not many men who go into Parliament with means so\r\nmoderate as yours; and they who do perhaps have stricter ideas of\r\neconomy." The dean did not say a word about Lucy Morris, and dealt\r\nentirely with generalities.\r\n\r\nIn compliance with her son\'s advice,--or almost command,--Mrs.\r\nGreystock did not answer Lady Linlithgow\'s letter. He was going back\r\nto London, and would give personally, or by letter written there,\r\nwhat answer might be necessary. "You will then see Miss Morris?"\r\nasked his mother.\r\n\r\n"I shall certainly see Lucy. Something must be settled." There was\r\na tone in his voice as he said this which gave some comfort to his\r\nmother.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVI\r\n\r\nLizzie\'s Guests\r\n\r\n\r\nTrue to their words, at the end of October, Mrs. Carbuncle and Miss\r\nRoanoke, and Lord George de Bruce Carruthers, and Sir Griffin Tewett,\r\narrived at Portray Castle. And for a couple of days there was a\r\nvisitor whom Lizzie was very glad to welcome, but of whose good\r\nnature on the occasion Mr. Camperdown thought very ill indeed. This\r\nwas John Eustace. His sister-in-law wrote to him in very pressing\r\nlanguage; and as,--so he said to Mr. Camperdown,--he did not wish\r\nto seem to quarrel with his brother\'s widow as long as such seeming\r\nmight be avoided, he accepted the invitation. If there was to be a\r\nlawsuit about the diamonds, that must be Mr. Camperdown\'s affair.\r\nLizzie had never entertained her friends in style before. She had\r\nhad a few people to dine with her in London, and once or twice\r\nhad received company on an evening. But in all her London doings\r\nthere had been the trepidation of fear,--to be accounted for by\r\nher youth and widowhood; and it was at Portray,--her own house at\r\nPortray,--that it would best become her to exercise hospitality. She\r\nhad bided her time even there, but now she meant to show her friends\r\nthat she had got a house of her own.\r\n\r\nShe wrote even to her husband\'s uncle, the bishop, asking him down\r\nto Portray. He could not come, but sent an affectionate answer, and\r\nthanked her for thinking of him. Many people she asked who, she\r\nfelt sure, would not come,--and one or two of them accepted her\r\ninvitation. John Eustace promised to be with her for two days. When\r\nFrank had left her, going out of her presence in the manner that has\r\nbeen described, she actually wrote to him, begging him to join her\r\nparty. This was her note:\r\n\r\n"Come to me, just for a week," she said, "when my people are here, so\r\nthat I may not seem to be deserted. Sit at the bottom of my table,\r\nand be to me as a brother might. I shall expect you to do so much for\r\nme." To this he had replied that he would come during the first week\r\nin November.\r\n\r\nAnd she got a clergyman down from London, the Rev. Joseph Emilius,\r\nof whom it was said that he was born a Jew in Hungary, and that his\r\nname in his own country had been Mealyus. At the present time he was\r\namong the most eloquent of London preachers, and was reputed by some\r\nto have reached such a standard of pulpit-oratory as to have had no\r\nequal within the memory of living hearers. In regard to his reading\r\nit was acknowledged that no one since Mrs. Siddons had touched him.\r\nBut he did not get on very well with any particular bishop, and there\r\nwas doubt in the minds of some people whether there was or was not\r\nany--Mrs. Emilius. He had come up quite suddenly within the last\r\nseason, and had made church-going quite a pleasant occupation to\r\nLizzie Eustace.\r\n\r\nOn the last day of October, Mr. Emilius and Mr. John Eustace\r\ncame, each alone. Mrs. Carbuncle and Miss Roanoke came over with\r\npost-horses from Ayr,--as also did Lord George and Sir Griffin about\r\nan hour after them. Frank was not yet expected. He had promised to\r\nname a day and had not yet named it.\r\n\r\n"Varra weel; varra weel," Gowran had said when he was told of what\r\nwas about to occur, and was desired to make preparations necessary in\r\nregard to the outside plenishing of the house; "nae doobt she\'ll do\r\nwith her ain what pleases her ainself. The mair ye poor out, the less\r\nthere\'ll be left in. Mr. Jo-ohn coming? I\'ll be glad then to see Mr.\r\nJo-ohn. Oo, ay; aits,--there\'ll be aits eneuch. And anither coo?\r\nYou\'ll want twa ither coos. I\'ll see to the coos." And Andy Gowran,\r\nin spite of the internecine warfare which existed between him and his\r\nmistress, did see to the hay, and the cows, and the oats, and the\r\nextra servants that were wanted both inside and outside the house.\r\nThere was enmity between him and Lady Eustace, and he didn\'t care who\r\nknew it;--but he took her wages and he did her work.\r\n\r\nMrs. Carbuncle was a wonderful woman. She was the wife of a man with\r\nwhom she was very rarely seen, whom nobody knew, who was something\r\nin the City, but somebody who never succeeded in making money; and\r\nyet she went everywhere. She had at least the reputation of going\r\neverywhere, and did go to a great many places. Carbuncle had no\r\nmoney,--so it was said; and she had none. She was the daughter of\r\na man who had gone to New York and had failed there. Of her own\r\nparentage no more was known. She had a small house in one of the very\r\nsmall Mayfair streets, to which she was wont to invite her friends\r\nfor five o\'clock tea. Other receptions she never attempted. During\r\nthe London seasons she always kept a carriage, and during the winters\r\nshe always had hunters. Who paid for them no one knew or cared. Her\r\ndress was always perfect,--as far as fit and performance went. As\r\nto approving Mrs. Carbuncle\'s manner of dress,--that was a question\r\nof taste. Audacity may, perhaps, be said to have been the ruling\r\nprinciple of her toilet;--not the audacity of indecency, which, let\r\nthe satirists say what they may, is not efficacious in England, but\r\naudacity in colour, audacity in design, and audacity in construction.\r\nShe would ride in the park in a black and yellow habit, and appear at\r\nthe opera in white velvet without a speck of colour. Though certainly\r\nturned thirty, and probably nearer to forty, she would wear her\r\njet-black hair streaming down her back, and when June came would\r\ndrive about London in a straw hat. But yet it was always admitted\r\nthat she was well dressed. And then would arise that question, who\r\npaid the bills?\r\n\r\nMrs. Carbuncle was certainly a handsome woman. She was\r\nfull-faced,--with bold eyes, rather far apart, perfect black\r\neyebrows, a well-formed broad nose, thick lips, and regular teeth.\r\nHer chin was round and short, with, perhaps, a little bearing towards\r\na double chin. But though her face was plump and round, there was\r\na power in it, and a look of command, of which it was, perhaps,\r\ndifficult to say in what features was the seat. But in truth the\r\nmind will lend a tone to every feature, and it was the desire of Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle\'s heart to command. But perhaps the wonder of her face was\r\nits complexion. People said,--before they knew her, that, as a matter\r\nof course, she had been made beautiful for ever. But, though that too\r\nbrilliant colour was almost always there, covering the cheeks but\r\nnever touching the forehead or the neck, it would at certain moments\r\nshift, change, and even depart. When she was angry, it would vanish\r\nfor a moment and then return intensified. There was no chemistry on\r\nMrs. Carbuncle\'s cheek; and yet it was a tint so brilliant and so\r\nlittle transparent, as almost to justify a conviction that it could\r\nnot be genuine. There were those who declared that nothing in the way\r\nof complexion so beautiful as that of Mrs. Carbuncle\'s had been seen\r\non the face of any other woman in this age, and there were others\r\nwho called her an exaggerated milkmaid. She was tall, too, and had\r\nlearned so to walk as though half the world belonged to her.\r\n\r\nHer niece, Miss Roanoke, was a lady of the same stamp, and of similar\r\nbeauty, with those additions and also with those drawbacks which\r\nbelong to youth. She looked as though she were four-and-twenty, but\r\nin truth she was no more than eighteen. When seen beside her aunt,\r\nshe seemed to be no more than half the elder lady\'s size; and yet her\r\nproportions were not insignificant. She, too, was tall, and was as\r\none used to command, and walked as though she were a young Juno. Her\r\nhair was very dark,--almost black,--and very plentiful. Her eyes were\r\nlarge and bright, though too bold for a girl so young. Her nose and\r\nmouth were exactly as her aunt\'s, but her chin was somewhat longer,\r\nso as to divest her face of that plump roundness which, perhaps,\r\ntook something from the majesty of Mrs. Carbuncle\'s appearance. Miss\r\nRoanoke\'s complexion was certainly marvellous. No one thought that\r\nshe had been made beautiful for ever, for the colour would go and\r\ncome and shift and change with every word and every thought;--but\r\nstill it was there, as deep on her cheeks as on her aunt\'s, though\r\nsomewhat more transparent, and with more delicacy of tint as the\r\nbright hues faded away and became merged in the almost marble\r\nwhiteness of her skin. With Mrs. Carbuncle there was no merging and\r\nfading. The red and white bordered one another on her cheek without\r\nany merging, as they do on a flag.\r\n\r\nLucinda Roanoke was undoubtedly a very handsome woman. It probably\r\nnever occurred to man or woman to say that she was lovely. She had\r\nsat for her portrait during the last winter, and her picture had\r\ncaused much remark in the Exhibition. Some said that she might be a\r\nBrinvilliers, others a Cleopatra, and others again a Queen of Sheba.\r\nIn her eyes as they were limned there had been nothing certainly of\r\nlove, but they who likened her to the Egyptian queen believed that\r\nCleopatra\'s love had always been used simply to assist her ambition.\r\nThey who took the Brinvilliers side of the controversy were men so\r\nused to softness and flattery from women as to have learned to think\r\nthat a woman silent, arrogant, and hard of approach, must be always\r\nmeditating murder. The disciples of the Queen of Sheba school, who\r\nformed, perhaps, the more numerous party, were led to their opinion\r\nby the majesty of Lucinda\'s demeanour rather than by any clear idea\r\nin their own minds of the lady who visited Solomon. All men, however,\r\nagreed in this, that Lucinda Roanoke was very handsome, but that she\r\nwas not the sort of girl with whom a man would wish to stray away\r\nthrough the distant beech-trees at a picnic.\r\n\r\nIn truth she was silent, grave, and, if not really haughty, subject\r\nto all the signs of haughtiness. She went everywhere with her aunt,\r\nand allowed herself to be walked out at dances, and to be accosted\r\nwhen on horseback, and to be spoken to at parties; but she seemed\r\nhardly to trouble herself to talk;--and as for laughing, flirting, or\r\ngiggling, one might as well expect such levity from a marble Minerva.\r\nDuring the last winter she had taken to hunting with her aunt, and\r\nalready could ride well to hounds. If assistance were wanted at a\r\ngate, or in the management of a fence, and the servant who attended\r\nthe two ladies were not near enough to give it, she would accept it\r\nas her due from the man nearest to her; but she rarely did more than\r\nbow her thanks, and, even by young lords, or hard-riding handsome\r\ncolonels, or squires of undoubted thousands, she could hardly ever be\r\nbrought to what might be called a proper hunting-field conversation.\r\nAll of which things were noted, and spoken of, and admired. It must\r\nbe presumed that Lucinda Roanoke was in want of a husband, and yet\r\nno girl seemed to take less pains to get one. A girl ought not to be\r\nalways busying herself to bring down a man, but a girl ought to give\r\nherself some charm. A girl so handsome as Lucinda Roanoke, with pluck\r\nenough to ride like a bird, dignity enough for a duchess, and who was\r\nundoubtedly clever, ought to put herself in the way of taking such\r\ngood things as her charms and merits would bring her;--but Lucinda\r\nRoanoke stood aloof and despised everybody. So it was that Lucinda\r\nwas spoken of when her name was mentioned; and her name was mentioned\r\na good deal after the opening of the exhibition of pictures.\r\n\r\nThere was some difficulty about her,--as to who she was. That she was\r\nan American was the received opinion. Her mother, as well as Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle, had certainly been in New York. Carbuncle was a London\r\nman; but it was supposed that Mr. Roanoke was, or had been, an\r\nAmerican. The received opinion was correct. Lucinda had been born\r\nin New York, had been educated there till she was sixteen, had then\r\nbeen taken to Paris for nine months, and from Paris had been brought\r\nto London by her aunt. Mrs. Carbuncle always spoke of Lucinda\'s\r\neducation as having been thoroughly Parisian. Of her own education\r\nand antecedents, Lucinda never spoke at all. "I\'ll tell you what\r\nit is," said a young scamp from Eton to his elder sister, when her\r\ncharacter and position were once being discussed. "She\'s a heroine,\r\nand would shoot a fellow as soon as look at him." In that scamp\'s\r\nfamily, Lucinda was ever afterwards called the heroine.\r\n\r\nThe manner in which Lord George de Bruce Carruthers had attached\r\nhimself to these ladies was a mystery;--but then Lord George was\r\nalways mysterious. He was a young man,--so considered,--about\r\nforty-five years of age, who had never done anything in the manner of\r\nother people. He hunted a great deal, but he did not fraternise with\r\nhunting men, and would appear now in this county and now in that,\r\nwith an utter disregard of grass, fences, friendships, or foxes.\r\nLeicester, Essex, Ayrshire, or the Baron had equal delights for\r\nhim; and in all counties he was quite at home. He had never owned a\r\nfortune, and had never been known to earn a shilling. It was said\r\nthat early in life he had been apprenticed to an attorney at Aberdeen\r\nas George Carruthers. His third cousin, the Marquis of Killiecrankie,\r\nhad been killed out hunting; the second scion of the noble family had\r\nfallen at Balaclava; a third had perished in the Indian Mutiny; and\r\na fourth, who did reign for a few months, died suddenly, leaving\r\na large family of daughters. Within three years the four brothers\r\nvanished, leaving among them no male heir, and George\'s elder\r\nbrother, who was then in a West India Regiment, was called home from\r\nDemerara to be Marquis of Killiecrankie. By a usual exercise of the\r\ncourtesy of the Crown, all the brothers were made lords, and some\r\ntwelve years before the date of our story George Carruthers, who had\r\nlong since left the attorney\'s office at Aberdeen, became Lord George\r\nde Bruce Carruthers. How he lived no one knew. That his brother did\r\nmuch for him was presumed to be impossible, as the property entailed\r\non the Killiecrankie title certainly was not large. He sometimes\r\nwent into the City, and was supposed to know something about shares.\r\nPerhaps he played a little, and made a few bets. He generally lived\r\nwith men of means;--or perhaps with one man of means at a time; but\r\nthey who knew him well declared that he never borrowed a shilling\r\nfrom a friend, and never owed a guinea to a tradesman. He always had\r\nhorses, but never had a home. When in London he lodged in a single\r\nroom, and dined at his club. He was a Colonel of Volunteers, having\r\ngot up the regiment known as the Long Shore Riflemen,--the roughest\r\nregiment of Volunteers in all England,--and was reputed to be a\r\nbitter Radical. He was suspected even of republican sentiments, and\r\nignorant young men about London hinted that he was the grand centre\r\nof the British Fenians. He had been invited to stand for the Tower\r\nHamlets, but had told the deputation which waited upon him that he\r\nknew a thing worth two of that. Would they guarantee his expenses,\r\nand then give him a salary? The deputation doubted its ability to\r\npromise so much. "I more than doubt it," said Lord George; and then\r\nthe deputation went away.\r\n\r\nIn person he was a long-legged, long-bodied, long-faced man, with\r\nrough whiskers and a rough beard on his upper lip, but with a shorn\r\nchin. His eyes were very deep set in his head, and his cheeks were\r\nhollow and sallow, and yet he looked to be and was a powerful,\r\nhealthy man. He had large hands, which seemed to be all bone, and\r\nlong arms, and a neck which looked to be long because he so wore his\r\nshirt that much of his throat was always bare. It was manifest enough\r\nthat he liked to have good-looking women about him, and yet nobody\r\npresumed it probable that he would marry. For the last two or three\r\nyears there had been friendship between him and Mrs. Carbuncle; and\r\nduring the last season he had become almost intimate with our Lizzie.\r\nLizzie thought that perhaps he might be the Corsair whom, sooner or\r\nlater in her life, she must certainly encounter.\r\n\r\nSir Griffin Tewett, who at the present period of his existence was\r\nbeing led about by Lord George, was not exactly an amiable young\r\nbaronet. Nor were his circumstances such as make a man amiable. He\r\nwas nominally, not only the heir to, but actually the possessor of,\r\na large property;--but he could not touch the principal, and of the\r\nincome only so much as certain legal curmudgeons would allow him. As\r\nGreystock had said, everybody was at law with him,--so successful\r\nhad been his father in mismanaging, and miscontrolling, and\r\nmisappropriating the property. Tewett Hall had gone to rack and ruin\r\nfor four years, and was now let almost for nothing. He was a fair,\r\nfrail young man, with a bad eye, and a weak mouth, and a thin hand,\r\nwho was fond of liqueurs, and hated to the death any acquaintance who\r\nwon a five-pound note of him, or any tradesman who wished to have\r\nhis bill paid. But he had this redeeming quality,--that having found\r\nLucinda Roanoke to be the handsomest woman he had ever seen, he did\r\ndesire to make her his wife.\r\n\r\nSuch were the friends whom Lizzie Eustace received at Portray Castle\r\non the first day of her grand hospitality,--together with John\r\nEustace and Mr. Joseph Emilius, the fashionable preacher from\r\nMayfair.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVII\r\n\r\nLizzie\'s First Day\r\n\r\n\r\nThe coming of John Eustace was certainly a great thing for Lizzie,\r\nthough it was only for two days. It saved her from that feeling of\r\ndesertion before her friends,--desertion by those who might naturally\r\nbelong to her,--which would otherwise have afflicted her. His\r\npresence there for two days gave her a start. She could call him\r\nJohn, and bring down her boy to him, and remind him, with the\r\nsweetest smile,--with almost a tear in her eye,--that he was the\r\nboy\'s guardian. "Little fellow! So much depends on that little\r\nlife,--does it not, John?" she said, whispering the words into his\r\near.\r\n\r\n"Lucky little dog!" said John, patting the boy\'s head. "Let me see!\r\nof course he\'ll go to Eton."\r\n\r\n"Not yet," said Lizzie with a shudder.\r\n\r\n"Well; no; hardly;--when he\'s twelve." And then the boy was done with\r\nand was carried away. She had played that card and had turned her\r\ntrick. John Eustace was a thoroughly good-natured man of the world,\r\nwho could forgive many faults, not expecting people to be perfect.\r\nHe did not like Mrs. Carbuncle;--was indifferent to Lucinda\'s\r\nbeauty;--was afraid of that Tartar, Lord George;--and thoroughly\r\ndespised Sir Griffin. In his heart he believed Mr. Emilius to be an\r\nimpostor, who might, for aught he knew, pick his pocket; and Miss\r\nMacnulty had no attraction for him. But he smiled, and was gay, and\r\ncalled Lady Eustace by her Christian name, and was content to be of\r\nuse to her in showing her friends that she had not been altogether\r\ndropped by the Eustace people. "I got such a nice affectionate letter\r\nfrom the dear bishop," said Lizzie, "but he couldn\'t come. He could\r\nnot escape a previous engagement."\r\n\r\n"It\'s a long way," said John, "and he\'s not so young as he was\r\nonce;--and then there are the Bobsborough parsons to look after."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t suppose anything of that kind stops him," said Lizzie, who\r\ndid not think it possible that a bishop\'s bliss should be alloyed\r\nby work. John was so very nice that she almost made up her mind to\r\ntalk to him about the necklace; but she was cautious, and thought of\r\nit, and found that it would be better that she should abstain. John\r\nEustace was certainly very good-natured, but perhaps he might say\r\nan ugly word to her if she were rash. She refrained, therefore, and\r\nafter breakfast on the second day he took his departure without an\r\nallusion to things that were unpleasant.\r\n\r\n"I call my brother-in-law a perfect gentleman," said Lizzie with\r\nenthusiasm, when his back was turned.\r\n\r\n"Certainly," said Mrs. Carbuncle. "He seems to me to be very quiet."\r\n\r\n"He didn\'t quite like his party," said Lord George.\r\n\r\n"I am sure he did," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"I mean as to politics. To him we are all turbulent demagogues\r\nand Bohemians. Eustace is an old-world Tory, if there\'s one left\r\nanywhere. But you\'re right, Lady Eustace; he is a gentleman."\r\n\r\n"He knows on which side his bread is buttered as well as any man,"\r\nsaid Sir Griffin.\r\n\r\n"Am I a demagogue," said Lizzie, appealing to the Corsair, "or a\r\nBohemian? I didn\'t know it."\r\n\r\n"A little in that way, I think, Lady Eustace;--not a demagogue, but\r\ndemagognical;--not a Bohemian, but that way given."\r\n\r\n"And is Miss Roanoke demagognical?"\r\n\r\n"Certainly," said Lord George. "I hardly wrong you there, Miss\r\nRoanoke?"\r\n\r\n"Lucinda is a democrat, but hardly a demagogue, Lord George," said\r\nMrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\n"Those are distinctions which we hardly understand on this\r\nthick-headed side of the water. But demagogues, democrats,\r\ndemonstrations, and Demosthenic oratory are all equally odious to\r\nJohn Eustace. For a young man he\'s about the best Tory I know."\r\n\r\n"He is true to his colours," said Mr. Emilius, who had been\r\nendeavouring to awake the attention of Miss Roanoke on the subject of\r\nShakespeare\'s dramatic action, "and I like men who are true to their\r\ncolours." Mr. Emilius spoke with the slightest possible tone of a\r\nforeign accent,--a tone so slight that it simply served to attract\r\nattention to him.\r\n\r\nWhile Eustace was still in the house, there had come a letter from\r\nFrank Greystock, saying that he would reach Portray, by way of\r\nGlasgow, on Wednesday, the 5th of November. He must sleep in Glasgow\r\non that night, having business, or friends, or pleasure demanding his\r\nattention in that prosperous mart of commerce. It had been impressed\r\nupon him that he should hunt, and he had consented. There was to be\r\na meet out on the Kilmarnock side of the county on that Wednesday,\r\nand he would bring a horse with him from Glasgow. Even in Glasgow a\r\nhunter was to be hired, and could be sent forty or fifty miles out\r\nof the town in the morning and brought back in the evening. Lizzie\r\nhad learned all about that, and had told him. If he would call\r\nat MacFarlane\'s stables in Buchanan Street, or even write to Mr.\r\nMacFarlane, he would be sure to get a horse that would carry him.\r\nMacFarlane was sending horses down into the Ayrshire country every\r\nday of his life. It was simply an affair of money. Three guineas for\r\nthe horse, and then just the expense of the railway. Frank, who knew\r\nquite as much about it as did his cousin, and who never thought much\r\nof guineas or of railway tickets, promised to meet the party at the\r\nmeet ready equipped. His things would go on by train, and Lizzie must\r\nsend for them to Troon. He presumed a beneficent Providence would\r\ntake the horse back to the bosom of Mr. MacFarlane. Such was the\r\ntenour of his letter. "If he don\'t mind, he\'ll find himself astray,"\r\nsaid Sir Griffin. "He\'ll have to go one way by rail and his horse\r\nanother." "We can manage better for our cousin than that," said\r\nLizzie, with a rebuking nod.\r\n\r\nBut there was hunting from Portray before Frank Greystock came. It\r\nwas specially a hunting party, and Lizzie was to be introduced to the\r\nglories of the field. In giving her her due, it must be acknowledged\r\nthat she was fit for the work. She rode well, though she had not\r\nridden to hounds, and her courage was cool. She looked well on\r\nhorseback, and had that presence of mind which should never desert a\r\nlady when she is hunting. A couple of horses had been purchased for\r\nher, under Lord George\'s superintendence,--his conjointly with\r\nMrs. Carbuncle\'s,--and had been at the castle for the last ten\r\ndays--"eating their varra heeds off," as Andy Gowran had said in\r\nsorrow. There had been practising even while John Eustace was there,\r\nand before her preceptors had slept three nights at the castle, she\r\nhad ridden backwards and forwards half-a-dozen times over a stone\r\nwall. "Oh, yes," Lucinda had said, in answer to a remark from\r\nSir Griffin, "It\'s easy enough,--till you come across something\r\ndifficult."\r\n\r\n"Nothing difficult stops you," said Sir Griffin;--to which compliment\r\nLucinda vouchsafed no reply.\r\n\r\nOn the Monday Lizzie went out hunting for the first time in her\r\nlife. It must be owned that, as she put her habit on, and afterwards\r\nbreakfasted with all her guests in hunting gear around her, and then\r\nwas driven with them in her own carriage to the meet, there was\r\nsomething of trepidation at her heart. And her feeling of cautious\r\nfear in regard to money had received a shock. Mrs. Carbuncle had told\r\nher that a couple of horses fit to carry her might perhaps cost her\r\nabout \xa3180. Lord George had received the commission, and the cheque\r\nrequired from her had been for \xa3320. Of course she had written the\r\ncheque without a word, but it did begin to occur to her that hunting\r\nwas an expensive amusement. Gowran had informed her that he had\r\nbought a rick of hay from a neighbour for \xa375 15s. 9d. "God forgie\r\nme," said Andy, "but I b\'lieve I\'ve been o\'er hard on the puir man\r\nin your leddyship\'s service." \xa375 15s. 9d. did seem a great deal of\r\nmoney to pay; and could it be necessary that she should buy a whole\r\nrick? There were to be eight horses in the stable. To what friend\r\ncould she apply to learn how much of a rick of hay one horse ought to\r\neat in a month of hunting? In such a matter she might have trusted\r\nAndy Gowran implicitly; but how was she to know that? And then, what\r\nif at some desperate fence she were to be thrown off and break her\r\nnose and knock out her front teeth! Was the game worth the candle?\r\nShe was by no means sure that she liked Mrs. Carbuncle very much. And\r\nthough she liked Lord George very well, could it be possible that he\r\nbought the horses for \xa390 each and charged her \xa3160? Corsairs do do\r\nthese sort of things. The horses themselves were two sweet dears,\r\nwith stars on their foreheads, and shining coats, and a delicious\r\naptitude for jumping over everything at a moment\'s notice. Lord\r\nGeorge had not, in truth, made a penny by them, and they were good\r\nhunters, worth the money;--but how was Lizzie to know that? But\r\nthough she doubted, and was full of fears, she could smile and look\r\nas though she liked it. If the worst should come she could certainly\r\nget money for the diamonds.\r\n\r\nOn that Monday the meet was comparatively near to them,--distant only\r\ntwelve miles. On the following Wednesday it would be sixteen, and\r\nthey would use the railway,--having the carriage sent to meet them\r\nin the evening. The three ladies and Lord George filled the carriage,\r\nand Sir Griffin was perched upon the box. The ladies\' horses had gone\r\non with two grooms, and those for Lord George and Sir Griffin were\r\nto come to the meet. Lizzie felt somewhat proud of her establishment\r\nand her equipage;--but at the same time somewhat fearful. Hitherto\r\nshe knew but very little of the county people, and was not sure how\r\nshe might be received;--and then how would it be with her if the fox\r\nshould at once start away across country, and she should lack either\r\nthe pluck or the power to follow? There was Sir Griffin to look after\r\nMiss Roanoke, and Lord George to attend to Mrs. Carbuncle. At last an\r\nidea so horrible struck her that she could not keep it down. "What\r\nam I to do," she said, "if I find myself all alone in a field, and\r\neverybody else gone away!"\r\n\r\n"We won\'t treat you quite in that fashion," said Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\n"The only possible way in which you can be alone in a field is that\r\nyou will have cut everybody else down," said Lord George.\r\n\r\n"I suppose it will all come right," said Lizzie, plucking up her\r\ncourage, and telling herself that a woman can die but once.\r\n\r\nEverything was right,--as it usually is. The horses were\r\nthere,--quite a throng of horses, as the two gentlemen had two each;\r\nand there was, moreover, a mounted groom to look after the three\r\nladies. Lizzie had desired to have a groom to herself, but had been\r\ntold that the expenditure in horseflesh was more than the stable\r\ncould stand. "All I ever want of a man is to carry for me my flask,\r\nand waterproof, and luncheon," said Mrs. Carbuncle. "I don\'t care if\r\nI never see a groom, except for that."\r\n\r\n"It\'s convenient to have a gate opened sometimes," said Lucinda,\r\nslowly.\r\n\r\n"Will no one but a groom do that for you?" asked Sir Griffin.\r\n\r\n"Gentlemen can\'t open gates," said Lucinda. Now, as Sir Griffin\r\nthought that he had opened many gates during the last season for Miss\r\nRoanoke, he felt this to be hard.\r\n\r\nBut there were eight horses, and eight horses with three servants and\r\na carriage made quite a throng. Among the crowd of Ayrshire hunting\r\nmen,--a lord or two, a dozen lairds, two dozen farmers, and as many\r\nmen of business out of Ayr, Kilmarnock, and away from Glasgow,--it\r\nwas soon told that Lady Eustace and her party were among them. A good\r\ndeal had been already heard of Lizzie, and it was at least known of\r\nher that she had, for her life, the Portray estate in her hands. So\r\nthere was an undercurrent of whispering, and that sort of commotion\r\nwhich the appearance of new-comers does produce at a hunt-meet.\r\nLord George knew one or two men, who were surprised to find him in\r\nAyrshire, and Mrs. Carbuncle was soon quite at home with a young\r\nnobleman whom she had met in the vale with the Baron. Sir Griffin did\r\nnot leave Lucinda\'s side, and for a while poor Lizzie felt herself\r\nalone in a crowd.\r\n\r\nWho does not know that terrible feeling, and the all but\r\nnecessity that exists for the sufferer to pretend that he is not\r\nsuffering,--which again is aggravated by the conviction that the\r\npretence is utterly vain? This may be bad with a man, but with a\r\nwoman, who never looks to be alone in a crowd, it is terrible.\r\nFor five minutes, during which everybody else was speaking to\r\neverybody,--for five minutes, which seemed to her to be an hour,\r\nLizzie spoke to no one, and no one spoke to her. Was it for such\r\nmisery as this that she was spending hundreds upon hundreds, and\r\nrunning herself into debt? For she was sure that there would be debt\r\nbefore she had parted with Mrs. Carbuncle. There are people, very\r\nmany people, to whom an act of hospitality is in itself a good\r\nthing; but there are others who are always making calculations, and\r\nendeavouring to count up the thing purchased against the cost. Lizzie\r\nhad been told that she was a rich woman,--as women go, very rich.\r\nSurely she was entitled to entertain a few friends; and if Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle and Miss Roanoke could hunt, it could not be that hunting\r\nwas beyond her own means. And yet she was spending a great deal of\r\nmoney. She had seen a large waggon loaded with sacks of corn coming\r\nup the hill to the Portray stables, and she knew that there would be\r\na long bill at the corn-chandler\'s. There had been found a supply\r\nof wine in the cellars at Portray,--which at her request had been\r\ninspected by her cousin Frank;--but it had been necessary, so he had\r\ntold her, to have much more sent down from London,--champagne, and\r\nliqueurs, and other nice things that cost money. "You won\'t like not\r\nto have them if these people are coming?" "Oh, no; certainly not,"\r\nsaid Lizzie, with enthusiasm. What other rich people did, she would\r\ndo. But now, in her five minutes of misery, she counted it all\r\nup, and was at a loss to find what was to be her return for her\r\nexpenditure. And then, if on this her first day she should have a\r\nfall, with no tender hand to help her, and then find that she had\r\nknocked out her front teeth!\r\n\r\nBut the cavalcade began to move, and then Lord George was by her\r\nside. "You mustn\'t be angry if I seem to stick too close to you," he\r\nsaid. She gave him her sweetest smile as she told him that that would\r\nbe impossible.
