"Because, you know, though it\'s the easiest thing in\r\nthe world to get along out hunting, and women never come to grief, a\r\nperson is a little astray at first."\r\n\r\n"I shall be so much astray," said Lizzie. "I don\'t at all know how we\r\nare going to begin. Are we hunting a fox now?" At this moment they\r\nwere trotting across a field or two, through a run of gates up to the\r\nfirst covert.\r\n\r\n"Not quite yet. The hounds haven\'t been put in yet. You see that wood\r\nthere? I suppose they\'ll draw that."\r\n\r\n"What is drawing, Lord George? I want to know all about it, and I am\r\nso ignorant. Nobody else will tell me." Then Lord George gave his\r\nlesson, and explained the theory and system of fox-hunting. "We\'re to\r\nwait here, then, till the fox runs away? But it\'s ever so large, and\r\nif he runs away, and nobody sees him? I hope he will, because it will\r\nbe nice to go on easily."\r\n\r\n"A great many people hope that, and a great many think it nice to go\r\non easily. Only you must not confess to it." Then he went on with\r\nhis lecture, and explained the meaning of scent, was great on the\r\ndifficulty of getting away, described the iniquity of heading the\r\nfox, spoke of up wind and down wind, got as far as the trouble of\r\n"carrying," and told her that a good ear was everything in a big\r\nwood,--when there came upon them the thrice-repeated note of an\r\nold hound\'s voice, and the quick scampering, and low, timid,\r\nanxious, trustful whinnying of a dozen comrade younger hounds, who\r\nrecognised the sagacity of their well-known and highly-appreciated\r\nelder,--"That\'s a fox," said Lord George.\r\n\r\n"What shall I do now?" said Lizzie, all in a twitter.\r\n\r\n"Sit just where you are and light a cigar, if you\'re given to\r\nsmoking."\r\n\r\n"Pray don\'t joke with me. You know I want to do it properly."\r\n\r\n"And therefore you must sit just where you are, and not gallop about.\r\nThere\'s a matter of a hundred and twenty acres here, I should say,\r\nand a fox doesn\'t always choose to be evicted at the first notice.\r\nIt\'s a chance whether he goes at all from a wood like this. I like\r\nwoods myself, because, as you say, we can take it easy; but if you\r\nwant to ride, you should-- By George, they\'ve killed him!"\r\n\r\n"Killed the fox?"\r\n\r\n"Yes; he\'s dead. Didn\'t you hear?"\r\n\r\n"And is that a hunt?"\r\n\r\n"Well;--as far as it goes, it is."\r\n\r\n"Why didn\'t he run away? What a stupid beast! I don\'t see so very\r\nmuch in that. Who killed him? That man that was blowing the horn?"\r\n\r\n"The hounds chopped him."\r\n\r\n"Chopped him!" Lord George was very patient, and explained to Lizzie,\r\nwho was now indignant and disappointed, the misfortune of chopping.\r\n"And are we to go home now? Is it all over?"\r\n\r\n"They say the country is full of foxes," said Lord George. "Perhaps\r\nwe shall chop half-a-dozen."\r\n\r\n"Dear me! Chop half-a-dozen foxes! Do they like to be chopped? I\r\nthought they always ran away."\r\n\r\nLord George was constant and patient, and rode at Lizzie\'s side from\r\ncovert to covert. A second fox they did kill in the same fashion as\r\nthe first; a third they couldn\'t hunt a yard; a fourth got to ground\r\nafter five minutes, and was dug out ingloriously;--during which\r\nprocess a drizzling rain commenced. "Where is the man with my\r\nwaterproof?" demanded Mrs. Carbuncle. Lord George had sent the man to\r\nsee whether there was shelter to be had in a neighbouring yard. And\r\nMrs. Carbuncle was angry. "It\'s my own fault," she said, "for not\r\nhaving my own man. Lucinda, you\'ll be wet."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t mind the wet," said Lucinda. Lucinda never did mind\r\nanything.\r\n\r\n"If you\'ll come with me, we\'ll get into a barn," said Sir Griffin.\r\n\r\n"I like the wet," said Lucinda. All the while seven men were at work\r\nwith picks and shovels, and the master and four or five of the more\r\nardent sportsmen were deeply engaged in what seemed to be a mining\r\noperation on a small scale. The huntsman stood over giving his\r\norders. One enthusiastic man, who had been lying on his belly,\r\ngrovelling in the mud for five minutes, with a long stick in his\r\nhand, was now applying the point of it scientifically to his nose.\r\nAn ordinary observer with a magnifying-glass might have seen a hair\r\nat the end of the stick. "He\'s there," said the enthusiastic man,\r\ncovered with mud, after a long-drawn, eager sniff at the stick.\r\nThe huntsman deigned to give one glance. "That\'s rabbit," said the\r\nhuntsman. A conclave was immediately formed over the one visible\r\nhair that stuck to the stick, and three experienced farmers decided\r\nthat it was rabbit. The muddy enthusiastic man, silenced but not\r\nconvinced, retired from the crowd, leaving his stick behind him, and\r\ncomforted himself with his brandy-flask.\r\n\r\n"He\'s here, my lord," said the huntsman to his noble master, "only\r\nwe ain\'t got nigh him yet." He spoke almost in a whisper, so that\r\nthe ignorant crowd should not hear the words of wisdom, which they\r\nwouldn\'t understand or perhaps believe. "It\'s that full of rabbits\r\nthat the holes is all hairs. They ain\'t got no terrier here, I\r\nsuppose. They never has aught that is wanted in these parts. Work\r\nround to the right, there;--that\'s his line." The men did work round\r\nto the right, and in something under an hour the fox was dragged out\r\nby his brush and hind legs, while the experienced whip who dragged\r\nhim held the poor brute tight by the back of his neck. "An old dog,\r\nmy lord. There\'s such a many of \'em here, that they\'ll be a deal\r\nbetter for a little killing." Then the hounds ate their third fox for\r\nthat day.\r\n\r\nLady Eustace, in the meantime, and Mrs. Carbuncle, with Lord George,\r\nhad found their way to the shelter of a cattle-shed. Lucinda had\r\nslowly followed, and Sir Griffin had followed her. The gentlemen\r\nsmoked cigars, and the ladies, when they had eaten their luncheons\r\nand drank their sherry, were cold and cross. "If this is hunting,"\r\nsaid Lizzie, "I really don\'t think so much about it."\r\n\r\n"It\'s Scotch hunting," said Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\n"I have seen foxes dug out south of the Tweed," suggested Lord\r\nGeorge.\r\n\r\n"I suppose everything is slow after the Baron," said Mrs. Carbuncle,\r\nwho had distinguished herself with the Baron\'s stag-hounds last\r\nMarch.\r\n\r\n"Are we to go home now?" asked Lizzie, who would have been\r\nwell-pleased to have received an answer in the affirmative.\r\n\r\n"I presume they\'ll draw again," exclaimed Mrs. Carbuncle, with an\r\nangry frown on her brow. "It\'s hardly two o\'clock."\r\n\r\n"They always draw till seven, in Scotland," said Lord George.\r\n\r\n"That\'s nonsense," said Mrs. Carbuncle. "It\'s dark at four."\r\n\r\n"They have torches in Scotland," said Lord George.\r\n\r\n"They have a great many things in Scotland that are very far from\r\nagreeable," said Mrs. Carbuncle. "Lucinda, did you ever see three\r\nfoxes killed without five minutes\' running, before? I never did."\r\n\r\n"I\'ve been out all day without finding at all," said Lucinda, who\r\nloved the truth.\r\n\r\n"And so have I," said Sir Griffin;--"often. Don\'t you remember\r\nthat day when we went down from London to Bringher Wood, and they\r\npretended to find at half-past four? That\'s what I call a sell."\r\n\r\n"They\'re going on, Lady Eustace," said Lord George. "If you\'re not\r\ntired, we might as well see it out." Lizzie was tired, but said that\r\nshe was not, and she did see it out. They found a fifth fox, but\r\nagain there was no scent. "Who the ---- is to hunt a fox with people\r\nscurrying about like that!" said the huntsman, very angrily, dashing\r\nforward at a couple of riders. "The hounds is behind you, only you\r\nain\'t a-looking. Some people never do look!" The two peccant riders\r\nunfortunately were Sir Griffin and Lucinda.\r\n\r\nThe day was one of those from which all the men and women return\r\nhome cross, and which induce some half-hearted folk to declare to\r\nthemselves that they never will hunt again. When the master decided a\r\nlittle after three that he would draw no more, because there wasn\'t a\r\nyard of scent, our party had nine or ten miles to ride back to their\r\ncarriages. Lizzie was very tired, and, when Lord George took her from\r\nher horse, could almost have cried from fatigue. Mrs. Carbuncle was\r\nnever fatigued, but she had become damp,--soaking wet through, as she\r\nherself said,--during the four minutes that the man was absent with\r\nher waterproof jacket, and could not bring herself to forget the\r\nill-usage she had suffered. Lucinda had become absolutely dumb, and\r\nany observer would have fancied that the two gentlemen had quarrelled\r\nwith each other. "You ought to go on the box now," said Sir Griffin,\r\ngrumbling. "When you\'re my age, and I\'m yours, I will," said Lord\r\nGeorge, taking his seat in the carriage. Then he appealed to Lizzie.\r\n"You\'ll let me smoke, won\'t you?" She simply bowed her head. And\r\nso they went home,--Lord George smoking, and the ladies dumb.\r\nLizzie, as she dressed for dinner, almost cried with vexation and\r\ndisappointment.\r\n\r\nThere was a little conversation up-stairs between Mrs. Carbuncle and\r\nLucinda, when they were free from the attendance of their joint maid.\r\n"It seems to me," said Mrs. Carbuncle, "that you won\'t make up your\r\nmind about anything."\r\n\r\n"There is nothing to make up my mind about."\r\n\r\n"I think there is;--a great deal. Do you mean to take this man who is\r\ndangling after you?"\r\n\r\n"He isn\'t worth taking."\r\n\r\n"Carruthers says that the property must come right, sooner or later.\r\nYou might do better, perhaps, but you won\'t trouble yourself. We\r\ncan\'t go on like this for ever, you know."\r\n\r\n"If you hated it as much as I do, you wouldn\'t want to go on."\r\n\r\n"Why don\'t you talk to him? I don\'t think he\'s at all a bad fellow."\r\n\r\n"I\'ve nothing to say."\r\n\r\n"He\'ll offer to-morrow, if you\'ll accept him."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t let him do that, Aunt Jane. I couldn\'t say Yes. As for loving\r\nhim;--oh, laws!"\r\n\r\n"It won\'t do to go on like this, you know."\r\n\r\n"I\'m only eighteen;--and it\'s my money, aunt."\r\n\r\n"And how long will it last? If you can\'t accept him, refuse him, and\r\nlet somebody else come."\r\n\r\n"It seems to me," said Lucinda, "that one is as bad as another. I\'d a\r\ndeal sooner marry a shoemaker and help him to make shoes."\r\n\r\n"That\'s downright wickedness," said Mrs. Carbuncle. And then they\r\nwent down to dinner.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVIII\r\n\r\nNappie\'s Grey Horse\r\n\r\n\r\nDuring the leisure of Tuesday, our friends regained their good\r\nhumour, and on the Wednesday morning they again started for the\r\nhunting-field. Mrs. Carbuncle, who probably felt that she had behaved\r\nill about the groom and in regard to Scotland, almost made an\r\napology, and explained that a cold shower always did make her cross.\r\n"My dear Lady Eustace, I hope I wasn\'t very savage." "My dear Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle, I hope I wasn\'t very stupid," said Lizzie with a smile.\r\n"My dear Lady Eustace, and my dear Mrs. Carbuncle, and my dear Miss\r\nRoanoke, I hope I wasn\'t very selfish," said Lord George.\r\n\r\n"I thought you were," said Sir Griffin.\r\n\r\n"Yes, Griff; and so were you;--but I succeeded."\r\n\r\n"I am almost glad that I wasn\'t of the party," said Mr. Emilius,\r\nwith that musical foreign tone of his. "Miss Macnulty and I did not\r\nquarrel; did we?"\r\n\r\n"No, indeed," said Miss Macnulty, who had liked the society of Mr.\r\nEmilius.\r\n\r\nBut on this morning there was an attraction for Lizzie which the\r\nMonday had wanted. She was to meet her cousin, Frank Greystock. The\r\njourney was long, and the horses had gone on over night. They went\r\nby railway to Kilmarnock, and there a carriage from the inn had been\r\nordered to meet them. Lizzie, as she heard the order given, wondered\r\nwhether she would have to pay for that, or whether Lord George\r\nand Sir Griffin would take so much off her shoulders. Young women\r\ngenerally pay for nothing; and it was very hard that she, who was\r\nquite a young woman, should have to pay for all. But she smiled,\r\nand accepted the proposition. "Oh, yes; of course a carriage at the\r\nstation. It is so nice to have some one to think of things, like Lord\r\nGeorge." The carriage met them, and everything went prosperously.\r\nAlmost the first person they saw was Frank Greystock, in a black\r\ncoat, indeed, but riding a superb grey horse, and looking quite as\r\nthough he knew what he was about. He was introduced to Mrs. Carbuncle\r\nand Miss Roanoke and Sir Griffin. With Lord George he had some slight\r\nprevious acquaintance.\r\n\r\n"You\'ve had no difficulty about a horse?" said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"Not the slightest. But I was in an awful fright this morning. I\r\nwrote to MacFarlane from London, and absolutely hadn\'t a moment to\r\ngo to his place yesterday or this morning. I was staying over at\r\nGlenshiels, and had not a moment to spare in catching the train. But\r\nI found a horse-box on, and a lad from MacFarlane\'s just leaving as I\r\ncame up."\r\n\r\n"Didn\'t he send a boy down with the horse?" asked Lord George.\r\n\r\n"I believe there is a boy, and the boy\'ll be awfully bothered. I told\r\nhim to book the horse for Kilmarnock."\r\n\r\n"They always do book for Kilmarnock for this meet," said a gentleman\r\nwho had made acquaintance with some of Lizzie\'s party on the previous\r\nhunting-day;--"but Stewarton is ever so much nearer."\r\n\r\n"So somebody told me in the carriage," continued Frank, "and I\r\ncontrived to get my box off at Stewarton. The guard was uncommon\r\ncivil, and so was the porter. But I hadn\'t a moment to look for the\r\nboy."\r\n\r\n"I always make my fellow stick to his horses," said Sir Griffin.\r\n\r\n"But you see, Sir Griffin, I haven\'t got a fellow, and I\'ve only\r\nhired a horse. But I shall hire a good many horses from Mr.\r\nMacFarlane if he\'ll always put me up like this."\r\n\r\n"I\'m so glad you\'re here," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"So am I. I hunt about twice in three years, and no man likes it so\r\nmuch. I\'ve still got to find out whether the beast can jump."\r\n\r\n"Any mortal thing alive, sir," said one of those horsey-looking\r\nmen who are to be found in all hunting-fields, who wear old brown\r\nbreeches, old black coats, old hunting-caps, who ride screws, and\r\nnever get thrown out.\r\n\r\n"You know him, do you?" said Frank.\r\n\r\n"I know him. I didn\'t know as Muster MacFarlane owned him. No more\r\nhe don\'t," said the horsey man, turning aside to one of his friends.\r\n"That\'s Nappie\'s horse, from Jamaica Street."\r\n\r\n"Not possible," said the friend.\r\n\r\n"You\'ll tell me I don\'t know my own horse next."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t believe you ever owned one," said the friend.\r\n\r\nLizzie was in truth delighted to have her cousin beside her. He had,\r\nat any rate, forgiven what she had said to him at his last visit,\r\nor he would not have been there. And then, too, there was a feeling\r\nof reality in her connexion with him, which was sadly wanting to\r\nher,--unreal as she was herself,--in her acquaintance with the other\r\npeople around her. And on this occasion three or four people spoke\r\nor bowed to her, who had only stared at her before; and the huntsman\r\ntook off his cap, and hoped that he would do something better for her\r\nthan on the previous Monday. And the huntsman was very courteous also\r\nto Miss Roanoke, expressing the same hope, cap in hand, and smiling\r\ngraciously. A huntsman at the beginning of any day or at the end of a\r\ngood day is so different from a huntsman at the end of a bad day! A\r\nhuntsman often has a very bad time out hunting, and it is sometimes a\r\nmarvel that he does not take the advice which Job got from his wife.\r\nBut now all things were smiling, and it was soon known that his\r\nlordship intended to draw Craigattan Gorse. Now in those parts there\r\nis no surer find, and no better chance of a run, than Craigattan\r\nGorse affords.\r\n\r\n"There is one thing I want to ask, Mr. Greystock," said Lord George,\r\nin Lizzie\'s hearing.\r\n\r\n"You shall ask two," said Frank.\r\n\r\n"Who is to coach Lady Eustace to-day;--you or I?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, do let me have somebody to coach me," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"For devotion in coachmanship," said Frank,--"devotion, that is,\r\nto my cousin,--I defy the world. In point of skill I yield to Lord\r\nGeorge."\r\n\r\n"My pretensions are precisely the same," said Lord George. "I glow\r\nwith devotion; my skill is naught."\r\n\r\n"I like you best, Lord George," said Lizzie, laughing.\r\n\r\n"That settles the question," said Lord George.\r\n\r\n"Altogether," said Frank, taking off his hat.\r\n\r\n"I mean as a coach," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"I quite understand the extent of the preference," said Lord George.\r\nLizzie was delighted, and thought the game was worth the candle.\r\nThe noble master had told her that they were sure of a run from\r\nCraigattan, and she wasn\'t in the least tired, and they were not\r\ncalled upon to stand still in a big wood, and it didn\'t rain, and,\r\nin every respect, the day was very different from Monday. Mounted\r\non a bright-skinned, lively steed, with her cousin on one side and\r\nLord George de Bruce Carruthers on the other, with all the hunting\r\nworld of her own county civil around her, and a fox just found in\r\nCraigattan Gorse, what could the heart of woman desire more? This was\r\nto live. There was, however, just enough of fear to make the blood\r\nrun quickly to her heart. "We\'ll be away at once now," said Lord\r\nGeorge with utmost earnestness; "follow me close, but not too close.\r\nWhen the men see that I am giving you a lead, they won\'t come\r\nbetween. If you hang back, I\'ll not go ahead. Just check your horse\r\nas he comes to his fences, and, if you can, see me over before you\r\ngo at them. Now then, down the hill;--there\'s a gate at the corner,\r\nand a bridge over the water. We couldn\'t be better. By George! there\r\nthey are,--all together. If they don\'t pull him down in the first two\r\nminutes, we shall have a run."\r\n\r\nLizzie understood most of it,--more at least than would nine out of\r\nten young women who had never ridden a hunt before. She was to go\r\nwherever Lord George led her, and she was not to ride upon his heels.\r\nSo much at least she understood,--and so much she was resolved to do.\r\nThat dread about her front teeth which had perplexed her on Monday\r\nwas altogether gone now. She would ride as fast as Lucinda Roanoke.\r\nThat was her prevailing idea. Lucinda, with Mrs. Carbuncle, Sir\r\nGriffin, and the ladies\' groom, was at the other side of the covert.\r\nFrank had been with his cousin and Lord George, but had crept down\r\nthe hill while the hounds were in the gorse. A man who likes hunting\r\nbut hunts only once a year is desirous of doing the best he can with\r\nhis day. When the hounds came out and crossed the brook at the end\r\nof the gorse, perhaps he was a little too forward. But, indeed, the\r\nstate of affairs did not leave much time for waiting, or for the\r\netiquette of the hunting-field. Along the opposite margin of the\r\nbrook there ran a low paling, which made the water a rather nasty\r\nthing to face. A circuit of thirty or forty yards gave the easy\r\nriding of a little bridge, and to that all the crowd hurried. But one\r\nor two men with good eyes, and hearts as good, had seen the leading\r\nhounds across the brook turning up the hill away from the bridge,\r\nand knew that two most necessary minutes might be lost in the crowd.\r\nFrank did as they did, having seen nothing of any hounds, but with\r\ninstinctive knowledge that they were men likely to be right in a\r\nhunting-field. "If that ain\'t Nappie\'s horse, I\'ll eat him," said one\r\nof the leading men to the other, as all the three were breasting the\r\nhill together. Frank only knew that he had been carried over water\r\nand timber without a mistake, and felt a glow of gratitude towards\r\nMr. MacFarlane. Up the hill they went, and, not waiting to inquire\r\ninto the circumstances of a little gate, jumped a four-foot wall and\r\nwere away. "How the mischief did he get atop of Nappie\'s horse?" said\r\nthe horsey man to his friend.\r\n\r\n"We\'re about right for it now," said the huntsman, as he came up\r\nalongside of Frank. He had crossed the bridge, but had been the first\r\nacross it, and knew how to get over his ground quickly. On they\r\nwent, the horsey man leading on his thoroughbred screw, the huntsman\r\nsecond, and Frank third. The pace had already been too good for the\r\nother horsey man.\r\n\r\nWhen Lord George and Lizzie had mounted the hill, there was a rush of\r\nhorses at the little gate. As they topped the hill Lucinda and Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle were jumping the wall. Lord George looked back and asked\r\na question without a word. Lizzie answered it as mutely, Jump it!\r\nShe was already a little short of breath, but she was ready to jump\r\nanything that Lucinda Roanoke had jumped. Over went Lord George,\r\nand she followed him almost without losing the stride of her horse.\r\nSurely in all the world there was nothing equal to this! There was a\r\nlarge grass field before them, and for a moment she came up alongside\r\nof Lord George. "Just steady him before he leaps," said Lord George.\r\nShe nodded her assent, and smiled her gratitude. She had plenty of\r\nbreath for riding, but none for speaking. They were now very near to\r\nLucinda, and Sir Griffin, and Mrs. Carbuncle. "The pace is too good\r\nfor Mrs. Carbuncle\'s horse," said Lord George. Oh, if she could only\r\npass them, and get up to those men whom she saw before her! She knew\r\nthat one of them was her cousin Frank. She had no wish to pass them,\r\nbut she did wish that he should see her. In the next fence Lord\r\nGeorge spied a rail, which he thought safer than a blind hedge, and\r\nhe made for it. His horse took it well, and so did Lizzie\'s; but\r\nLizzie jumped it a little too near him, as he had paused an instant\r\nto look at the ground. "Indeed, I won\'t do it again," she said,\r\ncollecting all her breath for an apology. "You are going admirably,"\r\nhe said, "and your horse is worth double the money." She was so glad\r\nnow that he had not spared for price in mounting her. Looking to the\r\nright she could see that Mrs. Carbuncle had only just floundered\r\nthrough the hedge. Lucinda was still ahead, but Sir Griffin was\r\nfalling behind, as though divided in duty between the niece and the\r\naunt. Then they passed through a gate, and Lord George stayed his\r\nhorse to hold it for her. She tried to thank him but he stopped her.\r\n"Don\'t mind talking, but come along; and take it easy." She smiled\r\nagain, and he told himself that she was wondrous pretty. And then her\r\npluck was so good! And then she had four thousand a year! "Now for\r\nthe gap!--don\'t be in a hurry. You first, and I\'ll follow you to keep\r\noff these two men. Keep to the left, where the other horses have\r\nbeen." On they went, and Lizzie was in heaven. She could not quite\r\nunderstand her feelings, because it had come to that with her that to\r\nsave her life she could not have spoken a word. And yet she was not\r\nonly happy but comfortable. The leaping was delightful, and her horse\r\ngalloped with her as though his pleasure was as great as her own.\r\nShe thought that she was getting nearer to Lucinda. For her, in her\r\nheart, Lucinda was the quarry. If she could only pass Lucinda! That\r\nthere were any hounds she had altogether forgotten. She only knew\r\nthat two or three men were leading the way, of whom her cousin Frank\r\nwas one, that Lucinda Roanoke was following them closely, and that\r\nshe was gaining upon Lucinda Roanoke. She knew she was gaining a\r\nlittle, because she could see now how well and squarely Lucinda sat\r\nupon her horse. As for herself, she feared that she was rolling;--but\r\nshe need not have feared. She was so small, and lithe, and light,\r\nthat her body adapted itself naturally to the pace of her horse.\r\nLucinda was of a different build, and it behoved her to make for\r\nherself a perfect seat. "We must have the wall," said Lord George,\r\nwho was again at her side for a moment. She would have "had" a castle\r\nwall, moat included, turrets and all, if he would only have shown her\r\nthe way. The huntsman and Frank had taken the wall. The horsey man\'s\r\nbit of blood, knowing his own powers to an inch, had declined,--not\r\nroughly, with a sudden stop and a jerk, but with a swerve to the left\r\nwhich the horsey man at once understood. What the brute lacked in\r\njumping he could make up in pace, and the horsey man was along the\r\nwall and over a broken bank at the head of it, with the loss of not\r\nmore than a minute. Lucinda\'s horse, following the ill example,\r\nbalked the jump. She turned him round with a savage gleam in her eye\r\nwhich Lizzie was just near enough to see, struck him rapidly over\r\nthe shoulders with her whip, and the animal flew with her into the\r\nnext field. "Oh, if I could do it like that!" thought Lizzie. But\r\nin that very minute she was doing it, not only as well but better.\r\nNot following Lord George, but close at his side, the little animal\r\nchanged his pace, trotted for a yard or two, hopped up as though the\r\nwall were nothing, knocked off a top stone with his hind feet, and\r\ndropped onto the ground so softly that Lizzie hardly believed that\r\nshe had gone over the big obstruction that had cost Lucinda such an\r\neffort. Lucinda\'s horse came down on all four legs, with a grunt\r\nand a groan, and she knew that she had bustled him. At that moment\r\nLucinda was very full of wrath against the horsey man with the screw\r\nwho had been in her way. "He touched it," gasped Lizzie, thinking\r\nthat her horse had disgraced himself. "He\'s worth his weight in\r\ngold," said Lord George. "Come along. There\'s a brook with a ford.\r\nMorgan is in it." Morgan was the huntsman. "Don\'t let them get before\r\nyou." Oh, no. She would let no one get before her. She did her very\r\nbest, and just got her horse\'s nose on the broken track leading down\r\ninto the brook before Lucinda. "Pretty good, isn\'t it?" said Lucinda.\r\nLizzie smiled sweetly. She could smile, though she could not speak.\r\n"Only they do balk one so at one\'s fences!" said Lucinda. The horsey\r\nman had all but regained his place, and was immediately behind\r\nLucinda, within hearing--as Lucinda knew.\r\n\r\nOn the further side of the field, beyond the brook, there was a\r\nlittle spinny, and for half a minute the hounds came to a check.\r\n"Give \'em time, sir, give \'em time," said Morgan to Frank, speaking\r\nin full good humour, with no touch of Monday\'s savagery. "Wind him,\r\nBolton; Beaver\'s got it. Very good thing, my lady, isn\'t it? Now,\r\nCarstairs, if you\'re a-going to \'unt the fox, you\'d better \'unt him."\r\nCarstairs was the horsey man,--and one with whom Morgan very often\r\nquarrelled. "That\'s it, my hearties," and Morgan was across a broken\r\nwall in a moment, after the leading hounds. "Are we to go on?" said\r\nLizzie, who feared much that Lucinda would get ahead of her. There\r\nwas a matter of three dozen horsemen up now, and, as far as Lizzie\r\nsaw, the whole thing might have to be done again. In hunting, to have\r\nridden is the pleasure;--and not simply to have ridden well, but to\r\nhave ridden better than others. "I call it very awkward ground,"\r\nsaid Mrs. Carbuncle, coming up. "It can\'t be compared to the Baron\'s\r\ncountry." "Stone walls four feet and a half high, and well built, are\r\nawkward," said the noble master.\r\n\r\nBut the hounds were away again, and Lizzie had got across the gap\r\nbefore Lucinda, who, indeed, made way for her hostess with a haughty\r\npoliteness which was not lost upon Lizzie. Lizzie could not stop to\r\nbeg pardon, but she would remember to do it in her prettiest way on\r\ntheir journey home. They were now on a track of open country, and\r\nthe pace was quicker even than before. The same three men were still\r\nleading, Morgan, Greystock, and Carstairs. Carstairs had slightly the\r\nbest of it; and of course Morgan swore afterwards that he was among\r\nthe hounds the whole run. "The scent was that good, there wasn\'t no\r\nputting of \'em off;--no thanks to him," said Morgan. "I \'ate to see\r\n\'em galloping, galloping, galloping, with no more eye to the \'ounds\r\nthan a pig. Any idiot can gallop, if he\'s got it under \'im." All\r\nwhich only signified that Jack Morgan didn\'t like to see any of his\r\nfield before him. There was need, indeed, now for galloping, and it\r\nmay be doubted whether Morgan himself was not doing his best. There\r\nwere about five or six in the second flight, and among these Lord\r\nGeorge and Lizzie were well placed. But Lucinda had pressed again\r\nahead. "Miss Roanoke had better have a care, or she\'ll blow her\r\nhorse," Lord George said. Lizzie didn\'t mind what happened to Miss\r\nRoanoke\'s horse, so that it could be made to go a little slower and\r\nfall behind. But Lucinda still pressed on, and her animal went with\r\na longer stride than Lizzie\'s horse.\r\n\r\nThey now crossed a road, descending a hill, and were again in a close\r\ncountry. A few low hedges seemed as nothing to Lizzie. She could\r\nsee her cousin gallop over them ahead of her, as though they were\r\nnothing; and her own horse, as he came to them, seemed to do exactly\r\nthe same. On a sudden they found themselves abreast with the\r\nhuntsman. "There\'s a biggish brook below there, my lord," said he.\r\nLizzie was charmed to hear it. Hitherto she had jumped all the big\r\nthings so easily, that it was a pleasure to hear of them. "How are\r\nwe to manage it?" asked Lord George. "It is rideable, my lord; but\r\nthere\'s a place about half a mile down. Let\'s see how\'ll they head.\r\nDrat it, my lord, they\'ve turned up, and we must have it or go back\r\nto the road." Morgan hurried on, showing that he meant to "have" it,\r\nas did also Lucinda. "Shall we go to the road?" said Lord George.\r\n"No, no!" said Lizzie. Lord George looked at her and at her horse,\r\nand then galloped after the huntsman and Lucinda. The horsey man with\r\nthe well-bred screw was first over the brook. The little animal could\r\ntake almost any amount of water, and his rider knew the spot. "He\'ll\r\ndo it like a bird," he had said to Greystock, and Greystock had\r\nfollowed him. Mr. MacFarlane\'s hired horse did do it like a bird. "I\r\nknow him, sir," said Carstairs. "Mr. Nappie gave \xa3250 for him down in\r\nNorthamptonshire last February;--bought him of Mr. Percival. You know\r\nMr. Percival, sir?" Frank knew neither Mr. Percival nor Mr. Nappie,\r\nand at this moment cared nothing for either of them. To him, at this\r\nmoment, Mr. MacFarlane, of Buchanan Street, Glasgow, was the best\r\nfriend he ever had.\r\n\r\nMorgan, knowing well the horse he rode, dropped him into the brook,\r\nfloundered and half swam through the mud and water, and scrambled out\r\nsafely on the other side. "He wouldn\'t have jumped it with me, if I\'d\r\nasked him ever so," he said afterwards. Lucinda rode at it, straight\r\nas an arrow, but her brute came to a dead balk, and, but that she\r\nsat well, would have thrown her into the stream. Lord George let\r\nLizzie take the leap before he took it, knowing that, if there were\r\nmisfortune, he might so best render help. To Lizzie it seemed as\r\nthough the river were the blackest, and the deepest, and the broadest\r\nthat ever ran. For a moment her heart quailed;--but it was but for a\r\nmoment. She shut her eyes, and gave the little horse his head. For a\r\nmoment she thought that she was in the water. Her horse was almost\r\nupright on the bank, with his hind-feet down among the broken ground,\r\nand she was clinging to his neck. But she was light, and the beast\r\nmade good his footing, and then she knew that she had done it. In\r\nthat moment of the scramble her heart had been so near her mouth that\r\nshe was almost choked. When she looked round, Lord George was already\r\nby her side. "You hardly gave him powder enough," he said, "but still\r\nhe did it beautifully. Good heavens! Miss Roanoke is in the river."\r\nLizzie looked back, and there, in truth, was Lucinda struggling with\r\nher horse in the water. They paused a moment, and then there were\r\nthree or four men assisting her. "Come on," said Lord George;--"there\r\nare plenty to take her out, and we couldn\'t get to her if we stayed."\r\n\r\n"I ought to stop," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"You couldn\'t get back if you gave your eyes for it," said Lord\r\nGeorge. "She\'s all right." So instigated, Lizzie followed her leader\r\nup the hill, and in a minute was close upon Morgan\'s heels.\r\n\r\nThe worst of doing a big thing out hunting is the fact that in nine\r\ncases out of ten they who don\'t do it are as well off as they who\r\ndo. If there were any penalty for riding round, or any mark given to\r\nthose who had ridden straight,--so that justice might in some sort\r\nbe done,--it would perhaps be better. When you have nearly broken\r\nyour neck to get to hounds, or made your horse exert himself beyond\r\nhis proper power, and then find yourself, within three minutes,\r\novertaking the hindmost ruck of horsemen on a road because of some\r\niniquitous turn that the fox has taken, the feeling is not pleasant.\r\nAnd some man who has not ridden at all, who never did ride at all,\r\nwill ask you where you have been; and his smile will give you the lie\r\nin your teeth if you make any attempt to explain the facts. Let it be\r\nsufficient for you at such a moment to feel that you are not ashamed\r\nof yourself. Self-respect will support a man even in such misery as\r\nthis.\r\n\r\nThe fox on this occasion, having crossed the river, had not left\r\nits bank, but had turned from his course up the stream, so that the\r\nleading spirits who had followed the hounds over the water came upon\r\na crowd of riders on the road in a space something short of a mile.\r\nMrs. Carbuncle, among others, was there, and had heard of Lucinda\'s\r\nmishap. She said a word to Lord George in anger, and Lord George\r\nanswered her. "We were over the river before it happened, and if we\r\nhad given our eyes we couldn\'t have got to her. Don\'t you make a fool\r\nof yourself!" The last words were spoken in a whisper, but Lizzie\'s\r\nsharp ears caught them.\r\n\r\n"I was obliged to do what I was told," said Lizzie apologetically.\r\n\r\n"It will be all right, dear Lady Eustace. Sir Griffin is with her. I\r\nam so glad you are going so well."\r\n\r\nThey were off again now, and the stupid fox absolutely went back\r\nacross the river. But, whether on one side or on the other, his\r\nstruggle for life was now in vain. Two years of happy, free existence\r\namidst the wilds of Craigattan had been allowed him. Twice previously\r\nhad he been "found," and the kindly storm or not less beneficent\r\nbrightness of the sun had enabled him to baffle his pursuers. Now\r\nthere had come one glorious day, and the common lot of mortals must\r\nbe his. A little spurt there was, back towards his own home,--just\r\nenough to give something of selectness to the few who saw him\r\nfall,--and then he fell. Among the few were Frank, and Lord George,\r\nand our Lizzie. Morgan was there, of course, and one of his whips.\r\nOf Ayrshire folk, perhaps five or six, and among them our friend\r\nMr. Carstairs. They had run him down close to the outbuildings of a\r\nfarm-yard, and they broke him up in the home paddock.\r\n\r\n"What do you think of hunting?" said Frank to his cousin.\r\n\r\n"It\'s divine!"\r\n\r\n"My cousin went pretty well, I think," he said to Lord George.\r\n\r\n"Like a celestial bird of Paradise. No one ever went better;--or I\r\nbelieve so well. You\'ve been carried rather nicely yourself."\r\n\r\n"Indeed I have," said Frank, patting his still palpitating horse,\r\n"and he\'s not to say tired now."\r\n\r\n"You\'ve taken it pretty well out of him, sir," said Carstairs. "There\r\nwas a little bit of hill that told when we got over the brook. I\r\nknow\'d you\'d find he\'d jump a bit."\r\n\r\n"I wonder whether he\'s to be bought?" asked Frank in his enthusiasm.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know the horse that isn\'t," said Mr. Carstairs,--"so long as\r\nyou don\'t stand at the figure."\r\n\r\nThey were collected on the farm road, and now, as they were speaking,\r\nthere was a commotion among the horses. A man, driving a little\r\nbuggy, was forcing his way along the road, and there was a sound of\r\nvoices, as though the man in the buggy were angry. And he was very\r\nangry. Frank, who was on foot by his horse\'s head, could see that the\r\nman was dressed for hunting, with a bright red coat and a flat hat,\r\nand that he was driving the pony with a hunting-whip. The man was\r\ntalking as he approached, but what he said did not much matter to\r\nFrank. It did not much matter to Frank till his new friend, Mr.\r\nCarstairs, whispered a word in his ear. "It\'s Nappie, by gum!" Then\r\nthere crept across Frank\'s mind an idea that there might be trouble\r\ncoming.\r\n\r\n"There he is," said Nappie, bringing his pony to a dead stop with a\r\nchuck, and jumping out of the buggy. "I say, you, sir; you\'ve stole\r\nmy \'orse!" Frank said not a word, but stood his ground with his hand\r\non the nag\'s bridle. "You\'ve stole my \'orse; you\'ve stole him off\r\nthe rail. And you\'ve been a-riding him all day. Yes, you \'ave. Did\r\never anybody see the like of this? Why, the poor beast can\'t a\'most\r\nstand!"\r\n\r\n"I got him from Mr. MacFarlane."\r\n\r\n"MacFarlane be blowed! You didn\'t do nothing of the kind. You stole\r\nhim off the rail at Stewarton. Yes, you did;--and him booked to\r\nKilmarnock. Where\'s a police? Who\'s to stand the like o\' this? I say,\r\nmy lord,--just look at this." A crowd had now been formed round poor\r\nFrank, and the master had come up. Mr. Nappie was a Huddersfield man,\r\nwho had come to Glasgow in the course of the last winter, and whose\r\npopularity in the hunting-field was not as yet quite so great as it\r\nperhaps might have been.\r\n\r\n"There\'s been a mistake, I suppose," said the master.\r\n\r\n"Mistake, my lord! Take a man\'s \'orse off the rail at Stewarton,\r\nand him booked to Kilmarnock, and ride him to a standstill! It\'s no\r\nmistake at all. It\'s \'orse-nobbling; that\'s what it is. Is there\r\nany police here, sir?" This he said, turning round to a farmer. The\r\nfarmer didn\'t deign any reply. "Perhaps you\'ll tell me your name,\r\nsir? if you\'ve got a name. No gen\'leman ever took a gen\'leman\'s \'orse\r\noff the rail like that."\r\n\r\n"Oh, Frank, do come away," said Lizzie, who was standing by.\r\n\r\n"We shall be all right in two minutes," said Frank.\r\n\r\n"No, we sha\'n\'t," said Mr. Nappie,--"nor yet in two hours. I\'ve asked\r\nwhat\'s your name?"\r\n\r\n"My name is--Greystock."\r\n\r\n"Greystockings," said Mr. Nappie more angrily than ever. "I don\'t\r\nbelieve in no such name. Where do you live?" Then somebody whispered\r\na word to him. "Member of Parliament,--is he? I don\'t care a ----. A\r\nmember of Parliament isn\'t to steal my \'orse off the rail, and him\r\nbooked to Kilmarnock. Now, my lord, what\'d you do if you was served\r\nlike that?" This was another appeal to the noble master.\r\n\r\n"I should express a hope that my horse had carried the gentleman as\r\nhe liked to be carried," said the master.\r\n\r\n"And he has,--carried me remarkably well," said Frank;--whereupon\r\nthere was a loud laugh among the crowd.\r\n\r\n"I wish he\'d broken the infernal neck of you, you scoundrel,\r\nyou,--that\'s what I do!" said Mr. Nappie. "There was my man, and my\r\n\'orse, and myself all booked from Glasgow to Kilmarnock;--and when I\r\ngot there what did the guard say to me?--why, just that a man in a\r\nblack coat had taken my horse off at Stewarton; and now I\'ve been\r\ndriving all about the country in that gig there for three hours!"\r\nWhen Mr. Nappie had got so far as this in his explanation he was\r\nalmost in tears. "I\'ll make \'im pay, that I will. Take your hand off\r\nmy horse\'s bridle, sir. Is there any gentleman here as would like to\r\ngive two hundred and eighty guineas for a horse, and then have him\r\nrid to a standstill by a fellow like that down from London? If you\'re\r\nin Parliament, why don\'t you stick to Parliament? I don\'t suppose\r\nhe\'s worth fifty pound this moment."\r\n\r\nFrank had all the while been endeavouring to explain the accident;\r\nhow he had ordered a horse from Mr. MacFarlane, and the rest of\r\nit,--as the reader will understand; but quite in vain. Mr. Nappie in\r\nhis wrath would not hear a word. But now that he spoke about money,\r\nFrank thought that he saw an opening. "Mr. Nappie," he said, "I\'ll\r\nbuy the horse for the price you gave for him."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll see you ----; extremely well ---- first," said Mr. Nappie.\r\n\r\nThe horse had now been surrendered to Mr. Nappie, and Frank suggested\r\nthat he might as well return to Kilmarnock in the gig, and pay for\r\nthe hire of it. But Mr. Nappie would not allow him to set a foot upon\r\nthe gig. "It\'s my gig for the day," said he, "and you don\'t touch it.\r\nYou shall foot it all the way back to Kilmarnock, Mr. Greystockings."\r\nBut Mr. Nappie, in making this threat, forgot that there were\r\ngentlemen there with second horses. Frank was soon mounted on one\r\nbelonging to Lord George, and Lord George\'s servant, at the corner of\r\nthe farm-yard, got into the buggy, and was driven back to Kilmarnock\r\nby the man who had accompanied poor Mr. Nappie in their morning\'s\r\nhunt on wheels after the hounds.\r\n\r\n"Upon my word, I was very sorry," said Frank as he rode back with his\r\nfriends to Kilmarnock; "and when I first really understood what had\r\nhappened, I would have done anything. But what could I say? It was\r\nimpossible not to laugh, he was so unreasonable."\r\n\r\n"I should have put my whip over his shoulder," said a stout farmer,\r\nmeaning to be civil to Frank Greystock.\r\n\r\n"Not after using it so often over his horse," said Lord George.\r\n\r\n"I never had to touch him once," said Frank.\r\n\r\n"And are you to have it all for nothing?" asked the thoughtful\r\nLizzie.\r\n\r\n"He\'ll send a bill in, you\'ll find," said a bystander.\r\n\r\n"Not he," said Lord George. "His grievance is worth more to him than\r\nhis money."\r\n\r\nNo bill did come to Frank, and he got his mount for nothing. When\r\nMr. MacFarlane was applied to, he declared that no letter ordering a\r\nhorse had been delivered in his establishment. From that day to this\r\nMr. Nappie\'s grey horse has had a great character in Ayrshire; but\r\nall the world there says that its owner never rides him as Frank\r\nGreystock rode him that day.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nVOLUME II\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIX\r\n\r\nSir Griffin Takes an Unfair Advantage\r\n\r\n\r\nWe must return to the unfortunate Lucinda, whom we last saw\r\nstruggling with her steed in the black waters of the brook which she\r\nattempted to jump. A couple of men were soon in after her, and she\r\nwas rescued and brought back to the side from which she had taken off\r\nwithout any great difficulty. She was neither hurt nor frightened,\r\nbut she was wet through; and for a while she was very unhappy,\r\nbecause it was not found quite easy to extricate her horse. During\r\nthe ten minutes of her agony, while the poor brute was floundering in\r\nthe mud, she had been quite disregardful of herself, and had almost\r\nseemed to think that Sir Griffin, who was with her, should go into\r\nthe water after her steed. But there were already two men in the\r\nwater, and three on the bank, and Sir Griffin thought that duty\r\nrequired him to stay by the young lady\'s side. "I don\'t care a bit\r\nabout myself," said Lucinda, "but if anything can be done for poor\r\nWarrior!" Sir Griffin assured her that "poor Warrior" was receiving\r\nthe very best attention; and then he pressed upon her the dangerous\r\ncondition in which she herself was standing,--quite wet through,\r\ncovered, as to her feet and legs, with mud, growing colder and colder\r\nevery minute. She touched her lips with a little brandy that somebody\r\ngave her, and then declared again that she cared for nothing but\r\npoor Warrior. At last poor Warrior was on his legs, with the water\r\ndripping from his black flanks, with his nose stained with mud,\r\nwith one of his legs a little cut,--and, alas! with the saddle wet\r\nthrough. Nevertheless, there was nothing to be done better than to\r\nride into Kilmarnock. The whole party must return to Kilmarnock,\r\nand, perhaps, if they hurried, she might be able to get her clothes\r\ndry before they would start by the train. Sir Griffin, of course,\r\naccompanied her, and they two rode into the town alone. Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle did hear of the accident soon after the occurrence, but had\r\nnot seen her niece; nor when she heard of it, could she have joined\r\nLucinda.\r\n\r\nIf anything would make a girl talk to a man, such a ducking as\r\nLucinda had had would do so. Such sudden events, when they come in\r\nthe shape of misfortune, or the reverse, generally have the effect\r\nof abolishing shyness for the time. Let a girl be upset with you in\r\na railway train, and she will talk like a Rosalind, though before\r\nthe accident she was as mute as death. But with Lucinda Roanoke the\r\naccustomed change did not seem to take place. When Sir Griffin had\r\nplaced her on her saddle, she would have trotted all the way into\r\nKilmarnock without a word if he would have allowed her. But he,\r\nat least, understood that such a joint misfortune should create\r\nconfidence,--for he, too, had lost the run, and he did not intend to\r\nlose his opportunity also. "I am so glad that I was near you," he\r\nsaid.\r\n\r\n"Oh, thank you, yes; it would have been bad to be alone."\r\n\r\n"I mean that I am glad that it was I," said Sir Griffin. "It\'s very\r\nhard even to get a moment to speak to you." They were now trotting\r\nalong on the road, and there were still three miles before them.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know," said she. "I\'m always with the other people."\r\n\r\n"Just so." And then he paused. "But I want to find you when you\'re\r\nnot with the other people. Perhaps, however, you don\'t like me."\r\n\r\nAs he paused for a reply, she felt herself bound to say something.\r\n"Oh, yes, I do," she said,--"as well as anybody else."\r\n\r\n"And is that all?"\r\n\r\n"I suppose so."\r\n\r\nAfter that he rode on for the best part of another mile before he\r\nspoke to her again. He had made up his mind that he would do it. He\r\nhardly knew why it was that he wanted her. He had not determined that\r\nhe was desirous of the charms or comfort of domestic life. He had\r\nnot even thought where he would live were he married. He had not\r\nsuggested to himself that Lucinda was a desirable companion, that her\r\ntemper would suit his, that her ways and his were sympathetic, or\r\nthat she would be a good mother to the future Sir Griffin Trewett.\r\nHe had seen that she was a very handsome girl, and therefore he had\r\nthought that he would like to possess her. Had she fallen like a ripe\r\nplum into his mouth, or shown herself ready so to fall, he would\r\nprobably have closed his lips and backed out of the affair. But the\r\ndifficulty no doubt added something to the desire. "I had hoped," he\r\nsaid, "that after knowing each other so long there might have been\r\nmore than that."\r\n\r\nShe was again driven to speak because he paused. "I don\'t know that\r\nthat makes much difference."\r\n\r\n"Miss Roanoke, you can\'t but understand what I mean."\r\n\r\n"I\'m sure I don\'t," said she.\r\n\r\n"Then I\'ll speak plainer."\r\n\r\n"Not now, Sir Griffin, because I\'m so wet."\r\n\r\n"You can listen to me even if you will not answer me. I am sure that\r\nyou know that I love you better than all the world. Will you be\r\nmine?" Then he moved on a little forward so that he might look back\r\ninto her face. "Will you allow me to think of you as my future wife?"\r\n\r\nMiss Roanoke was able to ride at a stone wall or at a river, and to\r\nride at either the second time when her horse balked the first. Her\r\nheart was big enough for that. But her heart was not big enough to\r\nenable her to give Sir Griffin an answer. Perhaps it was that, in\r\nregard to the river and the stone wall, she knew what she wanted; but\r\nthat, as to Sir Griffin, she did not. "I don\'t think this is a proper\r\ntime to ask," she said.\r\n\r\n"Why not?"\r\n\r\n"Because I am wet through and cold. It is taking an unfair\r\nadvantage."\r\n\r\n"I didn\'t mean to take any unfair advantage," said Sir Griffin\r\nscowling--"I thought we were alone--"\r\n\r\n"Oh, Sir Griffin, I am so tired!" As they were now entering\r\nKilmarnock, it was quite clear he could press her no further. They\r\nclattered up, therefore, to the hotel, and he busied himself in\r\ngetting a bedroom fire lighted, and in obtaining the services of the\r\nlandlady. A cup of tea was ordered, and toast, and in two minutes\r\nLucinda Roanoke was relieved from the presence of the baronet. "It\'s\r\na kind of thing a fellow doesn\'t quite understand," said Sir Griffin\r\nto himself. "Of course she means it, and why the devil can\'t she\r\nsay so?" He had no idea of giving up the chase, but he thought that\r\nperhaps he would take it out of her when she became Lady Tewett.\r\n\r\nThey were an hour at the inn before Mrs. Carbuncle and Lady Eustace\r\narrived, and during that hour Sir Griffin did not see Miss Roanoke.\r\nFor this there was, of course, ample reason. Under the custody of the\r\nlandlady, Miss Roanoke was being made dry and clean, and was by no\r\nmeans in a condition to receive a lover\'s vows. The baronet sent up\r\nhalf-a-dozen messages as he sauntered about the yard of the inn, but\r\nhe got no message in return. Lucinda, as she sat drinking her tea and\r\ndrying her clothes, did no doubt think about him,--but she thought\r\nabout him as little as she could. Of course, he would come again, and\r\nshe could make up her mind then. It was no doubt necessary that she\r\nshould do something. Her fortune, such as it was, would soon be spent\r\nin the adventure of finding a husband. She also had her ideas about\r\nlove, and had enough of sincerity about her to love a man thoroughly;\r\nbut it had seemed to her that all the men who came near her were\r\nmen whom she could not fail to dislike. She was hurried here and\r\nhurried there, and knew nothing of real social intimacies. As she\r\ntold her aunt in her wickedness, she would almost have preferred a\r\nshoemaker,--if she could have become acquainted with a shoemaker in\r\na manner that should be unforced and genuine. There was a savageness\r\nof antipathy in her to the mode of life which her circumstances had\r\nproduced for her. It was that very savageness which made her ride so\r\nhard, and which forbade her to smile and be pleasant to people whom\r\nshe could not like. And yet she knew that something must be done. She\r\ncould not afford to wait as other girls might do. Why not Sir Griffin\r\nas well as any other fool? It may be doubted whether she knew how\r\nobstinate, how hard, how cruel to a woman a fool can be.\r\n\r\nHer stockings had been washed and dried, and her boots and trousers\r\nwere nearly dry, when Mrs. Carbuncle, followed by Lizzie, rushed into\r\nthe room. "Oh, my darling, how are you?" said the aunt, seizing her\r\nniece in her arms.\r\n\r\n"I\'m only dirty now," said Lucinda.\r\n\r\n"We\'ve got off the biggest of the muck, my lady," said the landlady.\r\n\r\n"Oh, Miss Roanoke," said Lizzie, "I hope you don\'t think I behaved\r\nbadly in going on."\r\n\r\n"Everybody always goes on, of course," said Lucinda.\r\n\r\n"I did so pray Lord George to let me try and jump back to you. We\r\nwere over, you know, before it happened. But he said it was quite\r\nimpossible. We did wait till we saw you were out."\r\n\r\n"It didn\'t signify at all, Lady Eustace."\r\n\r\n"And I was so sorry when I went through the wall at the corner of\r\nthe wood before you. But I was so excited I hardly knew what I\r\nwas doing." Lucinda, who was quite used to these affairs in the\r\nhunting-field, simply nodded her acceptance of this apology. "But it\r\nwas a glorious run; wasn\'t it?"\r\n\r\n"Pretty well," said Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\n"Oh, it was glorious,--but then I got over the river. And oh, if you\r\nhad been there afterwards. There was such an adventure between a man\r\nin a gig and my cousin Frank." Then they all went to the train, and\r\nwere carried home to Portray.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XL\r\n\r\n"You Are Not Angry?"\r\n\r\n\r\nOn their journey back to Portray, the ladies were almost too tired\r\nfor talking; and Sir Griffin was sulky. Sir Griffin had as yet heard\r\nnothing about Greystock\'s adventure, and did not care to be told.\r\nBut when once they were at the castle, and had taken warm baths, and\r\nglasses of sherry, and got themselves dressed and had come down to\r\ndinner, they were all very happy. To Lizzie it had certainly been the\r\nmost triumphant day of her life. Her marriage with Sir Florian had\r\nbeen triumphant, but that was only a step to something good that was\r\nto come after. She then had at her own disposal her little wits and\r\nher prettiness, and a world before her in which, as it then seemed\r\nto her, there was a deal of pleasure if she could only reach it. Up\r\nto this period of her career she had hardly reached any pleasure;\r\nbut this day had been very pleasant. Lord George de Bruce Carruthers\r\nhad in truth been her Corsair, and she had found the thing which\r\nshe liked to do, and would soon know how to do. How glorious it was\r\nto jump over that black, yawning stream, and then to see Lucinda\r\nfall into it! And she could remember every jump, and her feeling of\r\necstasy as she landed on the right side. And she had by heart every\r\nkind word that Lord George had said to her,--and she loved the sweet,\r\npleasant, Corsair-like intimacy that had sprung up between them. She\r\nwondered whether Frank was at all jealous. It wouldn\'t be amiss that\r\nhe should be a little jealous. And then somebody had brought home in\r\nhis pocket the fox\'s brush, which the master of the hounds had told\r\nthe huntsman to give her. It was all delightful;--and so much more\r\ndelightful because Mrs. Carbuncle had not gone quite so well as she\r\nliked to go, and because Lucinda had fallen into the water.\r\n\r\nThey did not dine till past eight, and the ladies and gentlemen all\r\nleft the room together. Coffee and liqueurs were to be brought into\r\nthe drawing-room, and they were all to be intimate, comfortable,\r\nand at their ease;--all except Sir Griffin Tewett, who was still\r\nvery sulky. "Did he say anything?" Mrs. Carbuncle had asked. "Yes."\r\n"Well?" "He proposed; but of course I could not answer him when I was\r\nwet through." There had been but a moment, and in that moment this\r\nwas all that Lucinda would say.\r\n\r\n"Now I don\'t mean to stir again," said Lizzie, throwing herself into\r\na corner of a sofa, "till somebody carries me to bed. I never was\r\nso tired in all my life." She was tired, but there is a fatigue\r\nwhich is delightful as long as all the surroundings are pleasant and\r\ncomfortable.\r\n\r\n"I didn\'t call it a very hard day," said Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\n"You only killed one fox," said Mr. Emilius, pretending a\r\ndelightfully clerical ignorance, "and on Monday you killed four. Why\r\nshould you be tired?"\r\n\r\n"I suppose it was nearly twenty miles," said Frank, who was also\r\nignorant.\r\n\r\n"About ten, perhaps," said Lord George. "It was an hour and forty\r\nminutes, and there was a good bit of slow hunting after we had come\r\nback over the river."\r\n\r\n"I\'m sure it was thirty," said Lizzie, forgetting her fatigue in her\r\nenergy.\r\n\r\n"Ten is always better than twenty," said Lord George, "and five\r\ngenerally better than ten."\r\n\r\n"It was just whatever is best," said Lizzie. "I know Frank\'s friend,\r\nMr. Nappie, said it was twenty. By-the-bye, Frank, oughtn\'t we to\r\nhave asked Mr. Nappie home to dinner?"\r\n\r\n"I thought so," said Frank; "but I couldn\'t take the liberty myself."\r\n\r\n"I really think poor Mr. Nappie was very badly used," said Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle.\r\n\r\n"Of course he was," said Lord George;--"no man ever worse since\r\nhunting was invented. He was entitled to a dozen dinners and no end\r\nof patronage; but you see he took it out in calling your cousin Mr.\r\nGreystockings."\r\n\r\n"I felt that blow," said Frank.\r\n\r\n"I shall always call you Cousin Greystockings," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"It was hard," continued Lord George, "and I understood it all so\r\nwell when he got into a mess in his wrath about booking the horse\r\nto Kilmarnock. If the horse had been on the roadside, he or his men\r\ncould have protected him. He is put under the protection of a whole\r\nrailway company, and the company gives him up to the first fellow\r\nthat comes and asks for him."\r\n\r\n"It was cruel," said Frank.\r\n\r\n"If it had happened to me, I should have been very angry," said Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle.\r\n\r\n"But Frank wouldn\'t have had a horse at all," said Lizzie, "unless he\r\nhad taken Mr. Nappie\'s."\r\n\r\nLord George still continued his plea for Mr. Nappie. "There\'s\r\nsomething in that, certainly; but, still, I agree with Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle. If it had happened to me, I should--just have committed\r\nmurder and suicide. I can\'t conceive anything so terrible. It\'s all\r\nvery well for your noble master to talk of being civil, and hoping\r\nthat the horse had carried him well, and all that. There are\r\ncircumstances in which a man can\'t be civil. And then everybody\r\nlaughed at him! It\'s the way of the world. The lower you fall, the\r\nmore you\'re kicked."\r\n\r\n"What can I do for him?" asked Frank.\r\n\r\n"Put him down at your club, and order thirty dozen of grey shirtings\r\nfrom Nappie and Co., without naming the price."\r\n\r\n"He\'d send you grey stockings instead," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\nBut though Lizzie was in heaven, it behoved her to be careful. The\r\nCorsair was a very fine specimen of the Corsair breed;--about the\r\nbest Corsair she had ever seen, and had been devoted to her for the\r\nday. But these Corsairs are known to be dangerous, and it would not\r\nbe wise that she should sacrifice any future prospect of importance\r\non behalf of a feeling, which, no doubt, was founded on poetry, but\r\nwhich might too probably have no possible beneficial result. As far\r\nas she knew, the Corsair had not even an island of his own in the\r\n\xc6gean Sea. And, if he had, might not the island too probably have a\r\nMedora or two of its own? In a ride across the country the Corsair\r\nwas all that a Corsair should be; but knowing, as she did, but very\r\nlittle of the Corsair, she could not afford to throw over her cousin\r\nfor his sake. As she was leaving the drawing-room, she managed to say\r\none word to her cousin. "You were not angry with me because I got\r\nLord George to ride with me instead of you?"\r\n\r\n"Angry with you?"\r\n\r\n"I knew I should only be a hindrance to you."\r\n\r\n"It was a matter of course. He knows all about it, and I know\r\nnothing. I am very glad that you liked it so much."\r\n\r\n"I did like it;--and so did you. I was so glad you got that poor\r\nman\'s horse. You were not angry then?" They had now passed across the\r\nhall, and were on the bottom stair.\r\n\r\n"Certainly not."\r\n\r\n"And you are not angry for what happened before?" She did not look\r\ninto his face as she asked this question, but stood with her eyes\r\nfixed on the stair-carpet.\r\n\r\n"Indeed no."\r\n\r\n"Good night, Frank."\r\n\r\n"Good night, Lizzie." Then she went, and he returned to a room below\r\nwhich had been prepared for purposes of tobacco and soda-water and\r\nbrandy.\r\n\r\n"Why, Griff, you\'re rather out of sorts to-night," said Lord George\r\nto his friend, before Frank had joined them.\r\n\r\n"So would you be out of sorts if you\'d lost your run and had to pick\r\na young woman out of the water. I don\'t like young women when they\'re\r\ndamp and smell of mud."\r\n\r\n"You mean to marry her, I suppose?"\r\n\r\n"How would you like me to ask you questions? Do you mean to marry the\r\nwidow? And, if you do, what\'ll Mrs. Carbuncle say? And if you don\'t,\r\nwhat do you mean to do; and all the rest of it?"\r\n\r\n"As for marrying the widow, I should like to know the facts first.\r\nAs to Mrs. C., she wouldn\'t object in the least. I generally have\r\nmy horses so bitted that they can\'t very well object. And as to the\r\nother question, I mean to stay here for the next fortnight, and I\r\nadvise you to make it square with Miss Roanoke. Here\'s my lady\'s\r\ncousin; for a man who doesn\'t ride often, he went very well to-day."\r\n\r\n"I wonder if he\'d take a twenty-pound note if I sent it to him," said\r\nFrank, when they broke up for the night. "I don\'t like the idea of\r\nriding such a fellow\'s horse for nothing."\r\n\r\n"He\'ll bring an action against the railway, and then you can offer to\r\npay if you like." Mr. Nappie did bring an action against the railway,\r\nclaiming exorbitant damages;--but with what result, we need not\r\ntrouble ourselves to inquire.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLI\r\n\r\n"Likewise the Bears in Couples Agree"\r\n\r\n\r\nFrank Greystock stayed till the following Monday at Portray, but\r\ncould not be induced to hunt on the Saturday,--on which day the other\r\nsporting men and women went to the meet. He could not, he said, trust\r\nto that traitor MacFarlane, and he feared that his friend Mr. Nappie\r\nwould not give him another mount on the grey horse. Lizzie offered\r\nhim one of her two darlings,--an offer which he, of course, refused;\r\nand Lord George also proposed to put him up. But Frank averred that\r\nhe had ridden his hunt for that season, and would not jeopardise the\r\nlaurels he had gained. "And, moreover," said he, "I should not dare\r\nto meet Mr. Nappie in the field." So he remained at the castle and\r\ntook a walk with Mr. Emilius. Mr. Emilius asked a good many questions\r\nabout Portray, and exhibited the warmest sympathy with Lizzie\'s\r\nwidowed condition. He called her a "sweet, gay, unsophisticated,\r\nlight-hearted young thing." "She is very young," replied her cousin.\r\n"Yes," he continued, in answer to further questions; "Portray is\r\ncertainly very nice. I don\'t know what the income is. Well; yes.\r\nI should think it is over a thousand. Eight! No, I never heard it\r\nsaid that it was as much as that." When Mr. Emilius put it down\r\nin his mind as five, he was not void of acuteness, as very little\r\ninformation had been given to him.\r\n\r\nThere was a joke throughout the castle that Mr. Emilius had fallen in\r\nlove with Miss Macnulty. They had been a great deal together on those\r\nhunting days; and Miss Macnulty was unusually enthusiastic in praise\r\nof his manner and conversation. To her, also, had been addressed\r\nquestions as to Portray and its income, all of which she had answered\r\nto the best of her ability;--not intending to betray any secret, for\r\nshe had no secret to betray; but giving ordinary information on that\r\ncommonest of all subjects, our friends\' incomes. Then there had risen\r\na question whether there was a vacancy for such promotion to Miss\r\nMacnulty. Mrs. Carbuncle had certainly heard that there was a Mrs.\r\nEmilius. Lucinda was sure that there was not,--an assurance which\r\nmight have been derived from a certain eagerness in the reverend\r\ngentleman\'s demeanour to herself on a former occasion. To Lizzie, who\r\nat present was very good-natured, the idea of Miss Macnulty having\r\na lover, whether he were a married man or not, was very delightful.\r\n"I\'m sure I don\'t know what you mean," said Miss Macnulty. "I don\'t\r\nsuppose Mr. Emilius had any idea of the kind." Upon the whole,\r\nhowever, Miss Macnulty liked it.\r\n\r\nOn the Saturday nothing especial happened. Mr. Nappie was out on\r\nhis grey horse, and condescended to a little conversation with Lord\r\nGeorge. He wouldn\'t have minded, he said, if Mr. Greystock had come\r\nforward; but he did think Mr. Greystock hadn\'t come forward as he\r\nought to have done. Lord George professed that he had observed the\r\nsame thing; but then, as he whispered into Mr. Nappie\'s ear, Mr.\r\nGreystock was particularly known as a bashful man. "He didn\'t ride\r\nmy \'orse anyway bashful," said Mr. Nappie;--all of which was told at\r\ndinner in the evening, amidst a great deal of laughter. There had\r\nbeen nothing special in the way of sport, and Lizzie\'s enthusiasm for\r\nhunting, though still high, had gone down a few degrees below fever\r\nheat. Lord George had again coached her; but there had been no great\r\nneed for coaching, no losing of her breath, no cutting down of\r\nLucinda, no river, no big wall,--nothing, in short, very fast. They\r\nhad been much in a big wood; but Lizzie, in giving an account of the\r\nday to her cousin, had acknowledged that she had not quite understood\r\nwhat they were doing at any time. "It was a blowing of horns and\r\na galloping up and down all the day," she said; "and then Morgan\r\ngot cross again and scolded all the people. But there was one nice\r\npaling, and Dandy flew over it beautifully. Two men tumbled down, and\r\none of them was a good deal hurt. It was very jolly;--but not at all\r\nlike Wednesday."\r\n\r\nNor had it been like Wednesday to Lucinda Roanoke, who did not fall\r\ninto the water, and who did accept Sir Griffin when he again proposed\r\nto her in Sarkie wood. A great deal had been said to Lucinda on the\r\nThursday and the Friday by Mrs. Carbuncle,--which had not been taken\r\nat all in good part by Lucinda. On those days Lucinda kept as much as\r\nshe could out of Sir Griffin\'s way, and almost snapped at the baronet\r\nwhen he spoke to her. Sir Griffin swore to himself that he wasn\'t\r\ngoing to be treated that way. He\'d have her, by George! There are\r\nmen in whose love a good deal of hatred is mixed;--who love as the\r\nhuntsman loves the fox, towards the killing of which he intends to\r\nuse all his energies and intellects. Mrs. Carbuncle, who did not\r\nquite understand the sort of persistency by which a Sir Griffin can\r\nbe possessed, feared greatly that Lucinda was about to lose her\r\nprize, and spoke out accordingly. "Will you, then, just have the\r\nkindness to tell me what it is you propose to yourself?" asked Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t propose anything."\r\n\r\n"And where will you go when your money\'s done?"\r\n\r\n"Just where I am going now!" said Lucinda. By which it may be feared\r\nthat she indicated a place to which she should not on such an\r\noccasion have made an allusion.\r\n\r\n"You don\'t like anybody else?" suggested Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t like anybody or anything," said Lucinda.\r\n\r\n"Yes, you do;--you like horses to ride, and dresses to wear."\r\n\r\n"No, I don\'t. I like hunting because, perhaps, some day I may break\r\nmy neck. It\'s no use your looking like that, Aunt Jane. I know what\r\nit all means. If I could break my neck it would be the best thing for\r\nme."\r\n\r\n"You\'ll break my heart, Lucinda."\r\n\r\n"Mine\'s broken long ago."\r\n\r\n"If you\'ll accept Sir Griffin, and just get a home round yourself,\r\nyou\'ll find that everything will be happy. It all comes from the\r\ndreadful uncertainty. Do you think I have suffered nothing? Carbuncle\r\nis always threatening that he\'ll go back to New York, and as for Lord\r\nGeorge, he treats me that way I\'m sometimes afraid to show my face."\r\n\r\n"Why should you care for Lord George?"\r\n\r\n"It\'s all very well to say, why should I care for him. I don\'t\r\ncare for him, only one doesn\'t want to quarrel with one\'s friends.\r\nCarbuncle says he owes him money."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t believe it," said Lucinda.\r\n\r\n"And he says Carbuncle owes him money."\r\n\r\n"I do believe that," said Lucinda.\r\n\r\n"Between it all, I don\'t know which way to be turning. And now, when\r\nthere\'s this great opening for you, you won\'t know your own mind."\r\n\r\n"I know my mind well enough."\r\n\r\n"I tell you you\'ll never have such another chance. Good looks isn\'t\r\neverything. You\'ve never a word to say to anybody; and when a man\r\ndoes come near you, you\'re as savage and cross as a bear."\r\n\r\n"Go on, Aunt Jane."\r\n\r\n"What with your hatings and dislikings, one would suppose you didn\'t\r\nthink God Almighty made men at all."\r\n\r\n"He made some of \'em very bad," said Lucinda. "As for some others,\r\nthey\'re only half made. What can Sir Griffin do, do you suppose?"\r\n\r\n"He\'s a gentleman."\r\n\r\n"Then if I were a man, I should wish not to be a gentleman; that\'s\r\nall. I\'d a deal sooner marry a man like that huntsman, who has\r\nsomething to do and knows how to do it." Again she said, "Don\'t worry\r\nany more, Aunt Jane. It doesn\'t do any good. It seems to me that to\r\nmake myself Sir Griffin\'s wife would be impossible; but I\'m sure\r\nyour talking won\'t do it." Then her aunt left her, and, having met\r\nLord George, at his bidding went and made civil speeches to Lizzie\r\nEustace.\r\n\r\nThat was on the Friday afternoon. On the Saturday afternoon Sir\r\nGriffin, biding his time, found himself, in a ride with Lucinda,\r\nsufficiently far from other horsemen for his purpose. He wasn\'t going\r\nto stand any more nonsense. He was entitled to an answer, and he\r\nknew that he was entitled, by his rank and position, to a favourable\r\nanswer. Here was a girl who, as far as he knew, was without a\r\nshilling, of whose birth and parentage nobody knew anything, who\r\nhad nothing but her beauty to recommend her,--nothing but that and\r\na certain capacity for carrying herself in the world as he thought\r\nladies should carry themselves,--and she was to give herself airs\r\nwith him, and expect him to propose to her half a dozen times! By\r\nGeorge!--he had a very good mind to go away and let her find out\r\nher mistake. And he would have done so,--only that he was a man who\r\nalways liked to have all that he wanted. It was intolerable to him\r\nthat anybody should refuse him anything. "Miss Roanoke," he said; and\r\nthen he paused.\r\n\r\n"Sir Griffin," said Lucinda, bowing her head.\r\n\r\n"Perhaps you will condescend to remember what I had the honour of\r\nsaying to you as we rode into Kilmarnock last Wednesday."\r\n\r\n"I had just been dragged out of a river, Sir Griffin, and I don\'t\r\nthink any girl ought to be asked to remember what was said to her in\r\nthat condition."\r\n\r\n"If I say it again now, will you remember?"\r\n\r\n"I cannot promise, Sir Griffin."\r\n\r\n"Will you give me an answer?"\r\n\r\n"That must depend."\r\n\r\n"Come;--I will have an answer. When a man tells a lady that he\r\nadmires her, and asks her to be his wife, he has a right to an\r\nanswer. Don\'t you think that in such circumstances a man has a right\r\nto expect an answer?"\r\n\r\nLucinda hesitated for a moment, and he was beginning again to\r\nremonstrate impatiently, when she altered her tone, and replied to\r\nhim seriously, "In such circumstances a gentleman has a right to\r\nexpect an answer."\r\n\r\n"Then give me one. I admire you above all the world, and I ask you to\r\nbe my wife. I\'m quite in earnest."\r\n\r\n"I know that you are in earnest, Sir Griffin. I would do neither you\r\nnor myself the wrong of supposing that it could be otherwise."\r\n\r\n"Very well then. Will you accept the offer that I make you?"\r\n\r\nAgain she paused. "You have a right to an answer,--of course; but it\r\nmay be so difficult to give it. It seems to me that you have hardly\r\nrealised how serious a question it is."\r\n\r\n"Haven\'t I, though! By George, it is serious!"\r\n\r\n"Will it not be better for you to think it over again?"\r\n\r\nHe now hesitated for a moment. Perhaps it might be better. Should she\r\ntake him at his word there would be no going back from it. But Lord\r\nGeorge knew that he had proposed before. Lord George had learned\r\nthis from Mrs. Carbuncle, and had shown that he knew it. And then,\r\ntoo,--he had made up his mind about it. He wanted her, and he meant\r\nto have her. "It requires no more thinking with me, Lucinda. I\'m not\r\na man who does things without thinking; and when I have thought I\r\ndon\'t want to think again. There\'s my hand;--will you have it?"\r\n\r\n"I will," said Lucinda, putting her hand into his. He no sooner felt\r\nher assurance than his mind misgave him that he had been precipitate,\r\nthat he had been rash, and that she had taken advantage of him. After\r\nall, how many things are there in the world more precious than a\r\nhandsome girl. And she had never told him that she loved him.\r\n\r\n"I suppose you love me?" he asked.\r\n\r\n"H\'sh!--here they all are." The hand was withdrawn, but not before\r\nboth Mrs. Carbuncle and Lady Eustace had seen it.\r\n\r\nMrs. Carbuncle, in her great anxiety, bided her time, keeping close\r\nto her niece. Perhaps she felt that if the two were engaged, it might\r\nbe well to keep the lovers separated for awhile, lest they should\r\nquarrel before the engagement should have been so confirmed by the\r\nauthority of friends as to be beyond the power of easy annihilation.\r\nLucinda rode quite demurely with the crowd. Sir Griffin remained near\r\nher, but without speaking. Lizzie whispered to Lord George that there\r\nhad been a proposal. Mrs. Carbuncle sat in stately dignity on her\r\nhorse, as though there were nothing which at that moment especially\r\nengaged her attention. An hour almost had passed before she was able\r\nto ask the important question, "Well;--what have you said to him?"\r\n\r\n"Oh;--just what you would have me."\r\n\r\n"You have accepted him?"\r\n\r\n"I suppose I was obliged. At any rate I did. You shall know\r\none thing, Aunt Jane, at any rate, and I hope it will make you\r\ncomfortable. I hate a good many people; but of all the people in the\r\nworld I hate Sir Griffin Tewett the worst."\r\n\r\n"Nonsense, Lucinda."\r\n\r\n"It shall be nonsense, if you please; but it\'s true. I shall have to\r\nlie to him,--but there shall be no lying to you, however much you may\r\nwish it. I hate him!"\r\n\r\nThis was very grim, but Mrs. Carbuncle quite understood that to\r\npersons situated in great difficulty things might be grim. A\r\ncertain amount of grimness must be endured. And she knew, too, that\r\nLucinda was not a girl to be driven without showing something of an\r\nintractable spirit in harness. Mrs. Carbuncle had undertaken the\r\ndriving of Lucinda, and had been not altogether unsuccessful. The\r\nthing so necessary to be done was now effected. Her niece was engaged\r\nto a man with a title, to a man reported to have a fortune, to a man\r\nof family, and a man of the world. Now that the engagement was made,\r\nthe girl could not go back from it, and it was for Mrs. Carbuncle to\r\nsee that neither should Sir Griffin go back. Her first steps must be\r\ntaken at once. The engagement should be made known to all the party,\r\nand should be recognised by some word spoken between herself and\r\nthe lover. The word between herself and the lover must be the first\r\nthing. She herself, personally, was not very fond of Sir Griffin; but\r\non such an occasion as this she could smile and endure the bear. Sir\r\nGriffin was a bear,--but so also was Lucinda. "The rabbits and hares\r\nAll go in pairs; And likewise the bears In couples agree." Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle consoled herself with the song, and assured herself that it\r\nwould all come right. No doubt the she-bears were not as civil to the\r\nhe-bears as the turtle doves are to each other. It was, perhaps, her\r\nmisfortune that her niece was not a turtle dove; but, such as she\r\nwas, the best had been done for her. "Dear Sir Griffin," she said on\r\nthe first available opportunity, not caring much for the crowd, and\r\nalmost desirous that her very words should be overheard, "my darling\r\ngirl has made me so happy by what she has told me."\r\n\r\n"She hasn\'t lost any time," said Sir Griffin.\r\n\r\n"Of course she would lose no time. She is the same to me as a\r\ndaughter. I have no child of my own, and she is everything to me. May\r\nI tell you that you are the luckiest man in Europe?"\r\n\r\n"It isn\'t every girl that would suit me, Mrs. Carbuncle."\r\n\r\n"I am sure of that. I have noticed how particular you are. I won\'t\r\nsay a word of Lucinda\'s beauty. Men are better judges of that than\r\nwomen; but for high, chivalrous spirit, for true principle and\r\nnobility, and what I call downright worth, I don\'t think you will\r\neasily find her superior. And she is as true as steel."\r\n\r\n"And about as hard, I was beginning to think."\r\n\r\n"A girl like that, Sir Griffin, does not give herself away easily.\r\nYou will not like her the less for that now that you are the\r\npossessor. She is very young, and has known my wish that she should\r\nnot engage herself to any one quite yet. But, as it is, I cannot\r\nregret anything."\r\n\r\n"I daresay not," said Sir Griffin.\r\n\r\nThat the man was a bear was a matter of course, and bears probably\r\ndo not themselves know how bearish they are. Sir Griffin, no doubt,\r\nwas unaware of the extent of his own rudeness. And his rudeness\r\nmattered but little to Mrs. Carbuncle, so long as he acknowledged the\r\nengagement. She had not expected a lover\'s raptures from the one more\r\nthan from the other. And was not there enough in the engagement to\r\nsatisfy her? She allowed, therefore, no cloud to cross her brow as\r\nshe rode up alongside of Lord George. "Sir Griffin has proposed,\r\nand she has accepted him," she said in a whisper. She was not now\r\ndesirous that any one should hear her but he to whom she spoke.\r\n\r\n"Of course she has," said Lord George.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know about that, George. Sometimes I thought she would, and\r\nsometimes that she wouldn\'t. You have never understood Lucinda."\r\n\r\n"I hope Griff will understand her,--that\'s all. And now that the\r\nthing is settled, you\'ll not trouble me about it any more. Their woes\r\nbe on their own head. If they come to blows Lucinda will thrash him,\r\nI don\'t doubt. But while it\'s simply a matter of temper and words,\r\nshe won\'t find Tewett so easy-going as he looks."\r\n\r\n"I believe they\'ll do very well together."\r\n\r\n"Perhaps they will. There\'s no saying who may do well together. You\r\nand Carbuncle get on \xe0 merveille. When is it to be?"\r\n\r\n"Of course nothing is settled yet."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t be too hard about settlements, or, maybe, he\'ll find a way of\r\nwriggling out. When a girl without a shilling asks very much, the\r\nworld supports a man for breaking his engagement. Let her pretend to\r\nbe indifferent about it;--that will be the way to keep him firm."\r\n\r\n"What is his income, George?"\r\n\r\n"I haven\'t an idea. There never was a closer man about money. I\r\nbelieve he must have the bulk of the Tewett property some day.
