When he had given her so much, and she had nothing but her\r\nconfidence to give in return, would she stint him in that? There can\r\nbe no love, she said, without confidence, and it was the pride of her\r\nheart to love him.\r\n\r\nThe circumstances of her present life were desperately weary to her.\r\nShe could hardly understand why it was that Lady Linlithgow should\r\ndesire her presence. She was required to do nothing. She had no\r\nduties to perform, and, as it seemed to her, was of no use to any\r\none. The countess would not even allow her to be of ordinary service\r\nin the house. Lady Linlithgow, as she had said of herself, poked her\r\nown fires, carved her own meat, lit her own candles, opened and shut\r\nthe doors for herself, wrote her own letters,--and did not even like\r\nto have books read to her. She simply chose to have some one sitting\r\nwith her to whom she could speak and make little cross-grained,\r\nsarcastic, and ill-natured remarks. There was no company at the house\r\nin Brook Street, and when the countess herself went out, she went\r\nout alone. Even when she had a cab to go shopping, or to make calls,\r\nshe rarely asked Lucy to go with her,--and was benevolent chiefly\r\nin this,--that if Lucy chose to walk round the square, or as far\r\nas the park, her ladyship\'s maid was allowed to accompany her for\r\nprotection. Poor Lucy often told herself that such a life would be\r\nunbearable,--were it not for the supreme satisfaction she had in\r\nremembering her lover. And then the arrangement had been made only\r\nfor six months. She did not feel quite assured of her fate at the end\r\nof those six months, but she believed that there would come to her a\r\nresidence in a sort of outer garden to that sweet Elysium in which\r\nshe was to pass her life. The Elysium would be Frank\'s house; and the\r\nouter garden was the deanery at Bobsborough.\r\n\r\nTwice during the three months Lady Fawn, with two of the girls, came\r\nto call upon her. On the first occasion she was unluckily out, taking\r\nadvantage of the protection of her ladyship\'s maid in getting a\r\nlittle air. Lady Linlithgow had also been away, and Lady Fawn had\r\nseen no one. Afterwards, both Lucy and her ladyship were found at\r\nhome, and Lady Fawn was full of graciousness and affection. "I\r\ndaresay you\'ve got something to say to each other," said Lady\r\nLinlithgow, "and I\'ll go away."\r\n\r\n"Pray don\'t let us disturb you," said Lady Fawn.\r\n\r\n"You\'d only abuse me if I didn\'t," said Lady Linlithgow.\r\n\r\nAs soon as she was gone Lucy rushed into her friend\'s arms.\r\n\r\n"It is so nice to see you again."\r\n\r\n"Yes, my dear, isn\'t it? I did come before, you know."\r\n\r\n"You have been so good to me! To see you again is like the violets\r\nand primroses." She was crouching close to Lady Fawn, with her hand\r\nin that of her friend Lydia. "I haven\'t a word to say against Lady\r\nLinlithgow, but it is like winter here, after dear Richmond."\r\n\r\n"Well;--we think we\'re prettier at Richmond," said Lady Fawn.\r\n\r\n"There were such hundreds of things to do there," said Lucy. "After\r\nall, what a comfort it is to have things to do."\r\n\r\n"Why did you come away?" said Lydia.\r\n\r\n"Oh, I was obliged. You mustn\'t scold me now that you have come to\r\nsee me."\r\n\r\nThere were a hundred things to be said about Fawn Court and the\r\nchildren, and a hundred more things about Lady Linlithgow and Bruton\r\nStreet. Then, at last, Lady Fawn asked the one important question.\r\n"And now, my dear, what about Mr. Greystock?"\r\n\r\n"Oh,--I don\'t know;--nothing particular, Lady Fawn. It\'s just as it\r\nwas, and I am--quite satisfied."\r\n\r\n"You see him sometimes?"\r\n\r\n"No, never. I have not seen him since the last time he came down to\r\nRichmond. Lady Linlithgow doesn\'t allow--followers." There was a\r\npleasant little spark of laughter in Lucy\'s eye as she said this,\r\nwhich would have told to any bystander the whole story of the\r\naffection which existed between her and Lady Fawn.\r\n\r\n"That\'s very ill-natured," said Lydia.\r\n\r\n"And he\'s a sort of cousin, too," said Lady Fawn.\r\n\r\n"That\'s just the reason why," said Lucy, explaining. "Of course, Lady\r\nLinlithgow thinks that her sister\'s nephew can do better than marry\r\nher companion. It\'s a matter of course she should think so. What I am\r\nmost afraid of is that the dean and Mrs. Greystock should think so\r\ntoo."\r\n\r\nNo doubt the dean and Mrs. Greystock would think so;--Lady Fawn\r\nwas very sure of that. Lady Fawn was one of the best women\r\nbreathing,--unselfish, motherly, affectionate, appreciative, and\r\nnever happy unless she was doing good to somebody. It was her nature\r\nto be soft, and kind, and beneficent. But she knew very well that if\r\nshe had had a son,--a second son,--situated as was Frank Greystock,\r\nshe would not wish him to marry a girl without a penny, who was\r\nforced to earn her bread by being a governess. The sacrifice on Mr.\r\nGreystock\'s part would, in her estimation, be so great, that she did\r\nnot believe that it would be made. Woman-like, she regarded the man\r\nas being so much more important than the woman, that she could not\r\nthink that Frank Greystock would devote himself simply to such a\r\none as Lucy Morris. Had Lady Fawn been asked which was the better\r\ncreature of the two, her late governess or the rising barrister who\r\nhad declared himself to be that governess\'s lover, she would have\r\nsaid that no man could be better than Lucy. She knew Lucy\'s worth\r\nand goodness so well that she was ready herself to do any act of\r\nfriendship on behalf of one so sweet and excellent. For herself and\r\nher girls Lucy was a companion and friend in every way satisfactory.\r\nBut was it probable that a man of the world, such as was Frank\r\nGreystock, a rising man, a member of Parliament, one who, as\r\neverybody knew, was especially in want of money,--was it probable\r\nthat such a man as this would make her his wife just because she was\r\ngood, and worthy, and sweet-natured? No doubt the man had said that\r\nhe would do so,--and Lady Fawn\'s fears betrayed on her ladyship\'s\r\npart a very bad opinion of men in general. It may seem to be a\r\nparadox to assert that such bad opinion sprung from the high idea\r\nwhich she entertained of the importance of men in general;--but it\r\nwas so. She had but one son, and of all her children he was the least\r\nworthy; but he was more important to her than all her daughters.\r\nBetween her own girls and Lucy she hardly made any difference;--but\r\nwhen her son had chosen to quarrel with Lucy it had been necessary to\r\nsend Lucy to eat her meals up-stairs. She could not believe that Mr.\r\nGreystock should think so much of such a little girl as to marry her.\r\nMr. Greystock would no doubt behave very badly in not doing so;--but\r\nthen men do so often behave very badly! And at the bottom of her\r\nheart she almost thought that they might be excused for doing so.\r\nAccording to her view of things, a man out in the world had so many\r\nthings to think of, and was so very important, that he could hardly\r\nbe expected to act at all times with truth and sincerity.\r\n\r\nLucy had suggested that the dean and Mrs. Greystock would dislike the\r\nmarriage, and upon that hint Lady Fawn spoke. "Nothing is settled, I\r\nsuppose, as to where you are to go when the six months are over?"\r\n\r\n"Nothing as yet, Lady Fawn."\r\n\r\n"They haven\'t asked you to go to Bobsborough?"\r\n\r\nLucy would have given the world not to blush as she answered, but she\r\ndid blush. "Nothing is fixed, Lady Fawn."\r\n\r\n"Something should be fixed, Lucy. It should be settled by this\r\ntime;--shouldn\'t it, dear? What will you do without a home, if at the\r\nend of the six months Lady Linlithgow should say that she doesn\'t\r\nwant you any more?"\r\n\r\nLucy certainly did not look forward to a condition in which Lady\r\nLinlithgow should be the arbitress of her destiny. The idea of\r\nstaying with the countess was almost as bad to her as that of finding\r\nherself altogether homeless. She was still blushing, feeling herself\r\nto be hot and embarrassed. But Lady Fawn sat, waiting for an answer.\r\nTo Lucy there was only one answer possible. "I will ask Mr. Greystock\r\nwhat I am to do." Lady Fawn shook her head. "You don\'t believe in Mr.\r\nGreystock, Lady Fawn; but I do."\r\n\r\n"My darling girl," said her ladyship, making the special speech for\r\nthe sake of making which she had travelled up from Richmond,--"it is\r\nnot exactly a question of belief, but one of common prudence. No girl\r\nshould allow herself to depend on a man before she is married to him.\r\nBy doing so she will be apt to lose even his respect."\r\n\r\n"I didn\'t mean for money," said Lucy, hotter than ever, with her eyes\r\nfull of tears.\r\n\r\n"She should not be in any respect at his disposal till he has bound\r\nhimself to her at the altar. You may believe me, Lucy, when I tell\r\nyou so. It is only because I love you so that I say so."\r\n\r\n"I know that, Lady Fawn."\r\n\r\n"When your time here is over, just put up your things and come back\r\nto Richmond. You need fear nothing with us. Frederic quite liked\r\nyour way of parting with him at last, and all that little affair is\r\nforgotten. At Fawn Court you\'ll be safe;--and you shall be happy,\r\ntoo, if we can make you happy. It\'s the proper place for you."\r\n\r\n"Of course you\'ll come," said Diana Fawn.\r\n\r\n"You\'ll be the worst little thing in the world if you don\'t," said\r\nLydia. "We don\'t know what to do without you. Do we, mamma?"\r\n\r\n"Lucy will please us all by coming back to her old home," said Lady\r\nFawn. The tears were now streaming down Lucy\'s face, so that she was\r\nhardly able to say a word in answer to all this kindness. And she did\r\nnot know what word to say. Were she to accept the offer made to her,\r\nand acknowledge that she could do nothing better than creep back\r\nunder her old friend\'s wing,--would she not thereby be showing\r\nthat she doubted her lover? And yet she could not go to the dean\'s\r\nhouse unless the dean and his wife were pleased to take her; and,\r\nsuspecting as she did, that they would not be pleased, would it\r\nbecome her to throw upon her lover the burthen of finding for her\r\na home with people who did not want her? Had she been welcome at\r\nBobsborough, Mrs. Greystock would surely have so told her before\r\nthis. "You needn\'t say a word, my dear," said Lady Fawn. "You\'ll\r\ncome, and there\'s an end of it."\r\n\r\n"But you don\'t want me any more," said Lucy, from amidst her sobs.\r\n\r\n"That\'s just all that you know about it," said Lydia. "We do want\r\nyou,--more than anything."\r\n\r\n"I wonder whether I may come in now," said Lady Linlithgow, entering\r\nthe room. As it was the countess\'s own drawing-room, as it was now\r\nmid-winter, and as the fire in the dining-room had been allowed,\r\nas was usual, to sink almost to two hot coals, the request was not\r\nunreasonable. Lady Fawn was profuse in her thanks, and immediately\r\nbegan to account for Lucy\'s tears, pleading their dear friendship and\r\ntheir long absence, and poor Lucy\'s emotional state of mind. Then\r\nshe took her leave, and Lucy, as soon as she had been kissed by her\r\nfriends outside the drawing-room door, took herself to her bedroom,\r\nand finished her tears in the cold.\r\n\r\n"Have you heard the news?" said Lady Linlithgow to her companion\r\nabout a month after this. Lady Linlithgow had been out, and asked the\r\nquestion immediately on her return. Lucy, of course, had heard no\r\nnews. "Lizzie Eustace has just come back to London, and has had all\r\nher jewels stolen on the road."\r\n\r\n"The diamonds?" asked Lucy, with amaze.\r\n\r\n"Yes,--the Eustace diamonds! And they didn\'t belong to her any more\r\nthan they did to you. They\'ve been taken, anyway; and from what I\r\nhear I shouldn\'t be at all surprised if she had arranged the whole\r\nmatter herself."\r\n\r\n"Arranged that they should be stolen?"\r\n\r\n"Just that, my dear. It would be the very thing for Lizzie Eustace to\r\ndo. She\'s clever enough for anything."\r\n\r\n"But, Lady Linlithgow--"\r\n\r\n"I know all about that. Of course, it would be very wicked, and if\r\nit were found out she\'d be put in the dock and tried for her life.\r\nIt is just what I expect she\'ll come to some of these days. She has\r\ngone and got up a friendship with some disreputable people, and\r\nwas travelling with them. There was a man who calls himself Lord\r\nGeorge de Bruce Carruthers. I know him, and can remember when he was\r\nerrand-boy to a disreputable lawyer at Aberdeen." This assertion was\r\na falsehood on the part of the countess; Lord George had never been\r\nan errand-boy, and the Aberdeen lawyer,--as provincial Scotch lawyers\r\ngo,--had been by no means disreputable. "I\'m told that the police\r\nthink that he has got them."\r\n\r\n"How very dreadful!"\r\n\r\n"Yes;--it\'s dreadful enough. At any rate, men got into Lizzie\'s room\r\nat night and took away the iron box and diamonds and all. It may be\r\nshe was asleep at the time;--but she\'s one of those who pretty nearly\r\nalways sleep with one eye open."\r\n\r\n"She can\'t be so bad as that, Lady Linlithgow."\r\n\r\n"Perhaps not. We shall see. They had just begun a lawsuit about the\r\ndiamonds,--to get them back. And then all at once,--they\'re stolen.\r\nIt looks what the men call--fishy. I\'m told that all the police in\r\nLondon are up about it."\r\n\r\nOn the very next day who should come to Brook Street, but Lizzie\r\nEustace herself. She and her aunt had quarrelled, and they hated\r\neach other;--but the old woman had called upon Lizzie, advising her,\r\nas the reader will perhaps remember, to give up the diamonds, and\r\nnow Lizzie returned the visit. "So you\'re here, installed in poor\r\nMacnulty\'s place," began Lizzie to her old friend, the countess at\r\nthe moment being out of the room.\r\n\r\n"I am staying with your aunt for a few months,--as her companion. Is\r\nit true, Lizzie, that all your diamonds have been stolen?" Lizzie\r\ngave an account of the robbery, true in every respect, except in\r\nregard to the contents of the box. Poor Lizzie had been wronged in\r\nthat matter by the countess, for the robbery had been quite genuine.\r\nThe man had opened her room and taken her box, and she had slept\r\nthrough it all. And then the broken box had been found, and was in\r\nthe hands of the police, and was evidence of the fact.\r\n\r\n"People seem to think it possible," said Lizzie, "that Mr. Camperdown\r\nthe lawyer arranged it all." As this suggestion was being made Lady\r\nLinlithgow came in, and then Lizzie repeated the whole story of the\r\nrobbery. Though the aunt and niece were open and declared enemies,\r\nthe present circumstances were so peculiar and full of interest that\r\nconversation, for a time almost amicable, took place between them.\r\n"As the diamonds were so valuable, I thought it right, Aunt Susanna,\r\nto come and tell you myself."\r\n\r\n"It\'s very good of you, but I\'d heard it already. I was telling Miss\r\nMorris yesterday what very odd things there are being said about it."\r\n\r\n"Weren\'t you very much frightened?" asked Lucy.\r\n\r\n"You see, my child, I knew nothing about it till it was all over. The\r\nman cut the bit out of the door in the most beautiful way, without my\r\never hearing the least sound of the saw."\r\n\r\n"And you that sleep so light," said the countess.\r\n\r\n"They say that perhaps something was put into the wine at dinner to\r\nmake me sleep."\r\n\r\n"Ah!" ejaculated the countess, who did not for a moment give up her\r\nown erroneous suspicion;--"very likely."\r\n\r\n"And they do say these people can do things without making the\r\nslightest tittle of noise. At any rate, the box was gone."\r\n\r\n"And the diamonds?" asked Lucy.\r\n\r\n"Oh yes;--of course. And now there is such a fuss about it! The\r\npolice keep on coming to me almost every day."\r\n\r\n"And what do the police think?" asked Lady Linlithgow. "I\'m told that\r\nthey have their suspicions."\r\n\r\n"No doubt they have their suspicions," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"You travelled up with friends, I suppose."\r\n\r\n"Oh yes,--with Lord George de Bruce Carruthers; and with Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle,--who is my particular friend, and with Lucinda Roanoke,\r\nwho is just going to be married to Sir Griffin Tewett. We were quite\r\na large party."\r\n\r\n"And Macnulty?"\r\n\r\n"No. I left Miss Macnulty at Portray with my darling. They thought he\r\nhad better remain a little longer in Scotland."\r\n\r\n"Ah, yes;--perhaps Lord George de Bruce Carruthers does not care for\r\nbabies. I can easily believe that. I wish Macnulty had been with\r\nyou."\r\n\r\n"Why do you wish that?" said Lizzie, who already was beginning\r\nto feel that the countess intended, as usual, to make herself\r\ndisagreeable.\r\n\r\n"She\'s a stupid, dull, pig-headed creature; but one can believe what\r\nshe says."\r\n\r\n"And don\'t you believe what I say?" demanded Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"It\'s all true, no doubt, that the diamonds are gone."\r\n\r\n"Indeed it is."\r\n\r\n"But I don\'t know much about Lord George de Bruce Carruthers."\r\n\r\n"He\'s the brother of a marquis, anyway," said Lizzie, who thought\r\nthat she might thus best answer the mother of a Scotch Earl.\r\n\r\n"I remember when he was plain George Carruthers, running about the\r\nstreets of Aberdeen, and it was well with him when his shoes weren\'t\r\nbroken at the toes and down at heel. He earned his bread then, such\r\nas it was;--nobody knows how he gets it now. Why does he call himself\r\nde Bruce, I wonder?"\r\n\r\n"Because his godfathers and godmothers gave him that name when he was\r\nmade a child of Christ, and an inheritor of the kingdom of heaven,"\r\nsaid Lizzie, ever so pertly.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t believe a bit of it."\r\n\r\n"I wasn\'t there to see, Aunt Susanna; and therefore I can\'t swear to\r\nit. That\'s his name in all the peerages, and I suppose they ought to\r\nknow."\r\n\r\n"And what does Lord George de Bruce say about the diamonds?"\r\n\r\nNow it had come to pass that Lady Eustace herself did not feel\r\naltogether sure that Lord George had not had a hand in this robbery.\r\nIt would have been a trick worthy of a genuine Corsair to arrange and\r\ncarry out such a scheme for the appropriation of so rich a spoil. A\r\nwatch or a brooch would, of course, be beneath the notice of a good\r\ngenuine Corsair,--of a Corsair who was written down in the peerage as\r\na marquis\'s brother;--but diamonds worth ten thousand pounds are not\r\nto be had every day. A Corsair must live, and if not by plunder rich\r\nas that,--how then? If Lord George had concocted this little scheme,\r\nhe would naturally be ignorant of the true event of the robbery till\r\nhe should meet the humble executors of his design, and would, as\r\nLizzie thought, have remained unaware of the truth till his arrival\r\nin London. That he had been ignorant of the truth during the journey\r\nwas evident to her. But they had now been three days in London,\r\nduring which she had seen him once. At that interview he had been\r\nsullen and almost cross,--and had said next to nothing about the\r\nrobbery. He made but one remark about it. "I have told the chief man\r\nhere," he said, "that I shall be ready to give any evidence in my\r\npower when called upon. Till then I shall take no further steps in\r\nthe matter. I have been asked questions that should not have been\r\nasked." In saying this he had used a tone which prevented further\r\nconversation on the subject, but Lizzie, as she thought of it all,\r\nremembered his jocular remark, made in the railway carriage, as to\r\nthe suspicion which had already been expressed on the matter in\r\nregard to himself. If he had been the perpetrator, and had then found\r\nthat he had only stolen the box, how wonderful would be the mystery!\r\n"He hasn\'t got anything to say," replied Lizzie to the question of\r\nthe countess.\r\n\r\n"And who is your Mrs. Carbuncle?" asked the old woman.\r\n\r\n"A particular friend of mine with whom I am staying at present. You\r\ndon\'t go about a great deal, Aunt Linlithgow, but surely you must\r\nhave met Mrs. Carbuncle."\r\n\r\n"I\'m an ignorant old woman, no doubt. My dear, I\'m not at all\r\nsurprised at your losing your diamonds. The pity is that they weren\'t\r\nyour own."\r\n\r\n"They were my own."\r\n\r\n"The loss will fall on you, no doubt, because the Eustace people will\r\nmake you pay for them. You\'ll have to give up half your jointure for\r\nyour life. That\'s what it will come to. To think of your travelling\r\nabout with those things in a box!"\r\n\r\n"They were my own, and I had a right to do what I liked with them.\r\nNobody accuses you of taking them."\r\n\r\n"That\'s quite true. Nobody will accuse me. I suppose Lord George\r\nhas left England for the benefit of his health. It would not at\r\nall surprise me if I were to hear that Mrs. Carbuncle had followed\r\nhim;--not in the least."\r\n\r\n"You\'re just like yourself, Aunt Susanna," said Lizzie, getting up\r\nand taking her leave. "Good-bye, Lucy,--I hope you\'re happy and\r\ncomfortable here. Do you ever see a certain friend of ours now?"\r\n\r\n"If you mean Mr. Greystock, I haven\'t seen him since I left Fawn\r\nCourt," said Lucy, with dignity.\r\n\r\nWhen Lizzie was gone, Lady Linlithgow spoke her mind freely about her\r\nniece. "Lizzie Eustace won\'t come to any good. When I heard that she\r\nwas engaged to that prig, Lord Fawn, I had some hopes that she might\r\nbe kept out of harm. That\'s all over, of course. When he heard about\r\nthe necklace he wasn\'t going to put his neck into that scrape. But\r\nnow she\'s getting among such a set that nothing can save her. She has\r\ntaken to hunting, and rides about the country like a madwoman."\r\n\r\n"A great many ladies hunt," said Lucy.\r\n\r\n"And she\'s got hold of this Lord George, and of that horrid American\r\nwoman that nobody knows anything about. They\'ve got the diamonds\r\nbetween them, I don\'t doubt. I\'ll bet you sixpence that the police\r\nfind out all about it, and that there is some terrible scandal. The\r\ndiamonds were no more hers than they were mine, and she\'ll be made to\r\npay for them."\r\n\r\nThe necklace, the meanwhile, was still locked up in Lizzie\'s\r\ndesk,--with a patent Bramah key,--in Mrs. Carbuncle\'s house, and was\r\na terrible trouble to our unhappy friend.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLVII\r\n\r\nMatching Priory\r\n\r\n\r\nBefore the end of January everybody in London had heard of the great\r\nrobbery at Carlisle,--and most people had heard also that there\r\nwas something very peculiar in the matter,--something more than a\r\nrobbery. Various rumours were afloat. It had become widely known that\r\nthe diamonds were to be the subject of litigation between the young\r\nwidow and the trustees of the Eustace estate; and it was known also\r\nthat Lord Fawn had engaged himself to marry the widow, and had then\r\nretreated from his engagement simply on account of this litigation.\r\nThere were strong parties formed in the matter,--whom we may call\r\nLizzieites and anti-Lizzieites. The Lizzieites were of opinion that\r\npoor Lady Eustace was being very ill-treated;--that the diamonds did\r\nprobably belong to her, and that Lord Fawn, at any rate, clearly\r\nought to be her own. It was worthy of remark that these Lizzieites\r\nwere all of them Conservatives. Frank Greystock had probably set the\r\nparty on foot;--and it was natural that political opponents should\r\nbelieve that a noble young Under-Secretary of State on the Liberal\r\nside,--such as Lord Fawn,--had misbehaved himself. When the matter at\r\nlast became of such importance as to demand leading articles in the\r\nnewspapers, those journals which had devoted themselves to upholding\r\nthe Conservative politicians of the day were very heavy indeed\r\nupon Lord Fawn. The whole force of the Government, however, was\r\nanti-Lizzieite; and as the controversy advanced, every good Liberal\r\nbecame aware that there was nothing so wicked, so rapacious, so bold,\r\nor so cunning but that Lady Eustace might have done it, or caused it\r\nto be done, without delay, without difficulty, and without scruple.\r\nLady Glencora Palliser for a while endeavoured to defend Lizzie in\r\nLiberal circles,--from generosity rather than from any real belief,\r\nand instigated, perhaps, by a feeling that any woman in society who\r\nwas capable of doing anything extraordinary ought to be defended.\r\nBut even Lady Glencora was forced to abandon her generosity, and to\r\nconfess, on behalf of her party, that Lizzie Eustace was--a very\r\nwicked young woman, indeed. All this, no doubt, grew out of the\r\ndiamonds, and chiefly arose from the robbery; but there had been\r\nenough of notoriety attached to Lizzie before the affair at Carlisle\r\nto make people fancy that they had understood her character long\r\nbefore that.\r\n\r\nThe party assembled at Matching Priory, a country house belonging\r\nto Mr. Palliser, in which Lady Glencora took much delight, was not\r\nlarge, because Mr. Palliser\'s uncle, the Duke of Omnium, who was\r\nwith them, was now a very old man, and one who did not like very\r\nlarge gatherings of people. Lord and Lady Chiltern were there,--that\r\nLord Chiltern who had been known so long and so well in the hunting\r\ncounties of England, and that Lady Chiltern who had been so popular\r\nin London as the beautiful Violet Effingham; and Mr. and Mrs. Grey\r\nwere there, very particular friends of Mr. Palliser\'s. Mr. Grey was\r\nnow sitting for the borough of Silverbridge, in which the Duke of\r\nOmnium was still presumed to have a controlling influence, in spite\r\nof all Reform bills, and Mrs. Grey was in some distant way connected\r\nwith Lady Glencora. And Madame Max Goesler was there,--a lady whose\r\nsociety was still much affected by the old duke; and Mr. and Mrs.\r\nBonteen,--who had been brought there, not, perhaps altogether because\r\nthey were greatly loved, but in order that the gentleman\'s services\r\nmight be made available by Mr. Palliser in reference to some great\r\nreform about to be introduced in monetary matters. Mr. Palliser, who\r\nwas now Chancellor of the Exchequer, was intending to alter the value\r\nof the penny. Unless the work should be too much for him, and he\r\nshould die before he had accomplished the self-imposed task, the\r\nfuture penny was to be made, under his auspices, to contain five\r\nfarthings, and the shilling ten pennies. It was thought that if this\r\ncould be accomplished, the arithmetic of the whole world would be so\r\nsimplified that henceforward the name of Palliser would be blessed\r\nby all schoolboys, clerks, shopkeepers, and financiers. But the\r\ndifficulties were so great that Mr. Palliser\'s hair was already grey\r\nfrom toil, and his shoulders bent by the burthen imposed upon them.\r\nMr. Bonteen, with two private secretaries from the Treasury, was now\r\nat Matching to assist Mr. Palliser;--and it was thought that both\r\nMr. and Mrs. Bonteen were near to madness under the pressure of\r\nthe five-farthing penny. Mr. Bonteen had remarked to many of his\r\npolitical friends that those two extra farthings that could not be\r\nmade to go into the shilling would put him into his cold grave before\r\nthe world would know what he had done,--or had rewarded him for it\r\nwith a handle to his name, and a pension. Lord Fawn was also at\r\nMatching,--a suggestion having been made to Lady Glencora by some\r\nleading Liberals that he should be supported in his difficulties by\r\nher hospitality.\r\n\r\nThe mind of Mr. Palliser himself was too deeply engaged to admit of\r\nits being interested in the great necklace affair; but, of all the\r\nothers assembled, there was not one who did not listen anxiously for\r\nnews on the subject. As regarded the old duke, it had been found\r\nto be quite a godsend; and from post to post as the facts reached\r\nMatching they were communicated to him. And, indeed, there were some\r\nthere who would not wait for the post, but had the news about poor\r\nLizzie\'s diamonds down by the wires. The matter was of the greatest\r\nmoment to Lord Fawn, and Lady Glencora was, perhaps, justified,\r\non his behalf, in demanding a preference for her affairs over the\r\nmessages which were continually passing between Matching and the\r\nTreasury respecting those two ill-conditioned farthings.\r\n\r\n"Duke," she said, entering rather abruptly the small, warm, luxurious\r\nroom in which her husband\'s uncle was passing his morning, "duke,\r\nthey say now that after all the diamonds were not in the box when it\r\nwas taken out of the room at Carlisle." The duke was reclining in an\r\neasy-chair, with his head leaning forward on his breast, and Madame\r\nGoesler was reading to him. It was now three o\'clock, and the old\r\nman had been brought down to this room after his breakfast. Madame\r\nGoesler was reading the last famous new novel, and the duke was\r\ndozing. That, probably, was the fault neither of the reader nor of\r\nthe novelist, as the duke was wont to doze in these days. But Lady\r\nGlencora\'s tidings awakened him completely. She had the telegram in\r\nher hand,--so that he could perceive that the very latest news was\r\nbrought to him.\r\n\r\n"The diamonds not in the box!" he said,--pushing his head a little\r\nmore forward in his eagerness, and sitting with the extended fingers\r\nof his two hands touching each other.\r\n\r\n"Barrington Erle says that Major Mackintosh is almost sure the\r\ndiamonds were not there." Major Mackintosh was an officer very\r\nhigh in the police force, whom everybody trusted implicitly, and\r\nas to whom the outward world believed that he could discover the\r\nperpetrators of any iniquity, if he would only take the trouble\r\nto look into it. Such was the pressing nature of his duties that\r\nhe found himself compelled in one way or another to give up about\r\nsixteen hours a day to them;--but the outer world accused him of\r\nidleness. There was nothing he couldn\'t find out;--only he would not\r\ngive himself the trouble to find out all the things that happened.\r\nTwo or three newspapers had already been very hard upon him in regard\r\nto the Eustace diamonds. Such a mystery as that, they said, he ought\r\nto have unravelled long ago. That he had not unravelled it yet was\r\nquite certain.\r\n\r\n"The diamonds not in the box!" said the duke.\r\n\r\n"Then she must have known it," said Madame Goesler.\r\n\r\n"That doesn\'t quite follow, Madame Max," said Lady Glencora.\r\n\r\n"But why shouldn\'t the diamonds have been in the box?" asked the\r\nduke. As this was the first intimation given to Lady Glencora of any\r\nsuspicion that the diamonds had not been taken with the box, and as\r\nthis had been received by telegraph, she could not answer the duke\'s\r\nquestion with any clear exposition of her own. She put up her hands\r\nand shook her head. "What does Plantagenet think about it?" asked the\r\nduke. Plantagenet Palliser was the full name of the duke\'s nephew and\r\nheir. The duke\'s mind was evidently much disturbed.\r\n\r\n"He doesn\'t think that either the box or the diamonds were ever worth\r\nfive farthings," said Lady Glencora.\r\n\r\n"The diamonds not in the box!" repeated the duke. "Madame Max, do\r\nyou believe that the diamonds were not in the box?" Madame Goesler\r\nshrugged her shoulders and made no answer; but the shrugging of her\r\nshoulders was quite satisfactory to the duke, who always thought that\r\nMadame Goesler did everything better than anybody else. Lady Glencora\r\nstayed with her uncle for the best part of an hour, and every word\r\nspoken was devoted to Lizzie and her necklace; but as this new idea\r\nhad been broached, and as they had no other information than that\r\nconveyed in the telegram, very little light could be thrown upon it.\r\nBut on the next morning there came a letter from Barrington Erle to\r\nLady Glencora, which told so much, and hinted so much more, that it\r\nwill be well to give it to the reader.\r\n\r\n\r\n   Travellers\', 29 Jan., 186--\r\n\r\n   MY DEAR LADY GLENCORA,\r\n\r\n   I hope you got my telegram yesterday. I had just seen\r\n   Mackintosh,--on whose behalf, however, I must say that\r\n   he told me as little as he possibly could. It is leaking\r\n   out, however, on every side, that the police believe that\r\n   when the box was taken out of the room at Carlisle, the\r\n   diamonds were not in it. As far as I can learn, they\r\n   ground this suspicion on the fact that they cannot trace\r\n   the stones. They say that, if such a lot of diamonds had\r\n   been through the thieves\' market in London, they would\r\n   have left some track behind them. As far as I can judge,\r\n   Mackintosh thinks that Lord George has them, but that her\r\n   ladyship gave them to him; and that this little game of\r\n   the robbery at Carlisle was planned to put John Eustace\r\n   and the lawyers off the scent. If it should turn out that\r\n   the box was opened before it left Portray, that the door\r\n   of her ladyship\'s room was cut by her ladyship\'s self,\r\n   or by his lordship with her ladyship\'s aid, and that the\r\n   fragments of the box were carried out of the hotel by\r\n   his lordship in person, it will altogether have been so\r\n   delightful a plot, that all concerned in it ought to be\r\n   canonised,--or at least allowed to keep their plunder. One\r\n   of the old detectives told me that the opening of the box\r\n   under the arch of the railway, in an exposed place, could\r\n   hardly have been executed so neatly as was done;--that no\r\n   thief so situated would have given the time necessary to\r\n   it; and that, if there had been thieves at all at work,\r\n   they would have been traced. Against this, there is the\r\n   certain fact,--as I have heard from various men engaged in\r\n   the inquiry,--that certain persons among the community of\r\n   thieves are very much at loggerheads with each other,--the\r\n   higher, or creative department in thiefdom, accusing the\r\n   lower or mechanical department of gross treachery in\r\n   having appropriated to its own sole profit plunder, for\r\n   the taking of which it had undertaken to receive a certain\r\n   stipulated price. But then it may be the case that his\r\n   lordship and her ladyship have set such a rumour abroad\r\n   for the sake of putting the police off the scent. Upon the\r\n   whole, the little mystery is quite delightful; and has put\r\n   the ballot, and poor Mr. Palliser\'s five-farthinged penny,\r\n   quite out of joint. Nobody now cares for anything except\r\n   the Eustace diamonds. Lord George, I am told, has offered\r\n   to fight everybody or anybody, beginning with Lord Fawn\r\n   and ending with Major Mackintosh. Should he be innocent,\r\n   which, of course, is possible, the thing must be annoying.\r\n   I should not at all wonder myself, if it should turn out\r\n   that her ladyship left them in Scotland. The place there,\r\n   however, has been searched, in compliance with an order\r\n   from the police and by her ladyship\'s consent.\r\n\r\n   Don\'t let Mr. Palliser quite kill himself. I hope the\r\n   Bonteen plan answers. I never knew a man who could find\r\n   more farthings in a shilling than Mr. Bonteen. Remember\r\n   me very kindly to the duke, and pray enable poor Fawn to\r\n   keep up his spirits. If he likes to arrange a meeting with\r\n   Lord George, I shall be only too happy to be his friend.\r\n   You remember our last duel. Chiltern is with you, and\r\n   can put Fawn up to the proper way of getting over to\r\n   Flanders,--and of returning, should he chance to escape.\r\n\r\n   Yours always most faithfully,\r\n\r\n   BARRINGTON ERLE.\r\n\r\n   Of course, I\'ll keep you posted in everything respecting\r\n   the necklace till you come to town yourself.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe whole of this letter Lady Glencora read to the duke, to Lady\r\nChiltern, and to Madame Goesler;--and the principal contents of it\r\nshe repeated to the entire company. It was certainly the general\r\nbelief at Matching that Lord George had the diamonds in his\r\npossession,--either with or without the assistance of their late fair\r\npossessor.\r\n\r\nThe duke was struck with awe when he thought of all the\r\ncircumstances. "The brother of a marquis!" he said to his nephew\'s\r\nwife. "It\'s such a disgrace to the peerage!"\r\n\r\n"As for that, duke," said Lady Glencora, "the peerage is used to it\r\nby this time."\r\n\r\n"I never heard of such an affair as this before."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t see why the brother of a marquis shouldn\'t turn thief\r\nas well as anybody else. They say he hasn\'t got anything of his\r\nown;--and I suppose that is what makes men steal other people\'s\r\nproperty. Peers go into trade, and peeresses gamble on the Stock\r\nExchange. Peers become bankrupt, and the sons of peers run\r\naway;--just like other men. I don\'t see why all enterprises should\r\nnot be open to them. But to think of that little purring cat,\r\nLady Eustace, having been so very--very clever! It makes me quite\r\nenvious."\r\n\r\nAll this took place in the morning;--that is, about two o\'clock;\r\nbut after dinner the subject became general. There might be some\r\nlittle reticence in regard to Lord Fawn\'s feelings,--but it was not\r\nsufficient to banish a subject so interesting from the minds and lips\r\nof the company. "The Tewett marriage is to come off, after all," said\r\nMrs. Bonteen. "I\'ve a letter from dear Mrs. Rutter, telling me so as\r\na fact."\r\n\r\n"I wonder whether Miss Roanoke will be allowed to wear one or two of\r\nthe diamonds at the wedding," suggested one of the private\r\nsecretaries.\r\n\r\n"Nobody will dare to wear a diamond at all next season," said Lady\r\nGlencora. "As for my own, I sha\'n\'t think of having them out. I\r\nshould always feel that I was being inspected."\r\n\r\n"Unless they unravel the mystery," said Madame Goesler.\r\n\r\n"I hope they won\'t do that," said Lady Glencora. "The play is too\r\ngood to come to an end so soon. If we hear that Lord George is\r\nengaged to Lady Eustace, nothing, I suppose, can be done to stop the\r\nmarriage."\r\n\r\n"Why shouldn\'t she marry if she pleases?" asked Mr. Palliser.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve not the slightest objection to her being married. I hope she\r\nwill, with all my heart. I certainly think she should have her\r\nhusband after buying him at such a price. I suppose Lord Fawn won\'t\r\nforbid the banns." These last words were only whispered to her next\r\nneighbour, Lord Chiltern; but poor Lord Fawn saw the whisper, and was\r\naware that it must have had reference to his condition.\r\n\r\nOn the next morning there came further news. The police had asked\r\npermission from their occupants to search the rooms in which lived\r\nLady Eustace and Lord George, and in each case the permission had\r\nbeen refused. So said Barrington Erle in his letter to Lady Glencora.\r\nLord George had told the applicant, very roughly, that nobody should\r\ntouch any article belonging to him without a search-warrant. If any\r\nmagistrate would dare to give such a warrant, let him do it. "I\'m\r\ntold that Lord George acts the indignant madman uncommonly well,"\r\nsaid Barrington Erle in his letter. As for poor Lizzie, she had\r\nfainted when the proposition was made to her. The request was renewed\r\nas soon as she had been brought to herself; and then she refused,--on\r\nthe advice, as she said, of her cousin, Mr. Greystock. Barrington\r\nErle went on to say that the police were very much blamed. It was\r\nbelieved that no information could be laid before a magistrate\r\nsufficient to justify a search-warrant;--and, in such circumstances,\r\nno search should have been attempted. Such was the public verdict, as\r\ndeclared in Barrington Erle\'s last letter to Lady Glencora.\r\n\r\nMr. Palliser was of opinion that the attempt to search the lady\'s\r\nhouse was iniquitous. Mr. Bonteen shook his head, and rather thought\r\nthat, if he were Home Secretary, he would have had the search made.\r\nLady Chiltern said that if policemen came to her, they might search\r\neverything she had in the world. Mrs. Grey reminded them that all\r\nthey really knew of the unfortunate woman was, that her jewel-box had\r\nbeen stolen out of her bedroom at her hotel. Madame Goesler was of\r\nopinion that a lady who could carry such a box about the country with\r\nher deserved to have it stolen. Lord Fawn felt himself obliged to\r\nconfess that he agreed altogether with Madame Goesler. Unfortunately,\r\nhe had been acquainted with the lady, and now was constrained to say\r\nthat her conduct had been such as to justify the suspicions of the\r\npolice. "Of course, we all suspect her," said Lady Glencora; "and,\r\nof course, we suspect Lord George too, and Mrs. Carbuncle and Miss\r\nRoanoke. But then, you know, if I were to lose my diamonds, people\r\nwould suspect me just the same,--or perhaps Plantagenet. It is so\r\ndelightful to think that a woman has stolen her own property, and\r\nput all the police into a state of ferment." Lord Chiltern declared\r\nhimself to be heartily sick of the whole subject; and Mr. Grey, who\r\nwas a very just man, suggested that the evidence, as yet, against\r\nanybody, was very slight. "Of course, it\'s slight," said Lady\r\nGlencora. "If it were more than slight, it would be just like any\r\nother robbery, and there would be nothing in it." On the same morning\r\nMrs. Bonteen received a second letter from her friend Mrs. Rutter.\r\nThe Tewett marriage had been certainly broken off. Sir Griffin had\r\nbeen very violent, misbehaving himself grossly in Mrs. Carbuncle\'s\r\nhouse, and Miss Roanoke had declared that under no circumstances\r\nwould she ever speak to him again. It was Mrs. Rutter\'s opinion,\r\nhowever, that this violence had been "put on" by Sir Griffin, who\r\nwas desirous of escaping from the marriage because of the affair of\r\nthe diamonds. "He\'s very much bound up with Lord George," said Mrs.\r\nRutter, "and is afraid that he may be implicated."\r\n\r\n"In my opinion he\'s quite right," said Lord Fawn.\r\n\r\nAll these matters were told to the duke by Lady Glencora and Madame\r\nGoesler in the recesses of his grace\'s private room; for the duke\r\nwas now infirm, and did not dine in company unless the day was\r\nvery auspicious to him. But in the evening he would creep into the\r\ndrawing-room, and on this occasion he had a word to say about the\r\nEustace diamonds to every one in the room. It was admitted by them\r\nall that the robbery had been a godsend in the way of amusing the\r\nduke. "Wouldn\'t have her boxes searched, you know," said the duke;\r\n"that looks uncommonly suspicious. Perhaps, Lady Chiltern, we shall\r\nhear to-morrow morning something more about it."\r\n\r\n"Poor dear duke," said Lady Chiltern to her husband.\r\n\r\n"Doting old idiot!" he replied.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLVIII\r\n\r\nLizzie\'s Condition\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen such a man as Barrington Erle undertakes to send information\r\nto such a correspondent as Lady Glencora in reference to such a\r\nmatter as Lady Eustace\'s diamonds, he is bound to be full rather\r\nthan accurate. We may say, indeed, that perfect accuracy would be\r\ndetrimental rather than otherwise, and would tend to disperse that\r\nfeeling of mystery which is so gratifying. No suggestion had in truth\r\nbeen made to Lord George de Bruce Carruthers as to the searching of\r\nhis lordship\'s boxes and desks. That very eminent detective officer,\r\nMr. Bunfit, had, however, called upon Lord George more than once, and\r\nLord George had declared very plainly that he did not like it. "If\r\nyou\'ll have the kindness to explain to me what it is you want, I\'ll\r\nbe much obliged to you," Lord George had said to Mr. Bunfit.\r\n\r\n"Well, my lord," said Bunfit, "what we want is these diamonds."\r\n\r\n"Do you believe that I\'ve got them?"\r\n\r\n"A man in my situation, my lord, never believes anything. We has to\r\nsuspect, but we never believes."\r\n\r\n"You suspect that I stole them?"\r\n\r\n"No, my lord;--I didn\'t say that. But things are very queer; aren\'t\r\nthey?" The immediate object of Mr. Bunfit\'s visit on this morning\r\nhad been to ascertain from Lord George whether it was true that his\r\nlordship had been with Messrs. Harter and Benjamin, the jewellers,\r\non the morning after his arrival in town. No one from the police\r\nhad as yet seen either Harter or Benjamin in connexion with this\r\nrobbery; but it may not be too much to say that the argus eyes of\r\nMajor Mackintosh were upon Messrs. Harter and Benjamin\'s whole\r\nestablishment, and it was believed that, if the jewels were in\r\nLondon, they were locked up in some box within that house. It was\r\nthought more than probable by Major Mackintosh and his myrmidons that\r\nthe jewels were already at Hamburg; and by this time, as the major\r\nhad explained to Mr. Camperdown, every one of them might have been\r\nreset,--or even recut. But it was known that Lord George had been at\r\nthe house of Messrs. Harter and Benjamin early on the morning after\r\nhis return to town, and the ingenuous Mr. Bunfit, who, by reason\r\nof his situation, never believed anything and only suspected, had\r\nexpressed a very strong opinion to Major Mackintosh that the necklace\r\nhad in truth been transferred to the Jews on that morning. That there\r\nwas nothing "too hot or too heavy" for Messrs. Harter and Benjamin\r\nwas quite a creed with the police of the west end of London. Might it\r\nnot be well to ask Lord George what he had to say about the visit?\r\nShould Lord George deny the visit, such denial would go far to\r\nconfirm Mr. Bunfit. The question was asked, and Lord George did not\r\ndeny the visit. "Unfortunately, they hold acceptances of mine," said\r\nLord George, "and I am often there." "We know as they have your\r\nlordship\'s name to paper," said Mr. Bunfit,--thanking Lord George,\r\nhowever, for his courtesy. It may be understood that all this would\r\nbe unpleasant to Lord George, and that he should be indignant almost\r\nto madness.\r\n\r\nBut Mr. Erle\'s information, though certainly defective in regard to\r\nLord George de Bruce Carruthers, had been more correct when he spoke\r\nof the lady. An interview that was very terrible to poor Lizzie did\r\ntake place between her and Mr. Bunfit in Mrs. Carbuncle\'s house on\r\nTuesday, the 30th of January. There had been many interviews between\r\nLizzie and various members of the police force in reference to the\r\ndiamonds, but the questions put to her had always been asked on the\r\nsupposition that she might have mislaid the necklace. Was it not\r\npossible that she might have thought that she locked it up, but\r\nhave omitted to place it in the box? As long as these questions had\r\nreference to a possible oversight in Scotland,--to some carelessness\r\nwhich she might have committed on the night before she left her\r\nhome,--Lizzie upon the whole seemed rather to like the idea. It\r\ncertainly was possible. She believed thoroughly that the diamonds had\r\nbeen locked by her in the box,--but she acknowledged that it might be\r\nthe case that they had been left on one side. This had happened when\r\nthe police first began to suspect that the necklace had not been in\r\nthe box when it was carried out of the Carlisle hotel, but before\r\nit had occurred to them that Lord George had been concerned in\r\nthe robbery, and possibly Lady Eustace herself. Men had been sent\r\ndown from London, of course at considerable expense, and Portray\r\nCastle had been searched, with the consent of its owner, from the\r\nweathercock to the foundation-stone,--much to the consternation of\r\nMiss Macnulty, and to the delight of Andy Gowran. No trace of the\r\ndiamonds was found, and Lizzie had so far fraternised with the\r\npolice. But when Mr. Bunfit called upon her, perhaps for the fifth\r\nor sixth time, and suggested that he should be allowed, with the\r\nassistance of the female whom he had left behind him in the hall, to\r\nsearch all her ladyship\'s boxes, drawers, presses, and receptacles in\r\nLondon, the thing took a very different aspect. "You see, my lady,"\r\nsaid Mr. Bunfit, excusing the peculiar nature of his request, "it may\r\nhave got anywhere among your ladyship\'s things, unbeknownst." Lady\r\nEustace and Mrs. Carbuncle were at the time sitting together, and\r\nMrs. Carbuncle was the first to protest. If Mr. Bunfit thought that\r\nhe was going to search her things, Mr. Bunfit was very much mistaken.\r\nWhat she had suffered about this necklace no man or woman knew,--and\r\nshe meant that there should be an end of it. It was her opinion that\r\nthe police should have discovered every stone of it days and days\r\nago. At any rate, her house was her own, and she gave Mr. Bunfit to\r\nunderstand that his repeated visits were not agreeable to her. But\r\nwhen Mr. Bunfit, without showing the slightest displeasure at the\r\nevil things said of him, suggested that the search should be confined\r\nto the rooms used exclusively by Lady Eustace, Mrs. Carbuncle\r\nabsolutely changed her views, and recommended that he should be\r\nallowed to have his way.\r\n\r\nAt that moment the condition of poor Lizzie Eustace was very sad.\r\nHe who recounts these details has scorned to have a secret between\r\nhimself and his readers. The diamonds were at this moment locked\r\nup within Lizzie\'s desk. For the last three weeks they had been\r\nthere,--if it may not be more truly said that they were lying heavily\r\non her heart. For three weeks had her mind with constant stretch been\r\nworking on that point,--whither should she take the diamonds, and\r\nwhat should she do with them? A certain very wonderful strength she\r\ndid possess, or she could not have endured the weight of so terrible\r\nan anxiety; but from day to day the thing became worse and worse\r\nwith her, as gradually she perceived that suspicion was attached to\r\nherself. Should she confide the secret to Lord George, or to Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle, or to Frank Greystock? She thought she could have borne\r\nit all if only some one would have borne it with her. But when the\r\nmoments came in which such confidence might be made, her courage\r\nfailed her. Lord George she saw frequently; but he was unsympathetic\r\nand almost rough with her. She knew that he also was suspected, and\r\nshe was almost disposed to think that he had planned the robbery.\r\nIf it were so, if the robbery had been his handiwork, it was not\r\nsingular that he should be unsympathetic with the owner and probable\r\nholder of the prey which he had missed. Nevertheless Lizzie thought\r\nthat if he would have been soft with her, like a dear, good, genuine\r\nCorsair, for half an hour, she would have told him all, and placed\r\nthe necklace in his hands. And there were moments in which she\r\nalmost resolved to tell her secret to Mrs. Carbuncle. She had stolen\r\nnothing;--so she averred to herself. She had intended only to defend\r\nand save her own property. Even the lie that she had told, and the\r\ntelling of which was continued from day to day, had in a measure been\r\nforced upon her by circumstances. She thought that Mrs. Carbuncle\r\nwould sympathise with her in that feeling which had prevented her\r\nfrom speaking the truth when first the fact of the robbery was made\r\nknown to herself in her own bedroom. Mrs. Carbuncle was a lady\r\nwho told many lies, as Lizzie knew well,--and surely could not be\r\nhorrified at a lie told in such circumstances. But it was not in\r\nLizzie\'s nature to trust a woman. Mrs. Carbuncle would tell Lord\r\nGeorge,--and that would destroy everything. When she thought of\r\nconfiding everything to her cousin, it was always in his absence. The\r\nidea became dreadful to her as soon as he was present. She could not\r\ndare to own to him that she had sworn falsely to the magistrate at\r\nCarlisle. And so the burthen had to be borne, increasing every hour\r\nin weight, and the poor creature\'s back was not broad enough to bear\r\nit. She thought of the necklace every waking minute, and dreamed of\r\nit when she slept. She could not keep herself from unlocking her desk\r\nand looking at it twenty times a day, although she knew the peril\r\nof such nervous solicitude. If she could only rid herself of it\r\naltogether, she was sure now that she would do so. She would throw\r\nit into the ocean fathoms deep, if only she could find herself alone\r\nupon the ocean. But she felt that, let her go where she might, she\r\nwould be watched. She might declare to-morrow her intention of going\r\nto Ireland,--or, for that matter, to America. But, were she to do so,\r\nsome horrid policeman would be on her track. The iron box had been\r\na terrible nuisance to her;--but the iron box had been as nothing\r\ncompared to the necklace locked up in her desk. From day to day\r\nshe meditated a plan of taking the thing out into the streets, and\r\ndropping it in the dark; but she was sure that, were she to do\r\nso, some one would have watched her while she dropped it. She was\r\nunwilling to trust her old friend Mr. Benjamin; but in these days her\r\nfavourite scheme was to offer the diamonds for sale to him at some\r\nvery low price. If he would help her they might surely be got out of\r\ntheir present hiding-place into his hands. Any man would be powerful\r\nto help, if there were any man whom she could trust. In furtherance\r\nof this scheme she went so far as to break a brooch,--a favourite\r\nbrooch of her own,--in order that she might have an excuse for\r\ncalling at the jewellers\'. But even this she postponed from day to\r\nday. Circumstances, as they had occurred, had taught her to believe\r\nthat the police could not insist on breaking open her desk unless\r\nsome evidence could be brought against her. There was no evidence,\r\nand her desk was so far safe. But the same circumstances had made\r\nher understand that she was already suspected of some intrigue with\r\nreference to the diamonds,--though of what she was suspected she did\r\nnot clearly perceive. As far as she could divine the thoughts of her\r\nenemies, they did not seem to suppose that the diamonds were in her\r\npossession. It seemed to be believed by those enemies that they had\r\npassed into the hands of Lord George. As long as her enemies were on\r\na scent so false, might it not be best that she should remain quiet?\r\n\r\nBut all the ingenuity, the concentrated force, and trained experience\r\nof the police of London would surely be too great and powerful for\r\nher in the long run. She could not hope to keep her secret and the\r\ndiamonds till they should acknowledge themselves to be baffled. And\r\nthen she was aware of a morbid desire on her own part to tell the\r\nsecret,--of a desire that amounted almost to a disease. It would soon\r\nburst her bosom open, unless she could share her knowledge with some\r\none. And yet, as she thought of it all, she told herself that she had\r\nno friend so fast and true as to justify such confidence. She was ill\r\nwith anxiety, and,--worse than that,--Mrs. Carbuncle knew that she\r\nwas ill. It was acknowledged between them that this affair of the\r\nnecklace was so terrible as to make a woman ill. Mrs. Carbuncle at\r\npresent had been gracious enough to admit so much as that. But might\r\nit not be probable that Mrs. Carbuncle would come to suspect that she\r\ndid not know the whole secret? Mrs. Carbuncle had already, on more\r\nthan one occasion, said a little word or two which had been\r\nunpleasant.\r\n\r\nSuch was Lizzie\'s condition when Mr. Bunfit came, with his\r\nauthoritative request to be allowed to inspect Lizzie\'s boxes,--and\r\nwhen Mrs. Carbuncle, having secured her own privacy, expressed her\r\nopinion that Mr. Bunfit should be allowed to do as he desired.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLIX\r\n\r\nBunfit and Gager\r\n\r\n\r\nAs soon as the words were out of Mrs. Carbuncle\'s mouth,--those\r\nill-natured words in which she expressed her assent to Mr. Bunfit\'s\r\nproposition that a search should be made after the diamonds among\r\nall the possessions of Lady Eustace which were now lodged in her own\r\nhouse,--poor Lizzie\'s courage deserted her entirely. She had been\r\nvery courageous; for, though her powers of endurance had sometimes\r\nnearly deserted her, though her heart had often failed her, still\r\nshe had gone on and had endured and been silent. To endure and to be\r\nsilent in her position did require great courage. She was all alone\r\nin her misery, and could see no way out of it. The diamonds were\r\nheavy as a load of lead within her bosom. And yet she had persevered.\r\nNow, as she heard Mrs. Carbuncle\'s words, her courage failed her.\r\nThere came some obstruction in her throat, so that she could not\r\nspeak. She felt as though her heart were breaking. She put out both\r\nher hands and could not draw them back again. She knew that she\r\nwas betraying herself by her weakness. She could just hear the man\r\nexplaining that the search was merely a thing of ceremony,--just to\r\nsatisfy everybody that there was no mistake;--and then she fainted.\r\nSo far, Barrington Erle was correct in the information given by him\r\nto Lady Glencora. She pressed one hand against her heart, gasped for\r\nbreath, and then fell back upon the sofa. Perhaps she could have\r\ndone nothing better. Had the fainting been counterfeit, the measure\r\nwould have shown ability. But the fainting was altogether true. Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle first, and then Mr. Bunfit, hurried from their seats to\r\nhelp her. To neither of them did it occur for a moment that the fit\r\nwas false.\r\n\r\n"The whole thing has been too much for her," said Mrs. Carbuncle\r\nseverely, ringing the bell at the same time for further aid.\r\n\r\n"No doubt,--mum; no doubt. We has to see a deal of this sort of\r\nthing. Just a little air, if you please, mum,--and as much water as\'d\r\ngo to christen a babby. That\'s always best, mum."\r\n\r\n"If you\'ll have the kindness to stand on one side," said Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle, as she stretched Lizzie on the sofa.\r\n\r\n"Certainly, mum," said Bunfit, standing erect by the wall, but not\r\nshowing the slightest disposition to leave the room.\r\n\r\n"You had better go," said Mrs. Carbuncle,--loudly and very severely.\r\n\r\n"I\'ll just stay and see her come to, mum. I won\'t do her a morsel of\r\nharm, mum. Sometimes they faints at the very fust sight of such as\r\nwe; but we has to bear it. A little more air, if you could, mum;--and\r\njust dash the water on in drops like. They feels a drop more than\r\nthey would a bucketful,--and then when they comes to they hasn\'t to\r\nchange theirselves."\r\n\r\nBunfit\'s advice, founded on much experience, was good, and Lizzie\r\ngradually came to herself and opened her eyes. She immediately\r\nclutched at her breast, feeling for her key. She found it unmoved,\r\nbut before her finger had recognised the touch, her quick mind had\r\ntold her how wrong the movement had been. It had been lost upon Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle, but not on Mr. Bunfit. He did not at once think that she\r\nhad the diamonds in her desk; but he felt almost sure that there was\r\nsomething in her possession,--probably some document,--which, if\r\nfound, would place him on the track of the diamonds. But he could\r\nnot compel a search. "Your ladyship\'ll soon be better," said Bunfit\r\ngraciously. Lizzie endeavoured to smile as she expressed her assent\r\nto this proposition. "As I was a saying to the elder lady--"\r\n\r\n"Saying to who, sir?" exclaimed Mrs. Carbuncle, rising up in wrath.\r\n"Elder, indeed!"\r\n\r\n"As I was a venturing to explain, these fits of fainting come often\r\nin our way. Thieves, mum,--that is, the regulars,--don\'t mind us a\r\nbit, and the women is more hardeneder than the men; but when we has\r\nto speak to a lady, it is so often that she goes off like that! I\'ve\r\nknown \'em do it just at being looked at."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t you think, sir, that you\'d better leave us now?" said Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle.\r\n\r\n"Indeed you had," said Lizzie. "I\'m fit for nothing just at present."\r\n\r\n"We won\'t disturb your ladyship the least in life," said Mr. Bunfit,\r\n"if you\'ll only just let us have your keys. Your servant can be with\r\nus, and we won\'t move one tittle of anything." But Lizzie, though she\r\nwas still suffering that ineffable sickness which always accompanies\r\nand follows a real fainting-fit, would not surrender her keys.\r\nAlready had an excuse for not doing so occurred to her. But for a\r\nwhile she seemed to hesitate. "I don\'t demand it, Lady Eustace," said\r\nMr. Bunfit, "but if you\'ll allow me to say so, I do think it will\r\nlook better for your ladyship."\r\n\r\n"I can take no step without consulting my cousin, Mr. Greystock,"\r\nsaid Lizzie; and having thought of this she adhered to it. The\r\ndetective supplied her with many reasons for giving up her keys,\r\nalleging that it would do no harm, and that her refusal would create\r\ninfinite suspicions. But Lizzie had formed her answer and stuck\r\nto it. She always consulted her cousin, and always acted upon his\r\nadvice. He had already cautioned her not to take any steps without\r\nhis sanction. She would do nothing till he consented. If Mr. Bunfit\r\nwould see Mr. Greystock, and if Mr. Greystock would come to her and\r\ntell her to submit,--she would submit. Ill as she was, she could\r\nbe obstinate, and Bunfit left the house without having been able\r\nto finger that key which he felt sure that Lady Eustace carried\r\nsomewhere on her person.\r\n\r\nAs he walked back to his own quarters in Scotland Yard, Bunfit was by\r\nno means dissatisfied with his morning\'s work. He had not expected to\r\nfind anything with Lady Eustace, and, when she fainted, had not hoped\r\nto be allowed to search. But he was now sure that her ladyship was\r\npossessed, at any rate, of some guilty knowledge. Bunfit was one\r\nof those who, almost from the first, had believed that the box was\r\nempty when taken out of the hotel. "Stones like them must turn up\r\nmore or less," was Bunfit\'s great argument. That the police should\r\nalready have found the stones themselves was not perhaps probable;\r\nbut had any ordinary thieves had them in their hands, they could\r\nnot have been passed on without leaving a trace behind them. It\r\nwas his opinion that the box had been opened and the door cut\r\nby the instrumentality and concurrence of Lord George de Bruce\r\nCarruthers,--with the assistance of some well-skilled mechanical\r\nthief. Nothing could be made out of the tall footman;--indeed,\r\nthe tall footman had already been set at liberty, although he was\r\nknown to have evil associates; and the tall footman was now loud in\r\ndemanding compensation for the injury done to him. Many believed that\r\nthe tall footman had been concerned in the matter,--many, that is,\r\namong the experienced craftsmen of the police force. Bunfit thought\r\notherwise. Bunfit believed that the diamonds were now either in the\r\npossession of Lord George or of Harter and Benjamin, that they had\r\nbeen handed over to Lord George to save them from Messrs. Camperdown\r\nand the lawsuit, and that Lord George and the lady were lovers. The\r\nlady\'s conduct at their last interview, her fit of fainting, and\r\nher clutching for the key, all confirmed Bunfit in his opinion. But\r\nunfortunately for Bunfit he was almost alone in his opinion. There\r\nwere men in the force,--high in their profession as detectives,--who\r\navowed that certainly two very experienced and well-known thieves had\r\nbeen concerned in the business. That a certain Mr. Smiler had been\r\nthere,--a gentleman for whom the whole police of London entertained a\r\nfeeling which approached to veneration, and that most diminutive of\r\nfull-grown thieves, Billy Cann,--most diminutive but at the same time\r\nmost expert,--was not doubted by some minds which were apt to doubt\r\ntill conviction had become certainty. The traveller who had left the\r\nScotch train at Dumfries had been a very small man, and it was a\r\nknown fact that Mr. Smiler had left London by train, from the Euston\r\nSquare station, on the day before that on which Lizzie and her party\r\nhad reached Carlisle. If it were so, if Mr. Smiler and Billy Cann had\r\nboth been at work at the hotel, then,--so argued they who opposed the\r\nBunfit theory,--it was hardly conceivable that the robbery should\r\nhave been arranged by Lord George. According to the Bunfit theory,\r\nthe only thing needed by the conspirators had been that the diamonds\r\nshould be handed over by Lady Eustace to Lord George in such a way\r\nas to escape suspicion that such transfer had been made. This might\r\nhave been done with very little trouble,--by simply leaving the box\r\nempty, with the key in it. The door of the bedroom had been opened\r\nby skilful professional men, and the box had been forced by the use\r\nof tools which none but professional gentlemen would possess. Was it\r\nprobable that Lord George would have committed himself with such men,\r\nand incurred the very heavy expense of paying for their services,\r\nwhen he was,--according to the Bunfit theory,--able to get at the\r\ndiamonds without any such trouble, danger, and expenditure? There\r\nwas a young detective in the force, very clever,--almost too clever,\r\nand certainly a little too fast,--Gager by name, who declared that\r\nthe Bunfit theory "warn\'t on the cards." According to Gager\'s\r\ninformation, Smiler was at this moment a broken-hearted man,--ranging\r\nbetween mad indignation and suicidal despondency, because he had been\r\ntreated with treachery in some direction. Mr. Gager was as fully\r\nconvinced as Bunfit that the diamonds had not been in the box. There\r\nwas bitter, raging, heart-breaking disappointment about the diamonds\r\nin more quarters than one. That there had been a double robbery Gager\r\nwas quite sure;--or rather a robbery in which two sets of thieves had\r\nbeen concerned, and in which one set had been duped by the other set.\r\nIn this affair Mr. Smiler and poor little Billy Cann had been the\r\ndupes. So far Gager\'s mind had arrived at certainty. But then how had\r\nthey been duped, and who had duped them? And who had employed them?\r\nSuch a robbery would hardly have been arranged and executed except\r\non commission. Even Mr. Smiler would not have burthened himself with\r\nsuch diamonds without knowing what to do with them, and what he\r\nshould get for them. That they were intended ultimately for the hands\r\nof Messrs. Harter and Benjamin, Gager almost believed. And Gager\r\nwas inclined to think that Messrs. Harter and Benjamin,--or rather\r\nMr. Benjamin, for Mr. Harter himself was almost too old for work\r\nrequiring so very great mental activity,--that Mr. Benjamin, fearing\r\nthe honesty of his executive officer Mr. Smiler, had been splendidly\r\ntreacherous to his subordinate. Gager had not quite completed his\r\ntheory; but he was very firm on one great point,--that the thieves at\r\nCarlisle had been genuine thieves, thinking that they were stealing\r\nthe diamonds, and finding their mistake out when the box had been\r\nopened by them under the bridge. "Who have \'em, then?" asked Bunfit\r\nof his younger brother, in a disparaging whisper.\r\n\r\n"Well; yes; who \'ave \'em? It\'s easy to say, who \'ave \'em? Suppose\r\n\'e \'ave \'em." The "he" alluded to by Gager was Lord George de Bruce\r\nCarruthers. "But laws, Bunfit, they\'re gone--weeks ago. You know\r\nthat, Bunfit." This had occurred before the intended search among\r\npoor Lizzie\'s boxes, but Bunfit\'s theory had not been shaken. Bunfit\r\ncould see all round his own theory. It was whole, and the motives as\r\nwell as the operations of the persons concerned were explained by it.\r\nBut the Gager theory only went to show what had not been done, and\r\noffered no explanation of the accomplished scheme. Then Bunfit went a\r\nlittle further in his theory, not disdaining to accept something from\r\nGager. Perhaps Lord George had engaged these men, and had afterwards\r\nfound it practicable to get the diamonds without their assistance. On\r\none great point all concerned in the inquiry were in unison,--that\r\nthe diamonds had not been in the box when it was carried out of the\r\nbedroom at Carlisle. The great point of difference consisted in this,\r\nthat whereas Gager was sure that the robbery when committed had been\r\ngenuine, Bunfit was of opinion that the box had been first opened,\r\nand then taken out of the hotel in order that the police might be put\r\non a wrong track.\r\n\r\nThe matter was becoming very important. Two or three of the leading\r\nnewspapers had first hinted at and then openly condemned the\r\nincompetence and slowness of the police. Such censure, as we all\r\nknow, is very common, and in nine cases out of ten it is unjust. They\r\nwho write it probably know but little of the circumstances;--and, in\r\nspeaking of a failure here and a failure there, make no reference\r\nto the numerous successes, which are so customary as to partake\r\nof the nature of routine. It is the same in regard to all public\r\nmatters,--army matters, navy matters, poor-law matters, and\r\npost-office matters. Day after day, and almost every day, one meets\r\ncensure which is felt to be unjust;--but the general result of all\r\nthis injustice is increased efficiency. The coach does go the faster\r\nbecause of the whip in the coachman\'s hand, though the horses driven\r\nmay never have deserved the thong. In this matter of the Eustace\r\ndiamonds the police had been very active; but they had been\r\nunsuccessful, and had consequently been abused. The robbery was now\r\nmore than three weeks old. Property to the amount of ten thousand\r\npounds had been abstracted, and as yet the police had not even formed\r\nan assured opinion on the subject! Had the same thing occurred in\r\nNew York or Paris every diamond would by this time have been traced.\r\nSuch were the assertions made, and the police were instigated to new\r\nexertions. Bunfit would have jeopardised his right hand, and Gager\r\nhis life, to get at the secret. Even Major Mackintosh was anxious.\r\n\r\nThe facts of the claim made by Mr. Camperdown, and of the bill which\r\nhad been filed in Chancery for the recovery of the diamonds, were\r\nof course widely known, and added much to the general interest and\r\ncomplexity. It was averred that Mr. Camperdown\'s determination\r\nto get the diamonds had been very energetic, and Lady Eustace\'s\r\ndetermination to keep them equally so. Wonderful stories were told of\r\nLizzie\'s courage, energy, and resolution. There was hardly a lawyer\r\nof repute but took up the question, and had an opinion as to Lizzie\'s\r\nright to the necklace. The Attorney and Solicitor-General were dead\r\nagainst her, asserting that the diamonds certainly did not pass to\r\nher under the will, and could not have become hers by gift. But they\r\nwere members of a Liberal government, and of course anti-Lizzieite.\r\nGentlemen who were equal to them in learning, who had held offices\r\nequally high, were distinctly of a different opinion. Lady\r\nEustace might probably claim the jewels as paraphernalia properly\r\nappertaining to her rank;--in which claim the bestowal of them by her\r\nhusband would no doubt assist her. And to these gentlemen,--who were\r\nLizzieites and of course Conservatives in politics,--it was by no\r\nmeans clear that the diamonds did not pass to her by will. If it\r\ncould be shown that the diamonds had been lately kept in Scotland,\r\nthe ex-Attorney-General thought that they would so pass. All which\r\nquestions, now that the jewels had been lost, were discussed openly,\r\nand added greatly to the anxiety of the police. Both Lizzieites and\r\nanti-Lizzieites were disposed to think that Lizzie was very clever.\r\n\r\nFrank Greystock in these days took up his cousin\'s part altogether in\r\ngood faith. He entertained not the slightest suspicion that she was\r\ndeceiving him in regard to the diamonds. That the robbery had been a\r\nbona-fide robbery, and that Lizzie had lost her treasure, was to him\r\nbeyond doubt. He had gradually convinced himself that Mr. Camperdown\r\nwas wrong in his claim, and was strongly of opinion that Lord Fawn\r\nhad disgraced himself by his conduct to the lady. When he now heard,\r\nas he did hear, that some undefined suspicion was attached to his\r\ncousin,--and when he heard also, as unfortunately he did hear,--that\r\nLord Fawn had encouraged that suspicion, he was very irate, and said\r\ngrievous things of Lord Fawn. It seemed to him to be the extremity\r\nof cruelty that suspicion should be attached to his cousin because\r\nshe had been robbed of her jewels. He was among those who were most\r\nsevere in their denunciation of the police,--and was the more so,\r\nbecause he had heard it asserted that the necklace had not in truth\r\nbeen stolen. He busied himself very much in the matter, and even\r\ninterrogated John Eustace as to his intentions. "My dear fellow,"\r\nsaid Eustace, "if you hated those diamonds as much as I do, you would\r\nnever mention them again." Greystock declared that this expression of\r\naversion to the subject might be all very well for Mr. Eustace, but\r\nthat he found himself bound to defend his cousin. "You cannot defend\r\nher against me," said Eustace, "for I do not attack her. I have never\r\nsaid a word against her. I went down to Portray when she asked me. As\r\nfar as I am concerned she is perfectly welcome to wear the necklace,\r\nif she can get it back again. I will not make or meddle in the matter\r\none way or the other." Frank, after that, went to Mr. Camperdown, but\r\nhe could get no satisfaction from the attorney. Mr. Camperdown would\r\nonly say that he had a duty to do, and that he must do it. On the\r\nmatter of the robbery he refused to give an opinion. That was in the\r\nhands of the police. Should the diamonds be recovered, he would, of\r\ncourse, claim them on behalf of the estate. In his opinion, whether\r\nthe diamonds were recovered or not, Lady Eustace was responsible to\r\nthe estate for their value. In opposition, first to the entreaties,\r\nand then to the demands of her late husband\'s family, she had\r\ninsisted on absurdly carrying about with her an enormous amount of\r\nproperty which did not belong to her. Mr. Camperdown opined that\r\nshe must pay for the lost diamonds out of her jointure. Frank, in a\r\nhuff, declared that, as far as he could see, the diamonds belonged\r\nto his cousin;--in answer to which Mr. Camperdown suggested that\r\nthe question was one for the decision of the Vice-Chancellor. Frank\r\nGreystock found that he could do nothing with Mr. Camperdown, and\r\nfelt that he could wreak his vengeance only on Lord Fawn.\r\n\r\nBunfit, when he returned from Mrs. Carbuncle\'s house to Scotland\r\nYard, had an interview with Major Mackintosh. "Well, Bunfit, have you\r\nseen the lady?"\r\n\r\n"Yes,--I did see her, sir."\r\n\r\n"And what came of it?"\r\n\r\n"She fainted away, sir--just as they always do."\r\n\r\n"There was no search, I suppose?"\r\n\r\n"No, sir;--no search. She wouldn\'t have it, unless her cousin, Mr.\r\nGreystock, permitted."\r\n\r\n"I didn\'t think she would."\r\n\r\n"Nor yet didn\'t I, sir. But I\'ll tell you what it is, major. She\r\nknows all about it."\r\n\r\n"You think she does, Bunfit?"\r\n\r\n"She does, sir; and she\'s got something locked up somewhere in that\r\nhouse as\'d elucidate the whole of this aggravating mystery, if only\r\nwe could get at it. Major,--"\r\n\r\n"Well, Bunfit?"\r\n\r\n"I ain\'t noways sure as she ain\'t got them very diamonds themselves\r\nlocked up, or, perhaps, tied round her person."\r\n\r\n"Neither am I sure that she has not," said the major.\r\n\r\n"The robbery at Carlisle was no robbery," continued Bunfit. "It was\r\na got-up plant, and about the best as I ever knowed. It\'s my mind\r\nthat it was a got-up plant between her ladyship and his lordship; and\r\neither the one or the other is just keeping the diamonds till it\'s\r\nsafe to take \'em into the market."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER L\r\n\r\nIn Hertford Street\r\n\r\n\r\nDuring all this time Lucinda Roanoke was engaged to marry Sir Griffin\r\nTewett, and the lover was an occasional visitor in Hertford Street.\r\nMrs. Carbuncle was as anxious as ever that the marriage should be\r\ncelebrated on the appointed day, and though there had been repeated\r\nquarrels, nothing had as yet taken place to make her despond. Sir\r\nGriffin would make some offensive speech; Lucinda would tell him\r\nthat she had no desire ever to see him again; and then the baronet,\r\nusually under the instigation of Lord George, would make some awkward\r\napology. Mrs. Carbuncle,--whose life at this period was not a\r\npleasant one,--would behave on such occasions with great patience,\r\nand sometimes with great courage. Lizzie, who in her present\r\nemergency could not bear the idea of losing the assistance of any\r\nfriend, was soft and graceful, and even gracious, to the bear. The\r\nbear himself certainly seemed to desire the marriage, though he would\r\nso often give offence which made any prospect of a marriage almost\r\nimpossible. But with Sir Griffin, when the prize seemed to be lost,\r\nit again became valuable. He would talk about his passionate love to\r\nMrs. Carbuncle, and to Lizzie,--and then, when things had been made\r\nstraight for him, he would insult them, and neglect Lucinda. To\r\nLucinda herself, however, he would rarely dare to say such words as\r\nhe used daily to the other two ladies in the house. What could have\r\nbeen the man\'s own idea of his future married life, how can any\r\nreader be made to understand, or any writer adequately describe! He\r\nmust have known that the woman despised him, and hated him. In the\r\nvery bottom of his heart he feared her. He had no idea of other\r\npleasure from her society than what might arise to him from the pride\r\nof having married a beautiful woman. Had she shown the slightest\r\nfondness for him, the slightest fear that she might lose him, the\r\nslightest feeling that she had won a valuable prize in getting him,\r\nhe would have scorned her, and jilted her without the slightest\r\nremorse. But the scorn came from her, and it beat him down.\r\n"Yes;--you hate me, and would fain be rid of me; but you have said\r\nthat you will be my wife, and you cannot now escape me." Sir Griffin\r\ndid not exactly speak such words as these, but he acted them. Lucinda\r\nwould bear his presence,--sitting apart from him, silent, imperious,\r\nbut very beautiful. People said that she became more handsome from\r\nday to day, and she did so, in spite of her agony. Hers was a face\r\nwhich could stand such condition of the heart without fading or\r\nsinking under it. She did not weep, or lose her colour, or become\r\nthin. The pretty softness of a girl,--delicate feminine weakness,\r\nor laughing eyes and pouting lips, no one expected from her. Sir\r\nGriffin, in the early days of their acquaintance, had found her to be\r\na woman with a character for beauty,--and she was now more beautiful\r\nthan ever.
