He probably thought that he loved her; but, at any rate,\r\nhe was determined that he would marry her.\r\n\r\nHe had expressed himself more than once as very angry about this\r\naffair of the jewels. He had told Mrs. Carbuncle that her inmate,\r\nLady Eustace, was suspected by the police, and that it might be well\r\nthat Lady Eustace should be--be made to go, in fact. But it did not\r\nsuit Mrs. Carbuncle that Lady Eustace should be made to go;--nor\r\ndid it suit Lord George de Bruce Carruthers. Lord George, at Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle\'s instance, had snubbed Sir Griffin more than once, and\r\nthen it came to pass that he was snubbed yet again more violently\r\nthan before. He was at the house in Hertford Street on the day of Mr.\r\nBunfit\'s visit, some hours after Mr. Bunfit was gone, when Lizzie was\r\nstill lying on her bed up-stairs, nearly beaten by the great danger\r\nwhich had oppressed her. He was told of Mr. Bunfit\'s visit, and then\r\nagain said that he thought that the continued residence of Lady\r\nEustace beneath that roof was a misfortune. "Would you wish us\r\nto turn her out because her necklace has been stolen?" asked Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle.\r\n\r\n"People say very queer things," said Sir Griffin.\r\n\r\n"So they do, Sir Griffin," continued Mrs. Carbuncle. "They say such\r\nqueer things that I can hardly understand that they should be allowed\r\nto say them. I am told that the police absolutely suggest that Lord\r\nGeorge stole the diamonds."\r\n\r\n"That\'s nonsense."\r\n\r\n"No doubt, Sir Griffin. And so is the other nonsense. Do you mean to\r\ntell us that you believe that Lady Eustace stole her own diamonds?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t see the use of having her here. Situated as I am, I have a\r\nright to object to it."\r\n\r\n"Situated as you are, Sir Griffin!" said Lucinda.\r\n\r\n"Well;--yes, of course; if we are to be married, I cannot but think a\r\ngood deal of the persons you stay with."\r\n\r\n"You were very glad to stay yourself with Lady Eustace at Portray,"\r\nsaid Lucinda.\r\n\r\n"I went there to follow you," said Sir Griffin gallantly.\r\n\r\n"I wish with all my heart you had stayed away," said Lucinda. At\r\nthat moment Lord George was shown into the room, and Miss Roanoke\r\ncontinued speaking, determined that Lord George should know how the\r\nbear was conducting himself. "Sir Griffin is saying that my aunt\r\nought to turn Lady Eustace out of the house."\r\n\r\n"Not quite that," said Sir Griffin with an attempt at laughter.\r\n\r\n"Quite that," said Lucinda. "I don\'t suppose that he suspects poor\r\nLady Eustace, but he thinks that my aunt\'s friend should be like\r\nCaesar\'s wife, above the suspicion of others."\r\n\r\n"If you would mind your own business, Tewett," said Lord George, "it\r\nwould be a deal better for us all. I wonder Mrs. Carbuncle does not\r\nturn you out of the room for making such a proposition here. If it\r\nwere my room, I would."\r\n\r\n"I suppose I can say what I please to Mrs. Carbuncle? Miss Roanoke is\r\nnot going to be your wife."\r\n\r\n"It is my belief that Miss Roanoke will be nobody\'s wife,--at any\r\nrate, for the present," said that young lady;--upon which Sir Griffin\r\nleft the room, muttering some words which might have been, perhaps,\r\nintended for an adieu. Immediately after this, Lizzie came in, moving\r\nslowly, but without a sound, like a ghost, with pale cheeks and\r\ndishevelled hair, and that weary, worn look of illness which was\r\nbecome customary with her. She greeted Lord George with a faint\r\nattempt at a smile, and seated herself in a corner of a sofa. She\r\nasked whether he had been told the story of the proposed search, and\r\nthen bade her friend Mrs. Carbuncle describe the scene.\r\n\r\n"If it goes on like this it will kill me," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"They are treating me in precisely the same way," said Lord George.\r\n\r\n"But think of your strength and of my weakness, Lord George."\r\n\r\n"By heavens, I don\'t know!" said Lord George. "In this matter your\r\nweakness is stronger than any strength of mine. I never was so cut up\r\nin my life. It was a good joke when we talked of the suspicions of\r\nthat fellow at Carlisle as we came up by the railway,--but it is no\r\njoke now. I\'ve had men with me, almost asking to search among my\r\nthings."\r\n\r\n"They have quite asked me!" said Lizzie piteously.\r\n\r\n"You;--yes. But there\'s some reason in that. These infernal diamonds\r\ndid belong to you, or, at any rate, you had them. You are the last\r\nperson known to have seen them. Even if you had them still, you\'d\r\nonly have what you call your own." Lizzie looked at him with all her\r\neyes and listened to him with all her ears. "But what the mischief\r\ncan I have had to do with them?"\r\n\r\n"It\'s very hard upon you," said Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\n"Unless I stole them," continued Lord George.\r\n\r\n"Which is so absurd, you know," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"That a pig-headed provincial fool should have taken me for a\r\nmidnight thief, did not disturb me much. I don\'t think I am very\r\neasily annoyed by what other people think of me. But these fellows, I\r\nsuppose, were sent here by the head of the metropolitan police; and\r\neverybody knows that they have been sent. Because I was civil enough\r\nto you women to look after you coming up to town, and because one\r\nof you was careless enough to lose her jewels, I--I am to be talked\r\nabout all over London as the man who took them!" This was not spoken\r\nwith much courtesy to the ladies present. Lord George had dropped\r\nthat customary chivalry of manner which, in ordinary life, makes it\r\nto be quite out of the question that a man shall be uncivil to a\r\nwoman. He had escaped from conventional usage into rough, truthful\r\nspeech, under stress from the extremity of the hardship to which he\r\nhad been subjected. And the women understood it and appreciated it,\r\nand liked it rather than otherwise. To Lizzie it seemed fitting that\r\na Corsair so circumstanced should be as uncivil as he pleased; and\r\nMrs. Carbuncle had long been accustomed to her friend\'s moods.\r\n\r\n"They can\'t really think it," said Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\n"Somebody thinks it. I am told that your particular friend, Lord\r\nFawn,"--this he said, specially addressing Lizzie,--"has expressed a\r\nstrong opinion that I carry about the necklace always in my pocket. I\r\ntrust to have the opportunity of wringing his neck some day."\r\n\r\n"I do so wish you would," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"I shall not lose a chance if I can get it. Before all this occurred\r\nI should have said of myself that nothing of the kind could put me\r\nout. I don\'t think there is a man in the world cares less what people\r\nsay of him than I do. I am as indifferent to ordinary tittle-tattle\r\nas a rhinoceros. But, by George,--when it comes to stealing ten\r\nthousand pounds\' worth of diamonds, and the delicate attentions\r\nof all the metropolitan police, one begins to feel that one is\r\nvulnerable. When I get up in the morning, I half feel that I shall be\r\nlocked up before night, and I can see in the eyes of every man I meet\r\nthat he takes me for the prince of burglars!"\r\n\r\n"And it is all my fault," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"I wish the diamonds had been thrown into the sea," said Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle.\r\n\r\n"What do you think about them yourself?" asked Lucinda.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know what to think. I\'m at a dead loss. You know that man\r\nMr. Benjamin, Lady Eustace?" Lizzie, with a little start, answered\r\nthat she did,--that she had had dealings with him before her\r\nmarriage, and had once owed him two or three hundred pounds. As the\r\nman\'s name had been mentioned, she thought it better to own as much.\r\n"So he tells me. Now, in all London, I don\'t suppose there is a\r\ngreater rascal than Benjamin."\r\n\r\n"I didn\'t know that," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"But I did; and with that rascal I have had money dealings for the\r\nlast six or seven years. He has cashed bills for me, and has my name\r\nto bills now,--and Sir Griffin\'s too. I\'m half inclined to think that\r\nhe has got the diamonds."\r\n\r\n"Do you indeed?" said Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\n"Mr. Benjamin!" said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"And he returns the compliment."\r\n\r\n"How does he return it?" asked Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\n"He either thinks that I\'ve got \'em, or he wants to make me believe\r\nthat he thinks so. He hasn\'t dared to say it;--but that\'s his\r\nintention. Such an opinion from such a man on such a subject would be\r\nquite a compliment. And I feel it. But yet it troubles me. You know\r\nthat greasy, Israelitish smile of his, Lady Eustace." Lizzie nodded\r\nher head and tried to smile. "When I asked him yesterday about the\r\ndiamonds, he leered at me and rubbed his hands. \'It\'s a pretty little\r\ngame;--ain\'t it, Lord George?\' he said. I told him that I thought it\r\na very bad game, and that I hoped the police would have the thief and\r\nthe necklace soon. \'It\'s been managed a deal too well for that, Lord\r\nGeorge;--don\'t you think so?\'" Lord George mimicked the Jew as he\r\nrepeated the words, and the ladies, of course, laughed. But poor\r\nLizzie\'s attempt at laughter was very sorry. "I told him to his face\r\nthat I thought he had them among his treasures. \'No, no, no, Lord\r\nGeorge,\' he said, and seemed quite to enjoy the joke. If he\'s got\r\nthem himself, he can\'t think that I have them;--but if he has not, I\r\ndon\'t doubt but he believes that I have. And I\'ll tell you another\r\nperson who suspects me."\r\n\r\n"What fools they are," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know how that may be. Sir Griffin, Lucinda, isn\'t at all\r\nsure but what I have them in my pocket."\r\n\r\n"I can believe anything of him," said Lucinda.\r\n\r\n"And it seems he can believe anything of me. I shall begin to think\r\nsoon that I did take them, myself,--or, at any rate, that I ought to\r\nhave done so. I wonder what you three women think of it. If you do\r\nthink I\'ve got \'em, don\'t scruple to say so. I\'m quite used to it,\r\nand it won\'t hurt me any further." The ladies again laughed. "You\r\nmust have your suspicions," continued he.\r\n\r\n"I suppose some of the London thieves did get them," said Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle.\r\n\r\n"The police say the box was empty," said Lord George.\r\n\r\n"How can the police know?" asked Lucinda. "They weren\'t there to see.\r\nOf course, the thieves would say that they didn\'t take them."\r\n\r\n"What do you think, Lady Eustace?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know what to think. Perhaps Mr. Camperdown did it."\r\n\r\n"Or the Lord Chancellor," said Lord George. "One is just as likely\r\nas the other. I wish I could get at what you really think. The whole\r\nthing would be so complete if all you three suspected me. I can\'t get\r\nout of it all by going to Paris or Kamschatka, as I should have half\r\na dozen detectives on my heels wherever I went. I must brazen it out\r\nhere; and the worst of it is, that I feel that a look of guilt is\r\ncreeping over me. I have a sort of conviction growing upon me that I\r\nshall be taken up and tried, and that a jury will find me guilty. I\r\ndream about it; and if,--as is probable,--it drives me mad, I\'m sure\r\nthat I shall accuse myself in my madness. There\'s a fascination about\r\nit that I can\'t explain or escape. I go on thinking how I would have\r\ndone it if I did do it. I spend hours in calculating how much I would\r\nhave realised, and where I would have found my market. I couldn\'t\r\nkeep myself from asking Benjamin the other day how much they would be\r\nworth to him."\r\n\r\n"What did he say?" asked Lizzie, who sat gazing upon the Corsair, and\r\nwho was now herself fascinated. Lord George was walking about the\r\nroom, then sitting for a moment in one chair and again in another,\r\nand after a while leaning on the mantelpiece. In his speaking he\r\naddressed himself almost exclusively to Lizzie, who could not keep\r\nher eyes from his.\r\n\r\n"He grinned greasily," said the Corsair, "and told me they had\r\nalready been offered to him once before by you."\r\n\r\n"That\'s false," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"Very likely. And then he said that no doubt they\'d fall into his\r\nhands some day. \'Wouldn\'t it be a game, Lord George,\' he said, \'if,\r\nafter all, they should be no more than paste?\' That made me think\r\nhe had got them, and that he\'d get paste diamonds put into the same\r\nsetting,--and then give them up with some story of his own making.\r\n\'You\'d know whether they were paste or not; wouldn\'t you, Lord\r\nGeorge?\' he asked." The Corsair, as he repeated Mr. Benjamin\'s words,\r\nimitated the Jew\'s manner so well, that he made Lizzie shudder.\r\n"While I was there, a detective named Gager came in."\r\n\r\n"The same man who came here, perhaps," suggested Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\n"I think not. He seemed to be quite intimate with Mr. Benjamin, and\r\nwent on at once about the diamonds. Benjamin said that they\'d made\r\ntheir way over to Paris, and that he\'d heard of them. I found myself\r\ngetting quite intimate with Mr. Gager, who seemed hardly to scruple\r\nat showing that he thought that Benjamin and I were confederates. Mr.\r\nCamperdown has offered four hundred pounds reward for the jewels,--to\r\nbe paid on their surrender to the hands of Mr. Garnett, the jeweller.\r\nGager declared that, if any ordinary thief had them, they would be\r\ngiven up at once for that sum."\r\n\r\n"That\'s true, I suppose," said Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\n"How would the ordinary thief get his money without being detected?\r\nWho would dare to walk into Garnett\'s shop with the diamonds in\r\nhis hands and ask for the four hundred pounds? Besides, they have\r\nbeen sold to some one,--and, as I believe, to my dear friend, Mr.\r\nBenjamin. \'I suppose you ain\'t a-going anywhere just at present, Lord\r\nGeorge?\' said that fellow Gager. \'What the devil\'s that to you?\' I\r\nasked him. He just laughed and shook his head. I don\'t doubt but\r\nthat there\'s a policeman about waiting till I leave this house;--or\r\nlooking at me now with a magnifying glass from the windows at the\r\nother side. They\'ve photographed me while I\'m going about, and\r\npublished a list of every hair on my face in the \'Hue and Cry.\' I\r\ndined at the club yesterday, and found a strange waiter. I feel\r\ncertain that he was a policeman done up in livery all for my sake.\r\nI turned sharp round in the street yesterday, and found a man at a\r\ncorner. I am sure that man was watching me, and was looking at my\r\npockets to see whether the jewel case was there. As for myself, I can\r\nthink of nothing else. I wish I had got them. I should have something\r\nthen to pay me for all this nuisance."\r\n\r\n"I do wish you had," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"What I should do with them I cannot even imagine. I am always\r\nthinking of that, too,--making plans for getting rid of them,\r\nsupposing I had stolen them. My belief is, that I should be so\r\nsick of them that I should chuck them over the bridge into the\r\nriver,--only that I should fear that some policeman\'s eye would be on\r\nme as I did it. My present position is not comfortable,--but if I had\r\ngot them, I think that the weight of them would crush me altogether.\r\nHaving a handle to my name, and being a lord, or, at least, called a\r\nlord, makes it all the worse. People are so pleased to think that a\r\nlord should have stolen a necklace."\r\n\r\nLizzie listened to it all with a strange fascination. If this strong\r\nman were so much upset by the bare suspicion, what must be her\r\ncondition? The jewels were in her desk up-stairs, and the police had\r\nbeen with her also,--were even now probably looking after her and\r\nwatching her. How much more difficult must it be for her to deal with\r\nthe diamonds than it would have been for this man. Presently Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle left the room, and Lucinda followed her. Lizzie saw them\r\ngo, and did not dare to go with them. She felt as though her limbs\r\nwould not have carried her to the door. She was now alone with her\r\nCorsair; and she looked up timidly into his deep-set eyes, as he came\r\nand stood over her. "Tell me all that you know about it," he said, in\r\nthat deep, low voice which, from her first acquaintance with him, had\r\nfilled her with interest, and almost with awe.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LI\r\n\r\nConfidence\r\n\r\n\r\nLizzie Eustace was speechless as she continued to look up into the\r\nCorsair\'s face. She ought to have answered him briskly, either with\r\nindignation or with a touch of humour. But she could not answer him\r\nat all. She was desired to tell him all that she knew about the\r\nrobbery, and she was unable to declare that she knew nothing. How\r\nmuch did he suspect? What did he believe? Had she been watched by\r\nMrs. Carbuncle, and had something of the truth been told to him?\r\nAnd then would it not be better for her that he should know it all?\r\nUnsupported and alone she could not bear the trouble which was on\r\nher. If she were driven to tell her secret to any one, had she not\r\nbetter tell it to him? She knew that if she did so, she would be a\r\ncreature in his hands to be dealt with as he pleased;--but would\r\nthere not be a certain charm in being so mastered? He was but a\r\npinchbeck lord. She had wit enough to know that; but then she had wit\r\nenough also to feel that she herself was but a pinchbeck lady. He\r\nwould be fit for her, and she for him,--if only he would take her.\r\nSince her daydreams first began, she had been longing for a Corsair;\r\nand here he was, not kneeling at her feet, but standing over her,--as\r\nbecame a Corsair. At any rate he had mastered her now, and she could\r\nnot speak to him.\r\n\r\nHe waited perhaps a minute, looking at her, before he renewed his\r\nquestion; and the minute seemed to her to be an age. During every\r\nsecond her power beneath his gaze sank lower and lower. There\r\ngradually came a grim smile over his face, and she was sure that\r\nhe could read her very heart. Then he called her by her Christian\r\nname,--as he had never called her before. "Come, Lizzie," he said,\r\n"you might as well tell me all about it. You know."\r\n\r\n"Know what?" The words were audible to him, though they were uttered\r\nin the lowest whisper.\r\n\r\n"About this d---- necklace. What is it all? Where are they? And how\r\ndid you manage it?"\r\n\r\n"I didn\'t manage anything!"\r\n\r\n"But you know where they are?" He paused again, still gazing at her.\r\nGradually there came across his face, or she fancied that it was so,\r\na look of ferocity which thoroughly frightened her. If he should turn\r\nagainst her, and be leagued with the police against her, what chance\r\nwould she have? "You know where they are," he said, repeating his\r\nwords. Then at last she nodded her head, assenting to his assertion.\r\n"And where are they? Come;--out with it! If you won\'t tell me, you\r\nmust tell some one else. There has been a deal too much of this\r\nalready."\r\n\r\n"You won\'t betray me?"\r\n\r\n"Not if you deal openly with me."\r\n\r\n"I will; indeed I will. And it was all an accident. When I took them\r\nout of the box, I only did it for safety."\r\n\r\n"You did take them out of the box then?" Again she nodded her head.\r\n"And have got them now?" There was another nod. "And where are they?\r\nCome; with such a spirit of enterprise as yours you ought to be able\r\nto speak. Has Benjamin got them?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, no."\r\n\r\n"And he knows nothing about them?"\r\n\r\n"Nothing."\r\n\r\n"Then I have wronged in my thoughts that son of Abraham?"\r\n\r\n"Nobody knows anything," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"Not even Jane or Lucinda?"\r\n\r\n"Nothing at all."\r\n\r\n"Then you have kept your secret marvellously. And where are they?"\r\n\r\n"Up-stairs."\r\n\r\n"In your bed-room?"\r\n\r\n"In my desk in the little sitting-room."\r\n\r\n"The Lord be good to us!" ejaculated Lord George. "All the police in\r\nLondon, from the chief downwards, are agog about this necklace. Every\r\nwell-known thief in the town is envied by every other thief because\r\nhe is thought to have had a finger in the pie. I am suspected, and\r\nMr. Benjamin is suspected; Sir Griffin is suspected, and half the\r\njewellers in London and Paris are supposed to have the stones in\r\ntheir keeping. Every man and woman is talking about it, and people\r\nare quarrelling about it till they almost cut each other\'s throats;\r\nand all the while you have got them locked up in your desk! How on\r\nearth did you get the box broken open and then conveyed out of your\r\nroom at Carlisle?"\r\n\r\nThen Lizzie, in a frightened whisper, with her eyes often turned on\r\nthe floor, told the whole story. "If I\'d had a minute to think of\r\nit," she said, "I would have confessed the truth at Carlisle. Why\r\nshould I want to steal what was my own? But they came to me all so\r\nquickly, and I didn\'t like to say that I had them under my pillow."\r\n\r\n"I daresay not."\r\n\r\n"And then I couldn\'t tell anybody afterwards. I always meant to tell\r\nyou,--from the very first; because I knew you would be good to me.\r\nThey are my own. Surely I might do what I liked with my own?"\r\n\r\n"Well,--yes; in one way. But you see there was a lawsuit in Chancery\r\ngoing on about them; and then you committed perjury at Carlisle. And\r\naltogether,--it\'s not quite straight sailing, you know."\r\n\r\n"I suppose not."\r\n\r\n"Hardly. Major Mackintosh, and the magistrates, and Messrs. Bunfit\r\nand Gager won\'t settle down, peaceable and satisfied, when they hear\r\nthe end of the story. And I think Messrs. Camperdown will have a bill\r\nagainst you. It\'s been uncommonly clever, but I don\'t see the use of\r\nit."\r\n\r\n"I\'ve been very foolish," said Lizzie,--"but you won\'t desert me!"\r\n\r\n"Upon my word I don\'t know what I\'m to do."\r\n\r\n"Will you have them,--as a present?"\r\n\r\n"Certainly not."\r\n\r\n"They\'re worth ever so much;--ten thousand pounds! And they are my\r\nown, to do just what I please with them."\r\n\r\n"You are very good;--but what should I do with them?"\r\n\r\n"Sell them."\r\n\r\n"Who\'d buy them? And before a week was over I should be in prison,\r\nand in a couple of months should be standing at the Old Bailey at my\r\ntrial. I couldn\'t just do that, my dear."\r\n\r\n"What will you do for me? You are my friend;--ain\'t you?" The diamond\r\nnecklace was not a desirable possession in the eyes of Lord George\r\nde Bruce Carruthers;--but Portray Castle, with its income, and\r\nthe fact that Lizzie Eustace was still a very young woman, was\r\ndesirable. Her prettiness too was not altogether thrown away on Lord\r\nGeorge,--though, as he was wont to say to himself, he was too old now\r\nto sacrifice much for such a toy as that. Something he must do,--if\r\nonly because of the knowledge which had come to him. He could not go\r\naway and leave her, and neither say nor do anything in the matter.\r\nAnd he could not betray her to the police. "You will not desert me!"\r\nshe said, taking hold of his hand, and kissing it as a suppliant.\r\n\r\nHe passed his arm round her waist, but more as though she were a\r\nchild than a woman, as he stood thinking. Of all the affairs in which\r\nhe had ever been engaged, it was the most difficult. She submitted\r\nto his embrace, and leaned upon his shoulder, and looked up into his\r\nface. If he would only tell her that he loved her, then he would\r\nbe bound to her,--then must he share with her the burthen of the\r\ndiamonds,--then must he be true to her. "George!" she said, and burst\r\ninto a low suppressed wailing, with her face hidden upon his arm.\r\n\r\n"That\'s all very well," said he, still holding her,--for she was\r\npleasant to hold,--"but what the d---- is a fellow to do? I don\'t\r\nsee my way out of it. I think you\'d better go to Camperdown, and\r\ngive them up to him, and tell him the truth." Then she sobbed more\r\nviolently than before, till her quick ear caught the sound of a\r\nfootstep on the stairs, and in a moment she was out of his arms and\r\nseated on the sofa, with hardly a trace of tears in her eyes. It was\r\nthe footman, who desired to know whether Lady Eustace would want the\r\ncarriage that afternoon. Lady Eustace, with her cheeriest voice, sent\r\nher love to Mrs. Carbuncle, and her assurance that she would not\r\nwant the carriage before the evening. "I don\'t know that you can do\r\nanything else," continued Lord George, "except just give them up and\r\nbrazen it out. I don\'t suppose they\'d prosecute you."\r\n\r\n"Prosecute me!" ejaculated Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"For perjury, I mean."\r\n\r\n"And what could they do to me?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, I don\'t know. Lock you up for five years, perhaps."\r\n\r\n"Because I had my own necklace under the pillow in my own room?"\r\n\r\n"Think of all the trouble you\'ve given."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll never give them up to Mr. Camperdown. They are mine;--my very\r\nown. My cousin, Mr. Greystock, who is much more of a lawyer than Mr.\r\nCamperdown, says so. Oh, George, do think of something! Don\'t tell me\r\nthat I must give them up! Wouldn\'t Mr. Benjamin buy them?"\r\n\r\n"Yes;--for half nothing; and then go and tell the whole story and get\r\nmoney from the other side. You can\'t trust Benjamin."\r\n\r\n"But I can trust you." She clung to him and implored him, and did\r\nget from him a renewed promise that he would not reveal her secret.\r\nShe wanted him to take the terrible packet from her there and then,\r\nand use his own judgment in disposing of it. But this he positively\r\nrefused to do. He protested that they were safer with her than they\r\ncould be with him. He explained to her that if they were found in his\r\nhands, his offence in having them in his possession would be much\r\ngreater than hers. They were her own,--as she was ever so ready to\r\nassert; or if not her own, the ownership was so doubtful that she\r\ncould not be accused of having stolen them. And then he needed to\r\nconsider it all,--to sleep upon it,--before he could make up his mind\r\nwhat he would do.\r\n\r\nBut there was one other trouble on her mind as to which he was called\r\nupon to give her counsel before he was allowed to leave her. She had\r\ntold the detective officer that she would submit her boxes and desks\r\nto be searched if her cousin Frank should advise it. If the policeman\r\nwere to return with her cousin while the diamonds were still in her\r\ndesk, what should she do? He might come at any time; and then she\r\nwould be bound to obey him. "And he thinks that they were stolen at\r\nCarlisle?" asked Lord George. "Of course he thinks so," said Lizzie,\r\nalmost indignantly. "They would never ask to search your person,"\r\nsuggested Lord George. Lizzie could not say. She had simply declared\r\nthat she would be guided by her cousin. "Have them about you when he\r\ncomes. Don\'t take them out with you; but keep them in your pocket\r\nwhile you are in the house during the day. They will hardly bring a\r\nwoman with them to search you."\r\n\r\n"But there was a woman with the man when he came before."\r\n\r\n"Then you must refuse in spite of your cousin. Show yourself angry\r\nwith him and with everybody. Swear that you did not intend to submit\r\nyourself to such indignity as that. They can\'t do it without a\r\nmagistrate\'s order, unless you permit it. I don\'t suppose they will\r\ncome at all; and if they do they will only look at your clothes and\r\nyour boxes. If they ask to do more, be stout with them and refuse. Of\r\ncourse they\'ll suspect you, but they do that already. And your cousin\r\nwill suspect you;--but you must put up with that. It will be very\r\nbad;--but I see nothing better. But, of all things, say nothing of\r\nme."\r\n\r\n"Oh, no," said Lizzie, promising to be obedient to him. And then he\r\ntook his leave of her. "You will be true to me;--will you not?" she\r\nsaid, still clinging to his arm. He promised her that he would. "Oh,\r\nGeorge," she said, "I have no friend now but you. You will care for\r\nme?" He took her in his arms and kissed her, and promised her that he\r\nwould care for her. How was he to save himself from doing so? When he\r\nwas gone, Lizzie sat down to think of it all, and felt sure that at\r\nlast she had found her Corsair.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LII\r\n\r\nMrs. Carbuncle Goes to the Theatre\r\n\r\n\r\nMrs. Carbuncle and Lizzie Eustace did not, in these days, shut\r\nthemselves up because there was trouble in the household. It would\r\nnot have suited the creed of Mrs. Carbuncle on social matters to be\r\nshut up from the amusements of life. She had sacrificed too much\r\nin seeking them for that, and was too conscious of the price she\r\npaid for them. It was still mid-winter, but nevertheless there was\r\ngenerally some amusement arranged for every evening. Mrs. Carbuncle\r\nwas very fond of the play, and made herself acquainted with every\r\nnew piece as it came out. Every actor and actress of note on the\r\nstage was known to her, and she dealt freely in criticisms on their\r\nrespective merits. The three ladies had a box at the Haymarket taken\r\nfor this very evening, at which a new piece, "The Noble Jilt," from\r\nthe hand of a very eminent author, was to be produced. Mrs. Carbuncle\r\nhad talked a great deal about "The Noble Jilt," and could boast\r\nthat she had discussed the merits of the two chief characters with\r\nthe actor and actress who were to undertake them. Miss Talbot had\r\nassured her that the Margaret was altogether impracticable, and\r\nMrs. Carbuncle was quite of the same opinion. And as for the hero,\r\nSteinmark,--it was a part that no man could play so as to obtain\r\nthe sympathy of an audience. There was a second hero,--a Flemish\r\nCount,--tame as rain-water, Mrs. Carbuncle said. She was very anxious\r\nfor the success of the piece, which, as she said, had its merits;\r\nbut she was sure that it wouldn\'t do. She had talked about it a\r\ngreat deal, and now, when the evening came, she was not going to be\r\ndeterred from seeing it by any trouble in reference to a diamond\r\nnecklace. Lizzie, when she was left by Lord George, had many doubts\r\non the subject,--whether she would go or stay at home. If he would\r\nhave come to her, or her cousin Frank, or if, had it been possible,\r\nLord Fawn would have come, she would have given up the play very\r\nwillingly. But to be alone,--with her necklace in the desk up-stairs,\r\nor in her pocket, was terrible to her. And then, they could not\r\nsearch her or her boxes while she was at the theatre. She must not\r\ntake the necklace with her there. He had told her to leave it in her\r\ndesk, when she went from home.\r\n\r\nLucinda, also, was quite determined that she would see the new piece.\r\nShe declared to her aunt, in Lizzie\'s presence, without a vestige\r\nof a smile, that it might be well to see how a jilt could behave\r\nherself, so as to do her work of jilting in any noble fashion. "My\r\ndear," said her aunt, "you let things weigh upon your heart a great\r\ndeal too much." "Not upon my heart, Aunt Jane," the young lady had\r\nanswered. She also intended to go, and when she had made up her mind\r\nto anything, nothing would deter her. She had no desire to stay at\r\nhome in order that she might see Sir Griffin. "I daresay the play may\r\nbe very bad," she said, "but it can hardly be so bad as real life."\r\n\r\nLizzie, when Lord George had left her, crept up-stairs, and sat for\r\nawhile thinking of her condition, with the key of her desk in her\r\nhand. Should there come a knock at the door, the case of diamonds\r\nwould be in her pocket in a moment. Her own room door was bolted on\r\nthe inside, so that she might have an instant for her preparation.\r\nShe was quite resolved that she would carry out Lord George\'s\r\nrecommendation, and that no policeman or woman should examine her\r\nperson, unless it were done by violence. There she sat, almost\r\nexpecting that at every moment her cousin would be there with Bunfit\r\nand the woman. But nobody came, and at six she went down to dinner.\r\nAfter much consideration she then left the diamonds in the desk.\r\nSurely no one would come to search at such an hour as that. No one\r\nhad come when the carriage was announced, and the three ladies went\r\noff together.\r\n\r\nDuring the whole way Mrs. Carbuncle talked of the terrible situation\r\nin which poor Lord George was placed by the robbery, and of all\r\nthat Lizzie owed him on account of his trouble. "My dear," said Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle, "the least you can do for him is to give him all that\r\nyou\'ve got to give." "I don\'t know that he wants me to give him\r\nanything," said Lizzie. "I think that\'s quite plain," said Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle, "and I\'m sure I wish it may be so. He and I have been dear\r\nfriends,--very dear friends, and there is nothing I wish so much\r\nas to see him properly settled. Ill-natured people like to say all\r\nmanner of things because everybody does not choose to live in their\r\nown heartless, conventional form. But I can assure you there is\r\nnothing between me and Lord George which need prevent him from giving\r\nhis whole heart to you." "I don\'t suppose there is," said Lizzie, who\r\nloved an opportunity of giving Mrs. Carbuncle a little rap.\r\n\r\nThe play, as a play, was a failure; at least so said Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\nThe critics, on the next morning, were somewhat divided,--not only in\r\njudgment, but as to facts. To say how a play has been received is of\r\nmore moment than to speak of its own merits or of the merits of the\r\nactors. Three or four of the papers declared that the audience was\r\nnot only eulogistic, but enthusiastic. One or two others averred that\r\nthe piece fell very flatly. As it was not acted above four or five\r\ndozen times consecutively, it must be regarded as a failure. On their\r\nway home Mrs. Carbuncle declared that Minnie Talbot had done her very\r\nbest with such a part as Margaret, but that the character afforded\r\nno scope for sympathy. "A noble jilt, my dears," said Mrs. Carbuncle\r\neloquently, "is a contradiction in terms. There can be no such thing.\r\nA woman, when she has once said the word, is bound to stick to it.\r\nThe delicacy of the female character should not admit of hesitation\r\nbetween two men. The idea is quite revolting."\r\n\r\n"But may not one have an idea of no man at all?"--asked Lucinda.\r\n"Must that be revolting also?"\r\n\r\n"Of course a young woman may entertain such an idea; though for my\r\npart I look upon it as unnatural. But when she has once given herself\r\nthere can be no taking back without the loss of that aroma which\r\nshould be the apple of a young woman\'s eye."\r\n\r\n"If she finds that she has made a mistake--?" said Lucinda fiercely.\r\n"Why shouldn\'t a young woman make a mistake as well as an old woman?\r\nHer aroma won\'t prevent her from having been wrong and finding it\r\nout."\r\n\r\n"My dear, such mistakes, as you call them, always arise from\r\nfantastic notions. Look at this piece. Why does the lady jilt her\r\nlover? Not because she doesn\'t like him. She\'s just as fond of him as\r\never."\r\n\r\n"He\'s a stupid sort of a fellow, and I think she was quite right,"\r\nsaid Lizzie. "I\'d never marry a man merely because I said I would. If\r\nI found I didn\'t like him, I\'d leave him at the altar. If I found I\r\ndidn\'t like him, I\'d leave him even after the altar. I\'d leave him\r\nany time I found I didn\'t like him. It\'s all very well to talk of\r\naroma, but to live with a man you don\'t like--is the devil!"\r\n\r\n"My dear, those whom God has joined together shouldn\'t be\r\nseparated,--for any mere likings or dislikings." This Mrs. Carbuncle\r\nsaid in a high tone of moral feeling, just as the carriage stopped\r\nat the door in Hertford Street. They at once perceived that the\r\nhall-door was open, and Mrs. Carbuncle, as she crossed the pavement,\r\nsaw that there were two policemen in the hall. The footman had\r\nbeen with them to the theatre, but the cook and housemaid, and Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle\'s own maid, were with the policemen in the passage. She\r\ngave a little scream, and then Lizzie, who had followed her, seized\r\nher by the arm. She turned round and saw by the gas-light that\r\nLizzie\'s face was white as a sheet, and that all the lines of her\r\ncountenance were rigid and almost distorted. "Then she does know all\r\nabout it!" said Mrs. Carbuncle to herself. Lizzie didn\'t speak, but\r\nstill hung on to Mrs. Carbuncle\'s arm, and Lucinda, having seen how\r\nit was, was also supporting her. A policeman stepped forward and\r\ntouched his hat. He was not Bunfit;--neither was he Gager. Indeed,\r\nthough the ladies had not perceived the difference, he was not at all\r\nlike Bunfit or Gager. This man was dressed in a policeman\'s uniform,\r\nwhereas Bunfit and Gager always wore plain clothes. "My lady," said\r\nthe policeman, addressing Mrs. Carbuncle, "there\'s been a robbery\r\nhere."\r\n\r\n"A robbery!" ejaculated Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\n"Yes, my lady. The servants all out,--all to one; and she\'s off.\r\nThey\'ve taken jewels, and, no doubt, money, if there was any. They\r\ndon\'t mostly come unless they know what they comes for."\r\n\r\nWith a horrid spasm across her heart, which seemed ready to kill\r\nher, so sharp was the pain, Lizzie recovered the use of her legs and\r\nfollowed Mrs. Carbuncle into the dining-room. She had been hardly\r\nconscious of hearing; but she had heard, and it had seemed to her\r\nthat the robbery spoken of was something distinct from her own\r\naffair. The policemen did not speak of having found the diamonds. It\r\nwas of something lost that they spoke. She seated herself in a chair\r\nagainst the wall, but did not utter a word. "We\'ve been up-stairs,\r\nmy lady, and they\'ve been in most of the rooms. There\'s a desk broke\r\nopen,"--Lizzie gave an involuntary little scream;--"Yes, mum, a\r\ndesk," continued the policeman turning to Lizzie, "and a bureau, and\r\na dressing-case. What\'s gone your ladyship can tell when you sees.\r\nAnd one of the young women is off. It\'s she as done it." Then the\r\ncook explained. She and the housemaid, and Mrs. Carbuncle\'s lady\'s\r\nmaid, had just stepped out, only round the corner, to get a little\r\nair, leaving Patience Crabstick in charge of the house; and when they\r\ncame back, the area gate was locked against them, the front door was\r\nlocked, and finding themselves unable to get in after many knockings,\r\nthey had at last obtained the assistance of a policeman. He had got\r\ninto the place over the area gate, had opened the front door from\r\nwithin, and then the robbery had been discovered. It was afterwards\r\nfound that the servants had all gone out to what they called a\r\ntea-party, at a public-house in the neighbourhood, and that by\r\nprevious agreement Patience Crabstick had remained in charge. When\r\nthey came back Patience Crabstick was gone, and the desk, and bureau,\r\nand dressing-case, were found to have been opened. "She had a reg\'lar\r\nthief along with her, my lady," said the policeman, still addressing\r\nhimself to Mrs. Carbuncle,--"\'cause of the way the things was\r\nopened."\r\n\r\n"I always knew that young woman was downright bad," said Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle in her first expression of wrath.\r\n\r\nBut Lizzie sat in her chair without saying a word, still pale, with\r\nthat almost awful look of agony in her face. Within ten minutes\r\nof their entering the house, Mrs. Carbuncle was making her way\r\nup-stairs, with the two policemen following her. That her bureau and\r\nher dressing-case should have been opened was dreadful to her, though\r\nthe value that she could thus lose was very small. She also possessed\r\ndiamonds,--but her diamonds were paste; and whatever jewellery she\r\nhad of any value,--a few rings, and a brooch, and such like,--had\r\nbeen on her person in the theatre. What little money she had by her\r\nwas in the drawing-room, and the drawing-room, as it seemed, had not\r\nbeen entered. In truth, all Mrs. Carbuncle\'s possessions in the house\r\nwere not sufficient to have tempted a well-bred, well-instructed\r\nthief. But it behoved her to be indignant; and she could be indignant\r\nwith grace, as the thief was discovered to be, not her maid, but\r\nPatience Crabstick. The policemen followed Mrs. Carbuncle, and the\r\nmaids followed the policemen; but Lizzie Eustace kept her seat in\r\nthe chair by the wall. "Do you think they have taken much of yours?"\r\nsaid Lucinda, coming up to her and speaking very gently. Lizzie\r\nmade a motion with her two hands upon her heart, and struggled, and\r\ngasped,--as though she wished to speak but could not. "I suppose it\r\nis that girl who has done it all," said Lucinda. Lizzie nodded her\r\nhead, and tried to smile. The attempt was so ghastly that Lucinda,\r\nthough not timid by nature, was frightened. She sat down and took\r\nLizzie\'s hand, and tried to comfort her. "It is very hard upon you,"\r\nshe said, "to be twice robbed." Lizzie again nodded her head. "I hope\r\nit is not much now. Shall we go up and see?" The poor creature did\r\nget upon her legs, but she gasped so terribly that Lucinda feared\r\nthat she was dying. "Shall I send for some one?" she said. Lizzie\r\nmade an effort to speak, was shaken convulsively while the other\r\nsupported her, and then burst into a flood of tears.\r\n\r\nWhen that had come she was relieved, and could again act her part.\r\n"Yes," she said, "we will go with them. It is so dreadful;--is it\r\nnot?"\r\n\r\n"Very dreadful;--but how much better that we weren\'t at home! Shall\r\nwe go now?" Then together they followed the others, and on the stairs\r\nLizzie explained that in her desk, of which she always carried\r\nthe key round her neck, there was what money she had by her;--two\r\nten-pound notes, and four five-pound notes, and three sovereigns;--in\r\nall, forty-three pounds. Her other jewels,--the jewels which she had\r\npossessed over and above the fatal diamond necklace,--were in her\r\ndressing-case. Patience, she did not doubt, had known that the money\r\nwas there, and certainly knew of her jewels. So they went up-stairs.\r\nThe desk was open and the money gone. Five or six rings and a\r\nbracelet had been taken also from Lizzie\'s dressing-case, which she\r\nhad left open. Of Mrs. Carbuncle\'s property sufficient had been\r\nstolen to make a long list in that lady\'s handwriting. Lucinda\r\nRoanoke\'s room had not been entered,--as far as they could judge.\r\nThe girl had taken the best of her own clothes, and a pair of strong\r\nboots belonging to the cook. A superintendent of police was there\r\nbefore they went to bed, and a list was made out. The superintendent\r\nwas of opinion that the thing had been done very cleverly, but was\r\nof opinion that the thieves had expected to find more plunder. "They\r\ndon\'t care so much about banknotes, my lady, because they fetches\r\nsuch a low price with them as they deal with. The three sovereigns is\r\nmore to them than all the forty pounds in notes." The superintendent\r\nhad heard of the diamond necklace, and expressed an opinion that poor\r\nLady Eustace was especially marked out for misfortune. "It all comes\r\nof having such a girl as that about her," said Mrs. Carbuncle. The\r\nsuperintendent, who intended to be consolatory to Lizzie, expressed\r\nhis opinion that it was very hard to know what a young woman was.\r\n"They looks as soft as butter, and they\'re as sly as foxes, and as\r\nquick, as quick--as quick as greased lightning, my lady." Such a\r\npiece of business as this which had just occurred, will make people\r\nintimate at a very short notice.\r\n\r\nAnd so the diamond necklace, known to be worth ten thousand pounds,\r\nhad at last been stolen in earnest! Lizzie, when the policemen were\r\ngone, and the noise was over, and the house was closed, slunk away to\r\nher bedroom, refusing any aid in lieu of that of the wicked Patience.\r\nShe herself had examined the desk beneath the eyes of her two friends\r\nand of the policemen, and had seen at once that the case was gone.\r\nThe money was gone too, as she was rejoiced to find. She perceived\r\nat once that had the money been left,--the very leaving of it would\r\nhave gone to prove that other prize had been there. But the money was\r\ngone,--money of which she had given a correct account;--and she could\r\nnow honestly allege that she had been robbed. But she had at last\r\nreally lost her great treasure;--and if the treasure should be found,\r\nthen would she infallibly be exposed. She had talked twice of giving\r\naway her necklace, and had seriously thought of getting rid of it by\r\nburying it deep in the sea. But now that it was in very truth gone\r\nfrom her, the loss of it was horrible to her. Ten thousand pounds,\r\nfor which she had struggled so much and borne so many things, which\r\nhad come to be the prevailing fact of her life, gone from her for\r\never! Nevertheless it was not that sorrow, that regret, which had\r\nso nearly overpowered her in the dining-parlour. At that moment she\r\nhardly knew, had hardly thought, whether the diamonds had or had\r\nnot been taken. But the feeling came upon her at once that her own\r\ndisgrace was every hour being brought nearer to her. Her secret was\r\nno longer quite her own. One man knew it, and he had talked to her of\r\nperjury and of five years\' imprisonment. Patience must have known it,\r\ntoo; and now some one else also knew it. The police, of course, would\r\nfind it out, and then horrid words would be used against her. She\r\nhardly knew what perjury was. It sounded like forgery and burglary.\r\nTo stand up before a judge and be tried,--and then to be locked up\r\nfor five years in prison--! What an end would this be to all her\r\nglorious success? And what evil had she done to merit all this\r\nterrible punishment? When they came to her in her bedroom at Carlisle\r\nshe had simply been too much frightened to tell them all that the\r\nnecklace was at that moment under her pillow.\r\n\r\nShe tried to think of it all, and to form some idea in her mind of\r\nwhat might be the truth. Of course, Patience Crabstick had known her\r\nsecret, but how long had the girl known it? And how had the girl\r\ndiscovered it? She was almost certain, from certain circumstances,\r\nfrom words which the girl had spoken, and from signs which she had\r\nobserved, that Patience had not even suspected that the necklace had\r\nbeen brought with them from Carlisle to London. Of course, the coming\r\nof Bunfit and the woman would have set the girl\'s mind to work in\r\nthat direction; but then Bunfit and the woman had only been there on\r\nthat morning. The Corsair knew the facts, and no one but the Corsair.\r\nThat the Corsair was a Corsair, the suspicions of the police had\r\nproved to her. She had offered the necklace to the Corsair; but when\r\nso offered, he had refused to take it. She could understand that he\r\nshould see the danger of accepting the diamonds from her hand, and\r\nyet should be desirous of having them. And might not he have thought\r\nthat he could best relieve her from the burthen of their custody in\r\nthis manner? She felt no anger against the Corsair as she weighed\r\nthe probability of his having taken them in this fashion. A Corsair\r\nmust be a Corsair. Were he to come to her and confess the deed, she\r\nwould almost like him the better for it,--admiring his skill and\r\nenterprise. But how very clever he must have been, and how brave!\r\nHe had known, no doubt, that the three ladies were all going to the\r\ntheatre; but in how short a time had he got rid of the other women\r\nand availed himself of the services of Patience Crabstick!\r\n\r\nBut in what way would she conduct herself when the police should come\r\nto her on the following morning,--the police and all the other people\r\nwho would crowd to the house? How should she receive her cousin\r\nFrank? How should she look when the coincidence of the double robbery\r\nshould be spoken of in her hearing? How should she bear herself when,\r\nas of course would be the case, she should again be taken before the\r\nmagistrates, and made to swear as to the loss of her property? Must\r\nshe commit more perjury, with the certainty that various people must\r\nknow that her oath was false? All the world would suspect her. All\r\nthe world would soon know the truth. Might it not be possible that\r\nthe diamonds were at this moment in the hands of Messrs. Camperdown,\r\nand that they would be produced before her eyes, as soon as her\r\nsecond false oath had been registered against her? And yet how could\r\nshe tell the truth? And what would the Corsair think of her,--the\r\nCorsair, who would know everything? She made one resolution during\r\nthe night. She would not be taken into court. The magistrates and\r\nthe people might come to her, but she would not go before them. When\r\nthe morning came she said that she was ill, and refused to leave her\r\nbed. Policemen, she knew, were in the house early. At about nine Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle and Lucinda were up and in her room. The excitement of the\r\naffair had taken them from their beds,--but she would not stir. If it\r\nwere absolutely necessary, she said, the men must come into her room.\r\nShe had been so overset by what had occurred on the previous night,\r\nthat she could not leave her room. She appealed to Lucinda as to the\r\nfact of her illness. The trouble of these robberies was so great\r\nupon her that her heart was almost broken. If her deposition must\r\nbe taken, she would make it in bed. In the course of the day the\r\nmagistrate did come into her room and the deposition was taken.\r\nForty-three pounds had been taken from her desk, and certain jewels,\r\nwhich she described, from her dressing-case. As far as she was aware,\r\nno other property of hers was missing. This she said in answer to a\r\ndirect question from the magistrate, which, as she thought, was asked\r\nwith a stern voice and searching eye. And so, a second time, she had\r\nsworn falsely. But this at least was gained,--that Lord George de\r\nBruce Carruthers was not looking at her as she swore.\r\n\r\nLord George was in the house for a great part of the day, but he did\r\nnot ask to be admitted to Lizzie\'s room;--nor did she ask to see him.\r\nFrank Greystock was there late in the afternoon, and went up at once\r\nto his cousin. The moment that she saw him she stretched out her arms\r\nto him, and burst into tears. "My poor girl," said he, "what is the\r\nmeaning of it all?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know. I think they will kill me. They want to kill me. How\r\ncan I bear it all? The robbers were here last night, and magistrates\r\nand policemen and people have been here all day." Then she fell\r\ninto a fit of sobbing and wailing, which was, in truth, hysterical.\r\nFor,--if the readers think of it,--the poor woman had a great deal to\r\nbear.\r\n\r\nFrank, into whose mind no glimmer of suspicion against his cousin had\r\nyet entered, and who firmly believed that she had been made a victim\r\nbecause of the value of her diamonds,--and who had a theory of his\r\nown about the robbery at Carlisle, to the circumstances of which he\r\nwas now at some pains to make these latter circumstances adhere,--was\r\nvery tender with his cousin, and remained in the house for more than\r\nan hour. "Oh, Frank, what had I better do?" she asked him.\r\n\r\n"I would leave London, if I were you."\r\n\r\n"Yes;--of course. I will. Oh yes, I will!"\r\n\r\n"If you don\'t fear the cold of Scotland--"\r\n\r\n"I fear nothing,--nothing but being where these policemen can come to\r\nme. Oh!"--and then she shuddered and was again hysterical. Nor was\r\nshe acting the condition. As she remembered the magistrates, and the\r\ndetectives, and the policemen in their uniforms,--and reflected that\r\nshe might probably see much more of them before the game was played\r\nout, the thoughts that crowded on her were almost more than she could\r\nbear.\r\n\r\n"Your child is there, and it is your own house. Go there till all\r\nthis passes by." Whereupon she promised him that, as soon as she was\r\nwell enough, she would at once go to Scotland.\r\n\r\nIn the meantime, the Eustace diamonds were locked up in a small\r\nsafe fixed into the wall at the back of a small cellar beneath the\r\nestablishment of Messrs. Harter and Benjamin, in Minto Lane, in\r\nthe City. Messrs. Harter and Benjamin always kept a second place\r\nof business. Their great shop was at the West-end; but they had\r\naccommodation in the City.\r\n\r\nThe chronicler states this at once, as he scorns to keep from his\r\nreader any secret that is known to himself.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LIII\r\n\r\nLizzie\'s Sick-Room\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen the Hertford Street robbery was three days old, and was still\r\nthe talk of all the town, Lizzie Eustace was really ill. She had\r\npromised to go down to Scotland in compliance with the advice given\r\nto her by her cousin Frank, and at the moment of promising would have\r\nbeen willing enough to be transported at once to Portray, had that\r\nbeen possible--so as to be beyond the visits of policemen and the\r\nauthority of lawyers and magistrates; but as the hours passed over\r\nher head, and as her presence of mind returned to her, she remembered\r\nthat even at Portray she would not be out of danger, and that she\r\ncould do nothing in furtherance of her plans if once immured there.\r\nLord George was in London, Frank Greystock was in London, and Lord\r\nFawn was in London. It was more than ever necessary to her that she\r\nshould find a husband among them,--a husband who would not be less\r\nher husband when the truth of that business at Carlisle should\r\nbe known to all the world. She had, in fact, stolen nothing. She\r\nendeavoured to comfort herself by repeating to herself over and over\r\nagain that assurance. She had stolen nothing; and she still thought\r\nthat if she could obtain the support of some strong arm on which to\r\nlean, she might escape punishment for those false oaths which she had\r\nsworn. Her husband might take her abroad, and the whole thing would\r\ndie away. If she should succeed with Lord George, of course he would\r\ntake her abroad, and there would be no need for any speedy return.\r\nThey might roam among islands in pleasant warm suns, and the dreams\r\nof her youth might be realised. Her income was still her own. They\r\ncould not touch that. So she thought, at least,--oppressed by some\r\nslight want of assurance in that respect. Were she to go at once to\r\nScotland, she must for the present give up that game altogether. If\r\nFrank would pledge himself to become her husband in three or four,\r\nor even in six months, she would go at once. She had more confidence\r\nin Frank than even in Lord George. As for love,--she would sometimes\r\ntell herself that she was violently in love; but she hardly knew with\r\nwhich. Lord George was certainly the best representative of that\r\nperfect Corsair which her dreams had represented to her; but, in\r\nregard to working life, she thought that she liked her cousin Frank\r\nbetter than she had ever yet liked any other human being. But, in\r\ntruth, she was now in that condition, as she acknowledged to herself,\r\nthat she was hardly entitled to choose. Lord Fawn had promised to\r\nmarry her, and to him as a husband she conceived that she still had a\r\nright. Nothing had as yet been proved against her which could justify\r\nhim in repudiating his engagement. She had, no doubt, asserted with\r\nall vehemence to her cousin that no consideration would now induce\r\nher to give her hand to Lord Fawn;--and when making that assurance\r\nshe had been, after her nature, sincere. But circumstances were\r\nchanged since that. She had not much hope that Lord Fawn might be\r\nmade to succumb,--though evidence had reached her before the last\r\nrobbery which induced her to believe that he did not consider himself\r\nto be quite secure. In these circumstances she was unwilling to leave\r\nLondon though she had promised, and was hardly sorry to find an\r\nexcuse in her recognised illness.\r\n\r\nAnd she was ill. Though her mind was again at work with schemes on\r\nwhich she would not have busied herself without hope, yet she had not\r\nrecovered from the actual bodily prostration to which she had been\r\ncompelled to give way when first told of the robbery on her return\r\nfrom the theatre. There had been moments then in which she thought\r\nthat her heart would have broken,--moments in which, but that the\r\npower of speech was wanting, she would have told everything to\r\nLucinda Roanoke. When Mrs. Carbuncle was marching up-stairs with the\r\npolicemen at her heels she would have willingly sold all her hopes,\r\nPortray Castle, her lovers, her necklace, her income, her beauty,\r\nfor any assurance of the humblest security. With that quickness of\r\nintellect which was her peculiar gift, she had soon understood, in\r\nthe midst of her sufferings, that her necklace had been taken by\r\nthieves whose robbery might assist her for a while in keeping her\r\nsecret, rather than lead to the immediate divulging of it. Neither\r\nCamperdown nor Bunfit had been at work among the boxes. Her secret\r\nhad been discovered, no doubt, by Patience Crabstick, and the\r\ndiamonds were gone. But money also was taken, and the world need not\r\nknow that the diamonds had been there. But Lord George knew. And then\r\nthere arose to her that question: Had the diamonds been taken in\r\nconsequence of that revelation to Lord George? It was not surprising\r\nthat in the midst of all this Lizzie should be really ill.\r\n\r\nShe was most anxious to see Lord George; but, if what Mrs. Carbuncle\r\nsaid to her was true, Lord George refused to see her. She did\r\nnot believe Mrs. Carbuncle, and was, therefore, quite in the\r\ndark about her Corsair. As she could only communicate with him\r\nthrough Mrs. Carbuncle, it might well be the case that he should\r\nhave been told that he could not have access to her. Of course\r\nthere were difficulties. That her cousin Frank should see her\r\nin her bedroom,--her cousin Frank, with whom it was essentially\r\nnecessary that she should hold counsel as to her present great\r\ndifficulties,--was a matter of course. There was no hesitation about\r\nthat. A fresh nightcap, and a clean pocket-handkerchief with a bit of\r\nlace round it, and, perhaps, some pretty covering to her shoulders if\r\nshe were to be required to sit up in bed, and the thing was arranged.\r\nHe might have spent the best part of his days in her bedroom if he\r\ncould have spared the time. But the Corsair was not a cousin,--nor\r\nas yet an acknowledged lover. There was difficulty even in framing a\r\nreason for her request, when she made it to Mrs. Carbuncle; and the\r\nvery reason which she gave was handed back to her as the Corsair\'s\r\nreason for not coming to her. She desired to see him because he had\r\nbeen so much mixed up in the matter of these terrible robberies. But\r\nMrs. Carbuncle declared to her that Lord George would not come to her\r\nbecause his name had been so frequently mentioned in connexion with\r\nthe diamonds. "You see, my dear," said Mrs. Carbuncle, "there can be\r\nno real reason for his seeing you up in your bedroom. If there had\r\nbeen anything between you, as I once thought there would--" There\r\nwas something in the tone of Mrs. Carbuncle\'s voice which grated on\r\nLizzie\'s ear,--something which seemed to imply that all that prospect\r\nwas over.\r\n\r\n"Of course," said Lizzie querulously, "I am very anxious to know what\r\nhe thinks. I care more about his opinion than anybody else\'s. As to\r\nhis name being mixed up in it,--that is all a joke."\r\n\r\n"It has been no joke to him, I can assure you," said Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\nLizzie could not press her request. Of course, she knew more about it\r\nthan did Mrs. Carbuncle. The secret was in her own bosom,--the secret\r\nas to the midnight robbery at Carlisle, and that secret she had told\r\nto Lord George. As to the robbery in London she knew nothing,--except\r\nthat it had been perpetrated through the treachery of Patience\r\nCrabstick. Did Lord George know more about it than she knew?--and if\r\nso, was he now deterred by that knowledge from visiting her? "You\r\nsee, my dear," said Mrs. Carbuncle, "that a gentleman visiting a lady\r\nwith whom he has no connexion, in her bedroom, is in itself something\r\nvery peculiar." Lizzie made a motion of impatience under the\r\nbedclothes. Any such argument was trash to her, and she knew that it\r\nwas trash to Mrs. Carbuncle also. What was one man in her bedroom\r\nmore than another? She could see a dozen doctors if she pleased, and\r\nif so, why not this man, whose real powers of doctoring her would be\r\nso much more efficacious? "You would want to see him alone, too,"\r\ncontinued Mrs. Carbuncle, "and, of course, the police would hear of\r\nit. I am not at all surprised that he should stay away." Lizzie\'s\r\ncondition did not admit of much argument on her side, and she only\r\nshowed her opposition to Mrs. Carbuncle by being cross and querulous.\r\n\r\nFrank Greystock came to her with great constancy almost every day,\r\nand from him she did hear about the robbery all that he knew or\r\nheard. When three days had passed,--when six days, and even when\r\nten days were gone, nobody had been as yet arrested. The police,\r\naccording to Frank, were much on the alert, but were very secret.\r\nThey either would not, or could not, tell anything. To him the two\r\nrobberies, that at Carlisle and the last affair in Hertford Street,\r\nwere of course distinct. There were those who believed that the\r\nHertford Street thieves and the Carlisle thieves were not only the\r\nsame, but that they had been in quest of the same plunder,--and had\r\nat last succeeded. But Frank was not one of these. He never for a\r\nmoment doubted that the diamonds had been taken at Carlisle, and\r\nexplained the second robbery by the supposition that Patience\r\nCrabstick had been emboldened by success. The iron box had no doubt\r\nbeen taken by her assistance, and her familiarity with the thieves,\r\nthen established, had led to the second robbery. Lizzie\'s loss in\r\nthat second robbery had amounted to some hundred pounds. This was\r\nFrank Greystock\'s theory, and of course it was one very comfortable\r\nto Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"They all seem to think that the diamonds are at Paris," he said to\r\nher one day.\r\n\r\n"If you only knew how little I care about them. It seems as though I\r\nhad almost forgotten them in these after troubles."\r\n\r\n"Mr. Camperdown cares about them. I\'m told he says that he can make\r\nyou pay for them out of your jointure."\r\n\r\n"That would be very terrible, of course," said Lizzie, to whose mind\r\nthere was something consolatory in the idea that the whole affair of\r\nthe robbery might perhaps remain so mysterious as to remove her from\r\nthe danger of other punishment than this.\r\n\r\n"I feel sure that he couldn\'t do it," said Frank, "and I don\'t think\r\nhe\'ll try it. John Eustace would not let him. It would be\r\npersecution."\r\n\r\n"Mr. Camperdown has always chosen to persecute me," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"I can understand that he shouldn\'t like the loss of the diamonds. I\r\ndon\'t think, Lizzie, you ever realised their true value."\r\n\r\n"I suppose not. After all, a necklace is only a necklace. I cared\r\nnothing for it,--except that I could not bear the idea that that\r\nman should dictate to me. I would have given it up at once, at the\r\nslightest word from you." He did not care to remind her then, as\r\nshe lay in bed, that he had been very urgent in his advice to her\r\nto abandon the diamonds,--and not the less urgent because he had\r\nthought that the demand for them was unjust. "I told you often," she\r\ncontinued, "that I was tempted to throw them among the waves. It was\r\ntrue;--quite true. I offered to give them to you, and should have\r\nbeen delighted to have been relieved from them."\r\n\r\n"That was, of course, simply impossible."\r\n\r\n"I know it was;--impossible on your part; but I would have been\r\ndelighted. Of what use were they to me? I wore them twice because\r\nthat man,"--meaning Lord Fawn,--"disputed my right to them. Before\r\nthat I never even looked at them. Do you think I had pleasure in\r\nwearing them, or pleasure in looking at them? Never. They were only a\r\ntrouble to me. It was a point of honour with me to keep them, because\r\nI was attacked. But I am glad they are gone,--thoroughly glad." This\r\nwas all very well, and was not without its effect on Frank Greystock.\r\nIt is hardly expected of a woman in such a condition, with so many\r\ntroubles on her mind, who had been so persecuted, that every word\r\nuttered by her should be strictly true. Lizzie, with her fresh\r\nnightcap, and her laced handkerchief, pale, and with her eyes just\r\nglittering with tears, was very pretty. "Didn\'t somebody once give\r\nsome one a garment which scorched him up when he wore it,--some woman\r\nwho sent it because she loved the man so much?"\r\n\r\n"The shirt, you mean, which Dejanira sent to Hercules. Yes;--Hercules\r\nwas a good deal scorched."\r\n\r\n"And that necklace, which my husband gave me because he loved me so\r\nwell, has scorched me horribly. It has nearly killed me. It has been\r\nlike the white elephant which the Eastern king gives to his subject\r\nwhen he means to ruin him. Only poor Florian didn\'t mean to hurt me.\r\nHe gave it all in love. If these people bring a lawsuit against me,\r\nFrank, you must manage it for me."\r\n\r\n"There will be no lawsuit. Your brother-in-law will stop it."\r\n\r\n"I wonder who will really get the diamonds after all, Frank? They\r\nwere very valuable. Only think that the ten thousand pounds should\r\ndisappear in such a way!" The subject was a very dangerous one, but\r\nthere was a fascination about it which made it impossible for her to\r\nrefrain from it.\r\n\r\n"A dishonest dealer in diamonds will probably realise the\r\nplunder,--after some years. There would be something very alluring\r\nin the theft of articles of great value, were it not that, when got,\r\nthey at once become almost valueless by the difficulty of dealing\r\nwith them. Supposing I had the necklace!"\r\n\r\n"I wish you had, Frank."\r\n\r\n"I could do nothing with it. Ten sovereigns would go further with\r\nme,--or ten shillings. The burthen of possessing it would in itself\r\nbe almost more than I could bear. The knowledge that I had the thing,\r\nand might be discovered in having it, would drive me mad. By my own\r\nweakness I should be compelled to tell my secret to some one. And\r\nthen I should never sleep for fear my partner in the matter should\r\nturn against me." How well she understood it all! How probable it\r\nwas that Lord George should turn against her! How exact was Frank\'s\r\ndescription of that burthen of a secret so heavy that it cannot be\r\nborne alone! "A little reflection," continued Frank, "soon convinces\r\na man that rough downright stealing is an awkward, foolish trade; and\r\nit therefore falls into the hands of those who want education for\r\nthe higher efforts of dishonesty. To get into a bank at midnight and\r\nsteal what little there may be in the till, or even an armful of\r\nbank-notes, with the probability of a policeman catching you as you\r\ncreep out of the chimney and through a hole, is clumsy work; but to\r\nwalk in amidst the smiles and bows of admiring managers and draw out\r\nmoney over the counter by thousands and tens of thousands, which you\r\nhave never put in and which you can never repay, and which, when all\r\nis done, you have only borrowed;--that is a great feat."\r\n\r\n"Do you really think so?"\r\n\r\n"The courage, the ingenuity, and the self-confidence needed are\r\ncertainly admirable. And then there is a cringing and almost\r\ncontemptible littleness about honesty, which hardly allows it to\r\nassert itself. The really honest man can never say a word to make\r\nthose who don\'t know of his honesty believe that it is there. He has\r\none foot in the grave before his neighbours have learned that he is\r\npossessed of an article for the use of which they would so willingly\r\nhave paid, could they have been made to see that it was there. The\r\ndishonest man almost doubts whether in him dishonesty is dishonest,\r\nlet it be practised ever so widely. The honest man almost doubts\r\nwhether his honesty be honest, unless it be kept hidden. Let two\r\nunknown men be competitors for any place, with nothing to guide the\r\njudges but their own words and their own looks, and who can doubt but\r\nthe dishonest man would be chosen rather than the honest? Honesty\r\ngoes about with a hang-dog look about him, as though knowing that\r\nhe cannot be trusted till he be proved. Dishonesty carries his eyes\r\nhigh, and assumes that any question respecting him must be considered\r\nto be unnecessary."\r\n\r\n"Oh, Frank, what a philosopher you are."\r\n\r\n"Well, yes; meditating about your diamonds has brought my philosophy\r\nout. When do you think you will go to Scotland?"\r\n\r\n"I am hardly strong enough for the journey yet. I fear the cold so\r\nmuch."\r\n\r\n"You would not find it cold there by the sea-side. To tell you the\r\ntruth, Lizzie, I want to get you out of this house. I don\'t mean to\r\nsay a word against Mrs. Carbuncle; but after all that has occurred,\r\nit would be better that you should be away. People talk about you and\r\nLord George."\r\n\r\n"How can I help it, Frank?"\r\n\r\n"By going away;--that is, if I may presume one thing. I don\'t want to\r\npry into your secrets."\r\n\r\n"I have none from you."\r\n\r\n"Unless there be truth in the assertion that you are engaged to marry\r\nLord George Carruthers."\r\n\r\n"There is no truth in it."\r\n\r\n"And you do not wish to stay here in order that there may be an\r\nengagement? I am obliged to ask you home questions, Lizzie, as I\r\ncould not otherwise advise you."\r\n\r\n"You do, indeed, ask home questions."\r\n\r\n"I will desist at once, if they be disagreeable."\r\n\r\n"Frank, you are false to me!" As she said this she rose in her bed,\r\nand sat with her eyes fixed upon his, and her thin hands stretched\r\nout upon the bedclothes. "You know that I cannot wish to be engaged\r\nto him or to any other man. You know, better almost than I can\r\nknow myself, how my heart stands. There has, at any rate, been no\r\nhypocrisy with me in regard to you. Everything has been told to\r\nyou;--at what cost I will not now say. The honest woman, I fear,\r\nfares worse even than the honest man of whom you spoke. I think you\r\nadmitted that he would be appreciated at last. She to her dying day\r\nmust pay the penalty of her transgressions. Honesty in a woman the\r\nworld never forgives." When she had done speaking, he sat silent by\r\nher bedside, but, almost unconsciously, he stretched out his left\r\nhand and took her right hand in his. For a few seconds she admitted\r\nthis, and she lay there with their hands clasped. Then with a start\r\nshe drew back her arm, and retreated as it were from his touch. "How\r\ndare you," she said, "press my hand, when you know that such pressure\r\nfrom you is treacherous and damnable!"\r\n\r\n"Damnable, Lizzie!"\r\n\r\n"Yes;--damnable. I will not pick my words for you. Coming from you,\r\nwhat does such pressure mean?"\r\n\r\n"Affection."\r\n\r\n"Yes;--and of what sort? You are wicked enough to feed my love by\r\nsuch tokens, when you know that you do not mean to return it. Oh,\r\nFrank, Frank, will you give me back my heart? What was it that you\r\npromised me when we sat together upon the rocks at Portray?"\r\n\r\nIt is inexpressibly difficult for a man to refuse the tender of a\r\nwoman\'s love. We may almost say that a man should do so as a matter\r\nof course,--that the thing so offered becomes absolutely valueless\r\nby the offer,--that the woman who can make it has put herself out\r\nof court by her own abandonment of the privileges due to her as a\r\nwoman,--that stern rebuke and even expressed contempt are justified\r\nby such conduct,--and that the fairest beauty and most alluring\r\ncharms of feminine grace should lose their attraction when thus\r\ntendered openly in the market. No doubt such is our theory as to love\r\nand love-making. But the action to be taken by us in matters as to\r\nwhich the plainest theory prevails for the guidance of our practice,\r\ndepends so frequently on accompanying circumstances and correlative\r\nissues, that the theory, as often as not, falls to the ground. Frank\r\ncould not despise this woman, and could not be stern to her. He could\r\nnot bring himself to tell her boldly that he would have nothing to\r\nsay to her in the way of love. He made excuses for her, and persuaded\r\nhimself that there were peculiar circumstances in her position\r\njustifying unwomanly conduct, although, had he examined himself on\r\nthe subject, he would have found it difficult to say what those\r\ncircumstances were. She was rich, beautiful, clever,--and he was\r\nflattered. Nevertheless he knew that he could not marry her;--and he\r\nknew also that much as he liked her he did not love her. "Lizzie," he\r\nsaid, "I think you hardly understand my position."\r\n\r\n"Yes, I do. That little girl has cozened you out of a promise."\r\n\r\n"If it be so, you would not have me break it."\r\n\r\n"Yes, I would, if you think she is not fit to be your wife. Is a\r\nman such as you are, to be tied by the leg for life, have all his\r\nambition clipped, and his high hopes shipwrecked, because a girl has\r\nbeen clever enough to extract a word from him? Is it not true that\r\nyou are in debt?"\r\n\r\n"What of that? At any rate, Lizzie, I do not want help from you."\r\n\r\n"That is so like a man\'s pride! Do we not all know that in such a\r\ncareer as you have marked out for yourself, wealth, or at any rate an\r\neasy income, is necessary? Do you think that I cannot put two and two\r\ntogether? Do you believe so meanly of me as to imagine that I should\r\nhave said to you what I have said, if I did not know that I could\r\nhelp you? A man, I believe, cannot understand that love which induces\r\na woman to sacrifice her pride simply for his advantage. I want to\r\nsee you prosper. I want to see you a great man and a lord, and I know\r\nthat you cannot become so without an income. Ah, I wish I could give\r\nyou all that I have got, and save you from the encumbrance that is\r\nattached to it!"\r\n\r\nIt might be that he would then have told her of his engagement to\r\nLucy, and of his resolution to adhere to that promise, had not Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle at that moment entered the room. Frank had been there for\r\nabove an hour, and as Lizzie was still an invalid, and to some extent\r\nunder the care of Mrs. Carbuncle, it was natural that that lady\r\nshould interfere. "You know, my dear, you should not exhaust yourself\r\naltogether. Mr. Emilius is to come to you this afternoon."\r\n\r\n"Mr. Emilius!" said Greystock.\r\n\r\n"Yes;--the clergyman. Don\'t you remember him at Portray? A dark man\r\nwith eyes close together! You used to be very wicked, and say that\r\nhe was once a Jew-boy in the streets." Lizzie, as she spoke of her\r\nspiritual guide, was evidently not desirous of doing him much honour.\r\n\r\n"I remember him well enough. He made sheep\'s eyes at Miss Macnulty,\r\nand drank a great deal of wine at dinner."\r\n\r\n"Poor Macnulty! I don\'t believe a word about the wine; and as for\r\nMacnulty, I don\'t see why she should not be converted as well as\r\nanother. He is coming here to read to me. I hope you don\'t object."\r\n\r\n"Not in the least;--if you like it."\r\n\r\n"One does have solemn thoughts sometimes, Frank,--especially when one\r\nis ill."\r\n\r\n"Oh, yes. Well or ill, one does have solemn thoughts;--ghosts, as\r\nit were, which will appear. But is Mr. Emilius good at laying such\r\napparitions?"\r\n\r\n"He is a clergyman, Mr. Greystock," said Mrs. Carbuncle, with\r\nsomething of rebuke in her voice.\r\n\r\n"So they tell me. I was not present at his ordination, but I daresay\r\nit was done according to rule. When one reflects what a deal of harm\r\na bishop may do, one wishes that there was some surer way of getting\r\nbishops."\r\n\r\n"Do you know anything against Mr. Emilius?" asked Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"Nothing at all but his looks, and manners, and voice,--unless it be\r\nthat he preaches popular sermons, and drinks too much wine, and makes\r\nsheep\'s eyes at Miss Macnulty. Look after your silver spoons, Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle,--if the last thieves have left you any. You were asking\r\nafter the fate of your diamonds, Lizzie. Perhaps they will endow a\r\nProtestant church in Mr. Emilius\'s native land."\r\n\r\nMr. Emilius did come and read to Lady Eustace that afternoon. A\r\nclergyman is as privileged to enter the bedroom of a sick lady as is\r\na doctor or a cousin. There was another clean cap, and another laced\r\nhandkerchief, and on this occasion a little shawl over Lizzie\'s\r\nshoulders. Mr. Emilius first said a prayer, kneeling at Lizzie\'s\r\nbedside; then he read a chapter in the Bible;--and after that he read\r\nthe first half of the fourth canto of Childe Harold so well, that\r\nLizzie felt for the moment that after all, poetry was life and life\r\nwas poetry.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LIV\r\n\r\n"I Suppose I May Say a Word"\r\n\r\n\r\nThe second robbery to which Lady Eustace had been subjected by no\r\nmeans decreased the interest which was attached to her and her\r\nconcerns in the fashionable world. Parliament had now met, and the\r\nparty at Matching Priory,--Lady Glencora Palliser\'s party in the\r\ncountry,--had been to some extent broken up. All those gentlemen\r\nwho were engaged in the service of Her Majesty\'s Government had\r\nnecessarily gone to London, and they who had wives at Matching had\r\ntaken their wives with them. Mr. and Mrs. Bonteen had seen the last\r\nof their holiday; Mr. Palliser himself was, of course, at his post;\r\nand all the private secretaries were with the public secretaries\r\non the scene of action. On the 13th of February Mr. Palliser made\r\nhis first great statement in Parliament on the matter of the\r\nfive-farthinged penny, and pledged himself to do his very best to\r\ncarry that stupendous measure through Parliament in the present\r\nsession. The City men who were in the House that night,--and all\r\nthe Directors of the Bank of England were in the gallery, and every\r\nchairman of a great banking company, and every Baring and every\r\nRothschild, if there be Barings and Rothschilds who have not been\r\nreturned by constituencies, and have not seats in the House by\r\nright,--agreed in declaring that the job in hand was too much for any\r\none member or any one session. Some said that such a measure never\r\ncould be passed, because the unfinished work of one session could\r\nnot be used in lessening the labours of the next. Everything must be\r\nrecommenced; and therefore,--so said these hopeless ones,--the penny\r\nwith five farthings, the penny of which a hundred would make ten\r\nshillings, the halcyon penny, which would make all future pecuniary\r\ncalculations easy to the meanest British capacity, could never become\r\nthe law of the land.
