"I will then endeavour to explain to\r\nyou the reasons which make me think that it will be better for us\r\nboth that our engagement should be at an end. If, after reading it,\r\nyou shall disagree with me, and still insist on the right which I\r\ngave you when I asked you to become my wife,--I will then perform the\r\npromise which I certainly made." To this most foolish proposal on his\r\npart, Lizzie, of course, acquiesced. She acquiesced, and bade him\r\nfarewell with her sweetest smile. It was now manifest to her that she\r\ncould have her husband,--or her revenge, just as she might prefer.\r\n\r\nThis had been a day of triumph to her, and she was talking of it in\r\nthe evening triumphantly to Mrs. Carbuncle, when she was told that a\r\npoliceman wanted to see her down-stairs! Oh, those wretched police!\r\nAgain all the blood rushed to her head and nearly killed her. She\r\ndescended slowly; and was then informed by a man, not dressed,\r\nlike Bunfit, in plain clothes, but with all the paraphernalia of a\r\npoliceman\'s uniform, that her late servant, Patience Crabstick, had\r\ngiven herself up as Queen\'s evidence, and was now in custody in\r\nScotland Yard. It had been thought right that she should be so far\r\ninformed; but the man was able to tell her nothing further.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXII\r\n\r\n"You Know Where My Heart Is"\r\n\r\n\r\nOn the Sunday following, Frank, as usual, was in Hertford Street. He\r\nhad become almost a favourite with Mrs. Carbuncle; and had so far\r\ningratiated himself even with Lucinda Roanoke that, according to\r\nLizzie\'s report, he might, if so inclined, rob Sir Griffin of his\r\nprize without much difficulty. On this occasion he was unhappy and in\r\nlow spirits; and when questioned on the subject made no secret of the\r\nfact that he was harassed for money. "The truth is I have overdrawn\r\nmy bankers by five hundred pounds, and they have, as they say,\r\nventured to remind me of it. I wish they were not venturesome quite\r\nso often; for they reminded me of the same fact about a fortnight\r\nago."\r\n\r\n"What do you do with your money, Mr. Greystock?" asked Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle, laughing.\r\n\r\n"Muddle it away, paying my bills with it,--according to the very,\r\nvery old story. The fact is, I live in that detestable no-man\'s land,\r\nbetween respectability and insolvency, which has none of the pleasure\r\nof either. I am fair game for every creditor, as I am supposed to pay\r\nmy way,--and yet I never can pay my way."\r\n\r\n"Just like my poor dear father," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"Not exactly, Lizzie. He managed much better, and never paid anybody.\r\nIf I could only land on terra-firma,--one side or the other,--I\r\nshouldn\'t much care which. As it is I have all the recklessness, but\r\nnone of the carelessness, of the hopelessly insolvent man. And it is\r\nso hard with us. Attorneys owe us large sums of money, and we can\'t\r\ndun them very well. I have a lot of money due to me from rich men,\r\nwho don\'t pay me simply because they don\'t think that it matters.\r\nI talk to them grandly, and look big, as though money was the last\r\nthing I thought of, when I am longing to touch my hat and ask them as\r\na great favour to settle my little bill." All this time Lizzie was\r\nfull of matter which she must impart to her cousin, and could impart\r\nto him only in privacy.\r\n\r\nIt was absolutely necessary that she should tell him what she had\r\nheard of Patience Crabstick. In her heart of hearts she wished that\r\nPatience Crabstick had gone off safely with her plunder to the\r\nAntipodes. She had no wish to get back what had been lost, either in\r\nthe matter of the diamonds or of the smaller things taken. She had\r\nsincerely wished that the police might fail in all their endeavours,\r\nand that the thieves might enjoy perfect security with their booty.\r\nShe did not even begrudge Mr. Benjamin the diamonds,--or Lord George,\r\nif in truth Lord George had been the last thief. The robbery had\r\nenabled her to get the better of Mr. Camperdown, and apparently of\r\nLord Fawn; and had freed her from the custody of property which she\r\nhad learned to hate. It had been a very good robbery. But now these\r\nwretched police had found Patience Crabstick, and would disturb her\r\nagain!\r\n\r\nOf course she must tell her cousin. He must hear the news, and it\r\nwould be better that he should hear it from her than from others.\r\nThis was Sunday, and she thought he would be sure to know the truth\r\non the following Monday. In this she was right; for on the Monday old\r\nLady Linlithgow saw it stated in the newspapers that an arrest had\r\nbeen made. "I have something to tell you," she said, as soon as she\r\nhad succeeded in finding herself alone with him.\r\n\r\n"Anything about the diamonds?"\r\n\r\n"Well, no; not exactly about the diamonds;--though perhaps it is. But\r\nfirst, Frank, I want to say something else to you."\r\n\r\n"Not about the diamonds?"\r\n\r\n"Oh no;--not at all. It is this. You must let me lend you that five\r\nhundred pounds you want."\r\n\r\n"Indeed you shall do no such thing. I should not have mentioned it to\r\nyou if I had not thought that you were one of the insolvent yourself.\r\nYou were in debt yourself when we last talked about money."\r\n\r\n"So I am;--and that horrid woman, Mrs. Carbuncle, has made me lend\r\nher one hundred and fifty pounds. But it is so different with you,\r\nFrank."\r\n\r\n"Yes;--my needs are greater than hers."\r\n\r\n"What is she to me?--while you are everything! Things can\'t be so bad\r\nwith me but what I can raise five hundred pounds. After all, I am not\r\nreally in debt, for a person with my income; but if I were, still my\r\nfirst duty would be to help you if you want help."\r\n\r\n"Be generous first, and just afterwards. That\'s it;--isn\'t it,\r\nLizzie? But indeed, under no circumstances could I take a penny of\r\nyour money. There are some persons from whom a man can borrow, and\r\nsome from whom he cannot. You are clearly one of those from whom I\r\ncannot borrow."\r\n\r\n"Why not?"\r\n\r\n"Ah,--one can\'t explain these things. It simply is so. Mrs. Carbuncle\r\nwas quite the natural person to borrow your money, and it seems that\r\nshe has complied with nature. Some Jew who wants thirty per cent. is\r\nthe natural person for me. All these things are arranged, and it is\r\nof no use disturbing the arrangements and getting out of course. I\r\nshall pull through. And now let me know your own news."\r\n\r\n"The police have taken Patience."\r\n\r\n"They have,--have they? Then at last we shall know all about the\r\ndiamonds." This was gall to poor Lizzie. "Where did they get her?"\r\n\r\n"Ah!--I don\'t know that."\r\n\r\n"And who told you?"\r\n\r\n"A policeman came here last night and said so. She is going to\r\nturn against the thieves, and tell all that she knows. Nasty, mean\r\ncreature."\r\n\r\n"Thieves are nasty, mean creatures generally. We shall get it all\r\nout now,--as to what happened at Carlisle and what happened here. Do\r\nyou know that everybody believes, up to this moment, that your dear\r\nfriend Lord George de Bruce sold the diamonds to Mr. Benjamin, the\r\njeweller?"\r\n\r\nLizzie could only shrug her shoulders. She herself, among many\r\ndoubts, was upon the whole disposed to think as everybody thought.\r\nShe did believe,--as far as she believed anything in the matter, that\r\nthe Corsair had determined to become possessed of the prize from the\r\nmoment that he saw it in Scotland, that the Corsair arranged the\r\nrobbery in Carlisle, and that again he arranged the robbery in the\r\nLondon house as soon as he learned from Lizzie where the diamonds\r\nwere placed. To her mind this had been the most ready solution of the\r\nmystery, and when she found that other people almost regarded him as\r\nthe thief, her doubts became a belief. And she did not in the least\r\ndespise or dislike him or condemn him for what he had done. Were he\r\nto come to her and confess it all, telling his story in such a manner\r\nas to make her seem to be safe for the future, she would congratulate\r\nhim and accept him at once as her own dear, expected Corsair. But, if\r\nso, he should not have bungled the thing. He should have managed his\r\nsubordinates better than to have one of them turn evidence against\r\nhim. He should have been able to get rid of a poor weak female like\r\nPatience Crabstick. Why had he not sent her to New York, or--or--or\r\nanywhere? If Lizzie were to hear that Lord George had taken Patience\r\nout to sea in a yacht,--somewhere among the bright islands of which\r\nshe thought so much,--and dropped the girl overboard, tied up in a\r\nbag, she would regard it as a proper Corsair arrangement. Now she was\r\nangry with Lord George because her trouble was coming back upon her.\r\nFrank had suggested that Lord George was the robber in chief, and\r\nLizzie merely shrugged her shoulders. "We shall know all about it\r\nnow," said he triumphantly.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know that I want to know any more about it. I have been so\r\ntortured about these wretched diamonds, that I never wish to hear\r\nthem mentioned again. I don\'t care who has got them. My enemies used\r\nto think that I loved them so well that I could not bear to part with\r\nthem. I hated them always, and never took any pleasure in them. I\r\nused to think that I would throw them into the sea; and when they\r\nwere gone I was glad of it."\r\n\r\n"Thieves ought to be discovered, Lizzie,--for the good of the\r\ncommunity."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t care for the community. What has the community ever done for\r\nme? And now I have something else to tell you. Ever so many people\r\ncame yesterday as well as that wretched policeman. Dear Lady Glencora\r\nwas here again."\r\n\r\n"They\'ll make a Radical of you among them, Lizzie."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t care a bit about that. I\'d just as soon be a Radical as a\r\nstupid old Conservative. Lady Glencora has been most kind, and she\r\nbrought me the dearest message from the Duke of Omnium. The duke had\r\nheard how ill I had been treated."\r\n\r\n"The duke is doting."\r\n\r\n"It is so easy to say that when a man is old. I don\'t think you know\r\nhim, Frank."\r\n\r\n"Not in the least;--nor do I wish."\r\n\r\n"It is something to have the sympathy of men high placed in the\r\nworld. And as to Lady Glencora, I do love her dearly. She just comes\r\nup to my beau-ideal of what a woman should be,--disinterested, full\r\nof spirit, affectionate, with a dash of romance about her."\r\n\r\n"A great dash of romance, I fancy."\r\n\r\n"And a determination to be something in the world. Lady Glencora\r\nPalliser is something."\r\n\r\n"She is awfully rich, Lizzie."\r\n\r\n"I suppose so. At any rate, that is no disgrace. And then, Frank,\r\nsomebody else came."\r\n\r\n"Lord Fawn was to have come."\r\n\r\n"He did come."\r\n\r\n"And how did it go between you?"\r\n\r\n"Ah,--that will be so difficult to explain. I wish you had been\r\nbehind the curtain to hear it all. It is so necessary that you should\r\nknow, and yet it is so hard to tell. I spoke up to him, and was quite\r\nhigh-spirited."\r\n\r\n"I daresay you were."\r\n\r\n"I told him out, bravely, of all the wrong he had done me. I did not\r\nsit and whimper, I can assure you. Then he talked about you,--of your\r\nattentions."\r\n\r\nFrank Greystock, of course, remembered the scene among the rocks, and\r\nMr. Gowran\'s wagging head and watchful eyes. At the time he had felt\r\ncertain that some use would be made of Andy\'s vigilance, though he\r\nhad not traced the connexion between the man and Mrs. Hittaway. If\r\nLord Fawn had heard of the little scene, there might, doubtless, be\r\ncause for him to talk of "attentions." "What did it matter to him?"\r\nasked Frank. "He is an insolent ass,--as I have told him once, and\r\nshall have to tell him again."\r\n\r\n"I think it did matter, Frank."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t see it a bit. He had resigned his rights,--whatever they\r\nwere."\r\n\r\n"But I had not accepted his resignation,--as they say in the\r\nnewspapers;--nor have I now."\r\n\r\n"You would still marry him?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t say that, Frank. This is an important business, and let us\r\ngo through it steadily. I would certainly like to have him again at\r\nmy feet. Whether I would deign to lift him up again is another thing.\r\nIs not that natural, after what he has done to me?"\r\n\r\n"Woman\'s nature."\r\n\r\n"And I am a woman. Yes, Frank. I would have him again at my\r\ndisposal,--and he is so. He is to write me a long letter;--so like\r\na Government-man, isn\'t it? And he has told me already what he is\r\nto put into the letter. They always do, you know. He is to say that\r\nhe\'ll marry me if I choose."\r\n\r\n"He has promised to say that?"\r\n\r\n"When he said that he would come, I made up my mind that he should\r\nnot go out of the house till he had promised that. He couldn\'t get\r\nout of it. What had I done?" Frank thought of the scene among the\r\nrocks. He did not, of course, allude to it, but Lizzie was not so\r\nreticent. "As to what that old rogue saw down in Scotland, I don\'t\r\ncare a bit about it, Frank. He has been up in London, and telling\r\nthem all, no doubt. Nasty, dirty eavesdropper! But what does it come\r\nto? Psha! When he mentioned your name I silenced him at once. What\r\ncould I have done, unless I had had some friend? At any rate, he is\r\nto ask me again in writing,--and then what shall I say?"\r\n\r\n"You must consult your own heart."\r\n\r\n"No, Frank;--I need not do that. Why do you say so?"\r\n\r\n"I know not what else to say."\r\n\r\n"A woman can marry without consulting her heart. Women do so every\r\nday. This man is a lord, and has a position. No doubt I despise him\r\nthoroughly,--utterly. I don\'t hate him, because he is not worth being\r\nhated."\r\n\r\n"And yet you would marry him?"\r\n\r\n"I have not said so. I will tell you this truth, though perhaps you\r\nwill say it is not feminine. I would fain marry some one. To be as I\r\nhave been for the last two years is not a happy condition."\r\n\r\n"I would not marry a man I despised."\r\n\r\n"Nor would I,--willingly. He is honest and respectable; and in spite\r\nof all that has come and gone would, I think, behave well to a woman\r\nwhen she was once his wife. Of course, I would prefer to marry a man\r\nthat I could love. But if that is impossible, Frank--"\r\n\r\n"I thought that you had determined that you would have nothing to do\r\nwith this lord."\r\n\r\n"I thought so too. Frank, you have known all that I have thought, and\r\nall that I have wished. You talk to me of marrying where my heart has\r\nbeen given. Is it possible that I should do so?"\r\n\r\n"How am I to say?"\r\n\r\n"Come, Frank, be true with me. I am forcing myself to speak truth to\r\nyou. I think that between you and me, at any rate, there should be no\r\nwords spoken that are not true. Frank, you know where my heart is."\r\nAs she said this, she stood over him, and laid her hand upon his\r\nshoulder. "Will you answer me one question?"\r\n\r\n"If I can, I will."\r\n\r\n"Are you engaged to marry Lucy Morris?"\r\n\r\n"I am."\r\n\r\n"And you intend to marry her?" To this question he made no immediate\r\nanswer. "We are old enough now, Frank, to know that something more\r\nthan what you call heart is wanted to make us happy when we marry. I\r\nwill say nothing hard of Lucy, though she be my rival."\r\n\r\n"You can say nothing hard of her. She is perfect."\r\n\r\n"We will let that pass, though it is hardly kind of you, just at the\r\npresent moment. Let her be perfect. Can you marry this perfection\r\nwithout a sixpence,--you that are in debt, and who never could save a\r\nsixpence in your life? Would it be for her good,--or for yours? You\r\nhave done a foolish thing, sir, and you know that you must get out of\r\nit."\r\n\r\n"I know nothing of the kind."\r\n\r\n"You cannot marry Lucy Morris. That is the truth. My present need\r\nmakes me bold. Frank, shall I be your wife? Such a marriage will not\r\nbe without love, at any rate on one side,--though there be utter\r\nindifference on the other!"\r\n\r\n"You know I am not indifferent to you," said he, with wicked\r\nweakness.\r\n\r\n"Now, at any rate," she continued, "you must understand what must\r\nbe my answer to Lord Fawn. It is you that must answer Lord Fawn. If\r\nmy heart is to be broken, I may as well break it under his roof as\r\nanother."\r\n\r\n"I have no roof to offer you," he said.\r\n\r\n"But I have one for you," she said, throwing her arm round his neck.\r\nHe bore her embrace for a minute, returning it with the pressure of\r\nhis arm; and then, escaping from it, seized his hat and left her\r\nstanding in the room.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXIII\r\n\r\nThe Corsair Is Afraid\r\n\r\n\r\nOn the following morning,--Monday morning,--there appeared in one\r\nof the daily newspapers the paragraph of which Lady Linlithgow had\r\nspoken to Lucy Morris. "We are given to understand,"--newspapers are\r\nvery frequently given to understand,--"that a man well-known to the\r\nLondon police as an accomplished housebreaker has been arrested in\r\nreference to the robbery which was effected on the 30th of January\r\nlast at Lady Eustace\'s house in Hertford Street. No doubt the same\r\nperson was concerned in the robbery of her ladyship\'s jewels at\r\nCarlisle on the night of the 8th of January. The mystery which has so\r\nlong enveloped these two affairs, and which has been so discreditable\r\nto the metropolitan police, will now probably be cleared up." There\r\nwas not a word about Patience Crabstick in this; and, as Lizzie\r\nobserved, the news brought by the policeman on Saturday night\r\nreferred only to Patience, and said nothing of the arrest of any\r\nburglar. The ladies in Hertford Street scanned the sentence with the\r\ngreatest care, and Mrs. Carbuncle was very angry because the house\r\nwas said to be Lizzie\'s house. "It wasn\'t my doing," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"The policeman came to you about it."\r\n\r\n"I didn\'t say a word to the man,--and I didn\'t want him to come."\r\n\r\n"I hope it will be all found out now," said Lucinda.\r\n\r\n"I wish it were all clean forgotten," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"It ought to be found out," said Mrs. Carbuncle. "But the police\r\nshould be more careful in what they say. I suppose we shall all have\r\nto go before the magistrates again."\r\n\r\nPoor Lizzie felt that fresh trouble was certainly coming upon her.\r\nShe had learned now that the crime for which she might be prosecuted\r\nand punished was that of perjury,--that even if everything was known,\r\nshe could not be accused of stealing, and that if she could only get\r\nout of the way till the wrath of the magistrate and policemen should\r\nhave evaporated, she might possibly escape altogether. At any rate,\r\nthey could not take her income away from her. But how could she get\r\nout of the way, and how could she endure to be cross-examined, and\r\nlooked at, and inquired into, by all those who would be concerned in\r\nthe matter? She thought that, if only she could have arranged her\r\nmatrimonial affairs before the bad day came upon her, she could have\r\nendured it better. If she might be allowed to see Lord George, she\r\ncould ask for advice,--could ask for advice, not as she was always\r\nforced to do from her cousin, on a false statement of facts, but with\r\neverything known and declared.\r\n\r\nOn that very day Lord George came to Hertford Street. He had been\r\nthere more than once, perhaps half a dozen times, since the robbery;\r\nbut on all these occasions Lizzie had been in bed, and he had\r\ndeclined to visit her in her chamber. In fact, even Lord George had\r\nbecome somewhat afraid of her since he had been told the true story\r\nas to the necklace at Carlisle. That story he had heard from herself,\r\nand he had also heard from Mr. Benjamin some other little details as\r\nto her former life. Mr. Benjamin, whose very close attention had been\r\ndrawn to the Eustace diamonds, had told Lord George how he had valued\r\nthem at her ladyship\'s request, and had caused an iron case to be\r\nmade for them, and how her ladyship had, on one occasion, endeavoured\r\nto sell the necklace to him. Mr. Benjamin, who certainly was intimate\r\nwith Lord George, was very fond of talking about the diamonds, and\r\nhad once suggested to his lordship that, were they to become his\r\nlordship\'s by marriage, he, Benjamin, might be willing to treat with\r\nhis lordship. In regard to treating with her ladyship,--Mr. Benjamin\r\nacknowledged that he thought it would be too hazardous. Then came the\r\nrobbery of the box, and Lord George was all astray. Mr. Benjamin was\r\nfor a while equally astray, but neither friend believed in the other\r\nfriend\'s innocence. That Lord George should suspect Mr. Benjamin was\r\nquite natural. Mr. Benjamin hardly knew what to think;--hardly gave\r\nLord George credit for the necessary courage, skill, and energy. But\r\nat last, as he began to put two and two together, he divined the\r\ntruth, and was enabled to set the docile Patience on the watch over\r\nher mistress\'s belongings. So it had been with Mr. Benjamin, who at\r\nlast was able to satisfy Mr. Smiler and Mr. Cann that he had been no\r\nparty to their cruel disappointment at Carlisle. How Lord George had\r\nlearned the truth has been told;--the truth as to Lizzie\'s hiding the\r\nnecklace under her pillow and bringing it up to London in her desk.\r\nBut of the facts of the second robbery he knew nothing up to this\r\nmorning. He almost suspected that Lizzie had herself again been at\r\nwork,--and he was afraid of her. He had promised her that he would\r\ntake care of her,--had, perhaps, said enough to make her believe\r\nthat some day he would marry her. He hardly remembered what he had\r\nsaid;--but he was afraid of her. She was so wonderfully clever that,\r\nif he did not take care, she would get him into some mess from which\r\nhe would be unable to extricate himself.\r\n\r\nHe had never whispered her secret to any one; and had still been at a\r\nloss about the second robbery, when he too saw the paragraph in the\r\nnewspaper. He went direct to Scotland Yard and made inquiry there.\r\nHis name had been so often used in the affair, that such inquiry from\r\nhim was justified. "Well, my lord; yes; we have found out something,"\r\nsaid Bunfit. "Mr. Benjamin is off, you know."\r\n\r\n"Benjamin off?"\r\n\r\n"Cut the painter, my lord, and started. But what\'s the good, now we\r\nhas the wires?"\r\n\r\n"And who were the thieves?"\r\n\r\n"Ah, my lord, that\'s telling. Perhaps I don\'t know. Perhaps I do.\r\nPerhaps two or three of us knows. You\'ll hear all in good time, my\r\nlord." Mr. Bunfit wished to appear communicative because he knew\r\nbut little himself. Gager, in the meanest possible manner, had kept\r\nthe matter very close; but the fact that Mr. Benjamin had started\r\nsuddenly on foreign travel had become known to Mr. Bunfit.\r\n\r\nLord George had been very careful, asking no question about the\r\nnecklace;--no question which would have shown that he knew that the\r\nnecklace had been in Hertford Street when the robbery took place\r\nthere; but it seemed to him now that the police must be aware that it\r\nwas so. The arrest had been made because of the robbery in Hertford\r\nStreet, and because of that arrest Mr. Benjamin had taken his\r\ndeparture. Mr. Benjamin was too big a man to have concerned himself\r\ndeeply in the smaller matters which had then been stolen.\r\n\r\nFrom Scotland Yard Lord George went direct to Hertford Street. He\r\nwas in want of money, in want of a settled home, in want of a future\r\nincome, and altogether unsatisfied with his present mode of life.\r\nLizzie Eustace, no doubt, would take him,--unless she had told her\r\nsecret to some other lover. To have his wife, immediately on her\r\nmarriage, or even before it, arraigned for perjury, would not be\r\npleasant. There was very much in the whole affair of which he would\r\nnot be proud as he led his bride to the altar;--but a man does not\r\nexpect to get four thousand pounds a year for nothing. Lord George,\r\nat any rate, did not conceive himself to be in a position to do so.\r\nHad there not been something crooked about Lizzie,--a screw loose, as\r\npeople say,--she would never have been within his reach. There are\r\nmen who always ride lame horses, and yet see as much of the hunting\r\nas others. Lord George, when he had begun to think that, after the\r\ntale which he had forced her to tell him, she had caused the diamonds\r\nto be stolen by her own maid out of her own desk, became almost\r\nafraid of her. But now, as he looked at the matter again and again,\r\nhe believed that the second robbery had been genuine. He did not\r\nquite make up his mind, but he went to Hertford Street resolved to\r\nsee her.\r\n\r\nHe asked for her, and was shown at once into her own sitting-room.\r\n"So you have come at last," she said.\r\n\r\n"Yes;--I\'ve come at last. It would not have done for me to come up to\r\nyou when you were in bed. Those women down-stairs would have talked\r\nabout it everywhere."\r\n\r\n"I suppose they would," said Lizzie almost piteously.\r\n\r\n"It wouldn\'t have been at all wise after all that has been said.\r\nPeople would have been sure to suspect that I had got the things out\r\nof your desk."\r\n\r\n"Oh, no;--not that."\r\n\r\n"I wasn\'t going to run the risk, my dear." His manner to her was\r\nanything but civil, anything but complimentary. If this was his\r\nCorsair humour, she was not sure that a Corsair might be agreeable to\r\nher. "And now tell me what you know about this second robbery."\r\n\r\n"I know nothing, Lord George."\r\n\r\n"Oh, yes, you do. You know something. You know, at any rate, that the\r\ndiamonds were there."\r\n\r\n"Yes;--I know that."\r\n\r\n"And that they were taken?"\r\n\r\n"Of course they were taken."\r\n\r\n"You are sure of that?" There was something in his manner absolutely\r\ninsolent to her. Frank was affectionate, and even Lord Fawn treated\r\nher with deference. "Because, you know, you have been very clever.\r\nTo tell you the truth, I did not think at first that they had been\r\nreally stolen. It might, you know, have been a little game to get\r\nthem out of your own hands,--between you and your maid."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know what you take me for, Lord George."\r\n\r\n"I take you for a lady who, for a long time, got the better of the\r\npolice and the magistrates, and who managed to shift all the trouble\r\noff your own shoulders on to those of other people. You have heard\r\nthat they have taken one of the thieves?"\r\n\r\n"And they have got the girl."\r\n\r\n"Have they? I didn\'t know that. That scoundrel Benjamin has levanted\r\ntoo."\r\n\r\n"Levanted!" said Lizzie, raising both her hands.\r\n\r\n"Not an hour too soon, my lady. And now what do you mean to do?"\r\n\r\n"What ought I to do?"\r\n\r\n"Of course the whole truth will come out."\r\n\r\n"Must it come out?"\r\n\r\n"Not a doubt of that. How can it be helped?"\r\n\r\n"You won\'t tell. You promised that you would not."\r\n\r\n"Psha;--promised! If they put me in a witness-box of course I must\r\ntell. When you come to this kind of work, promises don\'t go for much.\r\nI don\'t know that they ever do. What is a broken promise?"\r\n\r\n"It\'s a story," said Lizzie, in innocent amazement.\r\n\r\n"And what was it you told when you were upon your oath at Carlisle;\r\nand again when the magistrate came here?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, Lord George;--how unkind you are to me!"\r\n\r\n"Patience Crabstick will tell it all, without any help from me. Don\'t\r\nyou see that the whole thing must be known? She\'ll say where the\r\ndiamonds were found;--and how did they come there, if you didn\'t put\r\nthem there? As for telling, there\'ll be telling enough. You\'ve only\r\ntwo things to do."\r\n\r\n"What are they, Lord George?"\r\n\r\n"Go off, like Mr. Benjamin; or else make a clean breast of it. Send\r\nfor John Eustace and tell him the whole. For his brother\'s sake he\'ll\r\nmake the best of it. It will all be published, and then, perhaps,\r\nthere will be an end of it."\r\n\r\n"I couldn\'t do that, Lord George!" said Lizzie, bursting into tears.\r\n\r\n"You ask me, and I can only tell you what I think. That you should\r\nbe able to keep the history of the diamonds a secret, does not seem\r\nto me to be upon the cards. No doubt people who are rich, and are\r\nconnected with rich people, and have great friends,--who are what the\r\nworld call swells,--have great advantages over their inferiors when\r\nthey get into trouble. You are the widow of a baronet, and you have\r\nan uncle a bishop, and another a dean, and a countess for an aunt.\r\nYou have a brother-in-law and a first-cousin in Parliament, and your\r\nfather was an admiral. The other day you were engaged to marry a\r\npeer."\r\n\r\n"Oh yes," said Lizzie, "and Lady Glencora Palliser is my particular\r\nfriend."\r\n\r\n"She is; is she? So much the better. Lady Glencora, no doubt, is a\r\nvery swell among swells."\r\n\r\n"The Duke of Omnium would do anything for me," said Lizzie with\r\nenthusiasm.\r\n\r\n"If you were nobody, you would, of course, be indicted for perjury,\r\nand would go to prison. As it is, if you will tell all your story\r\nto one of your swell friends, I think it very likely that you may\r\nbe pulled through. I should say that Mr. Eustace, or your cousin\r\nGreystock, would be the best."\r\n\r\n"Why couldn\'t you do it? You know it all. I told you\r\nbecause--because--because I thought you would be the kindest to me."\r\n\r\n"You told me, my dear, because you thought it would not matter much\r\nwith me, and I appreciate the compliment. I can do nothing for you. I\r\nam not near enough to those who wear wigs."\r\n\r\nLizzie did not above half understand him,--did not at all understand\r\nhim when he spoke of those who wore wigs, and was quite dark to his\r\nirony about her great friends;--but she did perceive that he was in\r\nearnest in recommending her to confess. She thought about it for a\r\nmoment in silence, and the more she thought the more she felt that\r\nshe could not do it. Had he not suggested a second alternative,--that\r\nshe should go off like Mr. Benjamin? It might be possible that she\r\nshould go off, and yet be not quite like Mr. Benjamin. In that case\r\nought she not to go under the protection of her Corsair? Would not\r\nthat be the proper way of going? "Might I not go abroad,--just for a\r\ntime?" she asked.\r\n\r\n"And so let it blow over?"\r\n\r\n"Just so, you know."\r\n\r\n"It is possible that you might," he said. "Not that it would blow\r\nover altogether. Everybody would know it. It is too late now to\r\nstop the police, and if you meant to be off, you should be off at\r\nonce;--to-day or to-morrow."\r\n\r\n"Oh dear!"\r\n\r\n"Indeed, there\'s no saying whether they will let you go. You could\r\nstart now, this moment;--and if you were at Dover could get over to\r\nFrance. But when once it is known that you had the necklace all that\r\ntime in your own desk, any magistrate, I imagine, could stop you.\r\nYou\'d better have some lawyer you can trust;--not that blackguard\r\nMopus."\r\n\r\nLord George had certainly brought her no comfort. When he told her\r\nthat she might go at once if she chose, she remembered, with a pang\r\nof agony, that she had already overdrawn her account at the bankers.\r\nShe was the actual possessor of an income of four thousand pounds a\r\nyear, and now, in her terrible strait, she could not stir because she\r\nhad no money with which to travel. Had all things been well with her,\r\nshe could, no doubt, have gone to her bankers and have arranged this\r\nlittle difficulty. But as it was, she could not move, because her\r\npurse was empty.\r\n\r\nLord George sat looking at her, and thinking whether he would make\r\nthe plunge and ask her to be his wife,--with all her impediments and\r\ndrawbacks about her. He had been careful to reduce her to such a\r\ncondition of despair, that she would undoubtedly have accepted him,\r\nso that she might have some one to lean upon in her trouble;--but,\r\nas he looked at her, he doubted. She was such a mass of deceit, that\r\nhe was afraid of her. She might say that she would marry him, and\r\nthen, when the storm was over, refuse to keep her word. She might\r\nbe in debt,--almost to any amount. She might be already married,\r\nfor anything that he knew. He did know that she was subject to all\r\nmanner of penalties for what she had done. He looked at her, and told\r\nhimself that she was very pretty. But in spite of her beauty, his\r\njudgment went against her. He did not dare to share even his boat\r\nwith so dangerous a fellow-passenger. "That\'s my advice," he said,\r\ngetting up from his chair.\r\n\r\n"Are you going?"\r\n\r\n"Well;--yes; I don\'t know what else I can do for you."\r\n\r\n"You are so unkind!" He shrugged his shoulders, just touched her\r\nhand, and left the room without saying another word to her.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXIV\r\n\r\nLizzie\'s Last Scheme\r\n\r\n\r\nLizzie, when she was left alone, was very angry with the Corsair,--in\r\ntruth, more sincerely angry than she had ever been with any of her\r\nlovers, or, perhaps, with any human being. Sincere, true, burning\r\nwrath was not the fault to which she was most exposed. She could snap\r\nand snarl, and hate, and say severe things; she could quarrel, and\r\nfight, and be malicious;--but to be full of real wrath was uncommon\r\nwith her. Now she was angry. She had been civil, more than civil,\r\nto Lord George. She had opened her house to him, and her heart. She\r\nhad told him her great secret. She had implored his protection.\r\nShe had thrown herself into his arms. And now he had rejected her.\r\nThat he should have been rough to her was only in accordance with\r\nthe poetical attributes which she had attributed to him. But his\r\nroughness should have been streaked with tenderness. He should not\r\nhave left her roughly. In the whole interview he had not said a\r\nloving word to her. He had given her advice,--which might be good or\r\nbad,--but he had given it as to one whom he despised. He had spoken\r\nto her throughout the interview exactly as he might have spoken to\r\nSir Griffin Tewett. She could not analyse her feelings thoroughly,\r\nbut she felt that because of what had passed between them, by reason\r\nof his knowledge of her secret, he had robbed her of all that\r\nobservance which was due to her as a woman and a lady. She had been\r\nroughly used before,--by people of inferior rank who had seen through\r\nher ways. Andrew Gowran had insulted her. Patience Crabstick had\r\nargued with her. Benjamin, the employer of thieves, had been familiar\r\nwith her. But hitherto, in what she was pleased to call her own set,\r\nshe had always been treated with that courtesy which ladies seldom\r\nfail to receive. She understood it all. She knew how much of mere\r\nword-service there often is in such complimentary usage. But,\r\nnevertheless, it implies respect, and an acknowledgement of the\r\nposition of her who is so respected. Lord George had treated her as\r\none schoolboy treats another.\r\n\r\nAnd he had not spoken to her one word of love. Love will excuse\r\nroughness. Spoken love will palliate even spoken roughness. Had he\r\nonce called her his own Lizzie, he might have scolded her as he\r\npleased,--might have abused her to the top of his bent. But as there\r\nhad been nothing of the manner of a gentleman to a lady, so also had\r\nthere been nothing of the lover to his mistress. That dream was over.\r\nLord George was no longer a Corsair, but a brute.\r\n\r\nBut what should she do? Even a brute may speak truth. She was to have\r\ngone to a theatre that evening with Mrs. Carbuncle, but she stayed\r\nat home thinking over her position. She heard nothing throughout the\r\nday from the police; and she made up her mind that, unless she were\r\nstopped by the police, she would go to Scotland on the day but one\r\nfollowing. She thought that she was sure that she would do so; but,\r\nof course, she must be guided by events as they occurred. She wrote,\r\nhowever, to Miss Macnulty saying that she would come, and she told\r\nMrs. Carbuncle of her proposed journey as that lady was leaving the\r\nhouse for the theatre. On the following morning, however, news came\r\nwhich again made her journey doubtful. There was another paragraph\r\nin the newspaper about the robbery, acknowledging the former\r\nparagraph to have been in some respect erroneous. The "accomplished\r\nhousebreaker" had not been arrested. A confederate of the\r\n"accomplished housebreaker" was in the hands of the police, and the\r\npolice were on the track of the "accomplished housebreaker" himself.\r\nThen there was a line or two alluding in a very mysterious way to the\r\ndisappearance of a certain jeweller. Taking it altogether, Lizzie\r\nthought that there was ground for hope,--and that, at any rate, there\r\nwould be delay. She would, perhaps, put off going to Scotland for\r\nyet a day or two. Was it not necessary that she should wait for Lord\r\nFawn\'s answer; and would it not be incumbent on her cousin Frank to\r\nsend her some account of himself after the abrupt manner in which he\r\nhad left her?\r\n\r\nIf in real truth she should be driven to tell her story to any\r\none,--and she began to think that she was so driven,--she would tell\r\nit to him. She believed more in his regard for her than that of any\r\nother human being. She thought that he would, in truth, have been\r\ndevoted to her, had he not become entangled with that wretched little\r\ngoverness. And she thought that if he could see his way out of that\r\nscrape, he would marry her even yet,--would marry her, and be good\r\nto her, so that her dream of a poetical phase of life should not\r\nbe altogether dissolved. After all, the diamonds were her own. She\r\nhad not stolen them. When perplexed in the extreme by magistrates\r\nand policemen, with nobody near her whom she trusted to give her\r\nadvice,--for Lizzie now of course declared to herself that she had\r\nnever for a moment trusted the Corsair,--she had fallen into an\r\nerror, and said what was not true. As she practised it before the\r\nglass, she thought that she could tell her story in a becoming\r\nmanner, with becoming tears, to Frank Greystock. And were it not for\r\nLucy Morris, she thought that he would take her with all her faults\r\nand all her burthens.\r\n\r\nAs for Lord Fawn, she knew well enough that, let him write what he\r\nwould, and renew his engagement in what most formal manner might be\r\npossible, he would be off again when he learned the facts as to that\r\nnight at Carlisle. She had brought him to succumb, because he could\r\nno longer justify his treatment of her by reference to the diamonds.\r\nBut when once all the world should know that she had twice perjured\r\nherself, his justification would be complete,--and his escape\r\nwould be certain. She would use his letter simply to achieve that\r\nrevenge which she had promised herself. Her effort,--her last final\r\neffort,--must be made to secure the hand and heart of her cousin\r\nFrank. "Ah, \'tis his heart I want!" she said to herself.\r\n\r\nShe must settle something before she went to Scotland,--if there was\r\nanything that could be settled. If she could only get a promise from\r\nFrank before all her treachery had been exposed, he probably would\r\nremain true to his promise. He would not desert her as Lord Fawn had\r\ndone. Then, after much thinking of it, she resolved upon a scheme\r\nwhich, of all her schemes, was the wickedest. Whatever it might cost\r\nher, she would create a separation between Frank Greystock and Lucy\r\nMorris. Having determined upon this, she wrote to Lucy, asking her to\r\ncall in Hertford Street at a certain hour.\r\n\r\n\r\n   DEAR LUCY,\r\n\r\n   I particularly want to see you,--on business. Pray come to\r\n   me at twelve to-morrow. I will send the carriage for you,\r\n   and it will take you back again. Pray do this. We used to\r\n   love one another, and I am sure I love you still.\r\n\r\n   Your affectionate old friend,\r\n\r\n   LIZZIE.\r\n\r\n\r\nAs a matter of course Lucy went to her. Lizzie, before the interview,\r\nstudied the part she was to play with all possible care,--even to the\r\nwords which she was to use. The greeting was at first kindly, for\r\nLucy had almost forgotten the bribe that had been offered to her, and\r\nhad quite forgiven it. Lizzie Eustace never could be dear to her;\r\nbut,--so Lucy had thought during her happiness,--this former friend\r\nof hers was the cousin of the man who was to be her husband, and was\r\ndear to him. Of course she had forgiven the offence. "And now, dear,\r\nI want to ask you a question," Lizzie said; "or rather, perhaps not a\r\nquestion. I can do it better than that. I think that my cousin Frank\r\nonce talked of--of making you his wife." Lucy answered not a word,\r\nbut she trembled in every limb, and the colour came to her face. "Was\r\nit not so, dear?"\r\n\r\n"What if it was? I don\'t know why you should ask me any question like\r\nthat about myself."\r\n\r\n"Is he not my cousin?"\r\n\r\n"Yes,--he is your cousin. Why don\'t you ask him? You see him every\r\nday, I suppose?"\r\n\r\n"Nearly every day."\r\n\r\n"Why do you send for me, then?"\r\n\r\n"It is so hard to tell you, Lucy. I have sent to you in good faith,\r\nand in love. I could have gone to you,--only for the old vulture, who\r\nwould not have let us had a word in peace. I do see him--constantly.\r\nAnd I love him dearly."\r\n\r\n"That is nothing to me," said Lucy. Anybody hearing them, and not\r\nknowing them, would have said that Lucy\'s manner was harsh in the\r\nextreme.\r\n\r\n"He has told me everything." Lizzie, when she said this, paused,\r\nlooking at her victim. "He has told me things which he could\r\nnot mention to you. It was only yesterday,--the day before\r\nyesterday,--that he was speaking to me of his debts. I offered to\r\nplace all that I have at his disposal, so as to free him, but he\r\nwould not take my money."\r\n\r\n"Of course he would not."\r\n\r\n"Not my money alone. Then he told me that he was engaged to you. He\r\nhad never told me before, but yet I knew it. It all came out then.\r\nLucy, though he is engaged to you, it is me that he loves."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t believe it," said Lucy.\r\n\r\n"You can\'t make me angry, Lucy, because my heart bleeds for you."\r\n\r\n"Nonsense! trash! I don\'t want your heart to bleed. I don\'t believe\r\nyou\'ve got a heart. You\'ve got money; I know that."\r\n\r\n"And he has got none. If I did not love him, why should I wish to\r\ngive him all that I have? Is not that disinterested?"\r\n\r\n"No. You are always thinking of yourself. You couldn\'t be\r\ndisinterested."\r\n\r\n"And of whom are you thinking? Are you doing the best for him,--a man\r\nin his position, without money, ambitious, sure to succeed if want\r\nof money does not stop him,--in wishing him to marry a girl with\r\nnothing? Cannot I do more for him than you can?"\r\n\r\n"I could work for him on my knees, I love him so truly!"\r\n\r\n"Would that do him any service? He cannot marry you. Does he ever see\r\nyou? Does he write to you as though you were to be his wife? Do you\r\nnot know that it is all over?--that it must be over? It is impossible\r\nthat he should marry you. But if you will give him back his word, he\r\nshall be my husband, and shall have all that I possess. Now, let us\r\nsee who loves him best!"\r\n\r\n"I do!" said Lucy.\r\n\r\n"How will you show it?"\r\n\r\n"There is no need that I should show it. He knows it. The only one\r\nin the world to whom I wish it to be known, knows it already well\r\nenough. Did you send for me for this?"\r\n\r\n"Yes;--for this."\r\n\r\n"It is for him to tell me the tidings;--not for you. You are nothing\r\nto me;--nothing. And what you say to me now is all for yourself,--not\r\nfor him. But it is true that he does not see me. It is true that he\r\ndoes not write to me. You may tell him from me,--for I cannot write\r\nto him myself,--that he may do whatever is best for him. But if you\r\ntell him that I do not love him better than all the world, you will\r\nlie to him. And if you say that he loves you better than he does me,\r\nthat also will be a lie. I know his heart."\r\n\r\n"But Lucy--"\r\n\r\n"I will hear no more. He can do as he pleases. If money be more to\r\nhim than love and honesty, let him marry you. I shall never trouble\r\nhim; he may be sure of that. As for you, Lizzie, I hope that we may\r\nnever meet again."\r\n\r\nShe would not get into the Eustace-Carbuncle carriage, which was\r\nwaiting for her at the door, but walked back to Bruton Street. She\r\ndid not doubt but that it was all over with her now. That Lizzie\r\nEustace was an inveterate liar, she knew well; but she did believe\r\nthat the liar had on this occasion been speaking truth. Lady Fawn was\r\nnot a liar, and Lady Fawn had told her the same. And, had she wanted\r\nmore evidence, did not her lover\'s conduct give it? "It is because I\r\nam poor," she said to herself,--"for I know well that he loves me!"\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXV\r\n\r\nTribute\r\n\r\n\r\nLizzie put off her journey to Scotland from day to day, though her\r\ncousin Frank continually urged upon her the expediency of going.\r\nThere were various reasons, he said, why she should go. Her child\r\nwas there, and it was proper that she should be with her child. She\r\nwas living at present with people whose reputation did not stand\r\nhigh,--and as to whom all manner of evil reports were flying about\r\nthe town. It was generally thought,--so said Frank,--that that Lord\r\nGeorge de Bruce Carruthers had assisted Mr. Benjamin in stealing the\r\ndiamonds, and Frank himself did not hesitate to express his belief\r\nin the accusation. "Oh no, that cannot be," said Lizzie, trembling.\r\nBut, though she rejected the supposition, she did not reject it very\r\nfirmly. "And then, you know," continued Lizzie, "I never see him. I\r\nhave actually only set eyes on him once since the second robbery,\r\nand then just for a minute. Of course, I used to know him,--down\r\nat Portray,--but now we are strangers." Frank went on with his\r\nobjections. He declared that the manner in which Mrs. Carbuncle\r\nhad got up the match between Lucinda Roanoke and Sir Griffin was\r\nshameful,--all the world was declaring that it was shameful,--that\r\nshe had not a penny, that the girl was an adventurer, and that Sir\r\nGriffin was an obstinate, pig-headed, ruined idiot. It was expedient\r\non every account that Lizzie should take herself away from that\r\n"lot." The answer that Lizzie desired to make was very simple. Let me\r\ngo as your betrothed bride, and I will start to-morrow,--to Scotland\r\nor elsewhere, as you may direct. Let that little affair be settled,\r\nand I shall be quite as willing to get out of London as you can be to\r\nsend me. But I am in such a peck of troubles that something must be\r\nsettled. And as it seems that after all the police are still astray\r\nabout the necklace, perhaps I needn\'t run away from them for a little\r\nwhile even yet. She did not say this. She did not even in so many\r\nwords make the first proposition. But she did endeavour to make Frank\r\nunderstand that she would obey his dictation if he would earn the\r\nright to dictate. He either did not or would not understand her, and\r\nthen she became angry with him,--or pretended to be angry. "Really,\r\nFrank," she said, "you are hardly fair to me."\r\n\r\n"In what way am I unfair?"\r\n\r\n"You come here and abuse all my friends, and tell me to go here and\r\ngo there, just as though I were a child. And--and--and--"\r\n\r\n"And what, Lizzie?"\r\n\r\n"You know what I mean. You are one thing one day, and one another. I\r\nhope Miss Lucy Morris was quite well when you last heard from her."\r\n\r\n"You have no right to speak to me of Lucy,--at least, not in\r\ndisparagement."\r\n\r\n"You are treating her very badly;--you know that."\r\n\r\n"I am."\r\n\r\n"Then why don\'t you give it up? Why don\'t you let her have her\r\nchances,--to do what she can with them? You know very well that you\r\ncan\'t marry her. You know that you ought not to have asked her. You\r\ntalk of Miss Roanoke and Sir Griffin Tewett. There are people quite\r\nas bad as Sir Griffin,--or Mrs. Carbuncle either. Don\'t suppose I am\r\nspeaking for myself. I\'ve given up all that idle fancy long ago. I\r\nshall never marry a second time myself. I have made up my mind to\r\nthat. I have suffered too much already." Then she burst into tears.\r\n\r\nHe dried her tears and comforted her, and forgave all the injurious\r\nthings she had said of him. It is almost impossible for a man,--a man\r\nunder forty and unmarried, and who is not a philosopher,--to have\r\nfamiliar and affectionate intercourse with a beautiful young woman,\r\nand carry it on as he might do with a friend of the other sex. In his\r\nvery heart Greystock despised this woman; he had told himself over\r\nand over again that were there no Lucy in the case he would not marry\r\nher; that she was affected, unreal,--and, in fact, a liar in every\r\nword and look and motion which came from her with premeditation.\r\nJudging, not from her own account, but from circumstances as he saw\r\nthem and such evidence as had reached him, he did not condemn her\r\nin reference to the diamonds. He had never for a moment conceived\r\nthat she had secreted them. He acquitted her altogether from those\r\nspecial charges which had been widely circulated against her; but,\r\nnevertheless, he knew her to be heartless and bad. He had told\r\nhimself a dozen times that it would be well for him that she should\r\nbe married and taken out of his hands. And yet he loved her after a\r\nfashion, and was prone to sit near her, and was fool enough to be\r\nflattered by her caresses. When she would lay her hand on his arm, a\r\nthrill of pleasure went through him. And yet he would willingly have\r\nseen any decent man take her and marry her, making a bargain that\r\nhe should never see her again. Young or old, men are apt to become\r\nMerlins when they encounter Viviens. On this occasion he left her,\r\ndisgusted indeed, but not having told her that he was disgusted.\r\n"Come again, Frank, to-morrow, won\'t you?" she said. He made her no\r\npromise as he went, nor had she expected it. He had left her quite\r\nabruptly the other day, and he now went away almost in the same\r\nfashion. But she was not surprised. She understood that the task she\r\nhad in hand was one very difficult to be accomplished,--and she did\r\nperceive, in some dark way, that, good as her acting was, it was not\r\nquite good enough. Lucy held her ground because she was real. You\r\nmay knock about a diamond, and not even scratch it; whereas paste\r\nin rough usage betrays itself. Lizzie, with all her self-assuring\r\nprotestations, knew that she was paste, and knew that Lucy was real\r\nstone. Why could she not force herself to act a little better, so\r\nthat the paste might be as good as the stone,--might at least seem to\r\nbe as good? "If he despises me now, what will he say when he finds it\r\nall out?" she asked herself.\r\n\r\nAs for Frank Greystock himself, though he had quite made up his mind\r\nabout Lizzie Eustace, he was still in doubt about the other girl. At\r\nthe present moment he was making over two thousand pounds a year,\r\nand yet was more in debt now than he had been a year ago. When he\r\nattempted to look at his affairs, he could not even remember what\r\nhad become of his money. He did not gamble. He had no little yacht,\r\ncosting him about six hundred a year. He kept one horse in London,\r\nand one only. He had no house. And when he could spare time from his\r\nwork, he was generally entertained at the houses of his friends. And\r\nyet from day to day his condition seemed to become worse and worse.\r\nIt was true that he never thought of half-a-sovereign; that in\r\ncalling for wine at his club he was never influenced by the cost;\r\nthat it seemed to him quite rational to keep a cab waiting for him\r\nhalf the day; that in going or coming he never calculated expense;\r\nthat in giving an order to a tailor he never dreamed of anything\r\nbeyond his own comfort. Nevertheless, when he recounted with pride\r\nhis great economies, reminding himself that he, a successful man,\r\nwith a large income and no family, kept neither hunters, nor yacht,\r\nnor moor, and that he did not gamble, he did think it very hard\r\nthat he should be embarrassed. But he was embarrassed, and in that\r\ncondition could it be right for him to marry a girl without a\r\nshilling?\r\n\r\nIn these days Mrs. Carbuncle was very urgent with her friend not\r\nto leave London till after the marriage. Lizzie had given no\r\npromise,--had only been induced to promise that the loan of one\r\nhundred and fifty pounds should not be held to have any bearing on\r\nthe wedding present to be made to Lucinda. That could be got on\r\ncredit from Messrs. Harter and Benjamin; for though Mr. Benjamin was\r\nabsent,--on a little tour through Europe in search of precious stones\r\nin the cheap markets, old Mr. Harter suggested,--the business went\r\non the same as ever. There was a good deal of consultation about\r\nthe present, and Mrs. Carbuncle at last decided, no doubt with the\r\nconcurrence of Miss Roanoke, that it should consist simply of silver\r\nforks and spoons,--real silver as far as the money would go. Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle herself went with her friend to select the articles,--as to\r\nwhich, perhaps, we shall do her no injustice in saying that a ready\r\nsale, should such a lamentable occurrence ever become necessary,\r\nwas one of the objects which she had in view. Mrs. Carbuncle\'s\r\ninvestigations as to the quality of the metal quite won Mr. Harter\'s\r\nrespect; and it will probably be thought that she exacted no\r\nmore than justice,--seeing that the thing had become a matter\r\nof bargain,--in demanding that the thirty-five pounds should be\r\nstretched to fifty, because the things were bought on long credit.\r\n"My dear Lizzie," Mrs. Carbuncle said, "the dear girl won\'t have an\r\nounce more than she would have got, had you gone into another sort of\r\nshop with thirty-five sovereigns in your hand." Lizzie growled, but\r\nMrs. Carbuncle\'s final argument was conclusive. "I\'ll tell you what\r\nwe\'ll do," said she; "we\'ll take thirty pounds down in ready money."\r\nThere was no answer to be made to so reasonable a proposition.\r\n\r\nThe presents to be made to Lucinda were very much thought of in\r\nHertford Street at this time, and Lizzie,--independently of any\r\nfeeling that she might have as to her own contribution,--did all she\r\ncould to assist the collection of tribute. It was quite understood\r\nthat as a girl can only be married once,--for a widow\'s chance in\r\nsuch matters amounts to but little,--everything should be done to\r\ngather toll from the tax-payers of society. It was quite fair on such\r\nan occasion that men should be given to understand that something\r\nworth having was expected,--no trumpery thirty-shilling piece of\r\ncrockery, no insignificant glass bottle, or fantastic paper-knife\r\nof no real value whatever, but got up just to put money into the\r\ntradesmen\'s hands. To one or two elderly gentlemen upon whom Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle had smiled, she ventured to suggest in plain words that a\r\ncheque was the most convenient cadeau. "What do you say to a couple\r\nof sovereigns?" one sarcastic old gentleman replied, upon whom\r\nprobably Mrs. Carbuncle had not smiled enough. She laughed and\r\ncongratulated her sarcastic friend upon his joke;--but the two\r\nsovereigns were left upon the table, and went to swell the spoil.\r\n\r\n"You must do something handsome for Lucinda," Lizzie said to her\r\ncousin.\r\n\r\n"What do you call handsome?"\r\n\r\n"You are a bachelor and a Member of Parliament. Say fifteen pounds."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll be ---- if I do!" said Frank, who was beginning to be very much\r\ndisgusted with the house in Hertford Street. "There\'s a five-pound\r\nnote, and you may do what you please with it." Lizzie gave over the\r\nfive-pound note,--the identical bit of paper that had come from\r\nFrank; and Mrs. Carbuncle, no doubt, did do what she pleased with it.\r\n\r\nThere was almost a quarrel because Lizzie, after much consideration,\r\ndeclared that she did not see her way to get a present from the Duke\r\nof Omnium. She had talked so much to Mrs. Carbuncle about the duke,\r\nthat Mrs. Carbuncle was almost justified in making the demand. "It\r\nisn\'t the value, you know," said Mrs. Carbuncle; "neither I nor\r\nLucinda would think of that; but it would look so well to have the\r\ndear duke\'s name on something." Lizzie declared that the duke was\r\nunapproachable on such subjects. "There you\'re wrong," said Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle. "I happen to know there is nothing his grace likes so much\r\nas giving wedding presents." This was the harder upon Lizzie as she\r\nactually did succeed in saying such kind things about Lucinda, that\r\nLady Glencora sent Miss Roanoke the prettiest smelling-bottle in the\r\nworld. "You don\'t mean to say you\'ve given a present to the future\r\nLady Tewett?" said Madame Max Goesler to her friend. "Why not? Sir\r\nGriffin can\'t hurt me. When one begins to be good-natured, why\r\nshouldn\'t one be good-natured all round?" Madame Max remarked that\r\nit might, perhaps, be preferable to put an end to good-nature\r\naltogether. "There I daresay you\'re right, my dear," said Lady\r\nGlencora. "I\'ve long felt that making presents means nothing. Only if\r\none has a lot of money and people like it, why shouldn\'t one? I\'ve\r\nmade so many to people I hardly ever saw that one more to Lady Tewett\r\ncan\'t hurt."\r\n\r\nPerhaps the most wonderful affair in that campaign was the spirited\r\nattack which Mrs. Carbuncle made on a certain Mrs. Hanbury Smith, who\r\nfor the last six or seven years had not been among Mrs. Carbuncle\'s\r\nmore intimate friends. Mrs. Hanbury Smith lived with her husband in\r\nParis, but before her marriage had known Mrs. Carbuncle in London.\r\nHer father, Mr. Bunbury Jones, had, from certain causes, chosen to\r\nshow certain civilities to Mrs. Carbuncle just at the period of his\r\ndaughter\'s marriage, and Mrs. Carbuncle being perhaps at that moment\r\nwell supplied with ready money, had presented a marriage present.\r\nFrom that to this present day Mrs. Carbuncle had seen nothing of Mrs.\r\nHanbury Smith, nor of Mr. Bunbury Jones, but she was not the woman to\r\nwaste the return-value of such a transaction. A present so given was\r\nseed sown in the earth,--seed, indeed, that could not be expected to\r\ngive back twenty-fold, or even ten-fold, but still seed from which\r\na crop should be expected. So she wrote to Mrs. Hanbury Smith,\r\nexplaining that her darling niece Lucinda was about to be married to\r\nSir Griffin Tewett, and that, as she had no child of her own, Lucinda\r\nwas the same to her as a daughter. And then, lest there might be any\r\nwant of comprehension, she expressed her own assurance that her\r\nfriend would be glad to have an opportunity of reciprocating the\r\nfeelings which had been evinced on the occasion of her own marriage.\r\n"It is no good mincing matters now-a-days," Mrs. Carbuncle would have\r\nsaid, had any friend pointed out to her that she was taking strong\r\nmeasures in the exaction of toll. "People have come to understand\r\nthat a spade is a spade, and \xa310, \xa310," she would have said. Had Mrs.\r\nHanbury Smith not noticed the application, there might, perhaps, have\r\nbeen an end of it, but she was silly enough to send over from Paris\r\na little trumpery bit of finery, bought in the Palais Royal for ten\r\nfrancs. Whereupon Mrs. Carbuncle wrote the following letter:--\r\n\r\n\r\n   MY DEAR MRS. HANBURY SMITH,\r\n\r\n   Lucinda has received your little brooch, and is much\r\n   obliged to you for thinking of her; but you must remember\r\n   that when you were married, I sent you a bracelet which\r\n   cost \xa310. If I had a daughter of my own, I should, of\r\n   course, expect that she would reap the benefit of this\r\n   on her marriage;--and my niece is the same to me as a\r\n   daughter. I think that this is quite understood now among\r\n   people in society. Lucinda will be disappointed much if\r\n   you do not send her what she thinks she has a right to\r\n   expect. Of course you can deduct the brooch if you please.\r\n\r\n   Yours very sincerely,\r\n\r\n   JANE CARBUNCLE.\r\n\r\n\r\nMr. Hanbury Smith was something of a wag, and caused his wife to\r\nwrite back as follows:--\r\n\r\n\r\n   DEAR MRS. CARBUNCLE,\r\n\r\n   I quite acknowledge the reciprocity system, but don\'t\r\n   think it extends to descendants,--certainly not to nieces.\r\n   I acknowledge, too, the present quoted at \xa310. I thought\r\n   it had been \xa37 10s.--["The nasty, mean creature," said\r\n   Mrs. Carbuncle, when showing the correspondence to\r\n   Lizzie, "must have been to the tradesman to inquire! The\r\n   price named was \xa310, but I got \xa32 l0s. off for ready\r\n   money."]--At your second marriage I will do what is\r\n   needful; but I can assure you I haven\'t recognised nieces\r\n   with any of my friends.\r\n\r\n   Yours very truly,\r\n\r\n   CAROLINE HANBURY SMITH.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe correspondence was carried no further, for not even can a Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle exact payment of such a debt in any established court; but\r\nshe inveighed bitterly against the meanness of Mrs. Smith, telling\r\nthe story openly, and never feeling that she told it against herself.\r\nIn her set it was generally thought that she had done quite right.\r\n\r\nShe managed better with old Mr. Cabob, who had certainly received\r\nmany of Mrs. Carbuncle\'s smiles, and who was very rich. Mr. Cabob did\r\nas he was desired, and sent a cheque,--a cheque for \xa320; and added\r\na message that he hoped Miss Roanoke would buy with it any little\r\nthing that she liked. Miss Roanoke,--or her aunt for her,--liked a\r\nthirty-guinea ring, and bought it, having the bill for the balance\r\nsent in to Mr. Cabob. Mr. Cabob, who probably knew that he must pay\r\nwell for his smiles, never said anything about it.\r\n\r\nLady Eustace went into all this work, absolutely liking it. She had\r\nfelt nothing of anger even as regarded her own contribution,--much as\r\nshe had struggled to reduce the amount. People, she felt, ought to be\r\nsharp;--and it was nice to look at pretty things, and to be cunning\r\nabout them. She would have applied to the Duke of Omnium had she\r\ndared, and was very triumphant when she got the smelling-bottle from\r\nLady Glencora. But Lucinda herself took no part whatever in all these\r\nthings. Nothing that Mrs. Carbuncle could say would induce her to\r\ntake any interest in them, or even in the trousseau, which, without\r\nreference to expense, was being supplied chiefly on the very\r\nindifferent credit of Sir Griffin. What Lucinda had to say about\r\nthe matter was said solely to her aunt. Neither Lady Eustace, nor\r\nLord George, nor even the maid who dressed her, heard any of her\r\ncomplaints. But complain she did, and that with terrible energy.\r\n"What is the use of it, Aunt Jane? I shall never have a house to put\r\nthem into."\r\n\r\n"What nonsense, my dear! Why shouldn\'t you have a house as well as\r\nothers?"\r\n\r\n"And if I had, I should never care for them. I hate them. What does\r\nLady Glencora Palliser or Lord Fawn care for me?" Even Lord Fawn\r\nhad been put under requisition, and had sent a little box full of\r\nstationery.\r\n\r\n"They are worth money, Lucinda; and when a girl marries she always\r\ngets them."\r\n\r\n"Yes;--and when they come from people who love her, and who pour them\r\ninto her lap with kisses, because she has given herself to a man she\r\nloves, then it must be nice. Oh,--if I were marrying a poor man, and\r\na poor friend had given me a gridiron to help me to cook my husband\'s\r\ndinner, how I could have valued it!"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know that you like poor things and poor people better than\r\nanybody else," said Aunt Jane.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t like anything or anybody," said Lucinda.\r\n\r\n"You had better take the good things that come to you, then; and not\r\ngrumble. How I have worked to get all this arranged for you, and now\r\nwhat thanks have I?"\r\n\r\n"You\'ll find you have worked for very little, Aunt Jane. I shall\r\nnever marry the man yet." This, however, had been said so often that\r\nAunt Jane thought nothing of the threat.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXVI\r\n\r\nThe Aspirations of Mr. Emilius\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was acknowledged by Mrs. Carbuncle very freely that in the matter\r\nof tribute no one behaved better than Mr. Emilius, the fashionable,\r\nforeign, ci-devant Jew preacher, who still drew great congregations\r\nin the neighbourhood of Mrs. Carbuncle\'s house. Mrs. Carbuncle, no\r\ndoubt, attended regularly at Mr. Emilius\'s church, and had taken\r\na sitting for thirteen Sundays at something like ten shillings a\r\nSunday. But she had not as yet paid the money, and Mr. Emilius was\r\nwell aware that if his tickets were not paid for in advance, there\r\nwould be considerable defalcations in his income. He was, as a rule,\r\nvery particular as to such payments, and would not allow a name to\r\nbe put on a sitting till the money had reached his pockets; but with\r\nMrs. Carbuncle he had descended to no such commercial accuracy. Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle had seats for three,--for one of which Lady Eustace paid\r\nher share in advance,--in the midst of the very best pews in the most\r\nconspicuous part of the house,--and hardly a word had been said to\r\nher about the money. And now there came to them from Mr. Emilius\r\nthe prettiest little gold salver that ever was seen. "I send Messrs.\r\nClerico\'s docket," wrote Mr. Emilius, "as Miss Roanoke may like to\r\nknow the quality of the metal." "Ah," said Mrs. Carbuncle, inspecting\r\nthe little dish, and putting two and two together; "he\'s got it\r\ncheap, no doubt,--at the place where they commissioned him to buy\r\nthe plate and candlesticks for the church; but at \xa33 16s. 3d. the\r\ngold is worth nearly twenty pounds." Mr. Emilius no doubt had had his\r\nouting in the autumn through the instrumentality of Mrs. Carbuncle\'s\r\nkindness; but that was past and gone, and such lavish gratitude for\r\na past favour could hardly be expected from Mr. Emilius. "I\'ll be\r\nhanged if he isn\'t after Portray Castle," said Mrs. Carbuncle to\r\nherself.\r\n\r\nMr. Emilius was after Portray Castle, and had been after Portray\r\nCastle in a silent, not very confident, but yet not altogether\r\nhopeless manner ever since he had seen the glories of that place, and\r\nlearned something of truth as to the widow\'s income. Mrs. Carbuncle\r\nwas led to her conclusion not simply by the wedding present, but in\r\npart also by the diligence displayed by Mr. Emilius in removing the\r\ndoubts which had got abroad respecting his condition in life. He\r\nassured Mrs. Carbuncle that he had never been married. Shortly after\r\nhis ordination, which had been effected under the hands of that great\r\nand good man the late Bishop of Jerusalem, he had taken to live with\r\nhim a lady who was-- Mrs. Carbuncle did not quite recollect who the\r\nlady was, but remembered that she was connected in some way with a\r\nstep-mother of Mr. Emilius who lived in Bohemia. This lady had for\r\nawhile kept house for Mr. Emilius;--but ill-natured things had been\r\nsaid, and Mr. Emilius, having respect to his cloth, had sent the poor\r\nlady back to Bohemia. The consequence was that he now lived in a\r\nsolitude which was absolute, and, as Mr. Emilius added, somewhat\r\nmelancholy. All this Mr. Emilius explained very fully, not to Lizzie\r\nherself, but to Mrs. Carbuncle. If Lady Eustace chose to entertain\r\nsuch a suitor, why should he not come? It was nothing to Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle.\r\n\r\nLizzie laughed when she was told that she might add the reverend\r\ngentleman to the list of her admirers. "Don\'t you remember," she\r\nsaid, "how we used to chaff Miss Macnulty about him?"\r\n\r\n"I knew better than that," replied Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\n"There is no saying what a man may be after," said Lizzie. "I didn\'t\r\nknow but what he might have thought that Macnulty\'s connexions would\r\nincrease his congregation."\r\n\r\n"He\'s after you, my dear, and your income. He can manage a\r\ncongregation for himself."\r\n\r\nLizzie was very civil to him, but it would be unjust to her to say\r\nthat she gave him any encouragement. It is quite the proper thing for\r\na lady to be on intimate, and even on affectionate, terms with her\r\nfavourite clergyman, and Lizzie certainly had intercourse with no\r\nclergyman who was a greater favourite with her than Mr. Emilius. She\r\nhad a dean for an uncle, and a bishop for an uncle-in-law; but she\r\nwas at no pains to hide her contempt for these old fogies of the\r\nChurch. "They preach now and then in the cathedral," she said to Mr.\r\nEmilius, "and everybody takes the opportunity of going to sleep." Mr.\r\nEmilius was very much amused at this description of the eloquence of\r\nthe dignitaries. It was quite natural to him that people should go to\r\nsleep in church who take no trouble in seeking eloquent preachers.\r\n"Ah," he said, "the Church in England, which is my Church,--the\r\nChurch which I love,--is beautiful. She is as a maiden, all glorious\r\nwith fine raiment. But alas! she is mute. She does not sing. She has\r\nno melody. But the time cometh in which she shall sing. I, myself,--I\r\nam a poor singer in the great choir." In saying which Mr. Emilius no\r\ndoubt intended to allude to his eloquence as a preacher.\r\n\r\nHe was a man who could listen as well as sing, and he was very\r\ncareful to hear well that which was being said in public about Lady\r\nEustace and her diamonds. He had learned thoroughly what was her\r\ncondition in reference to the Portray estate, and was rejoiced rather\r\nthan otherwise to find that she enjoyed only a life-interest in the\r\nproperty. Had the thing been better than it was, it would have been\r\nthe further removed from his reach. And in the same way, when rumours\r\nreached him prejudicial to Lizzie in respect of the diamonds, he\r\nperceived that such prejudice might work weal for him. A gentleman\r\nonce, on ordering a mackerel for dinner, was told that a fresh\r\nmackerel would come to a shilling. He could have a stale mackerel for\r\nsixpence. "Then bring me a stale mackerel," said the gentleman. Mr.\r\nEmilius coveted fish, but was aware that his position did not justify\r\nhim in expecting the best fish on the market. The Lord Fawns and the\r\nFrank Greystocks of the world would be less likely to covet Lizzie,\r\nshould she, by any little indiscretion, have placed herself under a\r\ntemporary cloud. Mr. Emilius had carefully observed the heavens, and\r\nknew how quickly such clouds will disperse themselves when they are\r\ntinged with gold. There was nothing which Lizzie had done, or would\r\nbe likely to do, which could materially affect her income. It might\r\nindeed be possible that the Eustaces should make her pay for the\r\nnecklace; but even in that case, there would be quite enough left for\r\nthat modest, unambitious comfort which Mr. Emilius desired. It was by\r\npreaching, and not by wealth, that he must make himself known in the\r\nworld!--but for a preacher to have a pretty wife with a title and a\r\ngood income,--and a castle in Scotland,--what an Elysium it would be!\r\nIn such a condition he would envy no dean, no bishop,--no archbishop!\r\nHe thought a great deal about it, and saw no positive bar to his\r\nsuccess.\r\n\r\nShe told him that she was going to Scotland. "Not immediately!" he\r\nexclaimed.\r\n\r\n"My little boy is there," she said.\r\n\r\n"But why should not your little boy be here? Surely, for people who\r\ncan choose, the great centre of the world offers attractions which\r\ncannot be found in secluded spots."\r\n\r\n"I love seclusion," said Lizzie, with rapture.\r\n\r\n"Ah, yes; I can believe that." Mr. Emilius had himself witnessed the\r\nseclusion of Portray Castle, and had heard, when there, many stories\r\nof the Ayrshire hunting. "It is your nature;--but, dear Lady Eustace,\r\nwill you allow me to say that our nature is implanted in us in\r\naccordance with the Fall?"\r\n\r\n"Do you mean to say that it is wicked to like to be in Scotland\r\nbetter than in this giddy town?"\r\n\r\n"I say nothing about wicked, Lady Eustace; but this I do say, that\r\nnature alone will not lead us always aright. It is good to be at\r\nPortray part of the year, no doubt; but are there not blessings in\r\nsuch a congregation of humanity as this London which you cannot find\r\nat Portray?"\r\n\r\n"I can hear you preach, Mr. Emilius, certainly."\r\n\r\n"I hope that is something, too, Lady Eustace;--otherwise a great many\r\npeople who kindly come to hear me must sadly waste their time. And\r\nyour example to the world around;--is it not more serviceable amidst\r\nthe crowds of London than in the solitudes of Scotland? There is more\r\ngood to be done, Lady Eustace, by living among our fellow-creatures\r\nthan by deserting them. Therefore I think you should not go to\r\nScotland before August, but should have your little boy brought to\r\nyou here."\r\n\r\n"The air of his native mountains is everything to my child," said\r\nLizzie. The child had, in fact, been born at Bobsborough, but that\r\nprobably would make no real difference.\r\n\r\n"You cannot wonder that I should plead for your stay," said Mr.\r\nEmilius, throwing all his soul into his eyes. "How dark would\r\neverything be to me if I missed you from your seat in the house of\r\npraise and prayer!"\r\n\r\nLizzie Eustace, like some other ladies who ought to be more\r\nappreciative, was altogether deficient in what may perhaps be called\r\ngood taste in reference to men. Though she was clever, and though,\r\nin spite of her ignorance, she at once knew an intelligent man from\r\na fool, she did not know the difference between a gentleman and\r\na--"cad." It was in her estimation something against Mr. Emilius that\r\nhe was a clergyman, something against him that he had nothing but\r\nwhat he earned, something against him that he was supposed to be a\r\nrenegade Jew, and that nobody knew whence he came nor who he was.\r\nThese deficiencies or drawbacks Lizzie recognised. But it was nothing\r\nagainst him in her judgment that he was a greasy, fawning, pawing,\r\ncreeping, black-browed rascal, who could not look her full in the\r\nface, and whose every word sounded like a lie. There was a twang\r\nin his voice which ought to have told her that he was utterly\r\nuntrustworthy. There was an oily pretence at earnestness in his\r\nmanner which ought to have told that he was not fit to associate with\r\ngentlemen. There was a foulness of demeanour about him which ought to\r\nhave given to her, as a woman at any rate brought up among ladies,\r\nan abhorrence of his society. But all this Lizzie did not feel. She\r\nridiculed to Mrs. Carbuncle the idea of the preacher\'s courtship.\r\nShe still thought that in the teeth of all her misfortunes she could\r\ndo better with herself than marry Mr. Emilius. She conceived that\r\nthe man must be impertinent if Mrs. Carbuncle\'s assertions were\r\ntrue;--but she was neither angry nor disgusted, and she allowed\r\nhim to talk to her, and even to make love to her, after his nasty\r\npseudo-clerical fashion.\r\n\r\nShe could surely still do better with herself than marry Mr. Emilius!\r\nIt was now the twentieth of March, and a fortnight had gone since an\r\nintimation had been sent to her from the headquarters of the police\r\nthat Patience Crabstick was in their hands. Nothing further had\r\noccurred, and it might be that Patience Crabstick had told no tale\r\nagainst her. She could not bring herself to believe that Patience had\r\nno tale to tell, but it might be that Patience, though she was in the\r\nhands of the police, would find it to her interest to tell no tale\r\nagainst her late mistress. At any rate, there was silence and quiet,\r\nand the affair of the diamonds seemed almost to be passing out of\r\npeople\'s minds. Greystock had twice called in Scotland Yard, but had\r\nbeen able to learn nothing. It was feared, they said, that the people\r\nreally engaged in the robbery had got away scot-free. Frank did\r\nnot quite believe them, but he could learn nothing from them. Thus\r\nencouraged, Lizzie determined that she would remain in London till\r\nafter Lucinda\'s marriage,--till after she should have received the\r\npromised letter from Lord Fawn, as to which, though it was so long in\r\ncoming, she did not doubt that it would come at last. She could do\r\nnothing with Frank,--who was a fool! She could do nothing with Lord\r\nGeorge,--who was a brute! Lord Fawn would still be within her reach,\r\nif only the secret about the diamonds could be kept a secret till\r\nafter she should have become his wife.\r\n\r\nAbout this time Lucinda spoke to her respecting her proposed journey.\r\n"You were talking of going to Scotland a week ago, Lady Eustace."\r\n\r\n"And am still talking of it."\r\n\r\n"Aunt Jane says that you are waiting for my wedding. It is very kind\r\nof you;--but pray don\'t do that."\r\n\r\n"I shouldn\'t think of going now till after your marriage. It only\r\nwants ten or twelve days."\r\n\r\n"I count them. I know how many days it wants. It may want more than\r\nthat."\r\n\r\n"You can\'t put it off now, I should think," said Lizzie; "and as I\r\nhave ordered my dress for the occasion I shall certainly stay and\r\nwear it."\r\n\r\n"I am very sorry for your dress. I am very sorry for it all. Do you\r\nknow;--I sometimes think I shall--murder him."\r\n\r\n"Lucinda,--how can you say anything so horrible! But I see you are\r\nonly joking." There did come a ghastly smile over that beautiful\r\nface, which was so seldom lighted up by any expression of mirth or\r\ngood humour. "But I wish you would not say such horrible things."\r\n\r\n"It would serve him right;--and if he were to murder me, that would\r\nserve me right. He knows that I detest him, and yet he goes on with\r\nit. I have told him so a score of times, but nothing will make him\r\ngive it up. It is not that he loves me, but he thinks that that will\r\nbe his triumph."\r\n\r\n"Why don\'t you give it up, if it makes you unhappy?"\r\n\r\n"It ought to come from him,--ought it not?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t see why," said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n"He is not bound to anybody as I am bound to my aunt. No one can have\r\nexacted an oath from him. Lady Eustace, you don\'t quite understand\r\nhow we are situated. I wonder whether you would take the trouble to\r\nbe good to me?"\r\n\r\nLucinda Roanoke had never asked a favour of her before;--had never,\r\nto Lizzie\'s knowledge, asked a favour of any one. "In what way can I\r\nbe good to you?" she said.\r\n\r\n"Make him give it up. You may tell him what you like of me. Tell him\r\nthat I shall only make him miserable, and more despicable than he\r\nis;--that I shall never be a good wife to him. Tell him that I am\r\nthoroughly bad, and that he will repent it to the last day of his\r\nlife.
