Such was\r\nher evidence for the prosecution, and then she was turned over to the\r\nvery learned and very acute gentleman whom Mr. Benjamin had hired for\r\nhis defence,--or rather, to show cause why he should not be sent for\r\ntrial.\r\n\r\nIt must be owned that poor Lizzie did receive from his hands some of\r\nthat punishment which she certainly deserved. This acute and learned\r\ngentleman seemed to possess for the occasion the blandest and most\r\ndulcet voice that ever was bestowed upon an English barrister. He\r\naddressed Lady Eustace with the softest words, as though he hardly\r\ndared to speak to a woman so eminent for wealth, rank, and beauty;\r\nbut nevertheless he asked her some very disagreeable questions. "Was\r\nhe to understand that she went of her own will before the bench\r\nof magistrates at Carlisle, with the view of enabling the police\r\nto capture certain persons for stealing certain jewels, while she\r\nknew that the jewels were actually in her own possession?" Lizzie,\r\nconfounded by the softness of his voice as joined to the harshness of\r\nthe question, could hardly understand him, and he repeated it thrice,\r\nbecoming every time more and more mellifluous. "Yes," said Lizzie at\r\nlast. "Yes?" he asked. "Yes," said Lizzie. "Your ladyship did send\r\nthe Cumberland police after men for stealing jewels which were in\r\nyour ladyship\'s own hands when you swore the information?" "Yes,"\r\nsaid Lizzie. "And your ladyship knew that the information was\r\nuntrue?" "Yes," said Lizzie. "And the police were pursuing the men\r\nfor many weeks?" "Yes," said Lizzie. "On your information?" "Yes,"\r\nsaid Lizzie, through her tears. "And your ladyship knew all the time\r\nthat the poor men were altogether innocent of taking the jewels?"\r\n"But they took the box," said Lizzie, through her tears. "Yes," said\r\nthe acute and learned gentleman, "somebody took your ladyship\'s\r\niron box out of the room, and you swore that the diamonds had been\r\ntaken. Was it not the fact that legal proceedings were being taken\r\nagainst you for recovery of the diamonds by persons who claimed the\r\nproperty?" "Yes," said Lizzie. "And these persons withdrew their\r\nproceedings as soon as they heard that the diamonds had been stolen?"\r\n\r\nSoft as he was in his manner, he nearly reduced Lizzie Eustace to\r\nfainting. It seemed to her that the questions would never end. It was\r\nin vain that the magistrate pointed out to the learned gentleman that\r\nLady Eustace had confessed her own false swearing, both at Carlisle\r\nand in London, a dozen times. He continued his questions over and\r\nover again, harping chiefly on the affair at Carlisle, and saying\r\nvery little as to the second robbery in Hertford Street. His idea was\r\nto make it appear that Lizzie had arranged the robbery with the view\r\nof defrauding Mr. Camperdown, and that Lord George Carruthers was\r\nher accomplice. He even asked her, almost in a whisper, and with the\r\nsweetest smile, whether she was not engaged to marry Lord George.\r\nWhen Lizzie denied this, he still suggested that some such alliance\r\nmight be in contemplation. Upon this, Frank Greystock called upon the\r\nmagistrate to defend Lady Eustace from such unnecessary vulgarity,\r\nand there was a scene in the court. Lizzie did not like the scene,\r\nbut it helped to protect her from the contemplation of the public,\r\nwho of course were much gratified by high words between two\r\nbarristers.\r\n\r\nLady Eustace was forced to remain in the private room during the\r\nexamination of Patience Crabstick and Mr. Cann; and she did not hear\r\nit. Patience was a most obdurate and difficult witness,--extremely\r\naverse to say evil of herself, and on that account unworthy\r\nof the good things which she had received. But Billy Cann was\r\ncharming,--graceful, communicative, and absolutely accurate. There\r\nwas no shaking him. The learned and acute gentleman who tried to tear\r\nhim in pieces could do nothing with him. He was asked whether he had\r\nnot been a professional thief for ten years. "Ten or twelve," he\r\nsaid. Did he expect that any juryman would believe him on his oath?\r\n"Not unless I am fully corroborated." "Can you look that man in the\r\nface,--that man who is at any rate so much honester than yourself?"\r\nasked the learned gentleman with pathos. Billy said that he thought\r\nhe could, and the way in which he smiled upon Smiler caused a roar\r\nthrough the whole court.\r\n\r\nThe two men were, as a matter of course, committed for trial at the\r\nCentral Criminal Court, and Lizzie Eustace was bound by certain\r\npenalties to come forward when called upon, and give her evidence\r\nagain. "I am glad that it is over," said Frank, as he left her at\r\nMrs. Carbuncle\'s hall-door.\r\n\r\n"Oh, Frank, dearest Frank, where should I be if it were not for you?"\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXXV\r\n\r\nLord George Gives His Reasons\r\n\r\n\r\nLady Eustace did not leave the house during the Saturday and Sunday,\r\nand engaged herself exclusively with preparing for her journey. She\r\nhad no further interview with Mrs. Carbuncle, but there were messages\r\nbetween them, and even notes were written. They resulted in nothing.\r\nLizzie was desirous of getting back the spoons and forks, and, if\r\npossible, some of her money. The spoons and forks were out of Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle\'s power,--in Albemarle Street; and the money had of course\r\nbeen spent. Lizzie might have saved herself the trouble, had it\r\nnot been that it was a pleasure to her to insult her late friend,\r\neven though in doing so new insults were heaped upon her own head.\r\nAs for the trumpery spoons, they,--so said Mrs. Carbuncle,--were\r\nthe property of Miss Roanoke, having been made over to her\r\nunconditionally long before the wedding, as a part of a separate\r\npecuniary transaction. Mrs. Carbuncle had no power of disposing of\r\nMiss Roanoke\'s property. As to the money which Lady Eustace claimed,\r\nMrs. Carbuncle asserted that, when the final accounts should be made\r\nup between them, it would be found that there was a considerable\r\nbalance due to Mrs. Carbuncle. But even were there anything due\r\nto Lady Eustace, Mrs. Carbuncle would decline to pay it, as she\r\nwas informed that all moneys possessed by Lady Eustace were now\r\nconfiscated to the Crown by reason of the PERJURIES,--the word was\r\ndoubly scored in Mrs. Carbuncle\'s note,--which Lady Eustace had\r\ncommitted. This, of course, was unpleasant; but Mrs. Carbuncle did\r\nnot have the honours of the battle all to herself. Lizzie also said\r\nsome unpleasant things,--which, perhaps, were the more unpleasant\r\nbecause they were true. Mrs. Carbuncle had come pretty nearly to\r\nthe end of her career, whereas Lizzie\'s income, in spite of her\r\nperjuries, was comparatively untouched. The undoubted mistress of\r\nPortray Castle, and mother of the Sir Florian Eustace of the day,\r\ncould still despise and look down upon Mrs. Carbuncle, although she\r\nwere known to have told fibs about the family diamonds.\r\n\r\nLord George always came to Hertford Street on a Sunday, and Lady\r\nEustace left word for him with the servant that she would be glad to\r\nsee him before her journey into Scotland. "Goes to-morrow, does she?"\r\nsaid Lord George to the servant. "Well; I\'ll see her." And he was\r\nshown up to her room before he went to Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\nLizzie, in sending to him, had some half-formed idea of a romantic\r\nfarewell. The man, she thought, had behaved very badly to her,--had\r\naccepted very much from her hands, and had refused to give her\r\nanything in return; had become the first depository of her great\r\nsecret, and had placed no mutual confidence in her. He had been harsh\r\nto her, and unjust; and then, too, he had declined to be in love with\r\nher! She was full of spite against Lord George, and would have been\r\nglad to injure him. But, nevertheless, there would be some excitement\r\nin a farewell in which some mock affection might be displayed, and\r\nshe would have an opportunity of abusing Mrs. Carbuncle.\r\n\r\n"So you are off to-morrow?" said Lord George, taking his place on the\r\nrug before her fire, and looking down at her with his head a little\r\non one side. Lizzie\'s anger against the man chiefly arose from a\r\nfeeling that he treated her with all a Corsair\'s freedom without\r\nany of a Corsair\'s tenderness. She could have forgiven the want of\r\ndeferential manner, had there been any devotion;--but Lord George was\r\nboth impudent and indifferent.\r\n\r\n"Yes," she said. "Thank goodness, I shall get out of this frightful\r\nplace to-morrow, and soon have once more a roof of my own over my\r\nhead. What an experience I have had since I have been here!"\r\n\r\n"We have all had an experience," said Lord George, still looking at\r\nher with that half-comic turn of his face,--almost as though he were\r\ninvestigating some curious animal of which so remarkable a specimen\r\nhad never before come under his notice.\r\n\r\n"No woman ever intended to show a more disinterested friendship than\r\nI have done; and what has been my return?"\r\n\r\n"You mean to me?--disinterested friendship to me?" And Lord George\r\ntapped his breast lightly with his fingers. His head was still a\r\nlittle on one side, and there was still the smile upon his face.\r\n\r\n"I was alluding particularly to Mrs. Carbuncle."\r\n\r\n"Lady Eustace, I cannot take charge of Mrs. Carbuncle\'s friendships.\r\nI have enough to do to look after my own. If you have any complaint\r\nto make against me,--I will at least listen to it."\r\n\r\n"God knows I do not want to make complaints," said Lizzie, covering\r\nher face with her hands.\r\n\r\n"They don\'t do much good;--do they? It\'s better to take people as you\r\nfind \'em, and then make the best of \'em. They\'re a queer lot;--ain\'t\r\nthey,--the sort of people one meets about in the world?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know what you mean by that, Lord George."\r\n\r\n"Just what you were saying, when you talked of your experiences.\r\nThese experiences do surprise one. I have knocked about the world a\r\ngreat deal, and would have almost said that nothing would surprise\r\nme. You are no more than a child to me, but you have surprised me."\r\n\r\n"I hope I have not injured you, Lord George."\r\n\r\n"Do you remember how you rode to hounds the day your cousin took that\r\nother man\'s horse? That surprised me."\r\n\r\n"Oh, Lord George, that was the happiest day of my life. How little\r\nhappiness there is for people!"\r\n\r\n"And when Tewett got that girl to say she\'d marry him, the coolness\r\nwith which you bore all the abomination of it in your house,--for\r\npeople who were nothing to you;--that surprised me!"\r\n\r\n"I meant to be so kind to you all."\r\n\r\n"And when I found that you always travelled with ten thousand pounds\'\r\nworth of diamonds in a box, that surprised me very much. I thought\r\nthat you were a very dangerous companion."\r\n\r\n"Pray don\'t talk about the horrid necklace."\r\n\r\n"Then came the robbery, and you seemed to lose your diamonds without\r\nbeing at all unhappy about them. Of course, we understand that now."\r\nOn hearing this, Lizzie smiled, but did not say a word. "Then I\r\nperceived that I--I was supposed to be the thief. You--you yourself\r\ncouldn\'t have suspected me of taking the diamonds, because--because\r\nyou\'d got them, you know, all safe in your pocket. But you might as\r\nwell own the truth now. Didn\'t you think that it was I who stole the\r\nbox?"\r\n\r\n"I wish it had been you," said Lizzie laughing.\r\n\r\n"All that surprised me. The police were watching me every day as a\r\ncat watches a mouse, and thought that they surely had got the thief\r\nwhen they found that I had dealings with Benjamin. Well; you--you\r\nwere laughing at me in your sleeve all the time."\r\n\r\n"Not laughing, Lord George."\r\n\r\n"Yes, you were. You had got the kernel yourself, and thought that I\r\nhad taken all the trouble to crack the nut and had found myself with\r\nnothing but the shell. Then, when you found you couldn\'t eat the\r\nkernel, that you couldn\'t get rid of the swag without assistance, you\r\ncame to me to help you. I began to think then that you were too many\r\nfor all of us. By Jove, I did! Then I heard of the second robbery,\r\nand, of course, I thought you had managed that too."\r\n\r\n"Oh, no," said Lizzie\r\n\r\n"Unfortunately you didn\'t; but I thought you did. And you thought\r\nthat I had done it! Mr. Benjamin was too clever for us both, and\r\nnow he is going to have penal servitude for the rest of his life. I\r\nwonder who will be the better of it all. Who\'ll have the diamonds at\r\nlast?"\r\n\r\n"I do not in the least care. I hate the diamonds. Of course I would\r\nnot give them up, because they were my own."\r\n\r\n"The end of it seems to be that you have lost your property, and\r\nsworn ever so many false oaths, and have brought all your friends\r\ninto trouble, and have got nothing by it. What was the good of being\r\nso clever?"\r\n\r\n"You need not come here to tease me, Lord George."\r\n\r\n"I came here because you sent for me. There\'s my poor friend, Mrs.\r\nCarbuncle, declares that all her credit is destroyed, and her niece\r\nunable to marry, and her house taken away from her,--all because of\r\nher connexion with you."\r\n\r\n"Mrs. Carbuncle is--is--is-- Oh, Lord George, don\'t you know what she\r\nis?"\r\n\r\n"I know that Mrs. Carbuncle is in a very bad way, and that that girl\r\nhas gone crazy, and that poor Griff has taken himself off to Japan,\r\nand that I am so knocked about that I don\'t know where to go; and\r\nsomehow it seems all to have come from your little manoeuvres. You\r\nsee, we have, all of us, been made remarkable; haven\'t we?"\r\n\r\n"You are always remarkable, Lord George."\r\n\r\n"And it is all your doing. To be sure you have lost your diamonds for\r\nyour pains. I wouldn\'t mind it so much if anybody were the better for\r\nit. I shouldn\'t have begrudged even Benjamin the pull, if he\'d got\r\nit."\r\n\r\nHe stood there, still looking down upon her, speaking with a\r\nsarcastic subrisive tone, and, as she felt, intending to be severe\r\nto her. She had sent for him, and now she didn\'t know what to say to\r\nhim. Though she believed that she hated him, she would have liked to\r\nget up some show of an affectionate farewell, some scene in which\r\nthere might have been tears, and tenderness, and poetry,--and,\r\nperhaps, a parting caress. But with his jeering words, and sneering\r\nface, he was as hard to her as a rock. He was now silent, but still\r\nlooking down upon her as he stood motionless upon the rug,--so that\r\nshe was compelled to speak again. "I sent for you, Lord George,\r\nbecause I did not like the idea of parting with you for ever, without\r\none word of adieu."\r\n\r\n"You are going to tear yourself away;--are you?"\r\n\r\n"I am going to Portray on Monday."\r\n\r\n"And never coming back any more? You\'ll be up here before the season\r\nis over, with fifty more wonderful schemes in your little head. So\r\nLord Fawn is done with, is he?"\r\n\r\n"I have told Lord Fawn that nothing shall induce me ever to see him\r\nagain."\r\n\r\n"And cousin Frank?"\r\n\r\n"My cousin attends me down to Scotland."\r\n\r\n"Oh-h. That makes it altogether another thing. He attends you down to\r\nScotland;--does he? Does Mr. Emilius go too?"\r\n\r\n"I believe you are trying to insult me, sir."\r\n\r\n"You can\'t expect but what a man should be a little jealous, when he\r\nhas been so completely cut out himself. There was a time, you know,\r\nwhen even cousin Frank wasn\'t a better fellow than myself."\r\n\r\n"Much you thought about it, Lord George."\r\n\r\n"Well;--I did. I thought about it a good deal, my lady. And I liked\r\nthe idea of it very much." Lizzie pricked up her ears. In spite of\r\nall his harshness, could it be that he should be the Corsair still?\r\n"I am a rambling, uneasy, ill-to-do sort of man; but still I thought\r\nabout it. You are pretty, you know,--uncommonly pretty."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t, Lord George."\r\n\r\n"And I\'ll acknowledge that the income goes for much. I suppose that\'s\r\nreal at any rate?"\r\n\r\n"Well;--I hope so. Of course it\'s real. And so is the prettiness,\r\nLord George;--if there is any."\r\n\r\n"I never doubted that, Lady Eustace. But when it came to my thinking\r\nthat you had stolen the diamonds, and you thinking that I had stolen\r\nthe box--! I\'m not a man to stand on trifles, but, by George, it\r\nwouldn\'t do then."\r\n\r\n"Who wanted it to do?" said Lizzie. "Go away. You are very unkind to\r\nme. I hope I may never see you again. I believe you care more for\r\nthat odious vulgar woman down-stairs than you do for anybody else in\r\nthe world."\r\n\r\n"Ah, dear! I have known her for many years, Lizzie, and that both\r\ncovers and discovers many faults. One learns to know how bad one\'s\r\nold friends are, but then one forgives them, because they are old\r\nfriends."\r\n\r\n"You can\'t forgive me,--because I\'m bad, and only a new friend."\r\n\r\n"Yes, I will. I forgive you all, and hope you may do well yet. If\r\nI may give you one bit of advice at parting, it is to caution you\r\nagainst being clever when there is nothing to get by it."\r\n\r\n"I ain\'t clever at all," said Lizzie, beginning to whimper.\r\n\r\n"Good-bye, my dear."\r\n\r\n"Good-bye," said Lizzie. He took her hand in one of his; patted her\r\non the head with the other, as though she had been a child, and then\r\nhe left her.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXXVI\r\n\r\nLizzie Returns to Scotland\r\n\r\n\r\nFrank Greystock, the writer fears, will not have recommended himself\r\nto those readers of this tale who think the part of lover to\r\nthe heroine should be always filled by a young man with heroic\r\nattributes. And yet the young member for Bobsborough was by no means\r\ndeficient in fine qualities, and perhaps was quite as capable of\r\nheroism as the majority of barristers and members of Parliament among\r\nwhom he consorted, and who were to him--the world. A man born to\r\ngreat wealth may,--without injury to himself or friends,--do pretty\r\nnearly what he likes in regard to marriage, always presuming that the\r\nwife he selects be of his own rank. He need not marry for money, nor\r\nneed he abstain from marriage because he can\'t support a wife without\r\nmoney. And the very poor man, who has no pretension to rank or\r\nstanding, other than that which honesty may give him, can do the\r\nsame. His wife\'s fortune will consist in the labour of her hands, and\r\nin her ability to assist him in his home. But between these there\r\nis a middle class of men, who, by reason of their education, are\r\npeculiarly susceptible to the charms of womanhood, but who literally\r\ncannot marry for love, because their earnings will do no more\r\nthan support themselves. As to this special young man, it must be\r\nconfessed that his earnings should have done much more than that; but\r\nnot the less did he find himself in a position in which marriage with\r\na penniless girl seemed to threaten him and her with ruin. All his\r\nfriends told Frank Greystock that he would be ruined were he to marry\r\nLucy Morris;--and his friends were people supposed to be very good\r\nand wise. The dean, and the dean\'s wife, his father and mother,\r\nwere very clear that it would be so. Old Lady Linlithgow had spoken\r\nof such a marriage as quite out of the question. The Bishop of\r\nBobsborough, when it was mentioned in his hearing, had declared that\r\nsuch a marriage would be a thousand pities. And even dear old Lady\r\nFawn, though she wished it for Lucy\'s sake, had many times prophesied\r\nthat such a thing was quite impossible. When the rumour of the\r\nmarriage reached Lady Glencora, Lady Glencora told her friend, Madame\r\nMax Goesler, that that young man was going to blow his brains out.\r\nTo her thinking, the two actions were equivalent. It is only when we\r\nread of such men that we feel that truth to his sweetheart is the\r\nfirst duty of man. I am afraid that it is not the advice which we\r\ngive to our sons.\r\n\r\nBut it was the advice which Frank Greystock had most persistently\r\ngiven to himself since he had first known Lucy Morris. Doubtless he\r\nhad vacillated, but, on the balance of his convictions as to his own\r\nfuture conduct, he had been much nobler than his friends. He had\r\nnever hesitated for a moment as to the value of Lucy Morris. She\r\nwas not beautiful. She had no wonderful gifts of nature. There was\r\nnothing of a goddess about her. She was absolutely penniless. She had\r\nnever been what the world calls well-dressed. And yet she had been\r\neverything to him. There had grown up a sympathy between them quite\r\nas strong on his part as on hers, and he had acknowledged it to\r\nhimself. He had never doubted his own love,--and when he had been\r\nmost near to convincing himself that in his peculiar position he\r\nought to marry his rich cousin, because of her wealth, then, at those\r\nmoments, he had most strongly felt that to have Lucy Morris close to\r\nhim was the greatest charm in existence. Hitherto his cousin\'s money,\r\njoined to flatteries and caresses,--which, if a young man can resist,\r\nhe is almost more than a young man,--had tempted him; but he had\r\ncombated the temptation. On one memorable evening his love for Lucy\r\nhad tempted him. To that temptation he had yielded, and the letter by\r\nwhich he became engaged to her had been written. He had never meant\r\nto evade it;--had always told himself that it should not be evaded;\r\nbut, gradually, days had been added to days, and months to months,\r\nand he had allowed her to languish without seeing him, and almost\r\nwithout hearing from him.\r\n\r\nShe, too, had heard from all sides that she was deserted by him, and\r\nshe had written to him to give him back his troth; but she had not\r\nsent her letters. She did not doubt that the thing was over,--she\r\nhardly doubted. And yet she would not send any letter. Perhaps it\r\nwould be better that the matter should be allowed to drop without any\r\nletter-writing. She would never reproach him,--though she would ever\r\nthink him to be a traitor. Would not she have starved herself for\r\nhim, could she so have served him? And yet he could bear for her sake\r\nno touch of delay in his prosperity! Would she not have been content\r\nto wait, and always to wait,--so that he with some word of love would\r\nhave told her that he waited also? But he would not only desert\r\nher,--but would give himself to that false, infamous woman, who was\r\nso wholly unfitted to be his wife. For Lucy, though to herself she\r\nwould call him a traitor,--and would think him to be a traitor, still\r\nregarded him as the best of mankind, as one who, in marrying such a\r\none as Lizzie Eustace, would destroy all his excellence, as a man\r\nmight mar his strength and beauty by falling into a pit. For Lizzie\r\nEustace Lucy Morris had now no forgiveness. Lucy had almost forgotten\r\nLizzie\'s lies, and her proffered bribe, and all her meanness, when\r\nshe made that visit to Hertford Street. Then, when Lizzie claimed\r\nthis man as her lover, a full remembrance of all the woman\'s\r\niniquities came back on Lucy\'s mind. The statement that Lizzie then\r\nmade, Lucy did believe. She did think that Frank, her Frank, the man\r\nwhom she worshipped, was to take this harpy to his bosom as his wife.\r\nAnd if it were to be so, was it not better that she should be so\r\ntold? But, from that moment, poor Lizzie\'s sins were ranker to Lucy\r\nMorris than even to Mr. Camperdown or Mrs. Hittaway. She could not\r\nrefrain from saying a word even to old Lady Linlithgow. The countess\r\nhad called her niece a little liar. "Liar!" said Lucy. "I do not\r\nthink Satan himself can lie as she does." "Heighty-tighty," said the\r\ncountess. "I suppose, then, there\'s to be a match between Lady Satan\r\nand her cousin Frank?" "They can do as they like about that," said\r\nLucy, walking out of the room.\r\n\r\nThen came the paragraph in the fashionable evening newspaper; after\r\nthat, the report of the examination before the magistrate, and\r\nthen certain information that Lady Eustace was about to proceed to\r\nScotland together with her cousin Mr. Greystock, the Member for\r\nBobsborough. "It is a large income," said the countess; "but, upon my\r\nword, she\'s dear at the money." Lucy did not speak, but she bit her\r\nlip till the blood ran into her mouth. She was going down to Fawn\r\nCourt almost immediately, to stay there with her old friends till she\r\nshould be able to find some permanent home for herself. Once, and\r\nonce only, would she endure discussion, and then the matter should be\r\nbanished for ever from her tongue.\r\n\r\nEarly on the appointed morning Frank Greystock, with a couple of\r\ncabs, was at Mrs. Carbuncle\'s door in Hertford Street. Lizzie had\r\nagreed to start by a very early train,--at eight a.m.,--so that\r\nshe might get through to Portray in one day. It had been thought\r\nexpedient, both by herself and by her cousin, that for the present\r\nthere should be no more sleeping at the Carlisle hotel. The robbery\r\nwas probably still talked about in that establishment; and the report\r\nof the proceedings at the police-court had, no doubt, travelled as\r\nfar north as the border city. It was to be a long day, and could\r\nhardly be other than sad. Lizzie, understanding this, feeling\r\nthat though she had been in a great measure triumphant over her\r\ndifficulties before the magistrate, she ought still to consider\r\nherself, for a short while, as being under a cloud, crept down into\r\nthe cab and seated herself beside her cousin almost without a word.\r\nShe was again dressed in black, and again wore the thick veil. Her\r\nmaid, with the luggage, followed them, and they were driven to Euston\r\nSquare almost without a word. On this occasion no tall footman\r\naccompanied them. "Oh, Frank; dear Frank," she had said, and that\r\nwas all. He had been active about the luggage and useful in giving\r\norders;--but beyond his directions and inquiries as to the journey,\r\nhe spoke not a word. Had she breakfasted? Would she have a cup of\r\ntea at the station? Should he take any luncheon for her? At every\r\nquestion she only looked into his face and shook her head. All\r\nthoughts as to creature-comforts were over with her now for ever.\r\nTranquillity, a little poetry, and her darling boy, were all that she\r\nneeded for the short remainder of her sojourn upon earth. These were\r\nthe sentiments which she intended to convey when she shook her head\r\nand looked up into his eyes. The world was over for her. She had had\r\nher day of pleasure, and found how vain it was. Now she would devote\r\nherself to her child. "I shall see my boy again to-night," she said,\r\nas she took her seat in the carriage.\r\n\r\nSuch was the state of mind, or such, rather, the resolutions,\r\nwith which she commenced her journey. Should he become bright,\r\ncommunicative, and pleasant, or even tenderly silent, or, perhaps,\r\nnow at length affectionate and demonstrative, she, no doubt, might be\r\nable to change as he changed. He had been cousinly, but gloomy, at\r\nthe police-court; in the same mood when he brought her home; and,\r\nas she saw with the first glance of her eye, in the same mood again\r\nwhen she met him in the hall this morning. Of course she must play\r\nhis tunes. Is it not the fate of women to play the tunes which men\r\ndictate,--except in some rare case in which the woman can make\r\nherself the dictator? Lizzie loved to be a dictator; but at the\r\npresent moment she knew that circumstances were against her.\r\n\r\nShe watched him,--so closely. At first he slept a good deal. He was\r\nnever in bed very early, and on this morning had been up at six. At\r\nRugby he got out and ate what he said was his breakfast. Would not\r\nshe have a cup of tea? Again she shook her head and smiled. She\r\nsmiled as some women smile when you offer them a third glass of\r\nchampagne. "You are joking with me, I know. You cannot think that\r\nI would take it." That was the meaning of Lizzie\'s smile. He went\r\ninto the refreshment-room, growled at the heat of the tea and the\r\nabominable nastiness of the food provided, and then, after the\r\nallotted five minutes, took himself to a smoking-carriage. He did not\r\nrejoin his cousin till they were at Crewe. When he went back to his\r\nold seat, she only smiled again. He asked her whether she had slept,\r\nand again she shook her head. She had been repeating to herself the\r\naddress to Ianthe\'s soul, and her whole being was pervaded with\r\npoetry.\r\n\r\nIt was absolutely necessary, as he thought, that she should eat\r\nsomething, and he insisted that she should dine upon the road,\r\nsomewhere. He, of course, was not aware that she had been nibbling\r\nbiscuits and chocolate while he had been smoking, and had had\r\nrecourse even to the comfort of a sherry-flask which she carried in\r\nher dressing-bag. When he talked of dinner she did more than smile\r\nand refuse. She expostulated. For she well knew that the twenty\r\nminutes for dinner were allowed at the Carlisle station; and even if\r\nthere had been no chocolate and no sherry, she would have endured\r\non, even up to absolute inanition, rather than step out upon this\r\nwell-remembered platform. "You must eat, or you\'ll be starved," he\r\nsaid. "I\'ll fetch you something." So he bribed a special waiter, and\r\nshe was supplied with cold chicken and more sherry. After this Frank\r\nsmoked again, and did not reappear till they had reached Dumfries.\r\n\r\nHitherto there had been no tenderness,--nothing but the coldest\r\ncousinship. He clearly meant her to understand that he had submitted\r\nto the task of accompanying her back to Portray Castle as a duty, but\r\nthat he had nothing to say to one who had so misbehaved herself. This\r\nwas very irritating. She could have taken herself home to Portray\r\nwithout his company, and have made the journey more endurable\r\nwithout him than with him, if this were to be his conduct throughout.\r\nThey had had the carriage to themselves all the way from Crewe to\r\nCarlisle, and he had hardly spoken a word to her. If he would have\r\nrated her soundly for her wickednesses, she could have made something\r\nof that. She could have thrown herself on her knees, and implored his\r\npardon; or, if hard pressed, have suggested the propriety of throwing\r\nherself out of the carriage-window. She could have brought him round\r\nif he would only have talked to her, but there is no doing anything\r\nwith a silent man. He was not her master. He had no power over her.\r\nShe was the lady of Portray, and he could not interfere with her.\r\nIf he intended to be sullen with her to the end, and to show his\r\ncontempt for her, she would turn against him. "The worm will turn,"\r\nshe said to herself. And yet she did not think herself a worm.\r\n\r\nA few stations beyond Dumfries they were again alone. It was now\r\nquite dark, and they had already been travelling over ten hours. They\r\nwould not reach their own station till eight, and then again there\r\nwould be the journey to Portray. At last he spoke to her. "Are you\r\ntired, Lizzie?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, so tired!"\r\n\r\n"You have slept, I think."\r\n\r\n"No, not once; not a wink. You have slept." This she said in a tone\r\nof reproach.\r\n\r\n"Indeed I have."\r\n\r\n"I have endeavoured to read, but one cannot command one\'s mind at\r\nall times. Oh, I am so weary. Is it much further? I have lost all\r\nreckoning as to time and place."\r\n\r\n"We change at the next station but one. It will soon be over now.\r\nWill you have a glass of sherry? I have some in my flask." Again she\r\nshook her head. "It is a long way down to Portray, I must own."\r\n\r\n"Oh, I am so sorry that I have given you the trouble to accompany\r\nme."\r\n\r\n"I was not thinking of myself. I don\'t mind it. It was better that\r\nyou should have somebody with you,--just for this journey."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know why this journey should be different from any other,"\r\nsaid Lizzie crossly. She had not done anything that made it necessary\r\nthat she should be taken care of,--like a naughty girl.\r\n\r\n"I\'ll see you to the end of it now, anyway."\r\n\r\n"And you\'ll stay a few days with me, Frank? You won\'t go away at\r\nonce? Say you\'ll stay a week. Dear, dear Frank; say you\'ll stay a\r\nweek. I know that the House doesn\'t meet for ever so long. Oh, Frank,\r\nI do so wish you\'d be more like yourself." There was no reason why\r\nshe should not make one other effort, and as she made it every sign\r\nof fatigue passed away from her.\r\n\r\n"I\'ll stay over to-morrow certainly," he replied.\r\n\r\n"Only one day!"\r\n\r\n"Days with me mean money, Lizzie, and money is a thing which is at\r\npresent very necessary to me."\r\n\r\n"I hate money."\r\n\r\n"That\'s very well for you, because you have plenty of it."\r\n\r\n"I hate money. It is the only thing that one has that one cannot give\r\nto those one loves. I could give you anything else;--though it cost a\r\nthousand pounds."\r\n\r\n"Pray don\'t. Most people like presents, but they only bore me."\r\n\r\n"Because you are so indifferent, Frank;--so cold. Do you remember\r\ngiving me a little ring?"\r\n\r\n"Very well indeed. It cost eight and sixpence."\r\n\r\n"I never thought what it cost;--but there it is." This she said,\r\ndrawing off her glove and showing him her finger. "And when I am\r\ndead, there it will be. You say you want money, Frank. May I not give\r\nit you? Are not we brother and sister?"\r\n\r\n"My dear Lizzie, you say you hate money. Don\'t talk about it."\r\n\r\n"It is you that talk about it. I only talk about it because I want\r\nto give it you;--yes, all that I have. When I first knew what was\r\nthe real meaning of my husband\'s will, my only thought was to be of\r\nassistance to you."\r\n\r\nIn real truth Frank was becoming very sick of her. It seemed to him\r\nnow to have been almost impossible that he should ever soberly have\r\nthought of making her his wife. The charm was all gone, and even her\r\nprettiness had in his eyes lost its value. He looked at her, asking\r\nhimself whether in truth she was pretty. She had been travelling all\r\nday, and perhaps the scrutiny was not fair. But he thought that even\r\nafter the longest day\'s journey Lucy would not have been soiled,\r\nhaggard, dishevelled, and unclean, as was this woman.\r\n\r\nTravellers again entered the carriage, and they went on with a crowd\r\nof persons till they reached the platform at which they changed the\r\ncarriage for Troon. Then they were again alone, for a few minutes,\r\nand Lizzie with infinite courage determined that she would make her\r\nlast attempt. "Frank," she said, "you know what it is that I mean.\r\nYou cannot feel that I am ungenerous. You have made me love you. Will\r\nyou have all that I have to give?" She was leaning over, close to\r\nhim, and he was observing that her long lock of hair was out of curl\r\nand untidy,--a thing that ought not to have been there during such a\r\njourney as this.\r\n\r\n"Do you not know," he said, "that I am engaged to marry Lucy Morris?"\r\n\r\n"No;--I do not know it."\r\n\r\n"I have told you so more than once."\r\n\r\n"You cannot afford to marry her."\r\n\r\n"Then I shall do it without affording." Lizzie was about to\r\nspeak,--had already pronounced her rival\'s name in that tone of\r\ncontempt which she so well knew how to use, when he stopped her. "Do\r\nnot say anything against her, Lizzie, in my hearing, for I will not\r\nbear it. It would force me to leave you at the Troon station, and\r\nI had better see you now to the end of the journey." Lizzie flung\r\nherself back into the corner of her carriage, and did not utter\r\nanother word till she reached Portray Castle. He handed her out of\r\nthe railway carriage, and into her own vehicle which was waiting for\r\nthem, attended to the maid, and got the luggage; but still she did\r\nnot speak. It would be better that she should quarrel with him. That\r\nlittle snake, Lucy, would of course now tell him of the meeting\r\nbetween them in Hertford Street, after which anything but quarrelling\r\nwould be impossible. What a fool the man must be, what an idiot, what\r\na soft-hearted, mean-spirited fellow! Lucy, by her sly, quiet little\r\nstratagems, had got him once to speak the word, and now he had not\r\ncourage enough to go back from it! He had less strength of will even\r\nthan Lord Fawn! What she offered to him would be the making of him.\r\nWith his position, his seat in Parliament, such a country house as\r\nPortray Castle, and the income which she would give him, there was\r\nnothing that he might not reach! And he was so infirm of purpose,\r\nthat though he had hankered after it all, he would not open his hand\r\nto take it,--because he was afraid of such a little thing as Lucy\r\nMorris! It was thus that she thought of him as she leaned back in\r\nthe carriage without speaking. In giving her all that is due to her,\r\nwe must acknowledge that she had less feeling of the injury done to\r\nher charms as a woman than might have been expected. That she hated\r\nLucy was a matter of course;--and equally so that she should be\r\nvery angry with Frank Greystock. But the anger arose from general\r\ndisappointment, rather than from any sense of her own despised\r\nbeauty. "Ah, now I shall see my child," she said, as the carriage\r\nstopped at the castle-gate.\r\n\r\nWhen Frank Greystock went to his supper, Miss Macnulty brought to him\r\nhis cousin\'s compliments with a message saying that she was too weary\r\nto see him again that night. The message had been intended to be curt\r\nand uncourteous, but Miss Macnulty had softened it,--so that no harm\r\nwas done. "She must be very weary," said Frank.\r\n\r\n"I suppose though that nothing would ever really tire Lady Eustace,"\r\nsaid Miss Macnulty. "When she is excited nothing will tire her.\r\nPerhaps the journey has been dull."\r\n\r\n"Exceedingly dull," said Frank, as he helped himself to the collops\r\nwhich the Portray cook had prepared for his supper.\r\n\r\nMiss Macnulty was very attentive to him, and had many questions to\r\nask. About the necklace she hardly dared to speak, merely observing\r\nhow sad it was that all those precious diamonds should have been lost\r\nfor ever. "Very sad indeed," said Frank with his mouth full. She then\r\nwent on to the marriage,--the marriage that was no marriage. Was not\r\nthat very dreadful? Was it true that Miss Roanoke was really--out of\r\nher mind? Frank acknowledged that it was dreadful, but thought that\r\nthe marriage had it been completed would have been more so. As for\r\nthe young lady, he only knew that she had been taken somewhere out of\r\nthe way. Sir Griffin, he had been told, had gone to Japan.\r\n\r\n"To Japan!" said Miss Macnulty, really interested. Had Sir Griffin\r\ngone no further than Boulogne, her pleasure in the news would\r\ncertainly have been much less. Then she asked some single question\r\nabout Lord George, and from that came to the real marrow of her\r\nanxiety. Had Mr. Greystock lately seen the--the Rev. Mr. Emilius?\r\nFrank had not seen the clergyman, and could only say of him that had\r\nLucinda Roanoke and Sir Griffin Tewett been made one, the knot would\r\nhave been tied by Mr. Emilius.\r\n\r\n"Would it indeed? Did you not think Mr. Emilius very clever when you\r\nmet him down here?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t doubt but what he is a sharp sort of fellow."\r\n\r\n"Oh, Mr. Greystock, I don\'t think that that\'s the word for him at\r\nall. He did promise me when he was here that he would write to\r\nme occasionally, but I suppose that the increasing duties of his\r\nposition have rendered that impossible." Frank, who had no idea of\r\nthe extent of the preacher\'s ambition, assured Miss Macnulty that\r\namong his multifarious clerical labours it was out of the question\r\nthat Mr. Emilius should find time to write letters.\r\n\r\nFrank had consented to stay one day at Portray, and did not now like\r\nto run away without again seeing his cousin. Though much tempted to\r\ngo at once, he did stay the day, and had an opportunity of speaking\r\na few words to Mr. Gowran. Mr. Gowran was very gracious, but said\r\nnothing of his journey up to London. He asked various questions\r\nconcerning her "leddyship\'s" appearance at the police-court, as to\r\nwhich tidings had already reached Ayrshire, and pretended to be\r\ngreatly shocked at the loss of the diamonds. "When they talk o\' ten\r\nthoosand poond, that\'s a lee, nae doobt?" asked Andy.\r\n\r\n"No lie at all, I believe," said Greystock.\r\n\r\n"And her leddyship wad tak\' aboot wi\' her ten thoosand poond--in a\r\nbox?" Andy still showed much doubt by the angry glance of his eye\r\nand the close compression of his lips, and the great severity of his\r\ndemeanour as he asked the question.\r\n\r\n"I know nothing about diamonds myself, but that is what they say they\r\nwere worth."\r\n\r\n"Her leddyship\'s her ain sell seems nae to ha\' been in ain story\r\naboot the box, Muster Greystock?" But Frank could not stand to be\r\ncross-questioned on this delicate matter, and walked off, saying that\r\nas the thieves had not yet been tried for the robbery, the less said\r\nabout it the better.\r\n\r\nAt four o\'clock on that afternoon he had not seen Lizzie, and then\r\nhe received a message from her to the effect that she was still\r\nso unwell from the fatigue of her journey that she could bear no\r\none with her but her child. She hoped that her cousin was quite\r\ncomfortable, and that she might be able to see him after breakfast\r\non the following day. But Frank was determined to leave Portray very\r\nearly on the following day, and therefore wrote a note to his cousin.\r\nHe begged that she would not disturb herself, that he would leave the\r\ncastle the next morning before she could be up, and that he had only\r\nfurther to remind her that she must come up to London at once as\r\nsoon as she should be summoned for the trial of Mr. Benjamin and his\r\ncomrade. It had seemed to Frank that she had almost concluded that\r\nher labours connected with that disagreeable matter were at an end.\r\n"The examination may be long, and I will attend you if you wish it,"\r\nsaid her cousin. Upon receiving this she thought it expedient to come\r\ndown to him, and there was an interview for about a quarter of an\r\nhour in her own little sitting-room looking out upon the sea. She\r\nhad formed a project, and at once suggested it to him. If she found\r\nherself ill when the day of the trial came, could they make her go up\r\nand give her evidence? Frank told her that they could, and that they\r\nwould. She was very clever about it. "They couldn\'t go back to what\r\nI said at Carlisle, you know; because they already have made me tell\r\nall that myself." As she had been called upon to criminate herself,\r\nshe could not now be tried for the crime. Frank, however, would not\r\nlisten to this, and told her that she must come. "Very well, Frank. I\r\nknow you like to have your own way. You always did. And you think so\r\nlittle of my feelings! I shall make inquiry, and if I must,--why I\r\nsuppose I must."\r\n\r\n"You\'d better make up your mind to come."\r\n\r\n"Very well. And now, Frank, as I am so very tired, if you please I\'ll\r\nsay good-bye to you. I am very much obliged to you for coming with\r\nme. Good-bye." And so they parted.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXXVII\r\n\r\nThe Story of Lucy Morris Is Concluded\r\n\r\n\r\nOn the day appointed, Lucy Morris went back from the house of the old\r\ncountess to Fawn Court. "My dear," said Lady Linlithgow, "I am sorry\r\nthat you are going. Perhaps you\'ll think I haven\'t been very kind to\r\nyou, but I never am kind. People have always been hard to me, and I\'m\r\nhard. But I do like you."\r\n\r\n"I\'m glad you like me, as we have lived together so long."\r\n\r\n"You may go on staying here, if you choose, and I\'ll try to make it\r\nbetter."\r\n\r\n"It hasn\'t been bad at all,--only that there\'s nothing particular\r\nto do. But I must go. I shall get another place as a governess\r\nsomewhere, and that will suit me best."\r\n\r\n"Because of the money, you mean."\r\n\r\n"Well;--that in part."\r\n\r\n"I mean to pay you something," said the countess, opening her\r\npocket-book, and fumbling for two bank-notes which she had deposited\r\nthere.\r\n\r\n"Oh, dear, no. I haven\'t earned anything."\r\n\r\n"I always gave Macnulty something, and she was not near so nice as\r\nyou." And then the countess produced two ten-pound notes. But Lucy\r\nwould have none of her money, and when she was pressed, became proud\r\nand almost indignant in her denial. She had earned nothing, and she\r\nwould take nothing; and it was in vain that the old lady spread the\r\nclean bits of paper before her. "And so you\'ll go and be a governess\r\nagain; will you?"\r\n\r\n"When I can get a place."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll tell you what, my dear. If I were Frank Greystock, I\'d stick to\r\nmy bargain." Lucy at once fell a-crying, but she smiled upon the old\r\nwoman through her tears. "Of course he\'s going to marry that little\r\nlimb of the devil."\r\n\r\n"Oh, Lady Linlithgow,--if you can, prevent that!"\r\n\r\n"How am I to prevent it, my dear? I\'ve nothing to say to either of\r\nthem."\r\n\r\n"It isn\'t for myself I\'m speaking. If I can\'t--if I can\'t--can\'t have\r\nthings go as I thought they would by myself, I will never ask any one\r\nto help me. It is not that I mean. I have given all that up."\r\n\r\n"You have given it up?"\r\n\r\n"Yes;--I have. But nevertheless I think of him. She is bad, and he\r\nwill never be happy if he marries her. When he asked me to be his\r\nwife, he was mistaken as to what would be good for him. He ought not\r\nto have made such a mistake. For my sake he ought not."\r\n\r\n"That\'s quite true, my dear."\r\n\r\n"But I do not wish him to be unhappy all his life. He is not bad, but\r\nshe is very bad. I would not for worlds that anybody should tell him\r\nthat he owed me anything; but if he could be saved from her,--oh, I\r\nshould be so-glad."\r\n\r\n"You won\'t have my money, then?"\r\n\r\n"No,--Lady Linlithgow."\r\n\r\n"You\'d better. It is honestly your own."\r\n\r\n"I will not take it, thank you."\r\n\r\n"Then I may as well put it up again." And the countess replaced the\r\nnotes in her pocket-book. When this conversation took place, Frank\r\nGreystock was travelling back alone from Portray to London. On the\r\nsame day the Fawn carriage came to fetch Lucy away. As Lucy was in\r\npeculiar distress, Lady Fawn would not allow her to come by any\r\nother conveyance. She did not exactly think that the carriage would\r\nconsole her poor favourite; but she did it as she would have ordered\r\nsomething specially nice to eat for any one who had broken his leg.\r\nHer soft heart had compassion for misery, though she would sometimes\r\nshow her sympathy by strange expressions. Lady Linlithgow was almost\r\nangry about the carriage. "How many carriages and how many horses\r\ndoes Lady Fawn keep?" she asked.\r\n\r\n"One carriage and two horses."\r\n\r\n"She\'s very fond of sending them up into the streets of London, I\r\nthink." Lucy said nothing more, knowing that it would be impossible\r\nto soften the heart of this dowager in regard to the other. But she\r\nkissed the old woman at parting, and then was taken down to Richmond\r\nin state.\r\n\r\nShe had made up her mind to have one discussion with Lady Fawn\r\nabout her engagement,--the engagement which was no longer an\r\nengagement,--and then to have done with it. She would ask Lady\r\nFawn to ask the girls never to mention Mr. Greystock\'s name in her\r\nhearing. Lady Fawn had also made up her mind to the same effect.\r\nShe felt that the subject should be mentioned once,--and once only.\r\nOf course Lucy must have another place, but there need be no hurry\r\nabout that. She fully recognised her young friend\'s feeling of\r\nindependence, and was herself aware that she would be wrong to offer\r\nto the girl a permanent home among her own daughters, and therefore\r\nshe could not abandon the idea of a future place; but Lucy would, of\r\ncourse, remain till a situation should have been found for her that\r\nwould be in every sense unexceptionable. There need, however, be no\r\nhaste,--and, in the meantime, the few words about Frank Greystock\r\nmust be spoken. They need not, however, be spoken quite immediately.\r\nLet there be smiles, and joy, and a merry ring of laughter on this\r\nthe first day of the return of their old friend. As Lucy had the same\r\nfeelings on that afternoon, they did talk pleasantly and were merry.\r\nThe girls asked questions about the Vulturess,--as they had heard her\r\ncalled by Lizzie Eustace,--and laughed at Lucy to her face when she\r\nswore that, after a fashion, she liked the old woman.\r\n\r\n"You\'d like anybody, then," said Nina.\r\n\r\n"Indeed I don\'t," said Lucy, thinking at once of Lizzie Eustace.\r\n\r\nLady Fawn planned out the next day with great precision. After\r\nbreakfast, Lucy and the girls were to spend the morning in the old\r\nschool-room, so that there might be a general explanation as to the\r\ndoings of the last six months. They were to dine at three, and after\r\ndinner there should be the discussion. "Will you come up to my room\r\nat four o\'clock, my dear?" said Lady Fawn, patting Lucy\'s shoulder,\r\nin the breakfast-parlour. Lucy knew well why her presence was\r\nrequired. Of course she would come. It would be wise to get it over\r\nand have done with it.\r\n\r\nAt noon Lady Fawn, with her three eldest daughters, went out in the\r\ncarriage, and Lucy was busy among the others with books and maps and\r\nsheets of scribbled music. Nothing was done on that day in the way\r\nof instruction; but there was much of half-jocose acknowledgement of\r\npast idleness, and a profusion of resolutions of future diligence.\r\nOne or two of the girls were going to commence a course of reading\r\nthat would have broken the back of any professor, and suggestions\r\nwere made as to very rigid rules as to the talking of French and\r\nGerman. "But as we can\'t talk German," said Nina, "we should simply\r\nbe dumb." "You\'d talk High Dutch, Nina, sooner than submit to that,"\r\nsaid one of the sisters.\r\n\r\nThe conclave was still sitting in full deliberation, when one of the\r\nmaids entered the room with a very long face. There was a gentleman\r\nin the drawing-room asking for Miss Morris! Lucy, who at the moment\r\nwas standing at a table on which were spread an infinity of books,\r\nbecame at once as white as a sheet. Her fast friend, Lydia Fawn, who\r\nwas standing by her, immediately took hold of her hand quite tightly.\r\nThe face of the maid was fit for a funeral. She knew that Miss Morris\r\nhad had a "follower,"--that the follower had come,--and that then\r\nMiss Morris had gone away. Miss Morris had been allowed to come back;\r\nand now, on the very first day, just when my lady\'s back was turned,\r\nhere was the follower again! Before she had come up with her message,\r\nthere had been an unanimous expression of opinion in the kitchen that\r\nthe fat would all be in the fire. Lucy was as white as marble, and\r\nfelt such a sudden shock at her heart, that she could not speak. And\r\nyet she never doubted for a moment that Frank Greystock was the man.\r\nAnd with what purpose but one could he have come there? She had on\r\nthe old, old frock in which, before her visit to Lady Linlithgow,\r\nshe used to pass the morning amidst her labours with the girls,--a\r\npale, grey, well-worn frock, to which must have been imparted some\r\nattraction from the milliner\'s art, because everybody liked it so\r\nwell,--but which she had put on this very morning as a testimony, to\r\nall the world around her, that she had abandoned the idea of being\r\nanything except a governess. Lady Fawn had understood the frock well.\r\n"Here is the dear little old woman just the same as ever," Lydia had\r\nsaid, embracing her. "She looks as if she\'d gone to bed before the\r\nwinter, and had a long sleep, like a dormouse," said Cecilia. Lucy\r\nhad liked it all, and thoroughly appreciated the loving-kindness; but\r\nshe had known what it all meant. She had left them as the engaged\r\nbride of Mr. Greystock, the member for Bobsborough; and now she had\r\ncome back as Lucy Morris, the governess, again. "Just the same as\r\never," Lucy had said, with the sweetest smile. They all understood\r\nthat, in so saying, she renounced her lover.\r\n\r\nAnd now there stood the maid, inside the room, who, having announced\r\nthat there was a gentleman asking for Miss Morris, was waiting for an\r\nanswer. Was the follower to be sent about his business, with a flea\r\nin his ear, having come, slyly, craftily, and wickedly, in Lady\r\nFawn\'s absence; or would Miss Morris brazen it out, and go and see\r\nhim?\r\n\r\n"Who is the gentleman?" asked Diana, who was the eldest of the Fawn\r\ngirls present.\r\n\r\n"It\'s he as used to come after Miss Morris before," said the maid.\r\n\r\n"It is Mr. Greystock," said Lucy, recovering herself with an effort.\r\n"I had better go down to him. Will you tell him, Mary, that I\'ll be\r\nwith him almost immediately?"\r\n\r\n"You ought to have put on the other frock, after all," said Nina,\r\nwhispering into her ear.\r\n\r\n"He has not lost much time in coming to see you," said Lydia.\r\n\r\n"I suppose it was all because he didn\'t like Lady Linlithgow," said\r\nCecilia. Lucy had not a word to say. She stood for a minute among\r\nthem, trying to think, and then she slowly left the room.\r\n\r\nShe would not condescend to alter her dress by the aid of a single\r\npin, or by the adjustment of a ribbon. It might well be that, after\r\nthe mingled work and play of the morning, her hair should not be\r\nsmooth; but she was too proud to look at her hair. The man whom she\r\nhad loved, who had loved her but had neglected her, was in the house.\r\nHe would surely not have followed her thither did he not intend\r\nto make reparation for his neglect. But she would use no art with\r\nhim;--nor would she make any entreaty. It might be that, after all,\r\nhe had the courage to come and tell her, in a manly, straightforward\r\nway, that the thing must be all over,--that he had made a mistake,\r\nand would beg her pardon. If it were so, there should be no word of\r\nreproach. She would be quite quiet with him; but there should be no\r\nword of reproach. But if-- In that other case she could not be sure\r\nof her behaviour, but she knew well that he would not have to ask\r\nlong for forgiveness. As for her dress,--he had chosen to love her\r\nin that frock before, and she did not think that he would pay much\r\nattention to her dress on the present occasion.\r\n\r\nShe opened the door very quietly and very slowly, intending to\r\napproach him in the same way. But in a moment, before she could\r\nremember that she was in the room, he had seized her in his arms, and\r\nwas showering kisses upon her forehead, her eyes, and her lips. When\r\nshe thought of it afterwards, she could not call to mind a single\r\nword that he had spoken before he held her in his embrace. It was\r\nshe, surely, who had spoken first, when she begged to be released\r\nfrom his pressure. But she well remembered the first words that\r\nstruck her ear. "Dearest Lucy, will you forgive me?" She could only\r\nanswer them through her tears by taking up his hand and kissing it.\r\n\r\nWhen Lady Fawn came back with the carriage, she herself saw the\r\nfigures of two persons, walking very close together, in the\r\nshrubberies. "Is that Lucy?" she asked.\r\n\r\n"Yes," said Augusta, with a tone of horror. "Indeed it is, and--Mr.\r\nGreystock."\r\n\r\nLady Fawn was neither shocked nor displeased; nor was she\r\ndisappointed; but a certain faint feeling of being ill-used by\r\ncircumstances came over her. "Dear me;--the very first day!" she\r\nsaid.\r\n\r\n"It\'s because he wouldn\'t go to Lady Linlithgow\'s," said Amelia. "He\r\nhas only waited, mamma."\r\n\r\n"But the very first day!" exclaimed Lady Fawn. "I hope Lucy will be\r\nhappy;--that\'s all."\r\n\r\nThere was a great meeting of all the Fawns, as soon as Lady Fawn and\r\nthe eldest girls were in the house. Mr. Greystock had been walking\r\nabout the grounds with Lucy for the last hour and a half. Lucy had\r\ncome in once to beg that Lady Fawn might be told directly she came\r\nin. "She said you were to send for her, mamma," said Lydia.\r\n\r\n"But it\'s dinner-time, my dear. What are we to do with Mr.\r\nGreystock?"\r\n\r\n"Ask him to lunch, of course," said Amelia.\r\n\r\n"I suppose it\'s all right," said Lady Fawn.\r\n\r\n"I\'m quite sure it\'s all right," said Nina.\r\n\r\n"What did she say to you, Lydia?" asked the mother.\r\n\r\n"She was as happy as ever she could be," said Lydia. "There\'s no\r\ndoubt about its being all right, mamma. She looked just as she did\r\nwhen she got the letter from him before."\r\n\r\n"I hope she managed to change her frock," said Augusta.\r\n\r\n"She didn\'t then," said Cecilia.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t suppose he cares one halfpenny about her frock," said Nina.\r\n"I should never think about a man\'s coat if I was in love."\r\n\r\n"Nina, you shouldn\'t talk in that way," said Augusta. Whereupon Nina\r\nmade a face behind one of her sisters\' backs. Poor Augusta was never\r\nallowed to be a prophetess among them.\r\n\r\nThe consultation was ended by a decision in accordance with which\r\nNina went as an ambassador to the lovers. Lady Fawn sent her\r\ncompliments to Mr. Greystock, and hoped he would come in to lunch.\r\nLucy must come in to dinner, because dinner was ready. "And mamma\r\nwants to see you just for a minute," added Nina, in a pretended\r\nwhisper.\r\n\r\n"Oh, Nina, you darling girl!" said Lucy, kissing her young friend in\r\nan ecstasy of joy.\r\n\r\n"It\'s all right?" asked Nina in a whisper which was really intended\r\nfor privacy. Lucy did not answer the question otherwise than by\r\nanother kiss.\r\n\r\nFrank Greystock was, of course, obliged to take his seat at the\r\ntable, and was entertained with a profusion of civility. Everybody\r\nknew that he had behaved badly to Lucy,--everybody, except Lucy\r\nherself, who, from this time forward, altogether forgot that she had\r\nfor some time looked upon him as a traitor, and had made up her mind\r\nthat she had been deceived and ill-used. All the Fawns had spoken\r\nof him, in Lucy\'s absence, in the hardest terms of reproach, and\r\ndeclared that he was not fit to be spoken to by any decent person.\r\nLady Fawn had known from the first that such a one as he was not to\r\nbe trusted. Augusta had never liked him. Amelia had feared that poor\r\nLucy Morris had been unwise, and too ambitious. Georgina had seen\r\nthat, of course, it would never do. Diana had sworn that it was a\r\ngreat shame. Lydia was sure that Lucy was a great deal too good for\r\nhim. Cecilia had wondered where he would go to;--a form of anathema\r\nwhich had brought down a rebuke from her mother. And Nina had always\r\nhated him like poison. But now nothing was too good for him. An\r\nunmarried man who is willing to sacrifice himself is, in feminine\r\neyes, always worthy of ribbons and a chaplet. Among all these Fawns\r\nthere was as little selfishness as can be found,--even among women.\r\nThe lover was not the lover of one of themselves, but of their\r\ngoverness. And yet, though he desired neither to eat nor drink at\r\nthat hour, something special had been cooked for him, and a special\r\nbottle of wine had been brought out of the cellar. All his sins were\r\nforgiven him. No single question was asked as to his gross misconduct\r\nduring the last six months. No pledge or guarantee was demanded for\r\nthe future. There he was, in the guise of a declared lover, and the\r\nfatted calf was killed.\r\n\r\nAfter this early dinner it was necessary that he should return to\r\ntown, and Lucy obtained leave to walk with him to the station. To her\r\nthinking now, there was no sin to be forgiven. Everything was, and\r\nhad been, just as it ought to be. Had any human being hinted that he\r\nhad sinned, she would have defended him to the death. Something was\r\nsaid between them about Lizzie, but nothing that arose from jealousy.\r\nNot till many months had passed did she tell him of Lizzie\'s message\r\nto herself, and of her visit to Hertford Street. But they spoke of\r\nthe necklace, and poor Lucy shuddered as she was told the truth about\r\nthose false oaths. "I really do think that, after that, Lord Fawn is\r\nright," she said, looking round at her lover. "Yes; but what he did,\r\nhe did before that," said Frank. "But are they not good and kind?"\r\nshe said, pleading for her friends. "Was ever anybody so well treated\r\nas they have treated me? I\'ll tell you what, sir, you mustn\'t quarrel\r\nwith Lord Fawn any more. I won\'t allow it." Then she walked back from\r\nthe station alone, almost bewildered by her own happiness.\r\n\r\nThat evening something like an explanation was demanded by Lady Fawn,\r\nbut no explanation was forthcoming. When questions were asked about\r\nhis silence, Lucy, half in joke and half in earnest, fired up and\r\ndeclared that everything had been as natural as possible. He could\r\nnot have come to Lady Linlithgow\'s house. Lady Linlithgow would not\r\nreceive him. No doubt she had been impatient, but then that had been\r\nher fault. Had he not come to her the very first day after her return\r\nto Richmond? When Augusta said something as to letters which might\r\nhave been written, Lucy snubbed her. "Who says he didn\'t write? He\r\ndid write. If I am contented, why should you complain?" "Oh, I don\'t\r\ncomplain," said Augusta.\r\n\r\nThen questions were asked as to the future,--questions to which Lady\r\nFawn had a right to demand an answer. What did Mr. Greystock propose\r\nto do now? Then Lucy broke down, sobbing, crying, triumphing, with\r\nmingled love and happiness. She was to go to the deanery. Frank had\r\nbrought with him a little note to her from his mother, in which she\r\nwas invited to make the deanery at Bobsborough her home for the\r\npresent.\r\n\r\n"And you are to go away just when you\'ve come?" asked Nina.\r\n\r\n"Stay with us a month, my dear," said Lady Fawn, "just to let people\r\nknow that we are friends, and after that the deanery will be the best\r\nhome for you." And so it was arranged.\r\n\r\n     *     *     *     *     *\r\n\r\nIt need only be further said, in completing the history of Lucy\r\nMorris as far as it can be completed in these pages, that she did\r\ngo to the deanery, and that there she was received with all the\r\naffection which Mrs. Greystock could show to an adopted daughter. Her\r\nquarrel had never been with Lucy personally,--but with the untoward\r\nfact that her son would not marry money. At the deanery she remained\r\nfor fifteen happy months, and then became Mrs. Greystock, with a bevy\r\nof Fawn bridesmaids around her. As the personages of a chronicle such\r\nas this should all be made to operate backwards and forwards on each\r\nother from the beginning to the end, it would have been desirable\r\nthat the chronicler should have been able to report that the ceremony\r\nwas celebrated by Mr. Emilius. But as the wedding did not take place\r\ntill the end of the summer, and as Mr. Emilius at that time never\r\nremained in town, after the season was over, this was impossible. It\r\nwas the Dean of Bobsborough, assisted by one of the minor canons, who\r\nperformed the service.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXXVIII\r\n\r\nThe Trial\r\n\r\n\r\nHaving told the tale of Lucy Morris to the end, the chronicler must\r\nnow go back to the more important persons of this history. It was\r\nstill early in April when Lizzie Eustace was taken down to Scotland\r\nby her cousin, and the trial of Mr. Benjamin and Mr. Smiler was fixed\r\nto take place at the Central Criminal Court about the middle of May.\r\nEarly in May the attorneys for the prosecution applied to Greystock,\r\nasking him whether he would make arrangements for his cousin\'s\r\nappearance on the occasion, informing him that she had already been\r\nformally summoned. Whereupon he wrote to Lizzie, telling her what\r\nshe had better do, in the kindest manner,--as though there had been\r\nno cessation of their friendly intercourse, offering to go with her\r\ninto court,--and naming an hotel at which he would advise her to\r\nstay during the very short time that she need remain in London. She\r\nanswered this letter at once. She was sorry to say that she was much\r\ntoo ill to travel, or even to think of travelling. Such was her\r\npresent condition that she doubted greatly whether she would ever\r\nagain be able to leave the two rooms to which she was at present\r\nconfined. All that remained to her in life was to watch her own blue\r\nwaves from the casement of her dear husband\'s castle,--that casement\r\nat which he had loved to sit, and to make herself happy in the smiles\r\nof her child. A few months would see the last of it all, and then,\r\nperhaps, they who had trampled her to death would feel some pangs of\r\nremorse as they thought of her early fate. She had given her evidence\r\nonce and had told all the truth,--though she was now aware that she\r\nneed not have done so, as she had been defrauded of a vast amount of\r\nproperty through the gross negligence of the police. She was advised\r\nnow by persons who seemed really to understand the law, that she\r\ncould recover the value of the diamonds which her dear, dear husband\r\nhad given her, from the freeholders of the parish in which the\r\nrobbery had taken place. She feared that her health did not admit of\r\nthe necessary exertion. Were it otherwise she would leave no stone\r\nunturned to recover the value of her property,--not on account of its\r\nvalue, but because she had been so ill-treated by Mr. Camperdown and\r\nthe police. Then she added a postscript to say that it was quite out\r\nof the question that she should take any journey for the next six\r\nmonths.\r\n\r\nThe reader need hardly be told that Greystock did not believe a word\r\nof what she said. He felt sure that she was not ill. There was an\r\nenergy in the letter hardly compatible with illness. But he could\r\nnot make her come. He certainly did not intend to go down again to\r\nScotland to fetch her,--and even had he done so he could not have\r\nforced her to accompany him. He could only go to the attorneys\r\nconcerned, and read to them so much of the letter as he thought fit\r\nto communicate to them. "That won\'t do at all," said an old gentleman\r\nat the head of the firm. "She has been very leniently treated, and\r\nshe must come."\r\n\r\n"You must manage it, then," said Frank.\r\n\r\n"I hope she won\'t give us trouble, because if she does we must expose\r\nher," said the second member.\r\n\r\n"She has not even sent a medical certificate," said the tyro of the\r\nfirm, who was not quite so sharp as he will probably become when he\r\nhas been a member of it for ten or twelve years. You should never ask\r\nthe ostler whether he greases his oats. In this case Frank Greystock\r\nwas not exactly in the position of the ostler; but he did inform\r\nhis cousin by letter that she would lay herself open to all manner\r\nof pains and penalties if she disobeyed such a summons as she had\r\nreceived, unless she did so by a very strong medical advice, backed\r\nby a medical certificate.\r\n\r\nLizzie, when she received this, had two strings to her bow. A\r\nwriter from Ayr had told her that the summons sent to her was not\r\nworth the paper on which it was printed in regard to a resident in\r\nScotland;--and she had also got a doctor from the neighbourhood\r\nwho was satisfied that she was far too ill to travel up to London.\r\nPulmonary debilitation was the complaint from which she was\r\nsuffering, which, with depressed vitality in all the organs, and\r\nundue languor in all the bodily functions, would be enough to bring\r\nher to a speedy end if she so much as thought of making a journey\r\nup to London. A certificate to this effect was got in triplicate.\r\nOne copy she sent to the attorneys, one to Frank, and one she kept\r\nherself.\r\n\r\nThe matter was very pressing indeed. It was considered that the\r\ntrial could not be postponed till the next sitting at the Criminal\r\nCourt, because certain witnesses in respect to the diamonds had been\r\nprocured from Hamburg and Vienna, at a very great cost; they were\r\nactually on their way to London when Lizzie\'s second letter was\r\nreceived. Mr. Camperdown had resolved to have the diamonds, still\r\nwith a hope that they might be restored to the keeping of Messrs.\r\nGarnett, there to lie hidden and unused at any rate for the next\r\ntwenty years. The diamonds had been traced first to Hamburg, and then\r\nto Vienna;--and it was to be proved that they were now adorning the\r\nbosom of a certain enormously rich Russian princess. From the grasp\r\nof the Russian princess it was found impossible to rescue them; but\r\nthe witnesses who, as it was hoped, might have aided Mr. Camperdown\r\nin his efforts, were to be examined at the trial.\r\n\r\nA confidential clerk was sent down to Portray, but the confidential\r\nclerk altogether failed in making his way into Lizzie\'s presence.\r\nWord was brought to him that nothing but force could take Lady\r\nEustace from her bed-chamber; and that force used to that effect\r\nmight take her out dead, but certainly not alive. He made inquiry,\r\nhowever, about the doctor, and found that he certainly was a doctor.\r\nIf a doctor will certify that a lady is dying, what can any judge\r\ndo, or any jury? There are certain statements which, though they are\r\nfalse as hell, must be treated as though they were true as gospel.\r\nThe clerk reported, when he got back to London, that, to his belief,\r\nLady Eustace was enjoying an excellent state of health;--but that he\r\nwas perfectly certain that she would not appear as a witness at the\r\ntrial.\r\n\r\nThe anger felt by many persons as to Lizzie\'s fraudulent obstinacy\r\nwas intense. Mr. Camperdown thought that she ought to be dragged up\r\nto London by cart ropes. The attorneys engaged for the prosecution\r\nwere almost beside themselves. They did send down a doctor of their\r\nown, but Lizzie would not see the doctor,--would not see the doctor\r\nthough threats of most frightful consequences were conveyed to her.\r\nShe would be exposed, fined thousands of pounds, committed to gaol\r\nfor contempt of court, and prosecuted for perjury into the bargain.\r\nBut she was firm. She wrote one scrap of a note to the doctor\r\nwho came from London, "I shall not live to satisfy their rabid\r\nvengeance." Even Frank Greystock felt almost more annoyed than\r\ngratified that she should be able thus to escape. People who had\r\nheard of the inquiry before the magistrate, had postponed their\r\nexcitement and interest on the occasion, because they knew that\r\nthe day of the trial would be the great day; and when they heard\r\nthat they were to be robbed of the pleasure of Lady Eustace\'s\r\ncross-examination, there arose almost a public feeling of wrath\r\nthat justice should be thus outraged. The doctor who had given the\r\ncertificate was vilified in the newspapers, and long articles were\r\nwritten as to the impotence of the law. But Lizzie was successful,\r\nand the trial went on without her.\r\n\r\nIt appeared that though her evidence was very desirable it was not\r\nabsolutely essential, as, in consequence of her certified illness,\r\nthe statement which she had made at the police-court could be brought\r\nup and used against the prisoners. All the facts of the robbery\r\nwere, moreover, proved by Patience Crabstick and Billy Cann; and the\r\ntransfer of the diamonds by Mr. Benjamin to the man who recut them at\r\nHamburg was also proved. Many other morsels of collateral evidence\r\nhad also been picked up by the police,--so that there was no possible\r\ndoubt as to any detail of the affair in Hertford Street. There was a\r\nrumour that Mr. Benjamin intended to plead guilty. He might, perhaps,\r\nhave done so had it not been for the absence of Lady Eustace; but as\r\nthat was thought to give him a possible chance of escape, he stood\r\nhis ground.\r\n\r\nLizzie\'s absence was a great disappointment to the sight-seers of\r\nLondon, but nevertheless the court was crowded. It was understood\r\nthat the learned serjeant who was retained on this occasion to defend\r\nMr. Benjamin, and who was assisted by the acute gentleman who had\r\nappeared before the magistrate, would be rather severe upon Lady\r\nEustace, even in her absence; and that he would ground his demand for\r\nan acquittal on the combined facts of her retention of the diamonds,\r\nher perjury, and of her obstinate refusal to come forward on the\r\npresent occasion. As it was known that he could be very severe, many\r\ncame to hear him,--and they were not disappointed. The reader shall\r\nsee a portion of his address to the jury,--which we hope may have\r\nhad some salutary effect on Lizzie, as she read it in her retreat at\r\nPortray, looking out upon her own blue waves.\r\n\r\n"And now, gentlemen of the jury, let me recapitulate to you the\r\nhistory of this lady as far as it relates to the diamonds as to which\r\nmy client is now in jeopardy. You have heard on the testimony of Mr.\r\nCamperdown that they were not hers at all,--that, at any rate, they\r\nwere not supposed to be hers by those in whose hands was left the\r\nadministration of her husband\'s estate, and that when they were first\r\nsupposed to have been stolen at the inn at Carlisle, he had already\r\ncommenced legal steps for the recovery of them from her clutches. A\r\nbill in Chancery had been filed because she had obstinately refused\r\nto allow them to pass out of her hands. It has been proved to you\r\nby Lord Fawn that though he was engaged to marry her, he broke his\r\nengagement because he supposed her possession of these diamonds to be\r\nfraudulent and dishonest." This examination had been terrible to the\r\nunfortunate Under-Secretary;--and had absolutely driven him away from\r\nthe India Board and from Parliament for a month. "It has been proved\r\nto you that when the diamonds were supposed to have vanished at\r\nCarlisle, she there committed perjury. That she did so she herself\r\nstated on oath in that evidence which she gave before the magistrate\r\nwhen my client was committed, and which has, as I maintain,\r\nimproperly and illegally been used against my client at this trial."\r\nHere the judge looked over his spectacles and admonished the learned\r\nserjeant, that his argument on that subject had already been heard,\r\nand the matter decided. "True, my lord; but my conviction of my duty\r\nto my client compels me to revert to it. Lady Eustace committed\r\nperjury at Carlisle, having the diamonds in her pocket at the very\r\nmoment in which she swore that they had been stolen from her. And\r\nif justice had really been done in this case, gentlemen, it is\r\nLady Eustace who should now be on her trial before you, and not my\r\nunfortunate client. Well,--what is the next that we hear of it? It\r\nseems that she brought the diamonds up to London; but how long she\r\nkept them there, nobody knows. It was, however, necessary to account\r\nfor them. A robbery is got up between a young woman who seems to have\r\nbeen the confidential friend rather than the maid of Lady Eustace,\r\nand that other witness whom you have heard testifying against\r\nhimself, and who is, of all the informers that ever came into my\r\nhands, the most flippant, the most hardened, the least conscientious,\r\nand the least credible. That they two were engaged in a conspiracy\r\nI cannot doubt. That Lady Eustace was engaged with them, I will not\r\nsay. But I will ask you to consider whether such may not probably\r\nhave been the case. At any rate, she then perjures herself again. She\r\ngives a list of the articles stolen from her, and omits the diamonds.\r\nShe either perjures herself a second time,--or else the diamonds, in\r\nregard to which my client is in jeopardy, were not in the house at\r\nall, and could not then have been stolen. It may very probably have\r\nbeen so. Nothing more probable. Mr. Camperdown and the managers of\r\nthe Eustace estate had gradually come to a belief that the Carlisle\r\nrobbery was a hoax,--and, therefore, another robbery is necessary\r\nto account for the diamonds. Another robbery is arranged, and this\r\nyoung and beautiful widow, as bold as brass, again goes before the\r\nmagistrate and swears. Either the diamonds were not stolen, or else\r\nagain she commits a second perjury.\r\n\r\n"And now, gentlemen, she is not here. She is sick forsooth at her own\r\ncastle in Scotland, and sends to us a medical certificate. But the\r\ngentlemen who are carrying on the prosecution know their witness, and\r\ndon\'t believe a word of her sickness. Had she the feelings of woman\r\nin her bosom she ought indeed to be sick unto death. But they know\r\nher better, and send down a doctor of their own. You have heard his\r\nevidence,--and yet this wonderful lady is not before us. I say again\r\nthat she ought to be here in that dock,--in that dock in spite of her\r\nfortune, in that dock in spite of her title, in that dock in spite of\r\nher castle, her riches, her beauty, and her great relatives. A most\r\nwonderful woman, indeed, is the widow Eustace. It is she whom public\r\nopinion will convict as the guilty one in this marvellous mass of\r\nconspiracy and intrigue. In her absence, and after what she has done\r\nherself, can you convict any man either of stealing or of disposing\r\nof these diamonds?" The vigour, the attitude, and the indignant tone\r\nof the man were more even than his words;--but, nevertheless, the\r\njury did find both Benjamin and Smiler guilty, and the judge did\r\nsentence them to penal servitude for fifteen years.\r\n\r\nAnd this was the end of the Eustace diamonds as far as anything was\r\never known of them in England. Mr. Camperdown altogether failed, even\r\nin his attempt to buy them back at something less than their value,\r\nand was ashamed himself to look at the figures when he found how much\r\nmoney he had wasted for his clients in their pursuit. In discussing\r\nthe matter afterwards with Mr. Dove, he excused himself by asserting\r\nhis inability to see so gross a robbery perpetrated by a little minx\r\nunder his very eyes without interfering with the plunder. "I knew\r\nwhat she was," he said, "from the moment of Sir Florian\'s unfortunate\r\nmarriage. He had brought a little harpy into the family, and I was\r\nobliged to declare war against her." Mr. Dove seemed to be of opinion\r\nthat the ultimate loss of the diamonds was upon the whole desirable,\r\nas regarded the whole community. "I should like to have had the case\r\nsettled as to right of possession," he said, "because there were in\r\nit one or two points of interest.
